1	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">1899 CONVENTION FOR THE PACIFIC SETTLEMENT OF INTERNATIONAL DISPUTES</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p><strong><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/political-diplomatic-defence/1899-convention-for-the-pacific-settlement-of-international-disputes/attachment/convention-for-the-pacific-settlement-of-internaional-disputes-the-hague-1899/" rel="attachment wp-att-6098">Convention for the Pacific Settlement of internaional Disputes, the Hague, 1899</a></strong></p><p>* The text of the Convention reproduced here is a translation of the French text adopted at the 1899</p><p>Peace Conference. The French-language version is authoritative.</p><p>CONVENTION</p><p>for the Pacific Settlement of International Disputes*</p><p>His Majesty the German Emperor, King of Prussia; His Majesty the Emperor of</p><p>Austria, King of Bohemia, etc. and Apostolic King of Hungary; His Majesty the King</p><p>of the Belgians; His Majesty the Emperor of China; His Majesty the King of Denmark;</p><p>His Majesty the King of Spain and in His Name Her Majesty the Queen Regent of the</p><p>Kingdom; the President of the United States of America; the President of the United</p><p>Mexican States; the President of the French Republic; Her Majesty the Queen of the</p><p>United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, Empress of India; His Majesty the King</p><p>of the Hellenes; His Majesty the King of Italy; His Majesty the Emperor of Japan; His</p><p>Royal Highness the Grand Duke of Luxembourg, Duke of Nassau; His Highness the</p><p>Prince of Montenegro; Her Majesty the Queen of the Netherlands; His Imperial Majesty</p><p>the Shah of Persia; His Majesty the King of Portugal and of the Algarves, etc.; His</p><p>Majesty the King of Roumania; His Majesty the Emperor of all the Russias; His Majesty</p><p>the King of Serbia; his Majesty the King of Siam; His Majesty the King of Sweden and</p><p>Norway; the Swiss Federal Council; His Majesty the Emperor of the Ottomans and His</p><p>Royal Highness the Prince of Bulgaria;</p><p>Animated by a strong desire to work for the maintenance of general peace;</p><p>Resolved to promote by their best efforts the friendly settlement of international</p><p>disputes;</p><p>Recognizing the solidarity uniting the members of the society of civilized nations;</p><p>Desirous of extending the empire of law, and of strengthening the appreciation of</p><p>international justice;</p><p>Convinced that the permanent institution of a tribunal of arbitration, accessible to all,</p><p>in the midst of the independent Powers, will contribute effectively to this result;</p><p>Having regard to the advantages attending the general and regular organization of the</p><p>procedure of arbitration;</p><p>Sharing the opinion of the august initiator of the International Peace Conference that</p><p>it is expedient to record in an international agreement the principles of equity and right</p><p>on which are based the security of States and the welfare of peoples;</p><p>Being desirous of concluding a Convention to this effect, have appointed as their</p><p>plenipotentiaries, to wit:</p><p><em>(Here follow the names of plenipotentiaries.)</em></p><p>PERMANENT COURT OF ARBITRATION – BASIC DOCUMENTS</p><p>4</p><p>Who, after having communicated their full powers, found in good and due form, have</p><p>agreed on the following provisions:</p><p>TITLE I. ON THE MAINTENANCE OF THE GENERAL PEACE</p><p><em>Article 1</em></p><p>With a view to obviating, as far as possible, recourse to force in the relations between</p><p>States, the Signatory Powers agree to use their best efforts to insure the pacific settlement</p><p>of international differences.</p><p>TITLE II. ON GOOD OFFICES AND MEDIATION</p><p><em>Article 2</em></p><p>In case of serious disagreement or conflict, before an appeal to arms the Signatory</p><p>Powers agree to have recourse, as far as circumstances allow, to the good offices or</p><p>mediation of one or more friendly Powers.</p><p><em>Article 3</em></p><p>Independently of this recourse, the Signatory Powers recommend that one or more</p><p>Powers, strangers to the dispute, should, on their own initiative, and as far as circumstances</p><p>may allow, offer their good offices or mediation to the States at variance.</p><p>Powers, strangers to the dispute, have the right to offer good offices or mediation,</p><p>even during the course of hostilities.</p><p>The exercise of this right can never be regarded by one or the other of the parties in</p><p>conflict as an unfriendly act.</p><p><em>Article 4</em></p><p>The part of the mediator consists in reconciling the opposing claims and appeasing</p><p>the feelings of resentment which may have arisen between the States at variance.</p><p><em>Article 5</em></p><p>The functions of the mediator are at an end when once it is declared, either by one of</p><p>the parties to the dispute, or by the mediator himself, that the means of reconciliation</p><p>proposed by him are not accepted.</p><p>1899 CONVENTION FOR THE PACIFIC SETTLEMENT OF INTERNATIONAL DISPUTES</p><p>5</p><p><em>Article 6</em></p><p>Good offices and mediation, either at the request of the parties at variance, or on the</p><p>initiative of Powers strangers to the dispute, have exclusively the character of advice,</p><p>and never have binding force.</p><p><em>Article 7</em></p><p>The acceptance of mediation cannot, unless there be an agreement to the contrary,</p><p>have the effect of interrupting, delaying, or hindering mobilization or other measures of</p><p>preparation for war.</p><p>If mediation occurs after the commencement of hostilities, it causes no interruption</p><p>to the military operations in progress, unless there be an agreement to the contrary.</p><p><em>Article 8</em></p><p>The Signatory Powers are agreed in recommending the application, when circumstances</p><p>allow, of special mediation in the following form:</p><p>In case of a serious difference endangering the peace, the States at variance choose</p><p>respectively a Power, to whom they intrust the mission of entering into direct communication</p><p>with the Power chosen on the other side, with the object of preventing the</p><p>rupture of pacific relations.</p><p>For the period of this mandate, the term of which, unless otherwise stipulated, cannot</p><p>exceed thirty days, the States in conflict cease from all direct communication on the</p><p>subject of the dispute, which is regarded as referred exclusively to the mediating Powers,</p><p>who must use their best efforts to settle it.</p><p>In case of a definite rupture of pacific relations, these Powers are charged with the</p><p>joint task of taking advantage of any opportunity to restore peace.</p><p>TITLE III. ON INTERNATIONAL COMMISSIONS OF INQUIRY</p><p><em>Article 9</em></p><p>In differences of an international nature involving neither honour nor vital interests,</p><p>and arising from a difference of opinion on points of fact, the Signatory Powers recommend</p><p>that the parties, who have not been able to come to an agreement by means of</p><p>diplomacy, should, as far as circumstances allow, institute an International Commission</p><p>of Inquiry, to facilitate a solution of these differences by elucidating the facts by means</p><p>of an impartial and conscientious investigation.</p><p><em>Article 10</em></p><p>The International Commissions of Inquiry are constituted by special agreement</p><p>between the parties in conflict.</p><p>PERMANENT COURT OF ARBITRATION – BASIC DOCUMENTS</p><p>6</p><p>The Convention for an inquiry defines the facts to be examined and the extent of the</p><p>Commissioners’ powers.</p><p>It settles the procedure.</p><p>On the inquiry both sides must be heard.</p><p>The form and the periods to be observed, if not stated in the Inquiry Convention, are</p><p>decided by the Commission itself.</p><p><em>Article 11</em></p><p>The International Commissions of Inquiry are formed, unless otherwise stipulated, in</p><p>the manner fixed by Article 32 of the present Convention.</p><p><em>Article 12</em></p><p>The Powers in dispute engage to supply the International Commission of Inquiry, as</p><p>fully as they may think possible, with all means and facilities necessary to enable it to</p><p>be completely acquainted with and to accurately understand the facts in question.</p><p><em>Article 13</em></p><p>The International Commission of Inquiry communicates its Report to the conflicting</p><p>Powers, signed by all the members of the Commission.</p><p><em>Article 14</em></p><p>The Report of the International Commission of Inquiry is limited to a statement of</p><p>facts, and has in no way the character of an Arbitral Award. It leaves the conflicting</p><p>Powers entire freedom as to the effect to be given to this statement.</p><p>TITLE IV. ON INTERNATIONAL ARBITRATION</p><p><strong>Chapter I. On the System of Arbitration</strong></p><p><em>Article 15</em></p><p>International arbitration has for its object the settlement of differences between States</p><p>by judges of their own choice, and on the basis of respect for law.</p><p><em>Article 16</em></p><p>In questions of a legal nature, and especially in the interpretation or application of</p><p>International Conventions, arbitration is recognized by the Signatory Powers as the most</p><p>effective, and at the same time the most equitable, means of settling disputes which</p><p>diplomacy has failed to settle.</p><p>1899 CONVENTION FOR THE PACIFIC SETTLEMENT OF INTERNATIONAL DISPUTES</p><p>7</p><p><em>Article 17</em></p><p>The Arbitration Convention is concluded for questions already existing or for</p><p>questions which may arise eventually.</p><p>It may embrace any dispute or only disputes of a certain category.</p><p><em>Article 18</em></p><p>The Arbitration Convention implies the engagement to submit loyally to the Award.</p><p><em>Article 19</em></p><p>Independently of general or private Treaties expressly stipulating recourse to arbitration</p><p>as obligatory on the Signatory Powers, these Powers reserve to themselves the</p><p>right of concluding, either before the ratification of the present Act or later, new Agreements,</p><p>general or private, with a view to extending obligatory arbitration to all cases</p><p>which they may consider it possible to submit to it.</p><p><strong>Chapter II. On the Permanent Court of Arbitration</strong></p><p><em>Article 20</em></p><p>With the object of facilitating an immediate recourse to arbitration for international</p><p>differences, which it has not been possible to settle by diplomacy, the Signatory Powers</p><p>undertake to organize a Permanent Court of Arbitration, accessible at all times and</p><p>operating, unless otherwise stipulated by the parties, in accordance with the Rules of</p><p>Procedure inserted in the present Convention.</p><p><em>Article 21</em></p><p>The Permanent Court shall be competent for all arbitration cases, unless the parties</p><p>agree to institute a special Tribunal.</p><p><em>Article 22</em></p><p>An International Bureau, established at The Hague, serves as record office for the</p><p>Court.</p><p>This Bureau is the channel for communications relative to the meetings of the Court.</p><p>It has the custody of the archives and conducts all the administrative business.</p><p>The Signatory Powers undertake to communicate to the International Bureau at The</p><p>Hague a duly certified copy of any conditions of arbitration arrived at between them, and</p><p>of any award concerning them delivered by special Tribunals.</p><p>They undertake also to communicate to the Bureau the Laws, Regulations, and</p><p>documents eventually showing the execution of the Awards given by the Court.</p><p>PERMANENT COURT OF ARBITRATION – BASIC DOCUMENTS</p><p>8</p><p><em>Article 23</em></p><p>Within the three months following its ratification of the present Act, each Signatory</p><p>Power shall select four persons at the most, of known competency in questions of</p><p>international law, of the highest moral reputation, and disposed to accept the duties of</p><p>Arbitrators.</p><p>The persons thus selected shall be inscribed, as Members of the Court, in a list which</p><p>shall be notified by the Bureau to all the Signatory Powers.</p><p>Any alteration in the list of Arbitrators is brought by the Bureau to the knowledge of</p><p>the Signatory Powers.</p><p>Two or more Powers may agree on the selection in common of one or more Members.</p><p>The same person can be selected by different Powers.</p><p>The Members of the Court are appointed for a term of six years. Their appointments</p><p>can be renewed.</p><p>In case of the death or retirement of a Member of the Court, his place shall be filled</p><p>in accordance with the method of this appointment.</p><p><em>Article 24</em></p><p>When the Signatory Powers desire to have recourse to the Permanent Court for the</p><p>settlement of a difference that has arisen between them, the Arbitrators called upon to</p><p>form the competent Tribunal to decide this difference, must be chosen from the general</p><p>list of Members of the Court.</p><p>Failing the direct agreement of the parties on the composition of the Arbitration</p><p>Tribunal, the following course shall be pursued:</p><p>Each party appoints two Arbitrators, and these together choose an Umpire.</p><p>If the votes are equal, the choice of the Umpire is intrusted to a third Power, selected</p><p>by the parties by common accord.</p><p>If an agreement is not arrived at on this subject, each party selects a different Power,</p><p>and the choice of the Umpire is made in concert by the Powers thus selected.</p><p>The Tribunal being thus composed, the parties notify to the Bureau their determination</p><p>to have recourse to the Court and the names of the Arbitrators.</p><p>The Tribunal of Arbitration assembles on the date fixed by the parties.</p><p>The Members of the Court, in the discharge of their duties and out of their own</p><p>country, enjoy diplomatic privileges and immunities.</p><p><em>Article 25</em></p><p>The Tribunal of Arbitration has its ordinary seat at The Hague.</p><p>Except in cases of necessity, the place of session can only be altered by the Tribunal</p><p>with the assent of the parties.</p><p>1899 CONVENTION FOR THE PACIFIC SETTLEMENT OF INTERNATIONAL DISPUTES</p><p>9</p><p><em>Article 26</em></p><p>The International Bureau at The Hague is authorized to place its premises and its staff</p><p>at the disposal of the Signatory Powers for the operations of any special Board of</p><p>Arbitration.</p><p>The jurisdiction of the Permanent Court may, within the conditions laid down in the</p><p>Regulations, be extended to disputes between non-Signatory Powers, or between</p><p>Signatory Powers and non-Signatory Powers, if the parties are agreed on recourse to this</p><p>Tribunal.</p><p><em>Article 27</em></p><p>The Signatory Powers consider it their duty, if a serious dispute threatens to break out</p><p>between two or more of them, to remind these latter that the Permanent Court is open to</p><p>them.</p><p>Consequently, they declare that the fact of reminding the conflicting parties of the</p><p>provisions of the present Convention, and the advice given to them, in the highest</p><p>interests of peace, to have recourse to the Permanent Court, can only be regarded as</p><p>friendly actions.</p><p><em>Article 28</em></p><p>A Permanent Administrative Council composed of the Diplomatic Representatives of</p><p>the Signatory Powers accredited to The Hague and of the Netherlands Minister for</p><p>Foreign Affairs, who will act as President, shall be instituted in this town as soon as</p><p>possible after the ratification of the present Act by at least nine Powers.</p><p>This Council will be charged with the establishment and organization of the</p><p>International Bureau, which will be under its direction and control.</p><p>It will notify to the Powers the constitution of the Court and will provide for its</p><p>installation.</p><p>It will settle its Rules of Procedure and all other necessary Regulations.</p><p>It will decide all questions of administration which may arise with regard to the</p><p>operations of the Court.</p><p>It will have entire control over the appointment, suspension or dismissal of the</p><p>officials and employees of the Bureau.</p><p>It will fix the payments and salaries, and control the general expenditure.</p><p>At meetings duly summoned the presence of five members is sufficient to render valid</p><p>the discussions of the Council. The decisions are taken by a majority of votes.</p><p>The Council communicates to the Signatory Powers without delay the Regulations</p><p>adopted by it. It furnished them with an annual Report on the labours of the Court, the</p><p>working of the administration, and the expenses.</p><p>PERMANENT COURT OF ARBITRATION – BASIC DOCUMENTS</p><p>10</p><p><em>Article 29</em></p><p>The expenses of the Bureau shall be borne by the Signatory Powers in the proportion</p><p>fixed for the International Bureau of the Universal Postal Union.</p><p><strong>Chapter III. On Arbitral Procedure</strong></p><p><em>Article 30</em></p><p>With a view to encourage the development of arbitration, the Signatory Powers have</p><p>agreed on the following Rules which shall be applicable to arbitral procedure, unless</p><p>other Rules have been agreed on by the parties.</p><p><em>Article 31</em></p><p>The Powers who have recourse to arbitration sign a special Act (‘Compromis’), in</p><p>which the subject of the difference is clearly defined, as well as the extent of the</p><p>Arbitrators’ powers. This Act implies the undertaking of the parties to submit loyally to</p><p>the Award.</p><p><em>Article 32</em></p><p>The duties of Arbitrator may be conferred on one Arbitrator alone or on several</p><p>Arbitrators selected by the parties as they please, or chosen by them from the Members</p><p>of the Permanent Court of Arbitration established by the present Act.</p><p>Failing the constitution of the Tribunal by direct agreement between the parties, the</p><p>following course shall be pursued:</p><p>Each party appoints two Arbitrators, and these latter together choose an Umpire.</p><p>In case of equal voting, the choice of the Umpire is intrusted to a third Power, selected</p><p>by the parties by common accord.</p><p>If no agreement is arrived at on this subject, each party selects a different Power, and</p><p>the choice of the Umpire is made in concert by the Powers thus selected.</p><p><em>Article 33</em></p><p>When a Sovereign or the Chief of a State is chosen as Arbitrator, the arbitral</p><p>procedure is settled by him.</p><p><em>Article 34</em></p><p>The Umpire is by right President of the Tribunal.</p><p>When the Tribunal does not include an Umpire, it appoints its own President.</p><p>1899 CONVENTION FOR THE PACIFIC SETTLEMENT OF INTERNATIONAL DISPUTES</p><p>11</p><p><em>Article 35</em></p><p>In case of the death, retirement, or disability from any cause of one of the Arbitrators,</p><p>his place shall be filled in accordance with the method of his appointment.</p><p><em>Article 36</em></p><p>The Tribunal’s place of session is selected by the parties. Failing this selection the</p><p>Tribunal sits at The Hague.</p><p>The place thus fixed cannot, except in case of necessity, be changed by the Tribunal</p><p>without the assent of the parties.</p><p><em>Article 37</em></p><p>The parties have the right to appoint delegates or special agents to attend the Tribunal,</p><p>for the purpose of serving as intermediaries between them and the Tribunal.</p><p>They are further authorized to retain, for the defence of their rights and interests</p><p>before the Tribunal, counsel or advocates appointed by them for this purpose.</p><p><em>Article 38</em></p><p>The Tribunal decides on the choice of languages to be used by itself, and to be</p><p>authorized for use before it.</p><p><em>Article 39</em></p><p>As a general rule the arbitral procedure comprises two distinct phases; preliminary</p><p>examination and discussion.</p><p>Preliminary examination consists in the communication by the respective agents to</p><p>the members of the Tribunal and to the opposite party of all printed or written Acts and</p><p>of all documents containing the arguments invoked in the case. This communication</p><p>shall be made in the form and within the periods fixed by the Tribunal in accordance</p><p>with Article 49.</p><p>Discussion consists in the oral development before the Tribunal of the arguments of</p><p>the parties.</p><p><em>Article 40</em></p><p>Every document produced by one party must be communicated to the other party.</p><p><em>Article 41</em></p><p>The discussions are under the direction of the President.</p><p>They are only public if it be so decided by the Tribunal, with the assent of the parties.</p><p>PERMANENT COURT OF ARBITRATION – BASIC DOCUMENTS</p><p>12</p><p>They are recorded in the <em>procès-verbaux </em>drawn up by the Secretaries appointed by the</p><p>President. These <em>procès-verbaux </em>alone have an authentic character.</p><p><em>Article 42</em></p><p>When the preliminary examination is concluded, the Tribunal has the right to refuse</p><p>discussion of all fresh Acts or documents which one party may desire to submit to it</p><p>without the consent of the other party.</p><p><em>Article 43</em></p><p>The Tribunal is free to take into consideration fresh Acts or documents to which its</p><p>attention may be drawn by the agents or counsel of the parties.</p><p>In this case, the Tribunal has the right to require the production of these Acts or</p><p>documents, but is obliged to make them known to the opposite party.</p><p><em>Article 44</em></p><p>The Tribunal can, besides, require from the agents of the parties the production of all</p><p>Acts, and can demand all necessary explanations. In case of refusal, the Tribunal takes</p><p>note of it.</p><p><em>Article 45</em></p><p>The agents and counsel of the parties are authorized to present orally to the Tribunal</p><p>all the arguments they may think expedient in defence of their case.</p><p><em>Article 46</em></p><p>They have the right to raise objections and points.</p><p>The decisions of the Tribunal on those points are final, and cannot form the subject</p><p>of any subsequent discussion.</p><p><em>Article 47</em></p><p>The members of the Tribunal have the right to put questions to the agents and counsel</p><p>of the parties, and to demand explanations from them on doubtful points.</p><p>Neither the questions put nor the remarks made by members of the Tribunal during</p><p>the discussions can be regarded as an expression of opinion by the Tribunal in general,</p><p>or by its members in particular.</p><p>1899 CONVENTION FOR THE PACIFIC SETTLEMENT OF INTERNATIONAL DISPUTES</p><p>13</p><p><em>Article 48</em></p><p>The Tribunal is authorized to declare its competence in interpreting the ‘Compromis’</p><p>as well as the other Treaties which may be invoked in the case, and in applying the</p><p>principles of international law.</p><p><em>Article 49</em></p><p>The Tribunal has the right to issue Rules of Procedure for the conduct of the case, to</p><p>decide the forms and periods within which each party must conclude its arguments, and</p><p>to arrange all the formalities required for dealing with the evidence.</p><p><em>Article 50</em></p><p>When the agents and counsel of the parties have submitted all explanations and</p><p>evidence in support of their case, the President pronounces the discussion closed.</p><p><em>Article 51</em></p><p>The deliberations of the Tribunal take place in private.</p><p>Every decision is taken by a majority of members of the Tribunal.</p><p>The refusal of a member to vote must be recorded in the <em>procès-verbal</em>.</p><p><em>Article 52</em></p><p>The Award, given by a majority of votes, is accompanied by a statement of reasons.</p><p>It is drawn up in writing and signed by each member of the Tribunal.</p><p>Those members who are in the minority may record their dissent when signing.</p><p><em>Article 53</em></p><p>The Award is read out at a public meeting of the Tribunal, the agents and counsel of</p><p>the parties being present, or duly summoned to attend.</p><p><em>Article 54</em></p><p>The Award, duly pronounced and notified to the agents of the parties at variance, puts</p><p>an end to the dispute definitively and without appeal.</p><p><em>Article 55</em></p><p>The parties can reserve in the ‘Compromis’ the right to demand the revision of the</p><p>Award.</p><p>In this case, and unless there be an agreement to the contrary, the demand must be</p><p>addressed to the Tribunal which pronounced the Award. It can only be made on the</p><p>PERMANENT COURT OF ARBITRATION – BASIC DOCUMENTS</p><p>14</p><p>ground of the discovery of some new fact calculated to exercise a decisive influence on</p><p>the Award, and which, at the time the discussion was closed, was unknown to the</p><p>Tribunal and to the party demanding the revision.</p><p>Proceedings for revision can only be instituted by a decision of the Tribunal expressly</p><p>recording the existence of the new fact, recognizing in it the character described in the</p><p>foregoing paragraph, and declaring the demand admissible on this ground.</p><p>The ‘Compromis’ fixes the period within which the demand for revision must be</p><p>made.</p><p><em>Article 56</em></p><p>The Award is only binding on the parties who concluded the ‘Compromis’.</p><p>When there is a question of interpreting a Convention to which Powers other than</p><p>those concerned in the dispute are parties, the latter notify to the former the ‘Compromis’</p><p>they have concluded. Each of these Powers has the right to intervene in the case. If one</p><p>or more of them avail themselves of this right, the interpretation contained in the Award</p><p>is equally binding on them.</p><p><em>Article 57</em></p><p>Each party pays its own expenses and an equal share of those of the Tribunal.</p><p>GENERAL PROVISIONS</p><p><em>Article 58</em></p><p>The present Convention shall be ratified as speedily as possible.</p><p>The ratifications shall be deposited at The Hague.</p><p>A <em>procès-verbal </em>shall be drawn up recording the receipt of each ratification, and a</p><p>copy duly certified shall be sent, through the diplomatic channel, to all the Powers who</p><p>were represented at the International Peace Conference at The Hague.</p><p><em>Article 59</em></p><p>The non-Signatory Powers who were represented at the International Peace Conference</p><p>can adhere to the present Convention. For this purpose they must make known their</p><p>adhesion to the Contracting Powers by a written notification addressed to the</p><p>Netherlands Government, and communicated by it to all the other Contracting Powers.</p><p><em>Article 60</em></p><p>The conditions on which the Powers who were not represented at the International</p><p>Peace Conference can adhere to the present Convention shall form the subject of a</p><p>subsequent Agreement among the Contracting Powers.</p><p>1899 CONVENTION FOR THE PACIFIC SETTLEMENT OF INTERNATIONAL DISPUTES</p><p>15</p><p><em>Article 61</em></p><p>In the event of one of the High Contracting Parties denouncing the present Convention,</p><p>this denunciation would not take effect until a year after its notification made</p><p>in writing to the Netherlands Government, and by it communicated at once to all the</p><p>other Contracting Powers.</p><p>This denunciation shall only affect the notifying Power.</p><p>In faith of which the Plenipotentiaries have signed the present Convention and affixed</p><p>their seals to it.</p><p>Done at The Hague, the 29th July, 1899, in a single copy, which shall remain in the</p><p>archives of the Netherlands Government, and copies of it, duly certified, be sent through</p><p>the diplomatic channel to the Contracting Powers.</p></div></div>

3	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">1954 Convention on the  Protection of Cultural Property  in the Event of Armed Conflict  and its Protocols</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/human-rights-conventions/1954-convention-on-the-protection-of-cultural-property-in-the-event-of-armed-conflict-and-its-protocols/attachment/cultural_property-geneva-convention/" rel="attachment wp-att-6111">1954 Convention on the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict and its Protocols</a></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>ADVISORY SERVICE</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">ON INTERNATIONAL HUMANITARIAN LAW</p><p style="text-align: justify;">____________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>1954 Convention on the</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Protection of Cultural Property</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>in the Event of Armed Conflict</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>and its Protocols</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Military operations have often resulted in the destruction of irreplaceable cultural property, a loss not only to the country of origin</p><p style="text-align: justify;">but also to the cultural heritage of all people. Recognizing the significance of this loss, the international community adopted the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1954 Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict (CCP). A Protocol dealing with</p><p style="text-align: justify;">cultural property during times of occupation (P1) was adopted at the same time as the 1954 Convention. Although the 1954</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention strengthens protection for cultural property, its provisions have not been implemented consistently. To address this</p><p style="text-align: justify;">problem, a second Protocol to the 1954 Convention (P2) was adopted on 26 March 1999. In addition to these instruments, the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1977 Protocols additional to the Geneva Conventions include provisions protecting cultural property (Protocol I, Art. 38, 53 and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">85, and Protocol II, Art. 16). Ratification of each of the above-mentioned instruments is essential to preserving objects precious</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to all humanity.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Cultural Property</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Cultural property is any movable or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">immovable property of great</p><p style="text-align: justify;">importance to the cultural heritage of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">all people, such as monuments of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">architecture or history, archaeological</p><p style="text-align: justify;">sites, works of art, books or any</p><p style="text-align: justify;">building whose main and effective</p><p style="text-align: justify;">purpose is to contain cultural property</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(CCP, Art. 1).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Identification</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Cultural property should be identified</p><p style="text-align: justify;">with the emblem of the 1954</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention, pictured above (CCP,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Art. 16, 17).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Systems of Protection</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Parties to the Convention must</p><p style="text-align: justify;">protect all cultural property, whether</p><p style="text-align: justify;">their own or that situated in the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">territory of other States Parties. The</p><p style="text-align: justify;">various systems that provide</p><p style="text-align: justify;">protection for cultural property are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">described below:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong><em>General Protection</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>All </em>cultural property must be afforded,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">at minimum, “general protection”, as</p><p style="text-align: justify;">described in the Convention.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Protection:</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;">_ Parties to the Convention must</p><p style="text-align: justify;">safeguard their own cultural</p><p style="text-align: justify;">property against foreseeable</p><p style="text-align: justify;">effects of armed conflict (CCP,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Art. 3).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">_ States Parties must also respect</p><p style="text-align: justify;">all cultural property by the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">following:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(1) not using cultural property for</p><p style="text-align: justify;">any purpose likely to expose</p><p style="text-align: justify;">it to destruction or damage in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the event of armed conflict;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) not directing any act of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">hostility against cultural</p><p style="text-align: justify;">property (CCP, Art. 4).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Exception</em>:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">_ The obligation to respect a l l</p><p style="text-align: justify;">cultural property, described</p><p style="text-align: justify;">above, may be waived on the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">basis of “imperative military</p><p style="text-align: justify;">necessity” (CCP, Art. 4).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">_ This waiver may be invoked:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(1) to <em>use </em>cultural property for</p><p style="text-align: justify;">purposes likely to endanger</p><p style="text-align: justify;">it, only if there is no feasible</p><p style="text-align: justify;">alternative available to obtain</p><p style="text-align: justify;">a similar military advantage.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(P2, Art. 6);</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) to <em>attack </em>cultural property,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">only when that property has,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">by its function, been made</p><p style="text-align: justify;">into a military objective and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">there is no feasible</p><p style="text-align: justify;">alternative available to obtain</p><p style="text-align: justify;">a similar military advantage.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Effective advance warning</p><p style="text-align: justify;">must be given,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">circumstances permitting</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(P2, Art. 6).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Precautions:</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;">_ Parties to the Convention must,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to the maximum extent feasible,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">either move cultural property</p><p style="text-align: justify;">away from military objectives or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">avoid placing military objectives</p><p style="text-align: justify;">near such property (P2, Art. 8).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">_ Parties to a conflict must do</p><p style="text-align: justify;">everything feasible to protect</p><p style="text-align: justify;">cultural property, including</p><p style="text-align: justify;">refraining from an attack that may</p><p style="text-align: justify;">cause incidental damage (P2,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Art. 7).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">International Committee of the Red Cross</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Occupied Territory</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;">_ Under the Convention, States</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Parties occupying foreign</p><p style="text-align: justify;">territory must preserve cultural</p><p style="text-align: justify;">property in that territory (CCP,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Art. 5).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">_ The 1954 Protocol requires</p><p style="text-align: justify;">States Parties occupying</p><p style="text-align: justify;">territory during armed conflict to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prevent the exportation of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">cultural property from that</p><p style="text-align: justify;">territory (P1, Art. 1). However, if</p><p style="text-align: justify;">cultural property is exported,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">States Parties must return it at</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the close of the hostilities (P1,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Art. 3).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong><em>Special protection</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">The 1954 Convention provides a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">system of “special protection”, which</p><p style="text-align: justify;">resulted in only limited success. In</p><p style="text-align: justify;">response to the limitations of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1954 system, the 1999 Protocol</p><p style="text-align: justify;">introduces a new system of</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>“</em>enhanced protection” <em>(see below</em>).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">If property has been granted both</p><p style="text-align: justify;">special and enhanced protection,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">only enhanced protection applies</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(P2, Art. 4).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong><em>Enhanced protection</em></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">The 1999 Protocol provides</p><p style="text-align: justify;">“enhanced protection” of certain</p><p style="text-align: justify;">cultural objects.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Criteria for Protection:</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;">_ To be granted “enhanced</p><p style="text-align: justify;">protection”, cultural property</p><p style="text-align: justify;">must meet the following three</p><p style="text-align: justify;">criteria (P2, Art. 10):</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(1) it is cultural heritage of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">greatest importance to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">humanity;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) it is protected by domestic</p><p style="text-align: justify;">measures that recognize its</p><p style="text-align: justify;">cultural and historical value</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and ensure the highest</p><p style="text-align: justify;">level of protection;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) it is not used for military</p><p style="text-align: justify;">purposes or to shield</p><p style="text-align: justify;">military sites, and the Party</p><p style="text-align: justify;">which has control over the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">property has formally</p><p style="text-align: justify;">declared that it will not be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">so used.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">_ Cultural property granted</p><p style="text-align: justify;">enhanced protection by the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Committee for the Protection of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Cultural Property in the Event of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Armed Conflict is placed on the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">“List of Cultural Property under</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Enhanced Protection” (P2, Art.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Protection:</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;">_ Parties holding property</p><p style="text-align: justify;">included on the List must not</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>use </em>such property or its</p><p style="text-align: justify;">immediate surroundings in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">support of military action (P2,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Art. 12). There is no exception</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to this obligation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">_ Parties to the Convention must</p><p style="text-align: justify;">refrain from <em>attack </em>against</p><p style="text-align: justify;">property on the List (P2, Art.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Exception:</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;">_ The obligation not to <em>attack</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;">property on the List does not</p><p style="text-align: justify;">apply if such property has, by</p><p style="text-align: justify;">virtue of its use, become a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">military objective. Attack is</p><p style="text-align: justify;">permitted only if it is the only</p><p style="text-align: justify;">feasible means of terminating</p><p style="text-align: justify;">such use and if precautions are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">taken to minimize damage to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the property. Effective advance</p><p style="text-align: justify;">warning must be given,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">circumstances permitting (P2,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Art. 13).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Criminal Responsibility and</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Jurisdiction</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Parties to the Convention must take</p><p style="text-align: justify;">all necessary steps to prosecute and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">impose sanctions on all persons</p><p style="text-align: justify;">who violate its provisions (CCP, Art.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">28).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">States party to the 1999 Protocol</p><p style="text-align: justify;">must ensure that the following are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">offences under domestic law (P2,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Art. 15):</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(1) making cultural property under</p><p style="text-align: justify;">enhanced protection the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">object of attack;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) using cultural property under</p><p style="text-align: justify;">enhanced protection or its</p><p style="text-align: justify;">immediate surroundings in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">support of military action;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) extensive destruction or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">appropriation of protected</p><p style="text-align: justify;">cultural property;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) making protected cultural</p><p style="text-align: justify;">property the object of attack;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) theft, pillage or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">misappropriation of, or acts of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">vandalism directed against,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">protected cultural property.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Each State Party must ensure that</p><p style="text-align: justify;">its legislation establishes jurisdiction</p><p style="text-align: justify;">when the offence is committed in its</p><p style="text-align: justify;">territory, when the alleged offender</p><p style="text-align: justify;">is a national of that State, and — in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">relation to the first three offences —</p><p style="text-align: justify;">when the offence is committed</p><p style="text-align: justify;">abroad by a non-national.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Dissemination</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Parties to the 1954 Convention and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">its Protocols must disseminate the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">treaty provisions as widely as</p><p style="text-align: justify;">possible, seeking to strengthen</p><p style="text-align: justify;">appreciation and respect for cultural</p><p style="text-align: justify;">property among the general</p><p style="text-align: justify;">population (CCP, Art. 25; P2, Art.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">30). Particular effort should be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">taken to disseminate information</p><p style="text-align: justify;">among the armed forces and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">personnel engaged in the protection</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of cultural property.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>09/2002</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;">International Committee of the Red Cross</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p></div></div>
4	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">2010 Review Conference of the Parties to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p>2010 Review Conferance of the Parties to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons</p><p>19 March 2010</p><p>Original: English</p><p>10-28119 (E) 300310</p><p>*1028119*</p><p>New York, 3-28 May 2010</p><p>Memorandum on activities relating to the South Pacific</p><p>Nuclear Free Zone Treaty (Treaty of Rarotonga)</p><p>Submitted by the Pacific Islands Forum secretariat</p><p>Introduction</p><p>1. The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty (Treaty of Rarotonga) was signed</p><p>at Rarotonga, Cook Islands, on 6 August 1985, and entered into force on</p><p>11 December 1986.</p><p>2. The Treaty is based on broad principles for Pacific countries to:</p><p>(a) Be free to live in peace and independence and to run their own affairs, in</p><p>accordance with the wishes and traditions of their people;</p><p>(b) Enjoy peaceful, social and economic development free from the threat of</p><p>environmental pollution;</p><p>(c) Acknowledge existing international treaties, organizations and regional</p><p>arrangements, such as the Charter of the United Nations, the Treaty on the</p><p>Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and the United Nations Convention on the</p><p>Law of the Sea, which contribute to these principles;</p><p>(d) Act in accordance with applicable international principles and treaties,</p><p>notably the Non-Proliferation Treaty, with respect to nuclear activities;</p><p>(e) Take account of other regional arrangements;</p><p>(f) Retain their unqualified sovereign rights to decide their security</p><p>arrangements for themselves, consistent with their support for these principles.</p><p>3. The Treaty of Rarotonga has been signed and ratified by 13 Forum members</p><p>within the original geographical boundaries of the Treaty, namely Australia, Cook</p><p>Islands, Fiji, Kiribati, Nauru, New Zealand, Niue, Papua New Guinea, Samoa,</p><p>Solomon Islands, Tonga, Tuvalu and Vanuatu. The States parties to the Treaty and</p><p>the Pacific Islands Forum secretariat maintain close working relations with the</p><p>Federated States of Micronesia, the Marshall Islands and Palau, which joined the</p><p>Pacific Islands Forum after the establishment of the Treaty of Rarotonga. Although</p><p>NPT/CONF.2010/7</p><p>10-28119 2</p><p>currently not parties to the Treaty, it is expected that, in time, these countries will</p><p>also become parties to the Treaty of Rarotonga.</p><p>4. The Treaty of Rarotonga represents a unified approach by the States members</p><p>of the Forum in fulfilling their commitments under article VII of the</p><p>Non-Proliferation Treaty. It also represents a significant achievement and</p><p>contribution of the Pacific Islands Forum to ongoing efforts to strengthen global</p><p>security and the international non-proliferation regime. Regional treaties such as the</p><p>Treaty of Rarotonga provide valuable support and strength to the Non-Proliferation</p><p>Treaty, as well as opportunities to enhance coordination and cooperation among</p><p>nuclear-weapon-free zones, in support of the process of nuclear disarmament, with</p><p>the ultimate goal of eliminating all nuclear weapons.</p><p>5. The States members of the Forum are deeply committed to world peace and</p><p>security, and have renounced the manufacture, acquisition and possession of nuclear</p><p>explosive devices. They are determined to keep the Pacific region free of</p><p>environmental pollution from radioactive waste and other radioactive matter, and</p><p>seek, from the nuclear-weapon States, a commitment not to conduct nuclear tests in</p><p>the South Pacific.</p><p>The Treaty of Rarotonga</p><p>6. The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty (Treaty of Rarotonga) was the</p><p>second such treaty in the world. Its area of application ranges from the west coast of</p><p>Australia to the Latin American nuclear free zone in the east and from just north of</p><p>the equator to the Antarctic Treaty area. Together with the Treaty of Tlatelolco,</p><p>which covers Latin America, and the Antarctic Treaty, the Treaty of Rarotonga</p><p>covers contiguously a very significant portion of the globe. This coverage was</p><p>greatly increased by the Treaty of Bangkok of December 1995, which created a</p><p>nuclear free zone for South-East Asia, and by the Treaty of Pelindaba of April 1996,</p><p>which created a similar zone for Africa.</p><p>7. The Treaty contains a preamble, 16 articles and 4 annexes. Under its terms, the</p><p>parties undertake:</p><p>(a) Not to manufacture or otherwise acquire, possess or have control over</p><p>any nuclear explosive device by any means anywhere inside or outside the South</p><p>Pacific Nuclear Free Zone; the term “nuclear explosive device” is used rather than</p><p>“nuclear weapon” to emphasize that the parties do not draw a distinction between</p><p>devices that have military purposes and those for which a peaceful purpose is</p><p>claimed;</p><p>(b) To prevent the testing of nuclear explosive devices and to prevent the</p><p>stationing of nuclear explosive devices in their territory;</p><p>(c) To take measures, including the application of full-scope International</p><p>Atomic Energy Agency safeguards, to all peaceful nuclear activities in their territory</p><p>and to prevent the diversion of fissionable material to non-peaceful purposes;</p><p>(d) Not to dump radioactive waste and other radioactive matter at sea in the</p><p>Zone, to prevent the dumping of such waste or matter by anyone, and to take no</p><p>action to assist or encourage dumping.</p><p>NPT/CONF.2010/7</p><p>3 10-28119</p><p>8. The Treaty of Raratonga does not interfere with the right of each State party to</p><p>decide for itself whether to allow visits by foreign ships and aircraft to its ports and</p><p>airfields. It also explicitly upholds the freedom of navigation on the high seas and</p><p>territorial waters guaranteed by international law.</p><p>9. The Treaty also provides for a comprehensive control system to verify parties’</p><p>compliance with the Treaty, including procedures for the investigation of any</p><p>complaints that may be made regarding the breach of Treaty obligations. There are</p><p>also provisions for review, amendment and withdrawal, and for the boundaries of</p><p>the Zone to be extended as further countries join the Forum and become parties to</p><p>the Treaty.</p><p>The Protocols</p><p>10. The implementation of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty is enhanced</p><p>by three Protocols that were opened for signature in 1986. Through these Protocols,</p><p>nuclear-weapon States have undertaken to apply the Treaty of Rarotonga to their</p><p>territories in the Pacific region (Protocol 1); to refrain from the use or threat of use</p><p>of nuclear explosive devices against any party (Protocol 2); and not to test any</p><p>nuclear explosive devices within the Zone (Protocol 3).</p><p>11. The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and China signed Protocols 2 and 3 in</p><p>1986 and 1987 respectively, and ratified both in 1988. Neither the Union of Soviet</p><p>Socialist Republics nor China has territories in the Zone that would require</p><p>adherence to Protocol 1. France, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern</p><p>Ireland and the United States of America signed Protocols 1, 2 and 3 on 25 March</p><p>1996. France ratified the Protocols in 1996 and the United Kingdom in 1997. The</p><p>United States has yet to ratify the Protocols.</p><p>Forum secretariat activities</p><p>12. The Forum secretariat continues to promote the Treaty of Rarotonga and to</p><p>monitor national, regional and global developments relevant to the non-proliferation</p><p>of nuclear weapons. It also remains in contact with the secretariats of other nuclear</p><p>free zones in relation to relevant developments and joint activities.</p></div></div>
5	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CONVENTION FOR THE PROTECTION OF HUMAN RIGHTS AND FUNDAMENTAL FREEDOMS</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/?attachment_id=6048" rel="attachment wp-att-6048">CONVENTION FOR THE PROTECTION OF HUMAN RIGHTS AND FUNDAMENTAL FREEDOMS</a></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms as amended by Protocols Nos. 11 and 14 with Protocols Nos. 1, 4, 6, 7, 12 and 13.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The text of the Convention is presented as amended by the provisions of Protocol No. 14 (CETS no. 194) as from its entry into force on 1 June 2010. The text of the Convention had previously been amended according to the provisions of Protocol No. 3 (ETS no. 45), which entered into force on 21 September 1970, of Protocol No. 5 (ETS no. 55), which entered into force on 20 December 1971, and of Protocol No. 8 (ETS no. 118), which entered into force on 1 January 1990, and comprised also the text of Protocol No. 2 (ETS no. 44) which, in accordance with Article 5 § 3 thereof, had been an integral part of the Convention since its entry into force on 21 September 1970. All provisions which had been amended or added by these Protocols were replaced by Protocol No. 11 (ETS no. 155), as from the date of its entry into force on 1 November 1998. As from that date, Protocol No. 9 (ETS no. 140), which entered into force on 1 October 1994, was repealed and Protocol No. 10 (ETS no. 146) lost its purpose. The current state of signatures and ratifications of the Convention and its Protocols as well as the complete list of declarations and reservations are available at http://conventions.coe.int. Registry of the European Court of Human Rights June 2010<br/>European Convention on Human Rights<br/>Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms Rome, 4.XI.1950 The governments signatory hereto, being members of the Council of Europe, Considering the Universal Declaration of Human Rights proclaimed by the General Assembly of the United Nations on 10 December 1948; Considering that this Declaration aims at securing the universal and effective recognition and observance of the Rights therein declared; Considering that the aim of the Council of Europe is the achievement of greater unity between its members and that one of the methods by which that aim is to be pursued is the maintenance and further realisation of human rights and fundamental freedoms; Reaffirming their profound belief in those fundamental freedoms which are the foundation of justice and peace in the world and are best maintained on the one hand by an effective political democracy and on the other by a common understanding and observance of the human rights upon which they depend; Being resolved, as the governments of European countries which are likeminded and have a common heritage of political traditions, ideals, freedom and the rule of law, to take the first steps for the collective enforcement of certain of the rights stated in the Universal Declar-ation, Have agreed as follows: Article 1 Obligation to respect human rights The High Contracting Parties shall secure to everyone within their jurisdiction the rights and freedoms defined in Section I of this Convention. Section I Rights and freedoms Article 2 Right to life 1. Everyone’s right to life shall be protected by law. No one shall be deprived of his life intentionally save in the execution of a sentence of a court following his conviction of a crime for which this penalty is provided by law. 2. Deprivation of life shall not be regarded as inflicted in contravention of this Article when it results from the use of force which is no more than abso-lutely necessary: (a) in defence of any person from unlawful violence; (b) in order to effect a lawful arrest or to prevent the escape of a person lawfully detained; (c) in action lawfully taken for the purpose of quelling a riot or insurrection. Article 3 Prohibition of torture No one shall be subjected to torture or to inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Article 4 Prohibition of slavery and forced labour 1. No one shall be held in slavery or servitude. 2. No one shall be required to perform forced or compulsory labour. 3. For the purpose of this Article the<br/>4<br/>European Convention on Human Rights<br/>term “forced or compulsory labour” shall not include: (a) any work required to be done in the ordinary course of detention imposed according to the provisions of Article 5 of this Convention or during conditional release from such detention; (b) any service of a military character or, in case of conscientious objectors in countries where they are recognised, service exacted instead of compulsory military service; (c) any service exacted in case of an emergency or calamity threatening the life or well-being of the community; (d) any work or service which forms part of normal civic obligations. Article 5 Right to liberty and security 1. Everyone has the right to liberty and security of person. No one shall be deprived of his liberty save in the following cases and in accordance with a procedure prescribed by law: (a) the lawful detention of a person after conviction by a competent court; (b) the lawful arrest or detention of a person for non-compliance with the lawful order of a court or in order to secure the fulfilment of any obligation prescribed by law; (c) the lawful arrest or detention of a person effected for the purpose of bringing him before the competent legal authority on reasonable suspicion of having committed an offence or when it is reasonably considered necessary to prevent his committing an offence or fleeing after having done so; (d) the detention of a minor by lawful order for the purpose of educational supervision or his lawful detention for the purpose of bringing him before the competent legal authority; (e) the lawful detention of persons for the prevention of the spreading of infectious diseases, of persons of un-sound mind, alcoholics or drug addicts or vagrants; (f) the lawful arrest or detention of a person to prevent his effecting an unauthorised entry into the country or of a person against whom action is being taken with a view to deportation or extradition. 2. Everyone who is arrested shall be informed promptly, in a language which he understands, of the reasons for his arrest and of any charge against him. 3. Everyone arrested or detained in accordance with the provisions of paragraph 1 (c) of this Article shall be brought promptly before a judge or other officer authorised by law to exercise judicial power and shall be entitled to trial within a reasonable time or to release pending trial. Release may be conditioned by guarantees to appear for trial. 4. Everyone who is deprived of his liberty by arrest or detention shall be entitled to take proceedings by which the lawfulness of his detention shall be decided speedily by a court and his release ordered if the detention is not lawful. 5. Everyone who has been the victim of arrest or detention in contravention of the provisions of this Article shall have an enforceable right to compensation. Article 6 Right to a fair trial 1. In the determination of his civil rights and obligations or of any criminal charge against him, everyone is entitled to a fair and public hearing within a reasonable time by an independent and impartial tribunal established by law. Judgment shall be pronounced publicly but the press and public may be excluded from all or part of the trial in the interests of morals, public order or national security in a democratic society, where the interests of juveniles or the protection of the private life of the parties so require, or to the extent strictly necessary in the opinion of the court in special circumstances where publicity would prejudice the interests of justice. 2. Everyone charged with a criminal offence shall be presumed innocent until proved guilty according to law. 3. Everyone charged with a criminal offence has the following minimum rights: (a) to be informed promptly, in a language which he understands and in 5<br/>European Convention on Human Rights<br/>detail, of the nature and cause of the accusation against him; (b) to have adequate time and facilities for the preparation of his defence; (c) to defend himself in person or through legal assistance of his own choosing or, if he has not sufficient means to pay for legal assistance, to be given it free when the interests of justice so require; (d) to examine or have examined witnesses against him and to obtain the attendance and examination of wit-nesses on his behalf under the same conditions as witnesses against him; (e) to have the free assistance of an interpreter if he cannot understand or speak the language used in court. Article 7 No punishment without law 1. No one shall be held guilty of any criminal offence on account of any act or omission which did not constitute a criminal offence under national or international law at the time when it was committed. Nor shall a heavier penalty be imposed than the one that was applicable at the time the criminal offence was committed. 2. This Article shall not prejudice the trial and punishment of any person for any act or omission which, at the time when it was committed, was criminal according to the general principles of law recognised by civilised nations. Article 8 Right to respect for private and family life 1. Everyone has the right to respect for his private and family life, his home and his correspondence. 2. There shall be no interference by a public authority with the exercise of this right except such as is in accordance with the law and is necessary in a democratic society in the interests of national security, public safety or the economic well-being of the country, for the prevention of disorder or crime, for the protection of health or morals, or for the protection of the rights and freedoms of others. Article 9 Freedom of thought, conscience and religion 1. Everyone has the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion; this right includes freedom to change his religion or belief and freedom, either alone or in community with others and in public or private, to manifest his religion or belief, in worship, teaching, practice and observance. 2. Freedom to manifest one’s religion or beliefs shall be subject only to such limitations as are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society in the interests of public safety, for the protection of public order, health or morals, or for the protection of the rights and freedoms of others. Article 10 Freedom of expression 1. Everyone has the right to freedom of expression. This right shall include freedom to hold opinions and to receive and impart information and ideas without interference by public authority and regardless of frontiers. This Article shall not prevent States from requiring the licensing of broadcasting, television or cinema enterprises. 2. The exercise of these freedoms, since it carries with it duties and responsibilities, may be subject to such formalities, conditions, restrictions or penalties as are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society, in the interests of national security, territorial integrity or public safety, for the prevention of disorder or crime, for the protection of health or morals, for the protection of the reputation or rights of others, for preventing the disclosure of information received in confidence, or for maintaining the authority and im-partiality of the judiciary. Article 11 Freedom of assembly and association 1. Everyone has the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and to freedom of association with others, including the 6<br/>European Convention on Human Rights<br/>right to form and to join trade unions for the protection of his interests. 2. No restrictions shall be placed on the exercise of these rights other than such as are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society in the interests of national security or public safety, for the prevention of disorder or crime, for the protection of health or morals or for the protection of the rights and freedoms of others. This Article shall not prevent the imposition of lawful restrictions on the exercise of these rights by members of the armed forces, of the police or of the administration of the State. Article 12 Right to marry Men and women of marriageable age have the right to marry and to found a family, according to the national laws governing the exercise of this right. Article 13 Right to an effective remedy Everyone whose rights and freedoms as set forth in this Convention are violated shall have an effective remedy before a national authority notwithstanding that the violation has been committed by persons acting in an official capacity. Article 14 Prohibition of discrimination The enjoyment of the rights and freedoms set forth in this Convention shall be secured without discrimination on any ground such as sex, race, colour, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, association with a national minority, property, birth or other status. Article 15 Derogation in time of emergency 1. In time of war or other public emergency threatening the life of the nation any High Contracting Party may take measures derogating from its obligations under this Convention to the extent strictly required by the exigencies of the situation, provided that such measures are not inconsistent with its other obligations under international law. 2. No derogation from Article 2, except in respect of deaths resulting from lawful acts of war, or from Articles 3, 4 § 1 and 7 shall be made under this provision. 3. Any High Contracting Party availing itself of this right of derogation shall keep the Secretary General of the Council of Europe fully informed of the measures which it has taken and the reasons therefor. It shall also inform the Secretary General of the Council of Europe when such measures have ceased to operate and the provisions of the Convention are again being fully executed. Article 16 Restrictions on political activity of aliens Nothing in Articles 10, 11 and 14 shall be regarded as preventing the High Contracting Parties from imposing restrictions on the political activity of aliens. Article 17 Prohibition of abuse of rights Nothing in this Convention may be interpreted as implying for any State, group or person any right to engage in any activity or perform any act aimed at the destruction of any of the rights and freedoms set forth herein or at their limitation to a greater extent than is provided for in the Convention. Article 18 Limitation on use of restrictions on rights The restrictions permitted under this Convention to the said rights and freedoms shall not be applied for any purpose other than those for which they have been prescribed. 7<br/>European Convention on Human Rights<br/>Section II European Court of Human Rights Article 19 Establishment of the Court To ensure the observance of the engagements undertaken by the High Contracting Parties in the Convention and the Protocols thereto, there shall be set up a European Court of Human Rights, hereinafter referred to as “the Court”. It shall function on a permanent basis. Article 20 Number of judges The Court shall consist of a number of judges equal to that of the High Contracting Parties. Article 21 Criteria for office 1. The judges shall be of high moral character and must either possess the qualifications required for appointment to high judicial office or be jurisconsults of recognised competence. 2. The judges shall sit on the Court in their individual capacity. 3. During their term of office the judges shall not engage in any activity which is incompatible with their independence, impartiality or with the demands of a full-time office; all questions arising from the application of this paragraph shall be decided by the Court. Article 22 Election of judges The judges shall be elected by the Parliamentary Assembly with respect to each High Contracting Party by a majority of votes cast from a list of three candidates nominated by the High Contracting Party. Article 23 Terms of office and dismissal 1. The judges shall be elected for a period of nine years. They may not be re-elected. 2. The terms of office of judges shall expire when they reach the age of 70. 3. The judges shall hold office until replaced. They shall, however, continue to deal with such cases as they already have under consideration. 4. No judge may be dismissed from office unless the other judges decide by a majority of two-thirds that that judge has ceased to fulfil the required conditions. Article 24 Registry and rapporteurs 1. The Court shall have a Registry, the functions and organisation of which shall be laid down in the rules of the Court. 2. When sitting in a single-judge formation, the Court shall be assisted by rapporteurs who shall function under the authority of the President of the Court. They shall form part of the Court’s Registry. Article 25 Plenary Court The plenary Court shall (a) elect its President and one or two Vice-Presidents for a period of three years; they may be re-elected; (b) set up Chambers, constituted for a fixed period of time; (c) elect the Presidents of the Chambers of the Court; they may be re-elected; (d) adopt the rules of the Court; (e) elect the Registrar and one or more Deputy Registrars; (f) make any request under Article 26 § 2. Article 26 Single-judge formation, Committees, Chambers and Grand Chamber 1. To consider cases brought before it, the Court shall sit in a single-judge formation, in Committees of three judges, in Chambers of seven judges<br/>8<br/>European Convention on Human Rights<br/>and in a Grand Chamber of seventeen judges. The Court’s Chambers shall set up Committees for a fixed period of time. 2. At the request of the plenary Court, the Committee of Ministers may, by a unanimous decision and for a fixed period, reduce to five the number of judges of the Chambers. 3. When sitting as a single judge, a judge shall not examine any application against the High Contracting Party in respect of which that judge has been elected. 4. There shall sit as an ex officio member of the Chamber and the Grand Chamber the judge elected in respect of the High Contracting Party concerned. If there is none or if that judge is unable to sit, a person chosen by the President of the Court from a list submitted in advance by that Party shall sit in the capacity of judge. 5. The Grand Chamber shall also include the President of the Court, the Vice-Presidents, the Presidents of the Chambers and other judges chosen in accordance with the rules of the Court. When a case is referred to the Grand Chamber under Article 43, no judge from the Chamber which rendered the judgment sha</p></div></div>
