The data<br/>thus obtained by the International Civil Aviation Organization shall be made<br/>available by it on request to the other contracting States.<br/>CHAPTER IV<br/>MEASURES TO FACILITATE AIR NAVIGATION<br/>Article 22<br/>Facilitation of formalities<br/>Each contracting State agrees to adopt all practicable measures,<br/>through the issuance of special regulations or otherwise, to facilitate and<br/>expedite navigation by aircraft between the territories of contracting States,<br/>and to prevent unnecessary delays to aircraft, crews, passengers and cargo,<br/>especially in the administration of the laws relating to immigration,<br/>quarantine, customs and clearance.<br/>Article 23<br/>Customs and immigration procedures<br/>Each contracting State undertakes, so far as it may find practicable,<br/>to establish customs and immigration procedures affecting international air<br/>navigation in accordance with the practices which may be established or<br/>recommended from time to time, pursuant to this Convention. Nothing in<br/>this Convention shall be construed as preventing the establishment of<br/>customs-free airports.<br/>Article 24<br/>Customs duty<br/>(a) Aircraft on a flight to, from, or across the territory of<br/>another contracting State shall be admitted temporarily free of duty,<br/>subject to the customs regulations of the State. Fuel, lubricating<br/>oils, spare parts, regular equipment and aircraft stores on board an<br/>aircraft of a contracting State, on arrival in the territory of another<br/>contracting State and retained on board on leaving the territory of<br/>that State shall be exempt from customs duty, inspection fees or<br/>similar national or local duties and charges. This exemption shall<br/>not apply to any quantities or articles unloaded, except in<br/>accordance with the customs regulations of the State, which may<br/>require that they shall be kept under customs supervision.<br/>(b) Spare parts and equipment imported into the territory<br/>of a contracting State for incorporation in or use on an aircraft of<br/>another contracting State engaged in international air navigation<br/>shall be admitted free of customs duty, subject to compliance with<br/>the regulations of the State concerned, which may provide that the<br/>articles shall be kept under customs supervision and control.<br/>Article 25<br/>Aircraft in distress<br/>Each contracting State undertakes to provide such measures of<br/>assistance to aircraft in distress in its territory as it may find practicable, and<br/>to permit, subject to control by its own authorities, the owners of the aircraft<br/>or authorities of the State in which the aircraft is registered to provide such<br/>measures of assistance as may be necessitated by the circumstances. Each<br/>contracting State, when undertaking search for missing aircraft, will<br/>collaborate in coordinated measures which may be recommended from time<br/>to time pursuant to this Convention.<br/>Article 26<br/>Investigation of accidents<br/>In the event of an accident to an aircraft of a contracting State<br/>occurring in the territory of another contracting State, and involving death<br/>or serious injury, or indicating serious technical defect in the aircraft or air<br/>navigation facilities, the State in which the accident occurs will institute an<br/>inquiry into the circumstances of the accident, in accordance, so far as its<br/>laws permit, with the procedure which may be recommended by the<br/>International Civil Aviation Organization. The State in which the aircraft is<br/>registered shall be given the opportunity to appoint observers to be present<br/>at the inquiry and the State holding the inquiry shall communicate the report<br/>and findings in the matter to that State.<br/>Article 27<br/>Exemption from seizure on patent claims<br/>(a) While engaged in international air navigation, any<br/>authorized entry of aircraft of a contracting State into the territory<br/>of another contracting State or authorized transit across the territory<br/>of such State with or without landings shall not entail any seizure<br/>or detention of the aircraft or any claim against the owner or<br/>operator thereof or any other interference therewith by or on behalf<br/>of such State or any person therein, on the ground that the<br/>construction, mechanism, parts, accessories or operation of the<br/>aircraft is an infringement of any patent, design, or model duly<br/>granted or registered in the State whose territory is entered by the<br/>aircraft, it being agreed that no deposit of security in connection<br/>with the foregoing exemption from seizure or detention of the<br/>aircraft shall in any case be required in the State entered by such<br/>aircraft.<br/>(b) The provisions of paragraph (a) of this Article shall<br/>also be applicable to the storage of spare parts and spare equipment<br/>for the aircraft and the right to use and install the same in the repair<br/>of an aircraft of a contracting State in the territory of any other<br/>contracting State, provided that any patented part or equipment so<br/>stored shall not be sold or distributed internally in or exported<br/>commercially from the contracting State entered by the aircraft.<br/>(c) The benefits of this Article shall apply only to such<br/>States, parties to this Convention, as either (1) are parties to the<br/>International Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property<br/>and to any amendments thereof; or (2) have enacted patent laws<br/>which recognize and give adequate protection to inventions made<br/>by the nationals of the other States parties to this Convention.<br/>Article 28<br/>Air navigation facilities<br/>and standard systems<br/>Each contracting State undertakes, so far as it may find practicable,<br/>to:<br/>(a) Provide, in its territory, airports, radio services,<br/>meteorological services and other air navigation facilities to<br/>facilitate international air navigation, in accordance with the<br/>standards and practices recommended or established from time to<br/>time, pursuant to this Convention;<br/>(b) Adopt and put into operation the appropriate standard<br/>systems of communications procedure, codes, markings, signals,<br/>lighting and other operational practices and rules which may be<br/>recommended or established from time to time, pursuant to this<br/>Convention;<br/>(c) Collaborate in international measures to secure the<br/>publication of aeronautical maps and charts in accordance with<br/>standards which may be recommended or established from time to<br/>time, pursuant to this Convention.<br/>CHAPTER V<br/>CONDITIONS TO BE FULFILLED<br/>WITH RESPECT TO AIRCRAFT<br/>Article 29<br/>Documents carried in aircraft<br/>Every aircraft of a contracting State, engaged in international<br/>navigation, shall carry the following documents in conformity with the<br/>conditions prescribed in this Convention:<br/>(a) Its certificate of registration;<br/>(b) Its certificate of airworthiness;<br/>(c) The appropriate licenses for each member of the crew;<br/>(d) Its journey log book;<br/>(e) If it is equipped with radio apparatus, the aircraft radio<br/>station license;<br/>(f) If it carries passengers, a list of their names and places<br/>of embarkation and destination;<br/>(g) If it carries cargo, a manifest and detailed declarations<br/>of the cargo.<br/>Article 30<br/>Aircraft radio equipment<br/>(a) Aircraft of each contracting State may, in or over the<br/>territory of other contracting States, carry radio transmitting<br/>apparatus only if a license to install and operate such apparatus has<br/>been issued by the appropriate authorities of the State in which the<br/>aircraft is registered. The use of radio transmitting apparatus in the<br/>territory of the contracting State whose territory is flown over shall<br/>be in accordance with the regulations prescribed by that State.<br/>(b) Radio transmitting apparatus may be used only by<br/>members of the flight crew who are provided with a special license<br/>for the purpose, issued by the appropriate authorities of the State<br/>in which the aircraft is registered.<br/>Article 31<br/>Certificates of airworthiness<br/>Every aircraft engaged in international navigation shall be provided<br/>with a certificate of airworthiness issued or rendered valid by the State in<br/>which it is registered.<br/>Article 32<br/>Licenses of personnel<br/>(a) The pilot of every aircraft and the other members of<br/>the operating crew of every aircraft engaged in international<br/>navigation shall be provided with certificates of competency and<br/>licenses issued or rendered valid by the State in which the aircraft<br/>is registered.<br/>(b) Each contracting State reserves the right to refuse to<br/>recognize, for the purpose of flight above its own territory,<br/>certificates of competency and licenses granted to any of its<br/>nationals by another contracting State.<br/>Article 33<br/>Recognition of certificates and licenses<br/>Certificates of airworthiness and certificates of competency and<br/>licenses issued or rendered valid by the contracting State in which the<br/>aircraft is registered, shall be recognized as valid by the other contracting<br/>States, provided that the requirements under which such certificates or<br/>licenses were issued or rendered valid are equal to or above the minimum<br/>standards which may be established from time to time pursuant to this<br/>Convention.<br/>Article 34<br/>Journey log books<br/>There shall be maintained in respect of every aircraft engaged in<br/>international navigation a journey log book in which shall be entered<br/>particulars of the aircraft, its crew and of each journey, in such form as may<br/>be prescribed from time to time pursuant to this Convention.<br/>Article 35<br/>Cargo restrictions<br/>(a) No munitions of war or implements of war may be<br/>carried in or above the territory of a State in aircraft engaged in<br/>international navigation, except by permission of such State. Each<br/>State shall determine by regulations what constitutes munitions of<br/>war or implements of war for the purposes of this Article, giving<br/>due consideration, for the purposes of uniformity, to such<br/>recommendations as the International Civil Aviation Organization<br/>may from time to time make.<br/>(b) Each contracting State reserves the right, for reasons<br/>of public order and safety, to regulate or prohibit the carriage in or<br/>above its territory of articles other than those enumerated in<br/>paragraph (a): provided that no distinction is made in this respect<br/>between its national aircraft engaged in international navigation and<br/>the aircraft of the other States so engaged; and provided further that<br/>no restriction shall be imposed which may interfere with the<br/>carriage and use on aircraft of apparatus necessary for the<br/>operation or navigation of the aircraft or the safety of the personnel<br/>or passengers.<br/>Article 36<br/>Photographic apparatus<br/>Each contracting State may prohibit or regulate the use of<br/>photographic apparatus in aircraft over its territory.<br/>CHAPTER VI<br/>INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS<br/>AND RECOMMENDED PRACTICES<br/>Article 37<br/>Adoption of international<br/>standards and procedures<br/>Each contracting State undertakes to collaborate in securing the<br/>highest practicable degree of uniformity in regulations, standards,<br/>procedures, and organization in relation to aircraft, personnel, airways and<br/>auxiliary services in all matters in which such uniformity will facilitate and<br/>improve air navigation.<br/>To this end the International Civil Aviation Organization shall adopt<br/>and amend from time to time, as may be necessary, international standards<br/>and recommended practices and procedures dealing with:<br/>(a) Communications systems and air navigation aids,<br/>including ground marking;<br/>(b) Characteristics of airports and landing areas;<br/>(c) Rules of the air and air traffic control practices;<br/>(d) Licensing of operating and mechanical personnel;<br/>(e) Airworthiness of aircraft;<br/>(f) Registration and identification of aircraft;<br/>(g) Collection and exchange of meteorological<br/>information;<br/>(h) Log books;<br/>(i) Aeronautical maps and charts;<br/>(j) Customs and immigration procedures;<br/>(k) Aircraft in distress and investigation of accidents;<br/>and such other matters concerned with the safety, regularity, and efficiency<br/>of air navigation as may from time to time appear appropriate.<br/>Article 38<br/>Departures from international<br/>standards and procedures<br/>Any State which finds it impracticable to comply in all respects<br/>with any such international standard or procedure, or to bring its own<br/>regulations or practices into full accord with any international standard or<br/>procedure after amendment of the latter, or which deems it necessary to<br/>adopt regulations or practices differing in any particular respect from those<br/>established by an international standard, shall give immediate notification to<br/>the International Civil Aviation Organization of the differences between its<br/>own practice and that established by the international standard. In the case<br/>of amendments to international standards, any State which does not make<br/>the appropriate amendments to its own regulations or practices shall give<br/>notice to the Council within sixty days of the adoption of the amendment to<br/>the international standard, or indicate the action which it proposes to take.<br/>In any such case, the Council shall make immediate notification to all other<br/>states of the difference which exists between one or more features of an<br/>international standard and the corresponding national practice of that State.<br/>Article 39<br/>Endorsement of certificates and licenses<br/>(a) Any aircraft or part thereof with respect to which there<br/>exists an international standard of airworthiness or performance,<br/>and which failed in any respect to satisfy that standard at the time<br/>of its certification, shall have endorsed on or attached to its<br/>airworthiness certificate a complete enumeration of the details in<br/>respect of which it so failed.<br/>(b) Any person holding a license who does not satisfy in<br/>full the conditions laid down in the international standard relating<br/>to the class of license or certificate which he holds shall have<br/>endorsed on or attached to his license a complete enumeration of<br/>the particulars in which he does not satisfy such conditions.<br/>Article 40<br/>Validity of endorsed<br/>certificates and licenses<br/>No aircraft or personnel having certificates or licenses so endorsed<br/>shall participate in international navigation, except with the permission of<br/>the State or States whose territory is entered. The registration or use of any<br/>such aircraft, or of any certificated aircraft part, in any State other than that<br/>in which it was originally certificated shall be at the discretion of the State<br/>into which the aircraft or part is imported.<br/>Article 41<br/>Recognition of existing<br/>standards of airworthiness<br/>The provisions of this Chapter shall not apply to aircraft and<br/>aircraft equipment of types of which the prototype is submitted to the<br/>appropriate national authorities for certification prior to a date three years<br/>after the date of adoption of an international standard of airworthiness for<br/>such equipment.<br/>Article 42<br/>Recognition of existing standards<br/>of competency of personnel<br/>The provisions of this Chapter shall not apply to personnel whose<br/>licences are originally issued prior to a date one year after initial adoption<br/>of an international standard of qualification for such personnel; but they<br/>shall in any case apply to all personnel whose licenses remain valid five<br/>years after the date of adoption of such standard.<br/>PART II<br/>THE INTERNATIONAL CIVIL<br/>AVIATION ORGANIZATION<br/>CHAPTER VII<br/>THE ORGANIZATION<br/>Article 43<br/>Name and composition<br/>An organization to be named the International Civil Aviation<br/>Organization is formed by the Convention. It is made up of an Assembly,<br/>a Council, and such other bodies as may be necessary.<br/>Article 44<br/>Objectives<br/>The aims and objectives of the Organization are to develop the<br/>principles and techniques of international air navigation and to foster the<br/>planning and development of international air transport so as to:<br/>(a) Insure the safe and orderly growth of international civil<br/>aviation throughout the world;<br/>(b) Encourage the arts of aircraft design and operation for<br/>peaceful purposes;<br/>(c) Encourage the development of airways, airports, and<br/>air navigation facilities for international civil aviation;<br/>(d) Meet the needs of the peoples of the world for safe,<br/>regular, efficient and economical air transport;<br/>(e) Prevent economic waste caused by unreasonable<br/>competition;<br/>(f) Insure that the rights of contracting States are fully<br/>respected and that every contracting State has a fair opportunity to<br/>operate international airlines;<br/>(g) Avoid discrimination between contracting States;<br/>(h) Promote safety of flight in international air navigation;<br/>(i) Promote generally the development of all aspects of<br/>international civil aeronautics.<br/>Article 45<br/>Permanent seat<br/>The permanent seat of the Organization shall be at such place as<br/>shall be determined at the final meeting of the Interim Assembly of the<br/>Provisional International Civil Aviation Organization set up by the Interim<br/>Agreement on International Civil Aviation signed at Chicago on December<br/>7, 1944. The seat may be temporarily transferred elsewhere by decision of<br/>the Council, and otherwise than temporarily by decision of the Assembly,<br/>such decision to be taken by the number of votes specified by the Assembly.<br/>The number of votes so specified will not be less than three-fifths of the<br/>total number of contracting States.<br/>Article 46<br/>First meeting of Assembly<br/>The first meeting of the Assembly shall be summoned by the<br/>Interim Council of the above-mentioned Provisional Organization as soon<br/>as the Convention has come into force, to meet at a time and place to be<br/>decided by the Interim Council.<br/>Article 47<br/>Legal capacity<br/>The Organization shall enjoy in the territory of each contracting<br/>State such legal capacity as may be necessary for the performance of its<br/>functions. Full juridical personality shall be granted wherever compatible<br/>with the constitution and laws of the State concerned.<br/>CHAPTER VIII<br/>THE ASSEMBLY<br/>Article 48<br/>Meetings of the Assembly and voting<br/>(a) The Assembly shall meet not less than once in three<br/>years and shall be convened by the Council at a suitable time and<br/>place. An extraordinary meeting of the Assembly may be held at<br/>any time upon the call of the Council or at the request of not less<br/>than one-fifth of the total number of contracting States addressed<br/>to the Secretary General.<br/>(b) All contracting States shall have an equal right to be<br/>represented at the meetings of the Assembly and each contracting<br/>State shall be entitled to one vote. Delegates representing contracting<br/>States may be assisted by technical advisers who may participate<br/>in the meetings but shall have no vote.<br/>(c) A majority of the contracting States is required to<br/>constitute a quorum for the meetings of the Assembly. Unless<br/>otherwise provided in this Convention, decisions of the Assembly<br/>shall be taken by a majority of the votes cast.<br/>Article 49<br/>Powers and duties of the Assembly<br/>The powers and duties of the Assembly shall be to:<br/>(a) Elect at each meeting its President and other officers;<br/>(b) Elect the contracting States to be represented on the<br/>Council, in accordance with the provisions of Chapter IX;<br/>(c) Examine and take appropriate action on the reports of<br/>the Council and decide on any matter referred to it by the Council;<br/>(d) Determine its own rules of procedure and establish<br/>such subsidiary commissions as it may consider to be necessary or<br/>desirable;<br/>(e) Vote annual budgets and determine the financial<br/>arrangements of the Organization, in accordance with the<br/>provisions of Chapter XII;<br/>(f) Review expenditures and approve the accounts of the<br/>Organization;<br/>(g) Refer, at its discretion, to the Council, to subsidiary<br/>commissions, or to any other body any matter within its sphere of<br/>action;<br/>(h) Delegate to the Council the powers and authority<br/>necessary or desirable for the discharge of the duties of the<br/>Organization and revoke or modify the delegations of authority at<br/>any time;<br/>(i) Carry out the appropriate provisions of Chapter XIII;<br/>(j) Consider proposals for the modification or amendment<br/>of the provisions of this Convention and, if it approves of the<br/>proposals, recommend them to the contracting States in accordance<br/>with the provisions of Chapter XXI;<br/>(k) Deal with any matter within the sphere of action of the<br/>Organization not specifically assigned to the Council.<br/>CHAPTER IX<br/>THE COUNCIL<br/>Article 50<br/>Composition and election of Council<br/>(a) The Council shall be a permanent body responsible to<br/>the Assembly. It shall be composed of thirty-three contracting<br/>States elected by the Assembly. An election shall be held at the first<br/>meeting of the Assembly and thereafter every three years, and the<br/>members of the Council so elected shall hold office until the next<br/>following election.<br/>(b) In electing the members of the Council, the Assembly<br/>shall give adequate representation to (1) the States of chief<br/>importance in air transport; (2) the States not otherwise included<br/>which make the largest contribution to the provision of facilities for<br/>international civil air navigation; and (3) the States not otherwise<br/>included whose designation will insure that all the major<br/>geographic areas of the world are represented on the Council. Any<br/>vacancy on the Council shall be filled by the Assembly as soon as<br/>possible; any contracting State so elected to the Council shall hold<br/>office for the unexpired portion of its predecessor’s term of office.<br/>(c) No representative of a contracting State on the Council<br/>shall be actively associated with the operation of an international air<br/>service or financially interested in such a service.<br/>Article 51<br/>President of Council<br/>The Council shall elect its President for a term of three years. He<br/>may be reelected. He shall have no vote. The Council shall elect from<br/>among its members one or more Vice Presidents who shall retain their right<br/>to vote when serving as acting President. The President need not be selected<br/>from among the representatives of the members of the Council but, if a<br/>representative is elected, his seat shall be deemed vacant and it shall be<br/>filled by the State which he represented. The duties of the President shall be<br/>to:<br/>(a) Convene meetings of the Council, the Air Transport<br/>Committee, and the Air Navigation Commission;<br/>(b) Serve as representative of the Council; and<br/>(c) Carry out on behalf of the Council the functions which<br/>the Council assigns to him.<br/>Article 52<br/>Voting in Council<br/>Decisions by the Council shall require approval by a majority of its<br/>members. The Council may delegate authority with respect to any particular<br/>matter to a committee of its members. Decisions of any committee of the<br/>Council may be appealed to the Council by any interested contracting State.<br/>Article 53<br/>Participation without a vote<br/>Any contracting State may participate, without a vote, in the<br/>consideration by the Council and by its committees and commissions of any<br/>question which especially affects its interests. No member of the Council<br/>shall vote in the consideration by the Council of a dispute to which it is a<br/>party.<br/>Article 54<br/>Mandatory functions of Council<br/>The Council shall:<br/>(a) Submit annual reports to the Assembly;<br/>(b) Carry out the directions of the Assembly and discharge<br/>the duties and obligations which are laid on it by this Convention;<br/>(c) Determine its organization and rules of procedure;<br/>(d) Appoint and define the duties of an Air Transport<br/>Committee, which shall be chosen from among the representatives<br/>of the members of the Council, and which shall be responsible to<br/>it;<br/>(e) Establish an Air Navigation Commission, in<br/>accordance with the provisions of Chapter X;<br/>(f) Administer the finances of the Organization in<br/>accordance with the provisions of Chapters XII and XV;<br/>(g) Determine the emoluments of the President of the<br/>Council;<br/>(h) Appoint a chief executive officer who shall be called<br/>the Secretary General, and make provision for the appointment of<br/>such other personnel as may be necessary, in accordance with the<br/>provisions of Chapter XI;<br/>(i) Request, collect, examine and publish information<br/>relating to the advancement of air navigation and the operation of<br/>international air services, including information about the costs of<br/>operation and particulars of subsidies paid to airlines from public<br/>funds;<br/>(j) Report to contracting States any infraction of this<br/>Convention, as well as any failure to carry out recommendations<br/>or determinations of the Council;<br/>(k) Report to the Assembly any infraction of this<br/>Convention where a contracting State has failed to take appropriate<br/>action within a reasonable time after notice of the infraction;<br/>(l) Adopt, in accordance with the provisions of Chapter VI<br/>of this Convention, international standards and recommended<br/>practices; for convenience, designate them as Annexes to this<br/>Convention; and notify all contracting States of the action taken;<br/>(m) Consider recommendations of the Air Navigation<br/>Commission for amendment of the Annexes and take action in<br/>accordance with the provisions of Chapter XX;<br/>(n) Consider any matter relating to the Convention which<br/>any contracting State refers to it.<br/>Article 55<br/>Permissive functions of Council<br/>The Council may:<br/>(a) Where appropriate and as experience may show to be<br/>desirable, create subordinate air transport commissions on a<br/>regional or other basis and define groups of states or airlines with<br/>or through which it may deal to facilitate the carrying out of the<br/>aims of this Convention;<br/>(b) Delegate to the Air Navigation Commission duties<br/>additional to those set forth in the Convention and revoke or<br/>modify such delegations of authority at any time;<br/>(c) Conduct research into all aspects of air transport and<br/>air navigation which are of international importance, communicate<br/>the results of its research to the contracting States, and facilitate the<br/>exchange of information between contracting States on air transport<br/>and air navigation matters;<br/>(d) Study any matters affecting the organization and<br/>operation of international air transport, including the international<br/>ownership and operation of international air services on trunk<br/>routes, and submit to the Assembly plans in relation thereto;<br/>(e) Investigate, at the request of any contracting State, any<br/>situation which may appear to present avoidable obstacles to the<br/>development of international air navigation; and, after such<br/>investigation, issue such reports as may appear to it desirable.<br/>CHAPTER X<br/>THE AIR NAVIGATION COMMISSION<br/>Article 56<br/>Nomination and appointment of Commission<br/>The Air Navigation Commission shall be composed of fifteen members<br/>appointed by the Council from among persons nominated by contracting<br/>States. These persons shall have suitable qualifications and experience in the<br/>science and practice of aeronautics. The Council shall request all contracting<br/>States to submit nominations. The President of the Air Navigation Commission<br/>shall be appointed by the Council.<br/>Article 57<br/>Duties of Commission<br/>The Air Navigation Commission shall:<br/>(a) Consider, and recommend to the Council for adoption,<br/>modifications of the Annexes to this Convention;<br/>(b) Establish technical subcommissions on which any<br/>contracting State may be represented, if it so desires;<br/>(c) Advise the Council concerning the collection and communication<br/>to the contracting States of all information which it<br/>considers necessary and useful for the advancement of air<br/>navigation.<br/>CHAPTER XI<br/>PERSONNEL<br/>Article 58<br/>Appointment of personnel<br/>Subject to any rules laid down by the Assembly and to the<br/>provisions of this Convention, the Council shall determine the method of<br/>appointment and of termination of appointment, the training, and the<br/>salaries, allowances, and conditions of service of the Secretary General and<br/>other personnel of the Organization, and may employ or make use of the<br/>services of nationals of any contracting State.<br/>Article 59<br/>International character of personnel<br/>The President of the Council, the Secretary General, and other<br/>personnel shall not seek or receive instructions in regard to the discharge of<br/>their responsibilities from any authority external to the Organization. Each<br/>contracting State undertakes fully to respect the international character of the<br/>responsibilities of the personnel and not to seek to influence any of its<br/>nationals in the discharge of their responsibilities.<br/>Article 60<br/>Immunities and privileges of personnel<br/>Each contracting State undertakes, so far as possible under its<br/>constitutional procedure, to accord to the President of the Council, the<br/>Secretary General, and the other personnel of the Organization, the<br/>immunities and privileges which are accorded to corresponding personnel<br/>of other public international organizations. If a general international<br/>agreement on the immunities and privileges of international civil servants is<br/>arrived at, the immunities and privileges accorded to the President, the<br/>Secretary General, and the other personnel of the Organization shall be the<br/>immunities and privileges accorded under that general international<br/>agreement.<br/>CHAPTER XII<br/>FINANCE<br/>Article 61<br/>Budget and apportionment of expenses<br/>The Council shall submit to the Assembly annual budgets, annual<br/>statements of accounts and estimates of all receipts and expenditures. The<br/>Assembly shall vote the budgets with whatever modification it sees fit to<br/>prescribe, and, with the exception of assessments under Chapter XV to<br/>States consenting thereto, shall apportion the expenses of the Organization<br/>among the contracting States on the basis which it shall from time to time<br/>determine.<br/>Article 62<br/>Suspension of voting power<br/>The Assembly may suspend the voting power in the Assembly and<br/>in the Council of any contracting State that fails to discharge within a<br/>reasonable period its financial obligations to the Organization.<br/>Article 63<br/>Expenses of delegations<br/>and other representatives<br/>Each contracting State shall bear the expenses of its own delegation<br/>to the Assembly and the remuneration, travel, and other expenses of any<br/>person whom it appoints to serve on the Council, and of its nominees or<br/>representatives on any subsidiary committees or commissions of the<br/>Organization.<br/>CHAPTER XIII<br/>OTHER INTERNATIONAL ARRANGEMENTS<br/>Article 64<br/>Security arrangements<br/>The Organization may, with respect to air matters within its<br/>competence directly affecting world security, by vote of the Assembly enter<br/>into appropriate arrangements with any general organization set up by the<br/>nations of the world to preserve peace.<br/>Article 65<br/>Arrangements with other international bodies<br/>The Council, on behalf of the Organization, may enter into<br/>agreements with other international bodies for the maintenance of common<br/>services and for common arrangements concerning personnel and, with the<br/>approval of the Assembly, may enter into such other arrangements as may<br/>facilitate the work of the Organization.<br/>Article 66<br/>Functions relating to other agreements<br/>(a) The Organization shall also carry out the functions<br/>placed upon it by the International Air Services Transit Agreement<br/>and by the International Air Transport Agreement drawn up at<br/>Chicago on December 7, 1944, in accordance with the terms and<br/>conditions therein set forth.<br/>(b) Members of the Assembly and the Council who have<br/>not accepted the International Air Services Transit Agreement or<br/>the International Air Transport Agreement drawn up at Chicago on<br/>December 7, 1944 shall not have the right to vote on any questions<br/>referred to the Assembly or Council under the provisions of the<br/>relevant Agreement.<br/>PART III<br/>INTERNATIONAL AIR TRANSPORT<br/>CHAPTER XIV<br/>INFORMATION AND REPORTS<br/>Article 67<br/>File reports with Council<br/>Each contracting State undertakes that its international airlines shall,<br/>in accordance with requirements laid down by the Council, file with the<br/>Council traffic reports, cost statistics and financial statements showing<br/>among other things all receipts and the sources thereof.<br/>CHAPTER XV<br/>AIRPORTS AND OTHER AIR<br/>NAVIGATION FACILITIES<br/>Article 68<br/>Designation of routes and airports<br/>Each contracting State may, subject to the provisions of this<br/>Convention, designate the route to be followed within its territory by any<br/>international air service and the airports which any such service may use.<br/>Article 69<br/>Improvement of air navigation facilities<br/>If the Council is of the opinion that the airports or other air<br/>navigation facilities, including radio and meteorological services, of a<br/>contracting State are not reasonably adequate for the safe, regular, efficient,<br/>and economical operation of international air services, present or<br/>contemplated, the Council shall consult with the State directly concerned,<br/>and other States affected, with a view to finding means by which the<br/>situation may be remedied, and may make recommendations for that<br/>purpose. No contracting State shall be guilty of an infraction of this<br/>Convention if it fails to carry out these recommendations.<br/>Article 70<br/>Financing of air navigation facilities<br/>A contracting State, in the circumstances arising under the<br/>provisions of Article 69, may conclude an arrangement with the Council for<br/>giving effect to such recommendations. The State may elect to bear all of<br/>the costs involved in any such arrangement. If the State does not so elect,<br/>the Council may agree, at the request of the State, to provide for all or a<br/>portion of the costs.<br/>Article 71<br/>Provision and maintenance<br/>of facilities by Council<br/>If a contracting State so requests, the Council may agree to provide,<br/>man, maintain, and administer any or all of the airports and other air<br/>navigation facilities including radio and meteorological services, required<br/>in its territory for the safe, regular, efficient and economical operation of the<br/>international air services of the other contracting States, and may specify<br/>just and reasonable charges for the use of the facilities provided.<br/>Article 72<br/>Acquisition or use of land<br/>Where land is needed for facilities financed in whole or in part by<br/>the Council at the request of a contracting State, that State shall either<br/>provide the land itself, retaining title if it wishes, or facilitate the use of the<br/>land by the Council on just and reasonable terms and in accordance with the<br/>laws of the State concerned.<br/>Article 73<br/>Expenditure and assessment of funds<br/>Within the limit of the funds which may be made available to it by<br/>the Assembly under Chapter XII, the Council may make current<br/>expenditures for the purposes of this Chapter from the general funds of the<br/>Organization. The Council shall assess the capital funds required for the<br/>purposes of this Chapter in previously agreed proportions over a reasonable<br/>period of time to the contracting States consenting thereto whose airlines use<br/>the facilities. The Council may also assess to States that consent any<br/>working funds that are required.<br/>Article 74<br/>Technical assistance and<br/>utilization of revenues<br/>When the Council, at the request of a contracting State, advances<br/>funds or provides airports or other facilities in whole or in part, the<br/>arrangement may provide, with the consent of that State, for technical<br/>assistance in the supervision and operation of the airports and other<br/>facilities, and for the payment, from the revenues derived from the<br/>operation of the airports and other facilities, of the operating expenses of the<br/>airports and the other facilities, and of interest and amortization charges.<br/>Article 75<br/>Taking over of facilities from Council<br/>A contracting State may at any time discharge any obligation into<br/>which it has entered under Article 70, and take over airports and other<br/>facilities which the Council has provided in its territory pursuant to the<br/>provisions of Articles 71 and 72, by paying to the Council an amount which<br/>in the opinion of the Council is reasonable in the circumstances. If the State<br/>considers that the amount fixed by the Council is unreasonable it may appeal<br/>to the Assembly against the decision of the Council and the Assembly may<br/>confirm or amend the decision of the Council.<br/>Article 76<br/>Return of funds<br/>Funds obtained by the Council through reimbursement under<br/>Article 75 and from receipts of interest and amortization payments under<br/>Article 74 shall, in the case of advances originally financed by States under<br/>Article 73, be returned to the States which were originally assessed in the<br/>proportion of their assessments, as determined by the Council.<br/>CHAPTER XVI<br/>JOINT OPERATING ORGANIZATIONS<br/>AND POOLED SERVICES<br/>Article 77<br/>Joint operating organizations permitted<br/>Nothing in this Convention shall prevent two or more contracting<br/>States from constituting joint air transport operating organizations or<br/>international operating agencies and from pooling their air services on any<br/>routes or in any regions, but such organizations or agencies and such pooled<br/>services shall be subject to all the provisions of this Convention, including<br/>those relating to the registration of agreements with the Council. The<br/>Council shall determine in what manner the provisions of this Convention<br/>relating to nationality of aircraft shall apply to aircraft operated by<br/>international operating agencies.<br/>Article 78<br/>Function of Council<br/>The Council may suggest to contracting States concerned that they<br/>form joint organizations to operate air services on any routes or in any<br/>regions.<br/>Article 79<br/>Participation in operating organizations<br/>A State may participate in joint operating organizations or in<br/>pooling arrangements, either through its government or through an airline<br/>company or companies designated by its government. The companies may,<br/>at the sole discretion of the State concerned, be state-owned or partly stateowned<br/>or privately owned.<br/>PART IV<br/>FINAL PROVISIONS<br/>CHAPTER XVII<br/>OTHER AERONAUTICAL AGREEMENTS<br/>AND ARRANGEMENTS<br/>Article 80<br/>Paris and Habana Conventions<br/>Each contracting State undertakes, immediately upon the coming<br/>into force of this Convention, to give notice of denunciation of the<br/>Convention relating to the Regulation of Aerial Navigation signed at Paris<br/>on October 13, 1919 or the Convention on Commercial Aviation signed at<br/>Habana on February 20, 1928, if it is a party to either. As between<br/>contracting States, this Convention supersedes the Conventions of Paris and<br/>Habana previously referred to.<br/>Article 81<br/>Registration of existing agreements<br/>All aeronautical agreements which are in existence on the coming<br/>into force of this Convention, and which are between a contracting State and<br/>any other State or between an airline of a contracting State and any other<br/>State or the airline of any other State, shall be forthwith registered with the<br/>Council.<br/>Article 82<br/>Abrogation of inconsistent arrangements<br/>The contracting States accept this Convention as abrogating all<br/>obligations and understandings between them which are inconsistent with its<br/>terms, and undertake not to enter into any such obligations and<br/>understandings. A contracting State which, before becoming a member of<br/>the Organization has undertaken any obligations toward a non-contracting<br/>State or a national of a contracting State or of a non-contracting State<br/>inconsistent with the terms of this Convention, shall take immediate steps<br/>to procure its release from the obligations. If an airline of any contracting<br/>State has entered into any such inconsistent obligations, the State of which<br/>it is a national shall use its best efforts to secure their termination forthwith<br/>and shall in any event cause them to be terminated as soon as such action<br/>can lawfully be taken after the coming into force of this Convention.<br/>Article 83<br/>Registration of new arrangements<br/>Subject to the provisions of the preceding Article, any contracting<br/>State may make arrangements not inconsistent with the provisions of this<br/>Convention. Any such arrangement shall be forthwith registered with the<br/>Council, which shall make it public as soon as possible.<br/>CHAPTER XVIII<br/>DISPUTES AND DEFAULT<br/>Article 84<br/>Settlement of disputes<br/>If any disagreement between two or more contracting States relating<br/>to the interpretation or application of this Convention and its Annexes<br/>cannot be settled by negotiation, it shall, on the application of any State<br/>concerned in the disagreement, be decided by the Council. No member of<br/>the Council shall vote in the consideration by the Council of any dispute to<br/>which it is a party. Any contracting State may, subject to Article 85, appeal<br/>from the decision of the Council to an ad hoc arbitral tribunal agreed upon<br/>with the other parties to the dispute or to the Permanent Court of<br/>International Justice. Any such appeal shall be notified to the Council within<br/>sixty days of receipt of notification of the decision of the Council.<br/>Article 85<br/>Arbitration procedure<br/>If any contracting State party to a dispute in which the decision of<br/>the Council is under appeal has not accepted the Statute of the Permanent<br/>Court of International Justice and the contracting States parties to the dispute<br/>cannot agree on the choice of the arbitral tribunal, each of the contracting<br/>States parties to the dispute shall name a single arbitrator who shall name an<br/>umpire. If either contracting State party to the dispute fails to name an<br/>arbitrator within a period of three months from the date of the appeal, an<br/>arbitrator shall be named on behalf of that State by the President of the<br/>Council from a list of qualified and available persons maintained by the<br/>Council. If, within thirty days, the arbitrators cannot agree on an umpire,<br/>the President of the Council shall designate an umpire from the list<br/>previously referred to. The arbitrators and the umpire shall then jointly<br/>constitute an arbitral tribunal. Any arbitral tribunal established under this or<br/>the preceding Article shall settle its own procedure and give its decisions by<br/>majority vote, provided that the Council may determine procedural<br/>questions in the event of any delay which in the opinion of the Council is<br/>excessive.<br/>Article 86<br/>Appeals<br/>Unless the Council decides otherwise any decision by the Council<br/>on whether an international airline is operating in conformity with the<br/>provisions of this Convention shall remain in effect unless reversed on<br/>appeal. On any other matter, decisions of the Council shall, if appealed<br/>from, be suspended until the appeal is decided. The decisions of the<br/>Permanent Court of International Justice and of an arbitral tribunal shall be<br/>final and binding.<br/>Article 87<br/>Penalty for non-conformity of airline<br/>Each contracting State undertakes not to allow the operation of an<br/>airline of a contracting State through the airspace above its territory if the<br/>Council has decided that the airline concerned is not conforming to a final<br/>decision rendered in accordance with the previous Article.<br/>Article 88<br/>Penalty for non-conformity by State<br/>The Assembly shall suspend the voting power in the Assembly and<br/>in the Council of any contracting State that is found in default under the<br/>provisions of this Chapter.<br/>CHAPTER XIX<br/>WAR<br/>Article 89<br/>War and emergency conditions<br/>In case of war, the provisions of this Convention shall not affect the<br/>freedom of action of any of the contracting States affected, whether as<br/>belligerents or as neutrals. The same principle shall apply in the case of any<br/>contracting State which declares a state of national emergency and notifies<br/>the fact to the Council.<br/>CHAPTER XX<br/>ANNEXES<br/>Article 90<br/>Adoption and amendment of Annexes<br/>(a) The adoption by the Council of the Annexes described<br/>in Article 54, subparagraph (l), shall require the vote of two-thirds<br/>of the Council at a meeting called for that purpose and shall then<br/>be submitted by the Council to each contracting State. Any such<br/>Annex or any amendment of an Annex shall become effective<br/>within three months after its submission to the contracting States or<br/>at the end of such longer period of time as the Council may<br/>prescribe, unless in the meantime a majority of the contracting<br/>States register their disapproval with the Council.<br/>(b) The Council shall immediately notify all contracting<br/>States of the coming into force of any Annex or amendment<br/>thereto.<br/>CHAPTER XXI<br/>RATIFICATIONS, ADHERENCES,<br/>AMENDMENTS, AND DENUNCIATIONS<br/>Article 91<br/>Ratification of Convention<br/>(a) This Convention shall be subject to ratification by the<br/>signatory States. The instruments of ratification shall be deposited<br/>in the archives of the Government of the United States of America,<br/>which shall give notice of the date of the deposit to each of the<br/>signatory and adhering States.<br/>(b) As soon as this Convention has been ratified or<br/>adhered to by twenty-six States it shall come into force between<br/>them on the thirtieth day after deposit of the twenty-sixth<br/>instrument. It shall come into force for each State ratifying<br/>thereafter on the thirtieth day after the deposit of its instrument of<br/>ratification.<br/>(c) It shall be the duty of the Government of the United<br/>States of America to notify the government of each of the signatory<br/>and adhering States of the date on which this Convention comes<br/>into force.<br/>Article 92<br/>Adherence to Convention<br/>(a) This Convention shall be open for adherence by<br/>members of the United Nations and States associated with them,<br/>and States which remained neutral during the present world<br/>conflict.<br/>(b) Adherence shall be effected by a notification addressed<br/>to the Government of the United States of America and shall take<br/>effect as from the thirtieth day from the receipt of the notification<br/>by the Government of the United States of America, which shall<br/>notify all the contracting States.<br/>Article 93<br/>Admission of other States<br/>States other than those provided for in Articles 91 and 92 (a) may,<br/>subject to approval by any general international organization set up by the<br/>nations of the world to preserve peace, be admitted to participation in this<br/>Convention by means of a four-fifths vote of the Assembly and on such<br/>conditions as the Assembly may prescribe: provided that in each case the<br/>assent of any State invaded or attacked during the present war by the State<br/>seeking admission shall be necessary.<br/>Article 93 bis<br/>(a) Notwithstanding the provisions of Articles 91, 92 and<br/>93 above:<br/>(1) A State whose government the General<br/>Assembly of the United Nations has recommended be<br/>debarred from membership in international agencies<br/>established by or brought into relationship with the United<br/>Nations shall automatically cease to be a member of the<br/>International Civil Aviation Organization;<br/>(2) A State which has been expelled from<br/>membership in the United Nations shall automatically<br/>cease to be a member of the International Civil Aviation<br/>Organization unless the General Assembly of the United<br/>Nations attaches to its act of expulsion a recommendation<br/>to the contrary.<br/>(b) A State which ceases to be a member of the<br/>International Civil Aviation Organization as a result of the<br/>provisions of paragraph (a) above may, after approval by the<br/>General Assembly of the United Nations, be readmitted to the<br/>International Civil Aviation Organization upon application and<br/>upon approval by a majority of the Council.<br/>(c) Members of the Organization which are suspended<br/>from the exercise of the rights and privileges of membership in the<br/>United Nations shall, upon the request of the latter, be suspended<br/>from the rights and privileges of membership in this Organization.<br/>Article 94<br/>Amendment of Convention<br/>(a) Any proposed amendment to this Convention must be<br/>approved by a two-thirds vote of the Assembly and shall then come<br/>into force in respect of States which have ratified such amendment<br/>when ratified by the number of contracting States specified by the<br/>Assembly. The number so specified shall not be less than twothirds<br/>of the total number of contracting States.<br/>(b) If in its opinion the amendment is of such a nature as<br/>to justify this course, the Assembly in its resolution recommending<br/>adoption may provide that any State which has not ratified within<br/>a specified period after the amendment has come into force shall<br/>thereupon cease to be a member of the Organization and a party to<br/>the Convention.<br/>Article 95<br/>Denunciation of Convention<br/>(a) Any contracting State may give notice of denunciation<br/>of this Convention three years after its coming into effect by<br/>notification addressed to the Government of the United States of<br/>America, which shall at once inform each of the contracting States.<br/>(b) Denunciation shall take effect one year from the date<br/>of the receipt of the notification and shall operate only as regards<br/>the State effecting the denunciation.<br/>CHAPTER XXII<br/>DEFINITIONS<br/>Article 96<br/>For the purpose of this Convention the expression:<br/>(a) “Air service” means any scheduled air service<br/>performed by aircraft for the public transport of passengers, mail<br/>or cargo.<br/>(b) “International air service” means an air service which<br/>passes through the air space over the territory of more than one<br/>State.<br/>(c) “Airline” means any air transport enterprise offering or<br/>operating an international air service.<br/>(d) “Stop for non-traffic purposes” means a landing for<br/>any purpose other than taking on or discharging passengers, cargo<br/>or mail.<br/>SIGNATURE OF CONVENTION<br/>IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the undersigned plenipotentiaries, having<br/>been duly authorized, sign this Convention on behalf of their respective<br/>governments on the dates appearing opposite their signatures.<br/>DONE at Chicago the seventh day of December 1944, in the<br/>English language. A text drawn up in the English, French and Spanish<br/>languages, each of which shall be of equal authenticity, shall be open for<br/>signature at Washington, D.C. Both texts shall be deposited in the archives<br/>of the Government of the United States of America, and certified copies<br/>shall be transmitted by that Government to the governments of all the States<br/>which may sign or adhere to this Convention.</p></div></div>
10	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/human-rights-conventions/convention-for-the-protection-of-human-rights-and-fundamental-freedoms/attachment/eng_conv-2/" rel="attachment wp-att-6064">Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms </a></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">as amended by Protocols Nos. 11 and 14</p><p style="text-align: justify;">with Protocols Nos. 1, 4, 6, 7, 12 and 13</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The text of the Convention is presented as amended by the provisions of Protocol No. 14 (CETS no. 194) as from its entry into force on 1 June 2010.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The text of the Convention had previously been amended according to the provisions of Protocol No. 3 (ETS no. 45), which entered into force on 21 September 1970, of Protocol No. 5 (ETS no. 55), which entered into force on 20 December 1971, and of Protocol No. 8 (ETS no. 118), which entered into force on 1 January 1990, and comprised also the text of Protocol No. 2 (ETS no. 44) which, in accordance with Article 5 § 3 thereof, had been an integral part of the Convention since its entry into force on 21 September 1970. All provisions which had been amended or added by these Protocols were replaced by Protocol No. 11 (ETS no. 155), as from the date of its entry into force on 1 November 1998. As from that date, Protocol No. 9 (ETS no. 140), which entered into force on 1 October 1994, was repealed and Protocol No. 10 (ETS no. 146) lost its purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The current state of signatures and ratifications of the Convention and its Protocols as well as the complete list of declarations and reservations are available at <span style="text-decoration: underline;">http://conventions.coe.int</span>.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Registry of the European Court of Human Rights</p><p style="text-align: justify;">June 2010</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">European Convention on Human Rights</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Rome, 4.XI.1950</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The governments signatory hereto, being members of the Council of Europe,</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Considering the Universal Declaration of Human Rights proclaimed by the General Assembly of the United Nations on 10 December 1948;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Considering that this Declaration aims at securing the universal and effective recognition and observance of the Rights therein declared;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Considering that the aim of the Council of Europe is the achievement of greater unity between its members and that one of the methods by which that aim is to be pursued is the maintenance and further realisation of human rights and fundamental freedoms;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Reaffirming their profound belief in those fundamental freedoms which are the foundation of justice and peace in the world and are best maintained on the one hand by an effective political</p><p style="text-align: justify;">democracy and on the other by a common understanding and observance of the human rights upon which they depend;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Being resolved, as the governments of European countries which are likeminded and have a common heritage of political traditions, ideals, freedom and the rule of law, to take the first steps for the collective enforcement of certain of the rights stated in the Universal Declar-ation,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Have agreed as follows:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Obligation to respect human rights</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The High Contracting Parties shall secure to everyone within their jurisdiction the rights and freedoms defined in Section I of this Convention.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Section I</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Rights and freedoms</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 2</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Right to life</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Everyone’s right to life shall be protected by law. No one shall be deprived of his life intentionally save in the execution of a sentence of a court following his conviction of a crime for which this penalty is provided by law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Deprivation of life shall not be regarded as inflicted in contravention of this Article when it results from the use of force which is no more than abso-lutely necessary:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) in defence of any person from unlawful violence;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) in order to effect a lawful arrest or to prevent the escape of a person lawfully detained;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) in action lawfully taken for the purpose of quelling a riot or insurrection.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 3</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prohibition of torture</p><p style="text-align: justify;">No one shall be subjected to torture or to inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 4</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prohibition of slavery and forced labour</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. No one shall be held in slavery or servitude.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. No one shall be required to perform forced or compulsory labour.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. For the purpose of this Article the</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 European Convention on Human Rights</p><p style="text-align: justify;">term “forced or compulsory labour” shall not include:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) any work required to be done in the ordinary course of detention imposed according to the provisions of Article 5 of this Convention or during conditional release from such detention;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) any service of a military character or, in case of conscientious objectors in countries where they are recognised, service exacted instead of compulsory military service;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) any service exacted in case of an emergency or calamity threatening the life or well-being of the community;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) any work or service which forms part of normal civic obligations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 5</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Right to liberty and security</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Everyone has the right to liberty and security of person. No one shall be deprived of his liberty save in the following cases and in accordance with a procedure prescribed by law:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the lawful detention of a person after conviction by a competent court;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the lawful arrest or detention of a person for non-compliance with the lawful order of a court or in order to secure the fulfilment of any obligation prescribed by law;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) the lawful arrest or detention of a person effected for the purpose of bringing him before the competent legal authority on reasonable suspicion of having committed an offence or when it is reasonably considered necessary to prevent his committing an offence or fleeing after having done so;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) the detention of a minor by lawful order for the purpose of educational supervision or his lawful detention for the purpose of bringing him before the competent legal authority;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) the lawful detention of persons for the prevention of the spreading of infectious diseases, of persons of un-sound mind, alcoholics or drug addicts or vagrants;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) the lawful arrest or detention of a person to prevent his effecting an unauthorised entry into the country or of a person against whom action is being taken with a view to deportation or extradition.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Everyone who is arrested shall be informed promptly, in a language which he understands, of the reasons for his arrest and of any charge against him.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Everyone arrested or detained in accordance with the provisions of paragraph 1 (c) of this Article shall be brought promptly before a judge or other officer authorised by law to exercise judicial power and shall be entitled to trial within a reasonable time or to release pending trial. Release may be conditioned by guarantees to appear for trial.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. Everyone who is deprived of his liberty by arrest or detention shall be entitled to take proceedings by which the lawfulness of his detention shall be decided speedily by a court and his release ordered if the detention is not lawful.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. Everyone who has been the victim of arrest or detention in contravention of the provisions of this Article shall have an enforceable right to compensation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 6</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Right to a fair trial</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. In the determination of his civil rights and obligations or of any criminal charge against him, everyone is entitled to a fair and public hearing within a reasonable time by an independent and impartial tribunal established by law. Judgment shall be pronounced publicly but the press and public may be excluded from all or part of the trial in the interests of morals, public order or national security in a democratic society, where the interests of juveniles or the protection of the private life of the parties so require, or to the extent strictly necessary in the opinion of the court in special circumstances where publicity would prejudice the interests of justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Everyone charged with a criminal offence shall be presumed innocent until proved guilty according to law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Everyone charged with a criminal offence has the following minimum rights:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) to be informed promptly, in a language which he understands and in</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 European Convention on Human Rights</p><p style="text-align: justify;">detail, of the nature and cause of the accusation against him;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) to have adequate time and facilities for the preparation of his defence;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) to defend himself in person or through legal assistance of his own choosing or, if he has not sufficient means to pay for legal assistance, to be given it free when the interests of justice so require;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) to examine or have examined witnesses against him and to obtain the attendance and examination of wit-nesses on his behalf under the same conditions as witnesses against him;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) to have the free assistance of an interpreter if he cannot understand or speak the language used in court.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 7</p><p style="text-align: justify;">No punishment without law</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. No one shall be held guilty of any criminal offence on account of any act or omission which did not constitute a criminal offence under national or international law at the time when it was committed. Nor shall a heavier penalty be imposed than the one that was applicable at the time the criminal offence was committed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. This Article shall not prejudice the trial and punishment of any person for any act or omission which, at the time when it was committed, was criminal according to the general principles of law recognised by civilised nations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 8</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Right to respect for private and family life</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Everyone has the right to respect for his private and family life, his home and his correspondence.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. There shall be no interference by a public authority with the exercise of this right except such as is in accordance with the law and is necessary in a democratic society in the interests of national security, public safety or the economic well-being of the country, for the prevention of disorder or crime, for the protection of health or morals, or for the protection of the rights and freedoms of others.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 9</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Freedom of thought, conscience and religion</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Everyone has the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion; this right includes freedom to change his religion or belief and freedom, either alone or in community with others and in public or private, to manifest his religion or belief, in worship, teaching, practice and observance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Freedom to manifest one’s religion or beliefs shall be subject only to such limitations as are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society in the interests of public safety, for the protection of public order, health or morals, or for the protection of the rights and freedoms of others.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 10</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Freedom of expression</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Everyone has the right to freedom of expression. This right shall include freedom to hold opinions and to receive and impart information and ideas without interference by public authority and regardless of frontiers. This Article shall not prevent States from requiring the licensing of broadcasting, television or cinema enterprises.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The exercise of these freedoms, since it carries with it duties and responsibilities, may be subject to such formalities, conditions, restrictions or penalties as are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society, in the interests of national security, territorial integrity or public safety, for the prevention of disorder or crime, for the protection of health or morals, for the protection of the reputation or rights of others, for preventing the disclosure of information received in confidence, or for maintaining the authority and im-partiality of the judiciary.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 11</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Freedom of assembly and association</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Everyone has the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and to freedom of association with others, including the</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6 European Convention on Human Rights</p><p style="text-align: justify;">right to form and to join trade unions for the protection of his interests.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. No restrictions shall be placed on the exercise of these rights other than such as are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society in the interests of national security or public safety, for the prevention of disorder or crime, for the protection of health or morals or for the protection of the rights and freedoms of others. This Article shall not prevent the imposition of lawful restrictions on the exercise of these rights by members of the armed forces, of the police or of the administration of the State.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 12</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Right to marry</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Men and women of marriageable age have the right to marry and to found a family, according to the national laws governing the exercise of this right.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 13</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Right to an effective remedy</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Everyone whose rights and freedoms as set forth in this Convention are violated shall have an effective remedy before a national authority notwithstanding that the violation has been committed by persons acting in an official capacity.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 14</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prohibition of discrimination</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The enjoyment of the rights and freedoms set forth in this Convention shall be secured without discrimination on any ground such as sex, race, colour, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, association with a national minority, property, birth or other status.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 15</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Derogation in time of emergency</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. In time of war or other public emergency threatening the life of the nation any High Contracting Party may take measures derogating from its</p><p style="text-align: justify;">obligations under this Convention to the extent strictly required by the exigencies of the situation, provided that such measures are not inconsistent with its other obligations under international law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. No derogation from Article 2, except in respect of deaths resulting from lawful acts of war, or from Articles 3, 4 § 1 and 7 shall be made under this provision.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Any High Contracting Party availing itself of this right of derogation shall keep the Secretary General of the Council of Europe fully informed of the measures which it has taken and the reasons therefor. It shall also inform the Secretary General of the Council of Europe when such measures have ceased to operate and the provisions of the Convention are again being fully executed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 16</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Restrictions on political activity of aliens</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Nothing in Articles 10, 11 and 14 shall be regarded as preventing the High Contracting Parties from imposing restrictions on the political activity of aliens.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 17</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prohibition of abuse of rights</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Nothing in this Convention may be interpreted as implying for any State, group or person any right to engage in any activity or perform any act aimed at the destruction of any of the rights and freedoms set forth herein or at their limitation to a greater extent than is provided for in the Convention.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 18</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Limitation on use of restrictions on rights</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The restrictions permitted under this Convention to the said rights and freedoms shall not be applied for any purpose other than those for which they have been prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7 European Convention on Human Rights</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Section II</p><p style="text-align: justify;">European Court of Human Rights</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 19</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Establishment of the Court</p><p style="text-align: justify;">To ensure the observance of the engagements undertaken by the High Contracting Parties in the Convention and the Protocols thereto, there shall be set up a European Court of Human Rights, hereinafter referred to as “the Court”. It shall function on a permanent basis.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 20</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Number of judges</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The Court shall consist of a number of judges equal to that of the High Contracting Parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 21</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Criteria for office</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. The judges shall be of high moral character and must either possess the qualifications required for appointment to high judicial office or be jurisconsults of recognised competence.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The judges shall sit on the Court in their individual capacity.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. During their term of office the judges shall not engage in any activity which is incompatible with their independence, impartiality or with the demands of a full-time office; all questions arising from the application of this paragraph shall be decided by the Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 22</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Election of judges</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The judges shall be elected by the Parliamentary Assembly with respect to each High Contracting Party by a majority of votes cast from a list of three candidates nominated by the High Contracting Party.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 23</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Terms of office and dismissal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. The judges shall be elected for a period of nine years. They may not be re-elected.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The terms of office of judges shall expire when they reach the age of 70.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. The judges shall hold office until replaced. They shall, however, continue to deal with such cases as they already have under consideration.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. No judge may be dismissed from office unless the other judges decide by a majority of two-thirds that that judge has ceased to fulfil the required conditions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 24</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Registry and rapporteurs</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. The Court shall have a Registry, the functions and organisation of which shall be laid down in the rules of the Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. When sitting in a single-judge formation, the Court shall be assisted by rapporteurs who shall function under the authority of the President of the Court. They shall form part of the Court’s Registry.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 25</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Plenary Court</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The plenary Court shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) elect its President and one or two Vice-Presidents for a period of three years; they may be re-elected;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) set up Chambers, constituted for a fixed period of time;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) elect the Presidents of the Chambers of the Court; they may be re-elected;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) adopt the rules of the Court;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) elect the Registrar and one or more Deputy Registrars;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) make any request under Article 26 § 2.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 26</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Single-judge formation, Committees, Chambers and Grand Chamber</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. To consider cases brought before it, the Court shall sit in a single-judge formation, in Committees of three judges, in Chambers of seven judges</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8 European Convention on Human Rights</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and in a Grand Chamber of seventeen judges. The Court’s Chambers shall set up Committees for a fixed period of time.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. At the request of the plenary Court, the Committee of Ministers may, by a unanimous decision and for a fixed period, reduce to five the number of judges of the Chambers.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. When sitting as a single judge, a judge shall not examine any application against the High Contracting Party in respect of which that judge has been elected.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. There shall sit as an ex officio member of the Chamber and the Grand Chamber the judge elected in respect of the High Contracting Party concerned. If there is none or if that judge is unable to sit, a person chosen by the President of the Court from a list submitted in advance by that Party shall sit in the capacity of judge.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. The Grand Chamber shall also include the President of the Court, the Vice-Presidents, the Presidents of the Chambers and other judges chosen in accordance with the rules of the Court. When a case is referred to the Grand Chamber under Article 43, no judge from the Chamber which rendered the judgment shall sit in the Grand Chamber, with the exception of the President of the Chamber and the judge who sat in respect of the High Contracting Party concerned.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 27</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Competence of single judges</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. A single judge may declare inadmissible or strike out of the Court’s list of cases an application submitted under Article 34, where such a decision can be taken without further examin-ation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The decision shall be final.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. If the single judge does not declare an application inadmissible or strike it out, that judge shall forward it to a Committee or to a Chamber for further examination.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 28</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Competence of Committees</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. In respect of an application sub-mitted under Article 34, a Committee may, by a unanimous vote,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) declare it inadmissible or strike it out of its list of cases, where such decision can be taken without further examination; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) declare it admissible and render at the same time a judgment on the merits, if the underlying question in the case, concerning the interpretation or the application of the Convention or the Protocols thereto, is already the subject of well-established case-law of the Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Decisions and judgments under paragraph 1 shall be final.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3.
