23	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Convention on the taking of evidence abroad in civil or  commercial matters. Opened for signature at The  Hague on 18 March 1970 &amp; Convention sur l’obtention des preuves à l’étranger en  matière dvfle ou commerciale. Ouverte à la signature à  La Haye le</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/international-crimes-conventions/convention-on-the-taking-of-evidence-abroad-in-civil-or-commercial-matters-opened-for-signature-at-the-hague-on-18-march-1970-convention-sur-lobtention-des-preuves-a-letranger-en-matiere-dv/attachment/00047259/" rel="attachment wp-att-6234">Convention on the taking of evidence abroad in civil or commercial matters. Opened for signature at The Hague on 18 March 1970</a></p><p><strong></strong></p><p><em>Authentic texts: French and English.</em></p><p><em>Registered by the </em><em>Netherlands</em><em> on </em><em>8 November 1972</em><em>.</em></p><p><strong><br/></strong></p><p><em>Textes authentiques : français et anglais.</em></p><p><em>Enregistrée par les Pays-Bas le 8 novembre 1972.</em></p><p><strong>1972 </strong>United Nation» Trealy S rie» * Natknu <strong>Unto </strong>Hecocfl d*s <strong>Traités </strong>241</p><p>CONVENTION1 ON THE TAKING OF EVIDENCE ABROAD IN</p><p>CIVIL OR COMMERCIAL MATTERS</p><p>The States signatory to the present Convention,</p><p>Desiring to facilitate the transmission and execution of Letters of Request</p><p>and to ftirther the accommodation of the different methods which they use for this</p><p>purpose,</p><p>Desiring to improve mutual judicial co-operation in civil or commercial</p><p>matters,</p><p>Have resolved to conclude a convention to this effect and have agreed upon</p><p>the following provisions</p><p>CHAPTER I. LETTERS OF REQUEST</p><p><em>Article 1. </em>In civil or commercial matters a judicial authority of a Contracting</p><p>State may, in accordance with the provisions of the law of that State, request the</p><p>competent authority of another Contracting State, by means of a Letter of Re</p><p>quest, to obtain evidence, or to perform some other judicial act.</p><p>A Letter shall not be used to obtain evidence which is not intended for use in</p><p>judicial proceedings, commenced or contemplated.</p><p>The expression ‘other judicial act’ does not cover the service of judicial</p><p>documents or the issuance of any process by which judgments or orders are</p><p>executed or enforced, or orders for provisional or protective measures.</p><p><em>Article 2. </em>A Contracting State shall designate a Central Authority which will</p><p>undertake to receive Letters of Request coming from a judicial authority of</p><p>another Contracting State and to transmit them to the authority competent to</p><p>execute them. Each State shall organize the Central Authority in accordance with</p><p>its own law.</p><p>Letters shall be sent to the Central Authority of the State of execution with</p><p>out being transmitted through any other authority of that State.</p><p><em>Article 3. </em>A Letter of Request shall specify:</p><p>(a) the authority requesting its execution and the authority requested to execute</p><p>it, if known to the requesting authority;</p><p><em>(b) </em>the names and addresses of the parties to the proceedings and their represen</p><p>tatives, if any;</p><p>(c) the nature of the proceedings for which the evidence is required, giving all</p><p>necessary information ht regard thereto;</p><p><strong>1 Came </strong>into force on 7 October 1972 <strong>in respect </strong>of the <strong>following three States, i.e. </strong>on the sixtieth day after</p><p>the deposit of the third instrument of ratification with <strong>the Government of the </strong>Netherlands, in accordance with</p><p>article 38 (1):</p><p><strong><em>Soar Due </em></strong><em>efdtposk</em></p><p>Denmark*………………………………………………… 20June 1972</p><p>Norway” ………………………………………………. 3 August 1972</p><p><strong>United States of America</strong><strong>………………………………….. </strong><em>8 </em>August 1972</p><p>* See p. 252 of Eh ) volume for the <strong>texts </strong>of Ehe reKrvations and declarations made upon ratification,</p><p>12 MO</p><p><strong>242 United Nations — Treaty Series • Nations Unies — Recueil des Traités 1972</strong></p><p><em>(d) </em>the evidence to be obtained or other judicial act to be performed.</p><p>Where appropriate, the Letter shall specify, <em>inter alia—</em></p><p><em>(e) </em>the names and addresses of the persons to be examined;</p><p>(/) the questions to be put to the persons to be examined or a statement of the</p><p>subject-matter about which they are to be examined;</p><p>(g) the documents or other property, real or personal, to be inspected;</p><p>(A) any requirement that the evidence is to be given on oath or affirmation, and</p><p>any special form to be used;</p><p>(0 any special method or procedure to be followed under article 9.</p><p>A Letter may also mention any information necessary for the application of</p><p>article 11.</p><p>No legalization or other like formality may be required.</p><p><em>Article 4. </em>A Letter of Request shall be in the language of the authority</p><p>requested to execute it or be accompanied by a translation into that language.</p><p>Nevertheless, a Contracting State shall accept a Letter in either English or</p><p>French, or a translation into one of these languages, unless it has made the</p><p>reservation authorized by article 33.</p><p>A Contracting State which has more than one official language and cannot,</p><p>for reasons of internal law, accept Letters in one of these languages for the whole</p><p>of its territory, shall, by declaration, specify the language in which the Letter or</p><p>translation thereof shall be expressed for execution in the specified parts of its</p><p>territory. In case of failure to comply with this declaration, without justifiable</p><p>excuse, the costs of translation into the required language shall be borne by the</p><p>State of origin.</p><p>A Contracting State may, by declaration, specify the language or languages</p><p>other than those referred to in the preceding paragraphs, in which a Letter may be</p><p>sent to its Central Authority.</p><p>Any translation accompanying a Letter shall be certified as correct, either by</p><p>a diplomatic officer or consular agent or by a sworn translator or by any other</p><p>person so authorized in either State.</p><p><em>Article 5. </em>If the Central Authority considers that the request does not com</p><p>ply with the provisions of the present Convention, it shall promptly inform the</p><p>authority of the State of origin which transmitted the Letter of Request, specifying</p><p>the objections to the Letter.</p><p><em>Article 6, </em>If the authority to whom a Letter of Request has been transmitted</p><p>is not competent to execute it, the Letter shall be sent forthwith to the authority in</p><p>the same State which is competent to execute it in accordance with the provisions</p><p>of its own law.</p><p><em>Article 7, </em>The requesting authority shall, if it so desires, be informed of the</p><p>time when, and the place where, the proceedings will take place, in order that the</p><p>parties concerned, and their representatives, if any, may be present. This infor</p><p>mation shall be sent directly to the parties or their representatives when the</p><p>authority of the State of origin so requests.</p><p>12140</p><p>1372 United Nations Treaty Series . Nations Unies <strong>Bccuefl </strong>des Trait s 243</p><p><em>Article 8. </em>A Contracting State may declare that members of the judicial</p><p>personnel of the requesting authority of another Contracting State may be present</p><p>at the execution of a Letter of Request. Prior authorization by the competent</p><p>authority designated by the declaring State may be required.</p><p><em>Article 9. </em>The judicial authority which executes a Letter of Request shall</p><p>apply its own law as to the methods and procedures to be followed.</p><p>However, it will follow a request of the requesting authority that a special</p><p>method or procedure be followed, unless this is incompatible with the internal law</p><p>of the State of execution or is impossible of performance by reason of its internal</p><p>practice and procedure or by reason of practical difficulties.</p><p>A Letter of Request shall be executed expeditiously.</p><p><em>Article 10. </em>In executing a Letter of Request the requested authority shall</p><p>apply the appropriate measures of compulsion in the instances and to the same</p><p>extent as are provided by its internal law for the execution of orders issued by</p><p>the authorities of its own country or of requests made by parties in internal pro</p><p>ceedings.</p><p><em>Article 11. </em>In the execution of a Letter of Request the person concerned</p><p>may remse to give evidence in so far as he has a privilege or duty to refuse to give</p><p>the evidence</p><p>(a) under the law of the State of execution; or</p><p>(£) under the law of the State of origin, and the privilege or duty has been</p><p>specified in the Letter, or, at the instance of the requested authority, has been</p><p>otherwise confirmed to that authority by the requesting authority.</p><p>A Contracting State may declare that, in addition, it will respect privileges</p><p>and duties existing under the law of States other than the State of origin and the</p><p>State of execution, to the extent specified in that declaration.</p><p><em>Article 12. </em>The execution of a Letter of Request may be refused only to the</p><p>extent that</p><p><em>(a) </em>in the State of execution the execution of the Letter does not fell within the</p><p>functions of the judiciary; or</p><p>( ) the State addressed considers that its sovereignty or security would be pre</p><p>judiced thereby.</p><p>Execution may not be refused solely on the ground that under its internal law</p><p>the State of execution claims exclusive jurisdiction over the subject-matter of the</p><p>action or that its internal law would not admit a right of action on it.</p><p><em>Article 13. </em>The documents establishing the execution of the Letter of Re</p><p>quest shall be sent by the requested authority to the requesting authority by the</p><p>same channel which was used by the latter.</p><p>In every instance where the Letter is not executed in whole or in part, the</p><p>requesting authority shall be informed immediately through the same channel and</p><p>advised of the reasons.</p><p><em>Article 14. </em>The execution of the Letter of Request shall not give rise to any</p><p>reimbursement of taxes or costs of any nature.</p><p>12140</p><p>244 United Nations Treaty Series Nations Unies <strong>Recaefl </strong>des Trait s 1972</p><p>Nevertheless, the State of execution has the right to require the State of</p><p>origin to reimburse the fees paid to experts and interpreters and the costs oc</p><p>casioned by the use of a special procedure requested by the State of origin under</p><p>article 9, paragraph 2.</p><p>The requested authority whose law obliges the parties themselves to secure</p><p>evidence, and which is not able itself to execute the Letter, may, after having</p><p>obtained the consent of the requesting authority, appoint a suitable person to do</p><p>so. When seeking this consent the requested authority shall indicate the approxi</p><p>mate costs which would result from this procedure. If the requesting authority</p><p>gives its consent it shall reimburse any costs incurred; without such consent the</p><p>requesting authority shall not be liable for the costs,</p><p>CHAPTER . TAKING OF EVIDENCE BY DIPLOMATIC OFFICERS, CONSULAR</p><p>AGENTS AND COMMISSIONERS</p><p><em>Article 15. </em>In a civil or commercial matter, a diplomatic officer or consular</p><p>agent of a Contracting State may, in the territory of another Contracting State and</p><p>within the area where he exercises his functions, take the evidence without com</p><p>pulsion of nationals of a State which he represents in aid of proceedings com</p><p>menced in the courts of a State which he represents.</p><p>A Contracting State may declare that evidence may be taken by a diplomatic</p><p>officer or consular agent only if permission to that effect is given upon application</p><p>made by him or on his behalf to the appropriate authority designated by the</p><p>declaring State.</p><p><em>Article 16. </em>A diplomatic officer or consular agent of a Contracting State</p><p>may, in the territory of another Contracting State and within the area where he</p><p>exercises his functions, also take the evidence, without compulsion, of nationals</p><p>of the State in which he exercises his functions or of a third State, in aid of</p><p>proceedings commenced in the courts of a State which he represents, if</p><p><em>(a) </em>a competent authority designated by the State in which he exercises his func</p><p>tions has given its permission either generally or in the particular case, and</p><p><em>(b) </em>he complies with the conditions which the competent authority has specified</p><p>in the permission.</p><p>A Contracting State may declare that evidence may be taken under this</p><p>article without its prior permission.</p><p><em>Article 17. </em>In a civil or commercial matter, a person duly appointed as a</p><p>commissioner for the purpose may, without compulsion, take evidence in the</p><p>territory of a Contracting State in aid of proceedings commenced in the courts of</p><p>another Contracting State if</p><p><em>(a) </em>a competent authority designated by the State where the evidence is to be</p><p>taken has given its permission either generally or in the particular case; and</p><p><em>(b) </em>he complies with the conditions which the competent authority has specified</p><p>in the permission.</p><p>A Contracting State may declare that evidence may be taken under this</p><p>article without its prior permission.</p><p>12140</p><p><strong>1972 United Nations — Treaty Serfe* * Nations Unies — Recueil des Traités 245</strong></p><p><em>Article 18. </em>A Contracting State may declare that a diplomatic officer, consu</p><p>lar agent or commissioner authorized to take evidence under articles IS, 16 or 17,</p><p>may apply to the competent authority designated by the declaring State for ap</p><p>propriate assistance to obtain the evidence by compulsion. The declaration may</p><p>contain such conditions as the declaring State may see fit to impose.</p><p>If the authority grants the application it shall apply any measures of compul</p><p>sion which are appropriate and are prescribed by its law for use in internal pro</p><p>ceedings.</p><p><em>Article 19. </em>The competent authority, in giving the permission referred to in</p><p>article 15,16 or 17, or in granting the application referred to in article 18, may lay</p><p>down such conditions as it deems fit, <em>inter alia, </em>as to the time and place of the</p><p>taking of the evidence. Similarly it may require that it be given reasonable ad</p><p>vance notice of the time, date and place of the taking of the evidence; in such a</p><p>case a representative of the authority shall be entitled to be present at the taking of</p><p>the evidence.</p><p><em>Article 20. </em>In the taking of evidence under any article of this chapter per</p><p>sons concerned may be legally represented.</p><p><em>Article 2Î. </em>Where a diplomatic officer, consular agent or commissioner is</p><p>authorized under articles 15, 16 or 17 to take evidence</p><p><em>(a) </em>he may take all kinds of evidence which are not incompatible with the law of</p><p>the State where the evidence is taken or contrary to any permission granted</p><p>pursuant to the above articles, and shall have power within such limits to</p><p>administer an oath or take an affirmation;</p><p>(£) a request to a person to appear or to give evidence shall, unless the recipient is</p><p>a national of the State where the action is pending, be drawn up in the lan</p><p>guage of the place where the evidence is taken or be accompanied by a</p><p>translation into such language;</p><p>(c) the request shall inform the person that he may be legally represented and, in</p><p>any State that has not filed a declaration under article 18, shall also inform him</p><p>that he is not compelled to appear or to give evidence;</p><p><em>(d) </em>the evidence may be taken in the manner provided by the law applicable to the</p><p>court in which the action is pending provided that such manner is not forbid</p><p>den by the law of the State where the evidence is taken;</p><p><em>(e) </em>a person requested to give evidence may invoke the privileges and duties to</p><p>refuse to give the evidence contained in article 11.</p><p><em>Article 22. </em>The fact that an attempt to take evidence under the procedure</p><p>laid down in this chapter has failed, owing to the refusal of a person to give</p><p>evidence, shall not prevent an application being subsequently made to take the</p><p>evidence in accordance with chapter I.</p><p>CHAPTER HI. GENERAL CLAUSES</p><p><em>Article 23. </em>A Contracting State may at the time of signature, ratification</p><p>or accession, declare that it will not execute Letters of Request issued for the pur</p><p>pose of obtaining pre-trial discovery of documents as known in Common Law</p><p>countries.</p><p>12140</p><p><strong>246 United Nations — Treaty Series • Nations Unies — Recueil des Traités 1972</strong></p><p><em>Article 24. </em>A Contracting State may designate other authorities in addition</p><p>to the Central Authority and shall determine the extent of their competence.</p><p>However, Letters of Request may in all cases be sent to the Central Authority.</p><p>Federal States shall be free to designate more than one Central Authority.</p><p><em>Article 25. </em>A Contracting State which has more than one legal system may</p><p>designate the authorities of one of such systems, which shall have exclusive</p><p>competence to execute Letters of Request pursuant to this Convention.</p><p><em>Article 26. </em>A Contracting State, if required to do so because of constitu</p><p>tional limitations, may request the reimbursement by the State of origin of fees</p><p>and costs, in connection with the execution of Letters of Request, for the service</p><p>of process necessary to compel the appearance of a person to give evidence, the</p><p>costs of attendance of such persons, and the cost of any transcript of the evidence.</p><p>Where a State has made a request pursuant to the above paragraph, any other</p><p>Contracting State may request from that State the reimbursement of similar fees</p><p>and costs.</p><p><em>Article 27. </em>The provisions of the present Convention shall not prevent a</p><p>Contracting State from</p><p><em>(a) </em>declaring that Letters of Request may be transmitted to its judicial authorities</p><p>through channels other than those provided for in article 2;</p><p>(£) permitting, by internal law or practice, any act provided for in this Convention</p><p>to be performed upon less restrictive conditions;</p><p>(c) permitting, by internal law or practice, methods of taking evidence other than</p><p>those provided for in this Convention.</p><p><em>Article 28. </em>The present Convention shall not prevent an agreement between</p><p>any two or more Contracting States to derogate from</p><p><em>(a) </em>the provisions of article 2 with respect to methods of transmitting Letters of</p><p>Request;</p><p><em>(b) </em>the provisions of article 4 with respect to the languages which may be used;</p><p>(c) the provisions of article 8 with respect to the presence of judicial personnel at</p><p>the execution of Letters;</p><p><em>(d) </em>the provisions of article 11 with respect to the privileges and duties of witnes</p><p>ses to refuse to give evidence;</p><p><em>(e) </em>the provisions of article 13 with respect to the methods of returning executed</p><p>Letters to the requesting authority;</p><p>(0 the provisions of article 14 with respect to fees and costs;</p><p><em>(g) </em>the provisions of chapter II.</p><p><em>Article 29. </em>Between Parties to the present Convention who are also Parties</p><p>to one or both of the Conventions on Civil Procedure signed at the Hague on the</p><p>17th of July 1905 and the 1st of March 1954,’ this Convention shall replace</p><p>articles 8-16 of the earlier Conventions.</p><p><strong>1 United Nations, <em>Treaty Series, </em>vol. 286, p. 265.</strong></p><p><strong>12140</strong></p><p>1972 United Nations <em>Treaty </em>Scries » Nations Unies Recueil de» Trait s 247</p><p><em>Article 30. </em>The pr sent Convention shall not affect the application of</p><p>article 23 of the Convention of 1905, or of article 24 of the Convention of 1954.</p><p><em>Article 31, </em>Supplementary Agreements between Parties to the Conventions</p><p>of 1905 and 1954 shall be considered as equally applicable to the present Conven</p><p>tion unless the Parties have otherwise agreed.</p><p><em>Article 32. </em>Without prejudice to the provisions of articles 29 and 31, the</p><p>present Convention shall not derogate from conventions containing provisions on</p><p>the matters covered by this Convention to which the Contracting States are, or</p><p>shall become Parties.</p><p><em>Article 33. </em>A State may, at the time of signature, ratification or accession</p><p>exclude, in whole or in part, the application of the provisions of paragraph 2 of</p><p>article 4 and of chapter ft. No other reservation shall be permitted.</p><p>Each Contracting State may at any time withdraw a reservation it has made;</p><p>the reservation shall cease to have effect on the sixtieth day after notification of</p><p>the withdrawal.</p><p>When a State has made a reservation, any other State affected thereby may</p><p>apply the same rule against the reserving State.</p><p><em>Article 34. </em>A State may at any time withdraw or modify a declaration.</p><p><em>Article 35. </em>A Contracting State shall, at the time of the deposit of its instru</p><p>ment of ratification or accession, or at a later date, inform the Ministry of Foreign</p><p>Affairs of the Netherlands of the designation of authorities, pursuant to articles 2,</p><p>8, 24 and 25.</p><p>A Contracting State shall likewise inform the Ministry, where appropriate, of</p><p>the following</p><p>(a) the designation of the authorities to whom notice must be given, whose per</p><p>mission may be required, and whose assistance may be invoked in the taking</p><p>of evidence fay diplomatic officers and consular agents, pursuant to</p><p>articles 15, 16 and 18 respectively;</p><p><em>(b) </em>the designation of the authorities whose permission may be required in the</p><p>taking of evidence by commissioners pursuant to article 17 and of those who</p><p>may grant the assistance provided for in article 18;</p><p>(c) declarations pursuant to articles 4, 8, 11, 15, 16, 17, 18, 23 and 27;</p><p><em>(d) </em>any withdrawal or modification of the above designations and declarations;</p><p><em>(ë) </em>the withdrawal of any reservation.</p><p><em>Article 36. </em>Any difficulties which may arise between Contracting States in</p><p>connection with the operation of this Convention shall be settled through diploma</p><p>tic channels.</p><p><em>Article 37. </em>The present Convention shall be open for signature by the States</p><p>represented at the Eleventh Session of the Hague Conference on Private Interna</p><p>tional Law.</p><p>It shall be ratified, and the instruments of ratification shall be deposited with</p><p>the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands.</p><p>12140</p><p><strong>248 United Nations — Treaty Series • Nations Unies — Recueil des Traites 1972</strong></p><p><em>Article 38. </em>The pr sent Convention shall enter into force on the sixtieth day</p><p>after the deposit of the third instrument of ratification referred to in the second</p><p>paragraph of article 37.</p><p>The Convention shall enter into force for each signatory State which ratifies</p><p>subsequently on the sixtieth day after the deposit of its instrument of ratification.</p><p><em>Article 39. </em>Any State not represented at the Eleventh Session of the Hague</p><p>Conference on Private International Law which is a Member of this Conference or</p><p>of the United Nations or of a specialized agency of that Organization, or a Party to</p><p>the Statute of the International Court of Justice may accede to the present Con</p><p>vention after it has entered into force in accordance with the first paragraph of</p><p>article 38.</p><p>The instrument of accession shall be deposited with the Ministry of Foreign</p><p>Affairs of the Netherlands.</p><p>The Convention shall enter into force for a State acceding to it on the sixtieth</p><p>day after the deposit of its instrument of accession.</p><p>The accession will have effect only as regards the relations between the</p><p>acceding State and such Contracting States as will have declared their acceptance</p><p>of the accession. Such declaration shall be deposited at the Ministry of Foreign</p><p>Affairs of the Netherlands; this Ministry shall forward, through diplomatic chan</p><p>nels, a certified copy to each of the Contracting States.</p><p>The Convention will enter into force as between the acceding State and the</p><p>State that has declared its acceptance of the accession on the sixtieth day after the</p><p>deposit of the declaration 6f acceptance.</p><p><em>Article 40. </em>Any State may, at the time of signature, ratification or accession,</p><p>declare that the present Convention shall extend to all the territories for the</p><p>international relations of which it is responsible, or to one or more of them. Such a</p><p>declaration shall take effect on the date of entry into force of the Convention for</p><p>the State concerned.</p><p>At any time thereafter, such extensions shall be notified to the Ministry of</p><p>Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands.</p><p>The Convention shall enter into force for the territories mentioned in such an</p><p>extension on the sixtieth day after the notification indicated in the preceding</p><p>paragraph.</p><p><em>Article 41. </em>The present Convention shall remain in force for five years from</p><p>the date of its entry into force in accordance with the first paragraph of article 38,</p><p>even for States which have ratified it or acceded to it subsequently.</p><p>If there has been no denunciation, it shall be renewed tacitly every five years.</p><p>Any denunciation shall be notified to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the</p><p>Netherlands at least six months before the end of the five year period.</p><p>It may be limited to certain of the territories to which the Convention applies.</p><p>The denunciation shall have effect only as regards the State which has</p><p>notified it. The Convention shall remain in force for the other Contracting States.</p><p><strong>12140</strong></p><p>1972 <strong>United Nrfow — Treaty </strong>Serin Nations Uni» <strong>Rcctufl des ÏVattéi 249</strong></p><p><em>Article 42. </em>The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands shall give</p><p>notice to the States referred to in article 37, and to the States which have acceded</p><p>in accordance with article 39, of the following</p><p>(a) the signatures and ratifications referred to in article 37;</p><p>(ft) the date on which the present Convention enters into force in accordance with</p><p>the erst paragraph of article 38;</p><p>(c) the accessions referred to in article 39 and the dates on which they take effect;</p><p><em>(d) </em>the extensions referred to in article 40 and the dates on which they take effect;</p><p><em>(e) </em>the designations, reservations and declarations referred to in articles 33 and</p><p>35;</p><p>CO the denunciations referred to in the third paragraph of article 41.</p><p>IN WITNESS WHEREOF the undersigned, being duly authorised thereto, have</p><p>signed the present Convention.</p><p>12140</p><p><strong>250 United Nations — Treaty Series • Nations Unies — Recueil des Traités 1972</strong></p><p>FAIT à La Haye, le 18 mars 1970, en français et en anglais, les deux textes</p><p>faisant également foi, en un seul exemplaire, qui sera déposé dans les archives du</p><p>Gouvernement des Pays-Bas et dont une copie certifiée conforme sera remise, par</p><p>la voie diplomatique, à chacun des Etats représentés à la onzième session de la</p><p>Conférence de La Haye de droit international privé.</p><p>DONE at The Hague, on the 18th day of March 1970, in the English and French</p><p>languages, both texts being 24	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CUSTOMS CONVENTION ON THE TEMPORARY IMPORTATION FOR PRIVATE USE OF AIRCRAFT AND PLEASURE BOATS and PROTOCOL OF SIGNATURE Done at Geneva on 18 May 1956</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/customes-conventions/customs-convention-on-the-temporary-importation-for-private-use-of-aircraft-and-pleasure-boats-and-protocol-of-signature-done-at-geneva-on-18-may-1956/attachment/aire/" rel="attachment wp-att-6290">CUSTOMS CONVENTION ON THE TEMPORARY IMPORTATION FOR PRIVATE USE OF AIRCRAFT AND PLEASURE BOATS and PROTOCOL OF SIGNATURE Done at Geneva on 18 May 1956(full text pdf file)</a></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>UNITED NATIONS</strong></p><p>– 2 –</p><p>CUSTOMS CONVENTION ON THE TEMPORARY IMPORTATION FOR</p><p>PRIVATE USE OF AIRCRAFT AND PLEASURE BOATS</p><p>Preamble</p><p>THE CONTRACTING PARTIES,</p><p>HAVING REGARD TO the Agreement providing for the Provisional Application of the</p><p>Draft International Customs Conventions on Touring, on Commercial   Road</p><p>Vehicles and on the International Transport of Goods by Road, done at Geneva on</p><p>16 June 1949, and in particular, to Article V of the Agreement, which provides</p><p>that in the event that world-wide conventions dealing with the subject matter of</p><p>the draft conventions provisionally applied by the Agreement “should be</p><p>concluded, and upon their entry into force, any Government party to this</p><p>Agreement, which becomes a party to one or more of those Conventions shall</p><p>automatically be regarded as having denounced the present Agreement with</p><p>respect to the Draft Convention or Conventions corresponding to any of those</p><p>Conventions to which that Government has become a party”;</p><p>HAVING REGARD TO the Convention concerning Customs Facilities for Touring</p><p>and the Customs Convention on the Temporary Importation of Private   Road</p><p>Vehicles, both done at New York on 4 June 1954;</p><p>CONSIDERING that unlike the Draft International Customs Convention on Touring</p><p>brought into provisional application by the Agreement of 16 June 1949, the</p><p>said Conventions contain no provision concerning temporary duty-free</p><p>importation of aircraft and pleasure boats other than kayaks and canoes in use</p><p>and under 5.5metres in length;</p><p>DESIRING to facilitate the development of international touring by means of aircraft and</p><p>pleasure boats;</p><p>HAVE agreed as follows:</p><p>– 3 –</p><p>Chapter I</p><p>DEFINITIONS</p><p>Article 1</p><p>For the purpose of this Convention:</p><p>(a) the term “import duties and import taxes” shall mean not only Customs duties but</p><p>also all duties and taxes whatever chargeable by reason of importation;</p><p>(b) the term “boats” shall mean all pleasure boats and pleasure vessels with or</p><p>without engines together with their spare parts, and their normal accessories and</p><p>equipment when imported with the boats or vessels;</p><p>(c) the term “aircraft” shall mean all aircraft with or without engines together with</p><p>their spare parts and their normal accessories and equipment when imported with</p><p>the aircraft;</p><p>(d) the term “private use” shall mean the use of aircraft or boats, by their owners or</p><p>by persons who have possession or control of them, whether on hire or otherwise,</p><p>for non-commercial purposes and, in particular, for purposes other than the</p><p>transport of persons for remuneration, reward or other consideration or the</p><p>industrial and commercial transport of goods with or without remuneration;</p><p>(e) the term “temporary importation papers” shall mean the Customs document</p><p>identifying the aircraft or boat and providing evidence of the guarantee or deposit</p><p>of import duties and import taxes;</p><p>(f) the term “persons” shall mean both natural and legal persons unless the context</p><p>otherwise requires.</p><p>Chapter II</p><p>TEMPORARY IMPORTATION WITHOUT PAYMENT OF IMPORT DUTIES AND</p><p>IMPORT TAXES AND FREE OF IMPORT PROHIBITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS</p><p>Article 2</p><p>1. Each of the Contracting Parties shall grant temporary admission without payment of</p><p>import duties and import taxes and free of import prohibitions and restrictions, subject to</p><p>re-exportation and to the other conditions laid down in this Convention, to aircraft and boats</p><p>owned by persons normally resident outside its territory which are imported and utilized, for</p><p>their private use on the occasion of a temporary visit, either by the owners of the aircraft or boats</p><p>or by other persons normally resident outside its territory.</p><p>– 4 –</p><p>2. Such aircraft and boats shall be covered by temporary importation papers guaranteeing</p><p>payment of import duties and import taxes, and if the case should arise, of any Customs penalties</p><p>incurred, subject to the special provision of paragraph 4 of Article 27.</p><p>Article 3</p><p>The fuel contained in the supply tanks of aircraft and boats temporarily imported shall be</p><p>admitted without payment of import duties and import taxes and free of import prohibitions and</p><p>restrictions, provided that the supply tanks are of normal capacity, are located in the usual places</p><p>and are connected to the engine, it being understood that the fuel contained in these tanks is</p><p>intended exclusively for consumption by the aircraft or boat.</p><p>Article 4</p><p>1. Component parts imported for the repair of a particular aircraft or boat already</p><p>temporarily imported shall be admitted temporarily without payment of import duties and import</p><p>taxes and free of import prohibitions and restrictions. Contracting Parties may require these</p><p>parts to be covered by temporary importation papers.</p><p>2. Replaced parts which are not re-exported shall be liable to import duties and import taxes</p><p>except where, in conformity with the regulations of the country concerned, they may be</p><p>abandoned free of all expense to the Exchequer or destroyed, under official supervision, at the</p><p>expense of the parties concerned.</p><p>Article 5</p><p>Temporary importation papers sent to associations authorized to issue the papers in</p><p>question by the corresponding foreign associations, by international organizations or by the</p><p>Customs authorities of the Contracting Parties, shall be admitted without payment of import</p><p>duties and import taxes and free of import prohibitions and restrictions.</p><p>Chapter III</p><p>ISSUE OF TEMPORARY IMPORTATION PAPERS</p><p>Article 6</p><p>1. Subject to such guarantees and under such conditions as it may determine, each</p><p>Contracting Party may authorize associations, such as those affiliated to an international</p><p>organization, to issue either directly or through corresponding associations the temporary</p><p>importation papers covered by this Convention.</p><p>– 5 –</p><p>2. Temporary importation papers may be valid for a single country or Customs territory or</p><p>for several countries or Customs territories.</p><p>3. The period of validity of these papers shall not exceed one year from the date of issue.</p><p>Article 7</p><p>1. Temporary importation papers valid for the territories of all or several of the Contracting</p><p>Parties shall be known as carnets de passages en douane and shall conform in respect of aircraft</p><p>to the standard form contained in Annex 1, and, in respect of boats, to the standard form</p><p>contained in Annex 2, to this Convention.</p><p>2. If a carnet de passages en douane is not valid for one or several territories, the issuing</p><p>association shall indicate the fact on the cover and on the importation vouchers of the carnet.</p><p>3. Temporary importation papers intended for boats and valid only for the territory of a</p><p>single Contracting Party may conform to the standard form contained in Annex 3 to this</p><p>Convention. Contracting Parties may also use other documents, in accordance with their</p><p>legislation or regulations.</p><p>4. The period of validity of temporary importation papers other than those issued by</p><p>authorized associations as provided for in Article 6 shall be laid down by each Contracting Party</p><p>in accordance with its legislation or regulations.</p><p>5. Each Contracting Party shall, upon request, supply the other Contracting Parties with</p><p>models of temporary importation papers valid for its territory, other than those appearing in the</p><p>Annexes to this Convention.</p><p>Chapter IV</p><p>PARTICULARS ON TEMPORARY IMPORTATION PAPERS</p><p>Article 8</p><p>Temporary importation papers issued by authorized associations shall be made out in the</p><p>name of the persons who own the aircraft or boats temporarily imported or who have the</p><p>possession or control of them. When such papers, issued in respect of hired aircraft or boats are</p><p>made out in the name of the person letting out on hire, the words “ON HIRE TO …” followed by</p><p>the name and the address of the normal residence in a foreign country of the person concerned,</p><p>shall, when the Customs authorities of the country of temporary importation so require, be</p><p>inserted on all counterfoils and vouchers used in connection with the journeys of the person</p><p>taking the aircraft or boat on hire.</p><p>– 6 –</p><p>Article 9</p><p>1. The weight to be declared on temporary importation papers is the net weight of aircraft or</p><p>boats. It shall be expressed in the metric system. In the case of papers valid for one country</p><p>only, the Customs authorities of that country may prescribe the use of another system.</p><p>2. The value to be declared on temporary importation papers valid for one country only</p><p>shall be expressed in the currency of that country. The value to be declared on a carnet de</p><p>passages en douane shall be expressed in the currency of the country where the carnet is issued.</p><p>3. The articles and tool-kit which form the normal equipment of aircraft or boats need not</p><p>be specially declared on the temporary importation papers.</p><p>4. When the Customs authorities so require, spare parts and accessories not considered as</p><p>constituting the normal equipment of the aircraft or boat shall be declared on the temporary</p><p>importation papers with the necessary particulars (such as weight and value) and shall be</p><p>produced on exit from the country visited.</p><p>Article 10</p><p>Any particulars inserted on temporary importation papers by the issuing association may</p><p>be altered only with the approval of the issuing or guaranteeing association. No alteration to the</p><p>papers may be made after they have been passed by the Customs authorities of the country of</p><p>importation except with the consent of those authorities.</p><p>Chapter V</p><p>CONDITIONS OF TEMPORARY IMPORTATION</p><p>Article 11</p><p>1. Aircraft and boats admitted under cover of temporary importation papers may be used,</p><p>for their private use, by third persons duly authorized by the holders of the papers, provided that</p><p>those third persons normally reside outside the country of importation and also fulfil the other</p><p>conditions laid down in this Convention. The Customs authorities of the Contracting Parties</p><p>shall have the right to require evidence that such third persons have been duly authorized by the</p><p>holders of the papers and fulfil the aforesaid conditions. If this evidence does not appear</p><p>sufficient, the Customs authorities may refuse use of these aircraft and boats in their country</p><p>under cover of the papers. In the case of aircraft or boats which have been hired, each</p><p>Contracting Party may require that the person taking the aircraft or boat on hire be present at the</p><p>time of importation of the aircraft or boat.</p><p>– 7 –</p><p>2. Notwithstanding the provisions of the preceding paragraph, the Customs authorities of</p><p>the Contracting Parties may permit, under conditions of which they shall be the sole judges, an</p><p>aircraft or boat circulating under cover of temporary importation papers to be manned by a crew</p><p>composed of persons who are normally resident in the country of importation, in particular when</p><p>the crew of the aircraft or boat acts on behalf of or under instructions from the holder of the</p><p>temporary importation papers.</p><p>Article 12</p><p>1. Aircraft or boats mentioned in temporary importation papers shall be re-exported in the</p><p>same general state, except for wear and tear, within the period of validity of such papers. In the</p><p>case of aircraft or boats which have been hired, the Customs authorities of the Contracting</p><p>Parties shall have the right to require the re-exportation of the aircraft or boat as soon as the hirer</p><p>has left the country of temporary importation.</p><p>2. Evidence of re-exportation shall be provided by the exit visa properly appended to the</p><p>temporary importation papers by the Customs authorities of the country into which the aircraft or</p><p>boat was temporarily imported.</p><p>3. Contracting Parties may, however, make the discharge of temporary importation papers</p><p>for aircraft subject to proof of the arrival of the aircraft in foreign territory.</p><p>Article 13</p><p>1. Notwithstanding the requirement of re-exportation laid down in Article 12, the</p><p>re-exportation of badly damaged aircraft or boats shall not be required, in the case of duly</p><p>authenticated accidents, provided that the aircraft or boats:</p><p>(a) are subjected to the import duties and import taxes to which they are liable; or</p><p>(b) are abandoned free of all expense to the Exchequer of the country into which they</p><p>were imported temporarily; or</p><p>(c) are destroyed, under official supervision, at the expense of the parties concerned,</p><p>any salvaged parts and materials being subjected to the import duties and import</p><p>taxes to which they are liable,</p><p>as the Customs authorities may require.</p><p>2. When an aircraft or boat temporarily imported cannot be re-exported as a result of a</p><p>seizure, other than a seizure made at the suit of private persons, the requirement of re-exportation</p><p>within the period of validity of the temporary importation papers shall be suspended for the</p><p>duration of the seizure.</p><p>– 8 –</p><p>3. The Customs authorities shall notify, so far as possible, to the guaranteeing association,</p><p>seizures made by or on behalf of those Customs authorities of aircraft or boats admitted under</p><p>cover of temporary importation papers guaranteed by that association and shall advise it of the</p><p>measures they intend to take.</p><p>Article 14</p><p>An aircraft or boat imported into the territory of one of the Contracting Parties under</p><p>cover of temporary importation papers may not be used, even incidentally, for transport against</p><p>remuneration, reward or other consideration between points within the frontiers of that territory</p><p>or outwards from that territory. It may not be hired out after importation and if it was imported</p><p>on hire it may not be re-hired to any person other than the person who hired it originally.</p><p>Article 15</p><p>Persons entitled to temporary importation facilities may, during the period of validity of</p><p>temporary importation papers, import the aircraft or boats covered by those papers as often as</p><p>necessary, on condition that they have each passage (entry and exit) established by a visa of the</p><p>Customs officers concerned if the Customs authorities so require. Temporary importation papers</p><p>may however be made valid for a single journey only.</p><p>Article 16</p><p>When temporary importation papers without detachable vouchers for each passage are</p><p>used for boats, the visas given by the Customs officers between the first entry and the final exit</p><p>shall be provisional. Nevertheless, when the last visa is a provisional exit visa, it shall be</p><p>admitted as proof of the re-exportation of the boat or component parts temporarily imported.</p><p>Article 17</p><p>When temporary importation papers with a detachable voucher for each passage are used,</p><p>each entry visa implies the passing of the document by the Customs authorities, and each</p><p>subsequent exit visa constitutes its final discharge, except as provided in Article 18.</p><p>Article 18</p><p>When the Customs authorities of a country have finally and unconditionally discharged</p><p>temporary importation papers they can no longer claim from the guaranteeing association</p><p>payment of import duties and import taxes, unless the certificate of discharge was obtained</p><p>improperly or fraudulently.</p><p>– 9 –</p><p>Article 19</p><p>Visas on temporary importation papers used under the conditions laid down in this</p><p>Convention shall not be subject to the payment of charges for Customs attendance, provided</p><p>such visas are issued at a Customs office or post during athorized hours.</p><p>Chapter VI</p><p>EXTENSION OF VALIDITY AND RENEWAL OF</p><p>TEMPORARY IMPORTATION PAPERS</p><p>Article 20</p><p>The lack of proof of re-exportation within the time allowed of aircraft or boats</p><p>temporarily imported shall be disregarded when the aircraft or boats are presented to the</p><p>Customs authorities for re-exportation within fourteen days from the expiry of the papers and</p><p>satisfactory explanations of the delay are given.</p><p>Article 21</p><p>Each of the Contracting Parties shall recognize as valid extensions of validity of carnets</p><p>de passages en douane granted by another Contracting  State in accordance with the procedure</p><p>laid down in Annex 4 to this Convention.</p><p>Article 22</p><p>1. Requests for extension of validity of temporary importation papers shall be presented to</p><p>the competent Customs authorities before the expiry of the period of validity of these papers,</p><p>unless this is rendered impossible by force majeure. If the temporary importation papers have</p><p>been issued by an authorized association, the request for extension shall be made by the</p><p>association which guarantees the papers.</p><p>2. Extensions of time necessary for the re-exportation of aircraft or boats or component</p><p>parts imported temporarily shall be granted when the persons concerned can establish to the</p><p>satisfaction of the Customs authorities that they are prevented by force majeure from</p><p>re-exporting the said aircraft, boats or component parts within the time allowed.</p><p>Article 23</p><p>Each of the Contracting Parties shall, unless the conditions of temporary admission are</p><p>no longer satisfied, authorize, subject to whatever measures of control it may consider necessary,</p><p>the renewal of temporary importation papers issued by the authorized associations and relating to</p><p>aircraft, boats or component parts temporarily imported into its territory. Requests for renewal</p><p>shall be presented by the guaranteeing association.</p><p>– 10 –</p><p>Chapter VII</p><p>REGULARIZATION OF TEMPORARY IMPORTATION PAPERS</p><p>Article 24</p><p>1. If temporary importation papers have not been regularly discharged, the Customs</p><p>authorities of the country of importation shall (whether the papers have expired or not) accept as</p><p>evidence of re-exportation of the aircraft, boats or component parts the presentation of a</p><p>certificate based on the standard form shown in Annex 5 to this Convention, issued by an official</p><p>authority (consul, Customs, police, mayor, judicial officer, etc.), attesting the facts that the</p><p>aircraft, boat or component parts in question have been presented to it and are outside the</p><p>country of importation. The said Customs authorities may also accept any other documentary</p><p>evidence that the aircraft, boat or component parts are outside the country of importation. In the</p><p>case of papers, other than carnets de passages en douane, which have not expired, the said</p><p>Customs authorities may required the papers to be surrendered to them before the date on which</p><p>the aircraft or boat in question was certified to be outside the country of temporary importation.</p><p>In the case of carnets, account shall be taken, as evidence of re-exportation of the aircraft, boats,</p><p>or component parts, of the visas entered thereon by the Customs authorities of countries</p><p>subsequently visited.</p><p>2. In the case of the destruction, loss or theft of temporary importation papers not regularly</p><p>discharged but relating to aircraft, boats or component parts which have been re-exported, the</p><p>Customs authorities of the country of importation shall accept as proof of re-exportation the</p><p>presentation of certificates based on the standard form shown in Annex 5 to this Convention</p><p>issued by an official authority (consul, Customs, police, mayor, judicial officer, etc.), attesting</p><p>the facts that the aircraft, boats or component parts in question have been presented to it and are</p><p>outside the country of importation after the date of expiry of the papers. They may also accept</p><p>any other documentary evidence that the aircraft, boats or component parts are outside the</p><p>country of temporary importation.</p><p>3. In the case of the destruction, loss or theft of carnets de passages en douane while</p><p>aircraft, boats or component parts to which they refer are in the territory of one of the</p><p>Contracting Parties, the Customs authorities of that Party shall, at the request of the association</p><p>concerned, accept replacement documents the validity of which shall expire on the date of expiry</p><p>of the validity of the carnets which they replace. This acceptance will annul the previous</p><p>– 11 –</p><p>acceptance of the carnets destroyed, lost or stolen. If, instead of replacement documents, export</p><p>licences or similar documents are issued for the re-exportation of the aircraft, boats or</p><p>component parts, the exit visas on these licences or documents shall be considered as sufficient</p><p>proof of re-exportation.</p><p>4. If aircraft or boats are stolen after having been re-exported from the country of</p><p>importation, without the exit having been regularly endorsed on the temporary importation</p><p>papers and in the absence of entry visas on the papers entered thereon by the Customs authorities</p><p>of countries subsequently visited, the papers may nevertheless be regularized provided that the</p><p>guaranteeing association furnishes the papers together with such evidence of theft as may be</p><p>considered sufficient. If the temporary importation papers have not expired, the Customs</p><p>authorities may require their surrender.</p><p>Article 25</p><p>In the cases referred to in Article 24, the Customs authorities shall have the right to</p><p>charge a regularization fee.</p><p>Article 26</p><p>Customs authorities shall not have the right to require from the guaranteeing association</p><p>payment of import duties and import taxes on aircraft, boats or component parts temporarily</p><p>imported when the non-discharge of the temporary importation papers has not been notified to</p><p>the guaranteeing association within one year of the date of expiry of the validity of those papers.</p><p>Article 27</p><p>1. The guaranteeing associations shall have a period of one year from the date of</p><p>notification of the non-discharge of temporary importation papers in which to furnish proof of</p><p>the re-exportation of the aircraft, boats or component parts in question under the conditions laid</p><p>down in this Convention.</p><p>2. If such proof is not furnished within the time allowed, the guaranteeing association shall</p><p>forthwith deposit or pay provisionally the import duties and import taxes payable. This deposit</p><p>or payment shall become final after a period of one year from the date of the deposit or</p><p>provisional payment. During the latter period, the guaranteeing association may still avail itself</p><p>of the facilities provided by the preceding paragraph with a view to repayment of the sums</p><p>deposited or paid.</p><p>– 12 –</p><p>3. For countries whose regulations do not provide for the deposit or provisional payment of</p><p>import duties and import taxes, payments made in conformity with the provisions of the</p><p>preceding paragraph will be regarded as final, it being understood that the sums paid may be</p><p>refunded when the conditions laid down in this article are fulfilled.</p><p>4. In the case of the non-discharge of temporary importation papers, the guaranteeing</p><p>association shall not be required to pay a sum greater than the total of the import duties and</p><p>import taxes applicable to the aircraft, boats or component parts not re-exported, together with</p><p>interest if applicable.</p><p>Article 28</p><p>The provisions of this Convention do not affect the right of the Contracting Parties, in the</p><p>event of fraud, contravention or abuse, to take proceedings against holders of, or the persons</p><p>using, temporary importation papers, for the recovery of the import duties and import taxes and</p><p>also to impose any penalties to which such persons have rendered themselves liable. In such</p><p>cases, the guaranteeing associations shall lend their assistance to the Customs authorities.</p><p>Chapter VIII</p><p>MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS</p><p>Article 29</p><p>The Contracting Parties shall endeavour not to introduce Customs procedures which</p><p>might have the effect of impeding the development of international touring.</p><p>Article 30</p><p>Any breach of the provisions of this Convention, any substitution, false declaration or act</p><p>having the effect of causing a person or an article improperly to benefit from the system of</p><p>importation laid down in this Convention, may render the offender liable in the country where</p><p>the offence was committed to the penalties prescribed by the laws of that country.</p><p>Article 31</p><p>Nothing in this Convention shall prevent Contracting Parties which form a Customs or economic</p><p>union from enacting special provisions applicable to persons normally resident in the countries</p><p>forming that union.</p><p>– 13 –</p><p>Article 32</p><p>Nothing in this Convention shall be deemed to prejudice the right of each Contracting</p><p>Party to apply import prohibitions or restrictions based on considerations other than economic in</p><p>character, for example considerations of public morality, public security, public health or</p><p>hygiene.</p><p>Chapter IX</p><p>FINAL PROVISIONS</p><p>Article 33</p><p>1. Countries members of the Economic Commission for Europe and countries admitted to</p><p>the Commission in a consultative capacity under paragraph 8 of the Commission’s Terms of</p><p>Reference, may become Contracting Parties to this Convention:</p><p>(a) by signing it;</p><p>(b) by ratifying it after signing it subject to ratification;</p><p>(c) by acceding to it.</p><p>2. Such countries as may participate in certain activities of the Economic Commission for</p><p>Europe in accordance with paragraph 11 of the Commission’s Terms of Reference may become</p><p>Contracting Parties to this Convention by acceding thereto after its entry into force.</p><p>3. The Convention shall be open for signature until 31 August 1956 inclusive. Thereafter, it</p><p>shall be open for accession.</p><p>4. Ratification or accession shall be effected by the deposit of an instrument with the</p><p>Secretary-General of the United Nations</p><p>Article 34</p><p>1. This Convention shall come into force on the ninetieth day after five of the countries</p><p>referred to in article 33, paragraph 1, have signed it without reservation of ratification or have</p><p>deposited their instruments of ratification or accession.</p><p>2. For any country ratifying or acceding to it after five countries have signed it without</p><p>reservation of ratification or have deposited their instruments of ratification or accession, this</p><p>Convention shall enter into force on the ninetieth day after the said country has deposited its</p><p>instrument of ratification or accession.</p><p>Article 35</p><p>1. Any Contracting Party may denounce this Convention by so notifying the</p><p>Secretary-General of the United Nations.</p><p>– 14 –</p><p>2. Denunciation shall take effect fifteen months after the date of receipt by the</p><p>Secretary-General of the notification of denunciation.</p><p>3. The validity of temporary importation papers issued before the date when the</p><p>denunciation takes effect shall not be affected thereby and the guarantee of the association shall</p><p>hold good. Extensions granted in accordance with the conditions laid down in Article 21 of this</p><p>Convention shall similarly remain valid.</p><p>Article 36</p><p>This Convention shall cease to have effect if, for any period of twelve consecutive</p><p>months after its entry into force, the number of Contracting Parties is less than five.</p><p>Article 37</p><p>1. Any country may, at the time of signing this Convention without reservation of</p><p>ratification or of depositing its instrument of ratification or accession or at any time thereafter,</p><p>declare by notification addressed to the Secretary-General of the United Nations that this</p><p>Convention shall extend to all or any of the territories for the international relations of which it is</p><p>responsible. The Convention shall extend to the territory or territories named in the notification</p><p>as from the ninetieth day after its receipt by the Secretary-General or, if on that day the</p><p>Convention has not yet entered into force, at the time of its entry into force.</p><p>2. Any country which has made a declaration under the preceding paragraph extending this</p><p>Convention to any territory for whose international relations it is responsible may denounce the</p><p>Convention separately in respect of that territory in accordance with the provisions of Article 35.</p><p>Article 38</p><p>1. Any dispute between two or more Contracting Parties concerning the interpretation or</p><p>application of this Convention shall so far as possible be settled by negotiation between them.</p><p>2. Any dispute which is not settled by negotiation shall be submitted to arbitration if any</p><p>one of the Contracting Parties in dispute so requests and shall be referred accordingly to one or</p><p>more arbitrators selected by agreement between the Parties in dispute. If within three months</p><p>from the date of the request for arbitration the Parties in dispute are unable to agree on the</p><p>selection of an arbitrator or arbitrators, any of those Parties may request the Secretary-General of</p><p>the United Nations to nominate a single arbitrator to whom the dispute shall be referred for</p><p>decision.</p><p>3. The decision of the arbitrator or arbitrators appointed under the preceding paragraph shall</p><p>be binding on the Contracting Parties in dispute.</p><p>– 15 –</p><p>Article 39</p><p>1. Each Contracting Party may, at the time of signing, ratifying, or acceding to, this</p><p>Convention, declare that it does not consider itself as bound by Article 38 of the Convention.</p><p>Other Contracting Parties shall not be bound by Article 38 in respect of any Contracting Party</p><p>which has entered such a reservation.</p><p>2. Any Contracting Party having entered a reservation as provided for in paragraph 1 may at</p><p>any time withdraw such reservation by notifying the Secretary-General of the United Nations.</p><p>3. No other reservation to this Convention shall be permitted.</p><p>Article 40</p><p>1. After this Convention has been in force for three years, any Contracting Party may, by</p><p>notification to the Secretary-General of the United Nations, request that a conference be</p><p>convened for the purpose of reviewing the Convention. The Secretary-General shall notify all</p><p>Contracting Parties of the request and a review conference shall be convened by the</p><p>Secretary-General if, within a period of four months following the date of notification by the</p><p>Secretary-General, not less than one third of the Contracting Parties notify him of their</p><p>concurrence with the request.</p><p>2. If a conference is convened in accordance with the preceding paragraph, the</p><p>Secretary-General shall notify all the Contracting Parties and invite them to submit within a</p><p>period of three months such proposals as they may wish the conference to consider. The</p><p>Secretary-General shall circulate to all Contracting Parties the provisional agenda for the</p><p>conference together with the texts of such proposals at least three months before the date on</p><p>which the conference is to meet.</p><p>3. The Secretary-General shall invite to any conference convened in accordance with this</p><p>article all countries referred to in Article 33, paragraph 1, and countries which have become</p><p>Contracting Parties under Article 33, paragraph 2.</p><p>Article 41</p><p>1. Any Contracting Party may propose one or more amendments to this Convention. The</p><p>text of any proposed amendments shall be transmitted to the Secretary-General of the</p><p>United Nations who shall transmit it to all Contracting Parties and inform all other countries</p><p>referred to in Article 33, paragraph 1.</p><p>– 16 –</p><p>2. Any proposed amendment circulated in accordance with the preceding paragraph shall be</p><p>deemed to be accepted if no Contracting Party expresses an objection within a period of six</p><p>months following the date of circulation of the proposed amendment by the Secretary-General.</p><p>3. The Secretary-General shall, as soon as possible, notify all Contracting Parties whether</p><p>an objection to the proposed amendment has been expressed. If an objection to the proposed</p><p>amendment has been expressed, the amendment shall be deemed not to have been accepted and</p><p>shall be of no effect whatever. If no such objection has been expressed the amendment shall</p><p>enter into force for all Contracting Parties three months after the expiry of the period of six</p><p>months referred to in the preceding paragraph.</p><p>4. Independently of the amendment procedure laid down in paragraphs 1, 2 and 3 of this</p><p>Article, the annexes to this Convention may be modified by agreement between the competent</p><p>Administrations of all the Contracting Parties. The Secretary-General shall fix the date of entry</p><p>into force of the new texts resulting from such modifications.</p><p>Article 42</p><p>In addition to the notifications provided for in articles 40 and 41, the Secretary-General</p><p>of the United Nations shall notify the countries referred to in Article 33, paragraph 1, and the</p><p>countries which have become Contracting Parties under Article 33, paragraph 2, of:</p><p>(a) signatures, ratifications and accessions under Article 33;</p><p>(b) the dates of entry into force of this Convention in accordance with Article 34;</p><p>(c) denunciations under Article 35;</p><p>(d) the termination of this Convention in accordance with Article 36;</p><p>(e) notifications received in accordance with Article 37;</p><p>(f) declarations and notifications received in accordance with Article 39,</p><p>paragraphs 1 and 2;</p><p>(g) the entry into force of any amendment in accordance with Article 41.</p><p>Article 43</p><p>As soon as a country which is a Contracting Party to the Agreement providing for the</p><p>Provisional Application of the Draft International Customs Conventions on Touring, on</p><p>Commercial Road Vehicles, and on the International Transport of Goods by Road done at</p><p>Geneva on 16 June 1949 becomes a Contracting Party to this Convention, it shall take the</p><p>– 17 –</p><p>measures required by Article IV of that Agreement to denounce it as regards the Draft</p><p>International Customs Convention on Touring, insofar as this denunciation does not already</p><p>result automatically from Article V of that Agreement.</p><p>Article 44</p><p>The Protocol of Signature of this Convention shall have the same force, effect and</p><p>duration as the Convention itself of which it shall be considered to be an integral part.</p><p>Article 45</p><p>After 31 August 1956, the original of this Convention shall be deposited with the</p><p>Secretary-General of the United Nations, who shall transmit certified true copies to each of the</p><p>countries mentioned in Article 33, paragraphs 1 and 2.</p><p>IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the undersigned,</p><p>being duly authorized thereto, have signed this</p><p>Convention.</p><p>DONE at Geneva, this eighteenth day</p><p>of May one thousand nine hundred and</p><p>fifty-six, in a single copy in the</p><p>English and French languages, each</p><p>text being equally authentic.</p><p>– 18 –</p><p>Annex 1</p><p>CARNET DE PASSAGES EN DOUANE FOR AN AIRCRAFT</p><p>The carnet is issued in French.</p><p>The dimensions are 33 x 24 cm.</p><p>– 19
