25	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">CUSTOMS CONVENTION ON THE TEMPORARY IMPORTATION OF COMMERCIAL ROAD VEHICLES</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/customes-conventions/customs-convention-on-the-temporary-importation-of-commercial-road-vehicles/attachment/impcom-e/" rel="attachment wp-att-6309">CUSTOMS CONVENTION ON THE TEMPORARY IMPORTATION OF COMMERCIAL ROAD VEHICLES</a>(full text pdf file)</p><p>Signed at Geneva on 18 May 1956</p><p>UNITED NATIONS</p><p>-2-</p><p>CUSTOMS CONVENTION ON THE TEMPORARY IMPORTATION</p><p>OF COMMERCIAL ROAD VEHICLES</p><p>Note: The text reproduced below, contains the complete text of the Customs Convention on the Temporary</p><p>Importation of Commercial Road Vehicles (1956) as amended on 30 October 1992 by virtue of depositary</p><p>notifications C.N.316.1991.TREATIES-1 and C.N.229.1992.TREATIES-1.</p><p>CUSTOMS CONVENTION ON THE TEMPORARY IMPORTATION</p><p>OF COMMERCIAL ROAD VEHICLES</p><p>THE CONTRACTING PARTIES,</p><p>DESIRING to facilitate international road traffic,</p><p>HAVING REGARD to the provisions of the Customs Convention on the Temporary Importation of</p><p>Private Road Vehicles, done at New York on 4 June 1954,</p><p>DESIRING to apply similar provisions, so far as possible, to the temporary importation of commercial</p><p>road vehicles and, in particular, to provide for the use, for those vehicles, of the Customs documents</p><p>prescribed for private road vehicles,</p><p>HAVE AGREED as follows:</p><p>CHAPTER I – DEFINITIONS</p><p>Article 1</p><p>For the purpose of this Convention:</p><p>(a) the term “import duties and import taxes” shall mean Customs duties and all other duties,</p><p>taxes, fees and other charges which are collected on, or in connection with, the import of goods mentioned</p><p>in this Convention, but not including fees and charges limited in amount to the approximate costs of services</p><p>rendered;</p><p>(b) the term “vehicles” shall mean all road motor vehicles and all trailers which can be coupled</p><p>to such vehicles (whether imported with the vehicle or separately), together with their spare parts and their</p><p>normal accessories and equipment, when imported with the vehicle;</p><p><strong>-3-</strong></p><p>(c) the term “commercial use” shall mean use for the transport of persons for remuneration,</p><p>reward or other consideration or for the industrial or commercial transport of goods with or without</p><p>remuneration;</p><p>(d) the term “temporary importation papers” shall mean the Customs document identifying the</p><p>vehicle and providing evidence of the guarantee or deposit of import duties and import taxes;</p><p>(e) the term “undertakings” shall mean commercial or industrial concerns, whatever their legal</p><p>status, and shall include natural persons engaged in commercial or industrial activities;</p><p>(f) the term “persons” shall mean both natural and legal persons;</p><p>(g) the term “issuing association” shall mean an association authorized to issue temporary</p><p>importation papers;</p><p>(h) the term “guaranteeing association” shall mean an association approved by the Customs</p><p>authorities of a Contracting Party to act as surety for persons using temporary importation papers;</p><p>(i) the term “international organization” shall mean an organization to which national associations</p><p>are affiliated which are entitled to issue and to guarantee temporary importation papers;</p><p>(j) the term “Contracting Party” shall mean a country or regional economic integration</p><p>organization, Party to this Convention;</p><p>(k) the term “regional economic integration organization” shall mean an organization constituted</p><p>by and composed of countries as referred to in Article 33, paragraph 1 of this Convention, which has</p><p>competence to adopt its own legislation that is binding on its Member States, in respect of matters governed</p><p>by this Convention, and has competence to decide, in accordance with its internal procedures, to accede to</p><p>this Convention.</p><p>CHAPTER II – TEMPORARY IMPORTATION WITHOUT</p><p>PAYMENT OF IMPORT DUTIES AND IMPORT TAXES</p><p>AND FREE OF IMPORT PROHIBITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS</p><p>Article 2</p><p>l. Each of the Contracting Parties shall grant temporary admission without payment of import duties</p><p>and import taxes and free of import prohibitions and restrictions, subject to re-exportation and to the other</p><p>conditions laid down in this Convention, to vehicles registered in the territory of any of the other Contracting</p><p>Parties and imported and used in international road traffic for commercial use by undertakings operating from</p><p>that territory</p><p><strong>-4-</strong></p><p>2. The Contracting Parties may under the conditions set out in this Convention prescribe that such</p><p>vehicles shall be covered by temporary importation papers guaranteeing payment of import duties and import</p><p>taxes or an equivalent sum subject to the special provisions of Article 27, paragraph 4, should the vehicles</p><p>covered by temporary importation papers not be re-exported within the prescribed time limit.</p><p>3. Vehicles which are imported with a view to their being hired out after importation shall not be entitled</p><p>to the benefits of this Convention.</p><p>Article 3</p><p>1. Subject to such conditions as the Customs authorities may impose, the driver and other members of</p><p>the crew of the vehicle shall be allowed to import temporarily a reasonable quantity of personal effects, having</p><p>regard to the period of stay in the country of importation.</p><p>2. Provisions for the journey and small quantities of tobacco, cigars and cigarettes for personal</p><p>consumption, shall be admitted free of import duties and import taxes.</p><p>Article 4</p><p>The fuel contained in the ordinary supply tanks of vehicles temporarily imported shall be admitted</p><p>without payment of import duties and import taxes and free of import prohibitions and restrictions. Each</p><p>Contracting Party may however fix maximum quantities for the fuel so admitted into its territory in the supply</p><p>tanks of the vehicles temporarily imported.</p><p>Article 5</p><p>1. Component parts imported for the repair of a particular vehicle already temporarily imported shall be</p><p>admitted temporarily without payment of import duties and import taxes and free of import prohibitions and</p><p>restrictions. Contracting Parties may require these parts to be covered by temporary importation papers.</p><p>2. Replaced parts which are not re-exported shall be liable to import duties and import taxes except</p><p>where, in conformity with the regulations of the country concerned, they may be abandoned free of all</p><p>expense to the Exchequer or destroyed, under official supervision, at the expense of the Parties concerned.</p><p>Article 6</p><p>Temporary importation papers and international circulation papers sent to associations authorized to</p><p>issue the papers in question by the corresponding foreign associations, by international organizations or by the</p><p>Customs authorities of the Contracting Parties, shall be admitted without payment of import duties and import</p><p>taxes and free of import prohibitions and restrictions.</p><p><strong>-5-</strong></p><p>CHAPTER III – ISSUE OF TEMPORARY IMPORTATION PAPERS</p><p>Article 7</p><p>l. Subject to such guarantees and under such conditions as it may determine, each Contracting Party</p><p>may authorize associations, such as those affiliated to an international organization, to issue either directly or</p><p>through corresponding associations the temporary importation papers covered by this Convention.</p><p>2. Temporary importation papers may be valid for a single country or Customs territory, or for several</p><p>countries or Customs territories.</p><p>3. The period of validity of these papers shall not exceed one year from the date of issue.</p><p>Article 8</p><p>l. Temporary importation papers valid for the territories of all or several of the Contracting Parties shall</p><p>be known as “carnets de passages en douane” and shall conform to the standard form contained in Annex 1</p><p>to this Convention.</p><p>2. If a “carnet de passages en douane” is not valid for one or several territories, the issuing association</p><p>shall indicate the fact on the cover and on the importation vouchers of the carnet.</p><p>3. Temporary importation papers valid only for the territory of a single Contracting Party may conform</p><p>to the standard form contained in Annex 2 of this Convention. Contracting Parties may also use other</p><p>documents, in accordance with their legislation or regulations.</p><p>4. The period of validity of temporary importation papers, other than those issued by authorized</p><p>associations as provided for in Article 7, shall be laid down by each Contracting Party in accordance with its</p><p>legislation or regulations.</p><p>5. Each Contracting Party shall, upon request, supply the other Contracting Parties with models of</p><p>temporary importation papers valid for its territory, other than those appearing in the annexes to this</p><p>Convention.</p><p>CHAPTER IV – PARTICULARS ON TEMPORARY IMPORTATION PAPERS</p><p>Article 9</p><p>Temporary importation papers issued by authorized associations shall be made out in the name of the</p><p>undertakings operating and temporarily importing the vehicles.</p><p><strong>-6-</strong></p><p>Article 10</p><p>1. The weight to be declared on temporary importation papers is the net weight of the vehicles. It shall</p><p>be expressed in the metric system. In the case of papers valid for one country only, the Customs authorities</p><p>of that country may prescribe the use of another system.</p><p>2. The value to be declared on temporary importation papers valid for one country only shall be</p><p>expressed in the currency of that country. The value to be declared on a “carnet de passages en douane” shall</p><p>be expressed in the currency of the country where the carnet is issued.</p><p>3. The Articles and tool- kit which form the normal equipment of vehicles need not be specially declared</p><p>on temporary importation papers.</p><p>4. When the Customs authorities so require, spare parts (such as wheels, tyres and inner tubes) and</p><p>accessories not considered as constituting the normal equipment of the vehicle (such as radio sets and luggage</p><p>carriers) shall be declared on temporary importation papers with the necessary particulars (such as weight and</p><p>value) and shall be produced on exit from the country visited.</p><p>5. Trailers shall be covered by separate importation papers.</p><p>Article 11</p><p>Any particulars inserted on temporary importation papers by the issuing associations may be altered</p><p>only with the approval of the issuing or guaranteeing association. No alteration to the papers may be made</p><p>after they have been passed by the Customs authorities of the country of importation except with the consent</p><p>of those authorities.</p><p>CHAPTER V – CONDITIONS OF TEMPORARY IMPORTATION</p><p>Article 12</p><p>Without prejudice to the application of the provisions of national legislations enabling the Customs</p><p>authorities of the Contracting Parties to refuse to allow vehicles admitted under cover of temporary importation</p><p>papers to be driven by persons who have been guilty of serious offences against the Customs or fiscal laws</p><p>or regulations of the country of temporary importation, vehicles admitted under cover of temporary</p><p>importation papers may be driven by persons duly authorized by the holders of the papers. The Customs</p><p>authorities of the Contracting Parties shall have the right to require evidence that such persons have been duly</p><p>authorized by the holders of the papers; if this evidence does not appear sufficient, the Customs authorities</p><p>may refuse use of these vehicles in their country under cover of the papers.</p><p>Article 13</p><p>1. Vehicles mentioned in temporary importation papers shall be re-exported in the same general state,</p><p>except for wear and tear, within the period of validity of such papers.</p><p><strong>-7-</strong></p><p>2. Evidence of re-exportation shall be provided by the exit visa properly appended to the temporary</p><p>importation papers by the Customs authorities of the country into which the vehicle was temporarily imported.</p><p>3. Each Contracting Party shall have the right to deny the benefit of temporary importation without</p><p>payment of import duties and import taxes and free of import prohibitions and restrictions to, or to withdraw</p><p>that benefit from, vehicles which are used, even occasionally, for the purpose of picking up passengers or</p><p>goods within the frontiers of the country into which the vehicle is imported, for deposit within those frontiers.</p><p>4. A hired vehicle temporarily imported under the terms of this Convention shall not be re-hired in the</p><p>country of temporary importation to any persons other than the persons who hired it originally, and the</p><p>Customs authorities of the Contracting Parties shall have the right to require that such a vehicle shall be reexported</p><p>when the transport operations for which it has been temporarily imported have been completed.</p><p>Article 14</p><p>1. Notwithstanding the requirement of re-exportation laid down in Article 13, the re-exportation of badly</p><p>damaged vehicles shall not be required, in the case of duly authenticated accidents, provided that the vehicles:</p><p>(a) are subjected to the import duties and import taxes to which they are liable; or</p><p>(b) are abandoned free of all expenses to the Exchequer of the country into which they were</p><p>imported temporarily, in which case the holder of the temporary importation papers shall be exempt from</p><p>import duties and import taxes; or</p><p>(c) are destroyed, under official supervision, at the expense of the Parties concerned, any</p><p>salvaged parts and materials being subjected to the import duties and import taxes to which they are liable, as</p><p>the Customs authorities may require.</p><p>2. When a vehicle temporarily imported cannot be re-exported as a result of a seizure, other than a</p><p>seizure made at the suit of private persons, the requirement of re-exportation within the period of validity of</p><p>the temporary importation papers shall be suspended for the duration of the seizure.</p><p>3. The Customs authorities shall notify, so far as possible, to the guaranteeing association, seizures made</p><p>by or on behalf of those Customs authorities of vehicles admitted under cover of temporary importation papers</p><p>guaranteed by that association and shall advise it of the measures they intend to take.</p><p>4. When the vehicle or the object listed in the papers are either lost or stolen during the course of the</p><p>seizure other than a seizure made at the suit of private persons, no import duties or import taxes can be levied</p><p>against the holder of the temporary importation papers, who should submit evidence of seizure to the Customs</p><p>authorities.</p><p>Article 15</p><p>Persons entitled to temporary importation facilities may, during the period of validity of temporary</p><p>importation papers, import the vehicles covered by those papers as often as necessary, on condition that they</p><p>have each passage (entry and exit) established by a visa of the Customs officers concerned if the Customs</p><p>authorities so require. Temporary importation papers may however be made valid for a single journey only.</p><p><strong>-8-</strong></p><p>Article 16</p><p>When temporary importation papers without detachable vouchers for each passage are used, the visas</p><p>given by the Customs officers between the first entry and the final exit are provisional. Nevertheless, when</p><p>the last visa is a provisional exit visa, it will be admitted as proof of the re-exportation of the vehicle or</p><p>component parts temporarily imported.</p><p>Article 17</p><p>When temporary importation papers with a detachable voucher for each passage are used, each entry</p><p>visa implies the passing of the document by the Customs authorities and each subsequent exit visa constitutes</p><p>its final discharge, except as provided in Article 18.</p><p>Article 18</p><p>When the Customs authorities of a country have finally and unconditionally discharged temporary</p><p>importation papers they can no longer claim from the guaranteeing association payment of import duties and</p><p>import taxes, unless the certificate of discharge was obtained improperly or fraudulently.</p><p>Article 19</p><p>Visas on temporary importation papers used under the conditions laid down in this Convention shall</p><p>not be subject to the payment of charges for Customs attendance provided such visas are issued at a Customs</p><p>office or post during authorized hours.</p><p>CHAPTER VI – EXTENSION OF VALIDITY AND</p><p>RENEWAL OF TEMPORARY IMPORTATION PAPERS</p><p>Article 20</p><p>The lack of proof of re-exportation within the time allowed of vehicles temporarily imported shall be</p><p>disregarded when the vehicles are presented to the Customs authorities for re-exportation within fourteen days</p><p>from the expiry of the temporary entry deadline for the vehicles and satisfactory explanations of the delay are</p><p>given.</p><p>Article 21</p><p>Each of the Contracting Parties shall recognize as valid extensions of validity of “carnets de passages</p><p>en douane” granted by another Contracting Party in accordance with the procedure laid down in Annex 3 to</p><p>this Convention.</p><p><strong>-9-</strong></p><p>Article 22</p><p>1. Requests for extension of validity of temporary importation papers shall be presented to the</p><p>competent Customs authorities before the expiry of the period of validity of these papers, unless this is</p><p>rendered impossible by force majeure. If the temporary importation papers have been issued by an authorized</p><p>association, the request for extension shall be made by the association which guarantees the papers.</p><p>2. Extensions of time necessary for the re-exportation of vehicles or component parts imported</p><p>temporarily shall be granted when the persons concerned can establish to the satisfaction of the Customs</p><p>authorities that they are prevented by force majeure from re-exporting the said vehicles or component parts</p><p>within the time allowed.</p><p>3. The validity of temporary importation papers can only be extended once for not more than one year.</p><p>After this period, a new carnet must be issued and delivered in replacement of the former carnet.</p><p>Article 23</p><p>Each of the Contracting Parties shall, unless the conditions of temporary admission are no longer</p><p>satisfied, authorize, subject to whatever measures of control it may consider necessary, the renewal of</p><p>temporary importation papers issued by the authorized associations and relating to vehicles or component parts</p><p>temporarily imported into its territory. Requests for renewal shall be presented by the guaranteeing</p><p>association.</p><p>CHAPTER VII – REGULARIZATION OF TEMPORARY IMPORTATION PAPERS</p><p>Article 24</p><p>1. If temporary importation papers have not been regularly discharged, the Customs authorities of the</p><p>country of importation shall (whether the papers have expired or not) accept as evidence of re-exportation of</p><p>the vehicle or component parts the presentation of a certificate based on the standard form shown in Annex</p><p>4 to this Convention, issued by an official authority (consul, Customs, police, mayor, judicial officer etc.),</p><p>attesting the facts that the vehicle or component parts in question have been presented to it and are outside</p><p>the country of importation. As an alternative they shall accept any other valid documentary evidence that the</p><p>vehicle or component parts are outside the country of temporary importation. In the case of papers, other</p><p>than the “carnets de passages en douane”, which have not expired, the papers shall be produced at the same</p><p>time as the evidence referred to above. In the case of carnets the Customs authorities shall accept, as</p><p>evidence of re-exportation of the vehicles or component parts, the visas entered thereon by the Customs</p><p>authorities of countries subsequently visited.</p><p>2. In the case of the destruction, loss or theft of temporary importation papers not regularly discharged</p><p>but relating to vehicles or component parts which have been re-exported, the Customs authorities of the</p><p>country of importation shall accept as proof of re-exportation the presentation of certificates based on the</p><p><strong>-10-</strong></p><p>standard form shown in Annex 4 to this Convention issued by an official authority (consul, Customs, police,</p><p>mayor, judicial officer etc.), attesting the facts that the vehicles or component parts in question have been</p><p>presented to it and are outside the country of importation after the date of expiry of the papers. As an</p><p>alternative they shall accept any other valid documentary evidence that the vehicle or component parts are</p><p>outside the country of temporary importation.</p><p>3. In the case of the destruction, loss or theft of “carnets de passages en douane” while vehicles or</p><p>component parts to which they refer are in the territory of one of the Contracting Parties, the Customs</p><p>authorities of that Party shall, at the request of the association concerned, accept replacement documents, the</p><p>validity of which shall expire on the date of expiry of the validity of the carnets which they replace. This</p><p>acceptance will annul the previous acceptance of the carnets destroyed, lost or stolen. In case of the misuse</p><p>of a carnet after cancellation by the Customs authorities and the issuing association, the latter cannot be held</p><p>responsible for import duties and import taxes payable. If, instead of replacement documents, export licences</p><p>or similar documents are issued for the re-exportation of the vehicles or component parts, the exit visas on</p><p>these licences or documents shall be considered as sufficient proof of re-exportation.</p><p>4. If vehicles are stolen after having been re-exported from the country of temporary importation,</p><p>without the exit having been regularly endorsed on the temporary importation papers and in the absence of</p><p>entry visas on the papers entered thereon by the Customs authorities of countries subsequently visited, the</p><p>papers may nevertheless be regularized provided that the guaranteeing association furnishes the papers together</p><p>with such evidence of theft as may be considered sufficient. If the temporary importation papers have not</p><p>expired, the Customs authorities may require their surrender.</p><p>Article 25</p><p>In the case referred to in Article 24, the Customs authorities shall have the right to charge a</p><p>regularization fee.</p><p>Article 25 bis</p><p>The competent Customs authorities shall not require payment of import duties and import taxes where</p><p>it is proved to their satisfaction that a vehicle imported under cover of temporary importation papers can no</p><p>longer be re-exported because it has been destroyed or irrecoverably lost for reasons of force majeure, in</p><p>particular on account of acts of war, riots or natural disasters.</p><p>Article 26</p><p>Customs authorities shall not have the right to require from the guaranteeing association payment of</p><p>import duties and import taxes on vehicles or component parts temporarily imported when the non-discharge</p><p>of the temporary importation papers has not been notified to the guaranteeing association within one year of</p><p>the date of expiry of the validity of those papers. The Customs authorities shall provide the guaranteeing</p><p>associations with details of the amount of import duties and import taxes within one year from the notification</p><p>of the non-discharge. The guaranteeing associations’ liability for these sums shall cease if such information</p><p>is not furnished within this one-year period.</p><p><strong>-11-</strong></p><p>Article 27</p><p>1. The guaranteeing associations shall have a period of one year from the date of notification of the nondischarge</p><p>of temporary importation papers in which to furnish proof of the re-exportation of the vehicles or</p><p>component parts in question under the conditions laid down in this Convention. Nevertheless, this period can</p><p>come into force only as of the date of expiry of the temporary importation papers. If the Customs authorities</p><p>contest the validity of the proof provided they must so inform the guarantor within a period not exceeding one</p><p>year.</p><p>2. If such proof is not furnished within the time limit allowed, the guaranteeing association shall deposit</p><p>or pay provisionally within a maximum period of three months the import duties and import taxes payable.</p><p>This deposit or payment shall become final after a period of one year from the date of the deposit or</p><p>provisional payment. During the latter period, the guaranteeing association may still avail itself of the facilities</p><p>provided by the preceding paragraph with a view to repayment of the sums deposited or paid.</p><p>3. For countries whose regulations do not provide for the deposit or provisional payment of import duties</p><p>and import taxes, payments made in conformity with the provisions of the preceding paragraph will be</p><p>regarded as final, it being understood that the sums paid may be refunded when the conditions laid down in</p><p>this Article are fulfilled.</p><p>4. In the case of the non-discharge of temporary importation papers, the guaranteeing association shall</p><p>not be required to pay a sum greater than the total of the import duties and import taxes applicable to the</p><p>vehicles or component parts not re-exported, together with interest if applicable.</p><p>Article 28</p><p>The provisions of this Convention do not affect the right of the Contracting Parties, in the event of</p><p>fraud, contravention or abuse, to take proceedings against holders of, or the persons using, temporary</p><p>importation papers, for the recovery of the import duties and import taxes and also to impose any penalties</p><p>to which such persons have rendered themselves liable. In such cases, the guaranteeing associations shall lend</p><p>their assistance to the Customs authorities.</p><p>CHAPTER VIII – MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS</p><p>Article 29</p><p>The Contracting Parties shall endeavour not to introduce Customs procedures which have the effect</p><p>of impeding the development of international commercial road traffic.</p><p>Article 30</p><p>In order to expedite Customs procedures contiguous Contracting Parties shall endeavour to place their</p><p>respective Customs offices and posts close together and to keep them open during the same hours.</p><p><strong>-12-</strong></p><p>Article 31</p><p>Any breach of the provisions of this Convention, any substitution, false declaration or act having the</p><p>effect of causing a person or an Article improperly to benefit from the system of importation laid down in this</p><p>Convention, may render the offender liable in the country where the offence was committed to the penalties</p><p>prescribed by the laws of that country.</p><p>Article 32</p><p>Nothing in this Convention shall prevent Contracting Parties which form a Customs or economic</p><p>union from enacting special provisions applic able to undertakings operating from the countries forming that</p><p>union.</p><p>Article 32 bis</p><p>This Convention shall not prevent the application of greater facilities which Contracting Parties grant</p><p>or may wish to grant, either by unilateral provisions or in virtue of bilateral or multilateral agreements, provided</p><p>that such facilities do not impede the application of the provisions of this Convention. The Contracting Parties</p><p>are recommended to waive the request for temporary importation papers and guarantees.</p><p>CHAPTER IX – FINAL PROVISIONS</p><p>Article 33</p><p>1. Countries members of the Economic Commission for Europe and countries admitted to the</p><p>Commission in a consultative capacity under paragraph 8 of the Commission’s Terms of Reference, may</p><p>become Contracting Parties to this Convention:</p><p>(a) by signing it;</p><p>(b) by ratifying it after signing it subject to ratification;</p><p>(c) by acceding to it.</p><p>2. Such countries as may participate in certain activities of the Economic Commission for Europe in</p><p>accordance with paragraph 11 of the Commission’s Terms of Reference may become Contracting Parties to</p><p>this Convention by acceding thereto after its entry into force.</p><p>2 bis. Any regional economic integration organization may become, in accordance with paragraph 1 of this</p><p>Article, a Contracting Party to this Convention. Such organization which has acceded to this Convention shall</p><p>inform the Secretary-General of the United Nations of its competence and any subsequent changes thereto,</p><p>with respect to the matters governed by this Convention. The organization and its Member States may,</p><p>without however any derogation from the obligations under this Convention, decide on their respective</p><p>responsibilities for the performance of their obligations under this Convention.</p><p><strong>-13-</strong></p><p>3. The Convention shall be open for signature until 31 August 1956 inclusive. Thereafter, it shall be open</p><p>for accession.</p><p>4. Ratification or accession shall be effected by the deposit of an instrument with the Secretary-General</p><p>of the United Nations.</p><p>Article 34</p><p>1. This Convention shall come into force on the ninetieth day after five of the countries referred to in</p><p>Article 33, paragraph 1, have signed it without reservation of ratification or have deposited their instruments</p><p>of ratification or accession.</p><p>2. For any country or regional economic integration organization ratifying or acceding to it after five</p><p>countries have signed it without reservation of ratification or have deposited their instrument of ratification</p><p>or accession, this Convention shall enter into force on the ninetieth day after the said country or regional</p><p>economic integration organization has deposited its instrument of ratification or accession.</p><p>Article 35</p><p>1. Any Contracting Party may denounce this Convention by so notifying the Secretary-General of the</p><p>United Nations.</p><p>2. Denunciation shall take effect fifteen months after the date of receipt by the Secretary-General of the</p><p>notification of denunciation.</p><p>3. The validity of temporary importation papers issued before the date when the denunciation takes effect</p><p>shall not be affected thereby and the guarantee of the association shall hold good. Extensions granted in</p><p>accordance with the conditions laid down in Article 21 of this Convention shall similarly remain valid.</p><p>Article 36</p><p>This Convention shall cease to have effect if, for any period of twelve consecutive months after its</p><p>entry into force, the number of Contracting Parties is less than five.</p><p>Article 37</p><p>1. Any country may, at the time of signing this Convention without reservation of ratification or of</p><p>depositing its instrument of ratification or accession or at any time thereafter, declare by notification addressed</p><p>to the Secretary-General of the United Nations that this Convention shall extend to all or any of the territories</p><p>for the international relations of which it is responsible. The Convention shall extend to the territory or</p><p>territories named in the notification as from the ninetieth day after its receipt by the Secretary-General or, if</p><p>on that day the Convention has not yet entered into force, at the time of its entry into force.</p><p>2. Any country which has made a declaration under the preceding paragraph extending this Convention</p><p>to any territory for whose international relations it is responsible may denounce the Convention separately in</p><p>respect of that territory in accordance with the provisions of Article 35.</p><p><strong>-14-</strong></p><p>Article 38</p><p>1. Any dispute between two or more Contracting Parties concerning the interpretation or application of</p><p>this Convention shall so far as possible be settled by negotiation between them.</p><p>2. Any dispute which is not settled by negotiation shall be submitted to arbitration if any one of the</p><p>Contracting Parties in dispute so requests and shall be referred accordingly to one or more arbitrators selected</p><p>by agreement between the Parties in dispute. If within three months from the date of the request for</p><p>arbitration the Parties in dispute are unable to agree on the selection of an arbitrator or arbitrators, any of those</p><p>Parties may request the Secretary-General of the United Nations to nominate a single arbitrator to whom the</p><p>dispute shall be referred for decision.</p><p>3. The decision of the arbitrator or arbitrators appointed under the preceding paragraph shall be binding</p><p>on the Contracting Parties in dispute.</p><p>Article 39</p><p>1. Each Contracting Party may, at the time of signing, ratifying, or acceding to, this Convention, declare</p><p>that it does not consider itself as bound by Article 38 of the Convention. Other Contracting Parties shall not</p><p>be bound by Article 38 in respect of any Contracting Party which has entered such a reservation.</p><p>2. Any Contracting Party having entered a reservation as provided for in paragraph 1 may at any time</p><p>withdraw such reservation by notifying the Secretary-General of the United Nations.</p><p>3. No other reservation to this Convention shall be permitted.</p><p>Article 40</p><p>1. After this Convention has been in force for three years, any Contracting Party may, by notification</p><p>to the Secretary-General of the United Nations, request that a conference be convened for the purpose of</p><p>reviewing the Convention. The Secretary-General shall notify all Contracting Parties of the request and a</p><p>review conference shall be convened by the Secretary-General if, within a period of four months following</p><p>the date of notification by the Secretary-General, not less than one third of the Contracting Parties notify him</p><p>of their concurrence with the request.</p><p>2. If a conference is convened in accordance with the preceding paragraph, the Secretary-General shall</p><p>notify all the Contracting Parties and invite them to submit within a period of three months such proposals as</p><p>they may wish the Conference to consider. The Secretary-General shall circulate to all Contracting Parties</p><p>the provisional agenda for the conference together with the texts of such proposals at least three months</p><p>before the date on which the conference is to meet.</p><p>3. The Secretary-General shall invite to any conference convened in accordance with this Article all</p><p>countries referred to in Article 33, paragraph 1, and the Contracting Parties referred to in Article 33,</p><p>paragraphs 2 and 2 bis.</p><p><strong>-15-</strong></p><p>Article 41</p><p>1. Any Contracting Party may propose one or more amendments to this Convention. The text of any</p><p>proposed amendments shall be transmitted to the Secretary-General of the United Nations who shall transmit</p><p>it to all Contracting Parties and inform all other countries referred to in Article 33, paragraph 1.</p><p>2. Any proposed amendment circulated in accordance with the preceding paragraph shall be deemed to</p><p>be accepted if no Contracting Party expresses an objection within a period of six months following the date</p><p>of circulation of the proposed amendment by the Secretary-General. Regional economic integration</p><p>organizations which are Contracting Parties to this Convention, for the matters within their competence, shall</p><p>exercise their right to express an objection. In such a case the Member States of said organizations, which</p><p>are Contracting Parties to this Convention, shall not be entitled to exercise individually such right.</p><p>3. The Secretary-General shall, as soon as possible, notify all Contracting Parties whether an objection</p><p>to the proposed amendment has been expressed. If an objection to the proposed amendment has been</p><p>expressed, the amendment shall be deemed not to have been accepted and shall be of no effect whatever. If</p><p>no such objection has been expressed the amendment shall enter into force for all Contracting Parties three</p><p>months after the expiry of the period of six months referred to in the preceding paragraph.</p><p>4. Independently of the amendment procedure laid down in paragraphs l, 2 and 3 of this Article, the</p><p>annexes to this Convention may be modified by agreement between the competent administrations of all the</p><p>Contracting Parties. The Secretary-General shall fix the date of entry into force of the new texts resulting</p><p>from such modifications.</p><p>Article 42</p><p>In addition to the notifications provided for in Articles 40 and 41, the Secretary-General of the United</p><p>Nations shall notify the countries referred to in Article 33, paragraph 1, and the Contracting Parties referred</p><p>to in Article 33, paragraphs 2 and 2 bis, of:</p><p>(a) signatures, ratifications and accessions under Article 33;</p><p>(a) bis information on the competence of regional economic integration organizations and any</p><p>subsequent changes thereto in accordance with Article 33, paragraph 2 bis;</p><p>(b) the dates of entry into force of this Convention in accordance with Article 34;</p><p>(c) denunciation under Article 35;</p><p>(d) the termination of this Convention in accordance with Article 36;</p><p>(e) notifications received in accordance with Article 37;</p><p>(f) declarations and notifications received in accordance with Article 39, paragraphs 1 and 2;</p><p>(g) the entry into force of any amendment in accordance with Article 41.</p><p><strong>-16-</strong></p><p>Article 43</p><p>As soon as a country which is a Contracting Party to the Agreement providing for the Provisional</p><p>Application of the Draft International Customs Conventions on Touring, on Commercial Road Vehicles, and</p><p>on the International Transport of Goods by Road done at Geneva on 16 June 1949 becomes a Contracting</p><p>Party to this Convention, it shall take the measures required by Article IV of that Agreement to denounce it</p><p>as regards the draft International Customs Convention on Commercial Road Vehicles.</p><p>Article 44</p><p>The Protocol of Signature of this Convention shall have the same force, effect and duration as the</p><p>Convention itself of which it shall be considered to be an integral part.</p><p>Article 45</p><p>After 31 August 1956, the original of this Convention shall be deposited with the Secretary-General</p><p>of the United Nations, who shall transmit certified true copies to each of the countries and Contracting Parties</p><p>mentioned in Article 33, paragraphs l to 2 bis.</p><p>IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the undersigned, being duly authorized thereto, have signed this</p><p>Convention.</p><p>DONE at Geneva, this eighteenth day of May one thousand nine hundred and fifty-six, in a single</p><p>copy in the English and French languages, each text being equally authentic.</p><p>_______________</p></div></div>
26	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Dispute Settlement in the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/customes-conventions/dispute-settlement-in-the-un-convention-on-the-law-of-the-sea/attachment/21214300_vorw_1/" rel="attachment wp-att-6278">Dispute Settlement in the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea</a>(full text pdf file)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea is one of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">most important constitutive instruments in international law. Not</p><p style="text-align: justify;">only does this treaty regulate the uses of the world’s largest resource,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">but it also contains a mandatory dispute settlement system — an</p><p style="text-align: justify;">unusual phenomenon in international law. While some scholars have</p><p style="text-align: justify;">lauded this development as a significant achievement, others have</p><p style="text-align: justify;">been highly skeptical of its comprehensiveness and effectiveness. This</p><p style="text-align: justify;">book explores whether a compulsory dispute settlement mechanism is</p><p style="text-align: justify;">necessary for the regulation of the oceans under the Convention. The</p><p style="text-align: justify;">requisite role of dispute settlement in the Convention is determined</p><p style="text-align: justify;">through an assessment of its relationship to the substantive</p><p style="text-align: justify;">provisions. Klein firstly describes the dispute settlement procedure in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the Convention. She then takes each of the issue areas subject to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">limitations or exceptions to compulsory procedures entailing binding</p><p style="text-align: justify;">decisions, and analyzes the inter-relationship between the substantive</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and procedural rules.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">natalie klein is a Lecturer at Macquarie University in Sydney,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Australia. She obtained her law degree from the University of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Adelaide, where she went on to teach international law. She</p><p style="text-align: justify;">completed her Doctorate at Yale Law School in 2003. Klein was</p><p style="text-align: justify;">recently an Associate at the New York office of Debevoise and Plimpton</p><p style="text-align: justify;">LLP, where she practiced in international litigation and arbitration.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Klein has also worked as counsel to the Government of Eritrea on the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Eritrea/Yemen maritime boundary arbitration and the Eritrea/Ethiopia</p><p style="text-align: justify;">boundary dispute, and as a consultant in the Codification Division of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the Office of Legal Affairs at the United Nations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">© Cambridge University Press www.cambridge.org</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Cambridge University Press</p><p style="text-align: justify;">0521835208 – Dispute Settlement in the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Natalie Klein</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Frontmatter</p><p style="text-align: justify;">More information</p><p style="text-align: justify;">cambridge studies in international and comparative law</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Established in 1946, this series produces high quality scholarship in the fields</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of public and private international law and comparative law. Although these</p><p style="text-align: justify;">are distinct legal subdisciplines, developments since 1946 confirm their</p><p style="text-align: justify;">interrelation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Comparative law is increasingly used as a tool in the making of law at</p><p style="text-align: justify;">national, regional, and international levels. Private international law is now</p><p style="text-align: justify;">often affected by international conventions, and the issues faced by classical</p><p style="text-align: justify;">conflicts rules are frequently dealt with by substantive harmonisation of law</p><p style="text-align: justify;">under international auspices. Mixed international arbitrations, especially those</p><p style="text-align: justify;">involving state economic activity, raise mixed questions of public and private</p><p style="text-align: justify;">international law, while in many fields (such as the protection of human rights</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and democratic standards, investment guarantees and international criminal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">law) international and national systems interact. National constitutional</p><p style="text-align: justify;">arrangements relating to ‘foreign affairs,’ and to the implementation of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">international norms, are a focus of attention.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The Board welcomes works of a theoretical or interdisciplinary character,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and those focusing on the new approaches to international or comparative law</p><p style="text-align: justify;">or conflicts of law. Studies of particular institutions or problems are equally</p><p style="text-align: justify;">welcome, as are translations of the best work published in other languages.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>General Editors </em>James Crawford SC FBA</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Whewell Professor of International Law, Faculty of Law, and</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Director, Lauterpacht Research Centre for International Law,</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>University</em><em> of </em><em>Cambridge</em><em> </em></p><p style="text-align: justify;">John S. justify;">under the supervision of Professor Michael Reisman. His advice and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">guidance throughout this project have been invaluable and I am very</p><p style="text-align: justify;">grateful for all of the time and consideration he has given to my work.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">This work was also significantly improved because of the intellectual</p><p style="text-align: justify;">contributions of Professor Lea Brilmayer and Professor Ruth Wedgwood.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Professor Brilmayer has indelibly influenced my life through our work</p><p style="text-align: justify;">for the Government of Eritrea. To me, she epitomizes what it means to be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">a teacher, scholar, and international lawyer. Professor Wedgwood always</p><p style="text-align: justify;">pushed me to think more critically and to take into account a political</p><p style="text-align: justify;">dynamic that I might well have otherwise overlooked. Most of all, Professors</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Reisman, Brilmayer, and Wedgwood fundamentally changed my</p><p style="text-align: justify;">understanding of public international law and as a result, their instruction</p><p style="text-align: justify;">has greatly enriched my scholarship.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">As a student of international law at the University of Adelaide in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Australia, Professor Hilary Charlesworth, Dr. Judith Gardam, and Gerald</p><p style="text-align: justify;">McGinley first introduced me to the world of international law and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">opened up many possibilities for me. I am particularly grateful for the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">ongoing support and advice of Dr. Gardam.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">This book is based on my dissertation prepared in fulfillment of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">requirements for the Doctor of the Science of Law at Yale Law School. My</p><p style="text-align: justify;">residence at Yale Law School was made possible through the award of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the Howard M. Holtzmann Fellowship in International Arbitration and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">a Lillian Goldman Fellowship. 27	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">EUROPEAN CONVENTION ON CUSTOMS TREATMENT OF PALLETS USED IN INTERNATIONAL TRANSPORT Done at Geneva on 9 December 1960</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/customes-conventions/european-convention-on-customs-treatment-of-pallets-used-in-international-transport-done-at-geneva-on-9-december-1960/attachment/88522420_pallette/" rel="attachment wp-att-6282">EUROPEAN CONVENTION ON CUSTOMS TREATMENT OF PALLETS USED IN INTERNATIONAL TRANSPORT Done at Geneva on 9 December 1960</a></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">EUROPEAN CONVENTION ON CUSTOMS TREATMENT OF PALLETS USED IN INTERNATIONAL TRANSPORT THE CONTRACTING PARTIES,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOTING the extension of the use of pallets in international transport, resulting in particular from the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">pooling of pallets,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">DESIRING, as a means of facilitating international transport and reducing its cost, to encourage this</p><p style="text-align: justify;">extension,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">HAVE AGREED as follows:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER I – GENERAL PROVISIONS</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. For the purposes of the present Convention,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the term “import duties and import taxes” shall mean not only Customs duties but also all</p><p style="text-align: justify;">duties and taxes whatsoever chargeable by reason of importation;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the term “pallet” shall mean a device on the deck of which a quantity of goods can be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">assembled to form a unit load for the purpose of transporting it, or of handling or stacking it with the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">assistance of mechanical appliances. This device is made up of two decks separated by bearers, or of a single</p><p style="text-align: justify;">deck supported by feet; its overall height is reduced to the minimum compatible with handling by fork lift</p><p style="text-align: justify;">trucks and pallet trucks; it may or may not have a superstructure;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) the term “persons” shall mean both natural and legal persons.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The present Convention shall apply to pallets imported into the territory of a Contracting Party from</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the territory of another Contracting Party.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 2</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Each Contracting Party shall grant admission, without payment of import duties and import taxes,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and free of import prohibitions or restrictions, to pallets on condition</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) that they have been previously exported or that they will be subsequently re-exported, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) that an equal number of pallets of the same type and substantially the same value have been</p><p style="text-align: justify;">previously exported or will be subsequently exported.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Subject to the provisions of article 3 of the present Convention, the procedure for the admission of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">pallets as provided for in paragraph 1 of this article shall be determined by the regulations of each of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Contracting Parties. These regulations, in particular, may include provisions for preventing the permanent</p><p style="text-align: justify;">importation, free of import duties and import taxes, of a number of pallets greater than the number exported</p><p style="text-align: justify;">or to be exported.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Each Contracting Party shall endeavour to make the formalities as simple as possible and in particular</p><p style="text-align: justify;">not to require a security in respect of import duties and import taxes.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 3</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Each Contracting Party shall apply the provisions of article 2, paragraph 1, of the present Convention,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">without requiring in respect of importation or exportation either the production of a Customs document or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">security in respect of import duties and import taxes, to pallets pooled under an agreement by which the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">parties thereto:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) exchange among themselves, from country to country, pallets of one and the same type in the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">course of operations involving the international transport of goods,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) keep accounts, for each type of pallet, showing the number of pallets so exchanged from</p><p style="text-align: justify;">country to country, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) undertake to deliver to one another within a specified period the number of pallets of each</p><p style="text-align: justify;">type necessary to offset at regular intervals, on a bilateral or multilateral basis, the outstanding balances of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the accounts so kept.2. The provisions of paragraph 1 of this article shall be applicable only if:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) pallets bear a marking conforming to that laid down in the pooling agreement;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the pooling agreement has been communicated to the Customs administrations of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Contracting Parties concerned and these administrations have approved it, being satisfied that the types of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">pallet are sufficiently well defined and that the due and proper implementation of the agreement is adequately</p><p style="text-align: justify;">ensured.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 4</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Each of the Contracting Parties reserves the right to levy the internal duties and taxes and the import</p><p style="text-align: justify;">duties and import taxes, if any, chargeable in its country in respect of pallets purchased, or subject to a similar</p><p style="text-align: justify;">contract entered into by persons resident or established in its territory. Each of the Contracting Parties</p><p style="text-align: justify;">reserves its right, in addition, to refuse in respect of pallets exported under the provisions of this Convention</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the refund of duties or taxes paid or the granting, wholly or in part, of such other benefits as may be provided</p><p style="text-align: justify;">for in the event of exportation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 5</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The present Convention shall not prevent the granting in respect of importation and exportation of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">pallets of facilities greater than those provided therein.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER II – FINAL PROVISIONS</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 6</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Countries members of the Economic Commission for Europe and countries admitted to the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Commission in a consultative capacity under paragraph 8 of the Commission’s terms of reference may</p><p style="text-align: justify;">become Contracting Parties to the present Convention –</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) by signing it;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) by ratifying it after signing it subject to ratification; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) by acceding to it.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Countries which may participate in certain activities of the Economic Commission for Europe in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">accordance with paragraph 11 of the Commission’s terms of reference may become Contracting Parties to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the present Convention by acceding to it after its entry into force.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. The present Convention shall be open for signature until 15 March 1961 inclusive. Thereafter, it shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">be open for accession.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. Ratification or accession shall be effected by the deposit of an instrument with the Secretary-General</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of the United Nations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 7</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. The present Convention shall come into force on the ninetieth day after five of the countries referred</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to in article 6, paragraph 1, thereof have signed it without reservation of ratification or have deposited their</p><p style="text-align: justify;">instruments of ratification or accession.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. With respect to any country which ratifies or accedes to this Convention after five countries have</p><p style="text-align: justify;">signed it without reservation of ratification or have deposited their instruments of ratification or accession,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the present Convention shall enter into force on the ninetieth day after the said country has deposited its</p><p style="text-align: justify;">instrument of ratification or accession.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 8</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Any Contracting Party may denounce the present Convention by giving notice of denunciation to the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Secretary-General of the United Nations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The denunciation shall take effect fifteen months after the date on which the Secretary-General</p><p style="text-align: justify;">received the notification of denunciation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 9</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The present Convention shall cease to have effect if, for any period of twelve consecutive months after</p><p style="text-align: justify;">its entry into force, the number of Contracting Parties is less than five.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 10</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Any country may, at the time of signing the present Convention without reservation of ratification</p><p style="text-align: justify;">or of depositing its instrument of ratification or accession or at any time thereafter, declare by notification</p><p style="text-align: justify;">addressed to the Secretary-General of the United Nations that the present Convention shall be applicable to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">all or any of the territories for the international relations of which it is responsible. The present Convention</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be applicable to the territory or territories named in the notification as from the ninetieth day after</p><p style="text-align: justify;">receipt of the notification by the Secretary-General or, if on that day the present Convention has not yet</p><p style="text-align: justify;">entered into force, as from the date of its entry into force.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Any country, which has made a declaration under the preceding paragraph making the present</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention applicable to a territory for whose international relations it is responsible, may denounce the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">present Convention separately in respect of that territory, in accordance with the provisions of article 8</p><p style="text-align: justify;">thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 11</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Any dispute between two or more Contracting Parties concerning the interpretation or application of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the present Convention shall, so far as possible, be settled by negotiation between them.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Any dispute which is not settled by negotiation shall be submitted to arbitration if any one of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Contracting Parties concerned in the dispute so requests and shall be referred accordingly to one or more</p><p style="text-align: justify;">arbitrators selected by agreement between the Parties in dispute. If within three months from the date of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">request for arbitration the Parties in dispute are unable to agree on the selection of an arbitrator or arbitrators,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">any of those Parties may request the Secretary-General of the United Nations to nominate a single arbitrator</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to whom the dispute shall be referred for decision.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. The decision of the arbitrator or arbitrators appointed under the preceding paragraph shall be binding</p><p style="text-align: justify;">on the Contracting Parties in dispute.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 12</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Any country may, at the time of signing, ratifying or acceding to the present Convention, declare that</p><p style="text-align: justify;">it does not consider itself bound by paragraphs 2 and 3 of article 11 of the present Convention. The other</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Contracting Parties shall not be bound by these paragraphs in respect of any Contracting Party which has</p><p style="text-align: justify;">entered such a reservation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Any Contracting Party which has entered a reservation as provided for in paragraph 1 of this article</p><p style="text-align: justify;">may at any time withdraw such reservation by notifying the Secretary-General.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Apart from the reservation provided for in paragraph 1 of this article, no reservation to the present</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention shall be permitted.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 13</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. After the present Convention has been in force for three years, any Contracting Party may, by</p><p style="text-align: justify;">notification to the Secretary-General of the United Nations, request that a conference be convened for the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">purpose of reviewing the present Convention. The Secretary-General shall notify all Contracting Parties of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the request and a review conference shall be convened by the Secretary-General if, within a period of four</p><p style="text-align: justify;">months from the date of the notification by the Secretary-General, not less than one-third of the Contracting</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Parties signify their assent to the request.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. If a conference is convened in accordance with the preceding paragraph, the Secretary-General shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">notify all the Contracting Parties and invite them to submit, within a period of three months, such proposals</p><p style="text-align: justify;">as they wish the conference to consider. The Secretary-General shall circulate to all Contracting Parties the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">provisional agenda for the conference, together with the text of such proposals, at least three months before</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the date on which the conference is to meet.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. The Secretary-General shall invite to any conference convened in accordance with this article all the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">countries referred to in article 6, paragraph 1, of the present Convention and countries which have become</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Contracting Parties under the said article 6, paragraph 2.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 14</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Any Contracting Party may propose one or more amendments to the present Convention. The text</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of any proposed amendment shall be communicated to the Secretary-General of the United Nations, who shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">communicate it to all Contracting Parties and inform all the other countries referred to in article 6, paragraph</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1, of this Convention.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Within a period of six months from the date on which the proposed amendment is communicated by</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the Secretary-General, any Contracting Party may inform the Secretary-General –</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) that it has an objection to the amendment proposed, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) that, although it intends to accept the proposal, the conditions necessary for such acceptance</p><p style="text-align: justify;">are not yet fulfilled in its country.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. If a Contracting Party sends the Secretary-General a communication such as is provided for in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">paragraph 2 (b), it may, so long as it has not notified the Secretary-General of its acceptance of the proposed</p><p style="text-align: justify;">amendment, submit an objection to the proposed amendment within a period of 9 months following the expiry</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of the six-month period from its initial communication.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. If an objection to the proposed amendment is stated in accordance with the terms of paragraphs 2 and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 of this article, the amendment shall be deemed not to have been accepted and shall be of no effect.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. If no objection to the proposed amendment in accordance with paragraphs 2 and 3 of the present</p><p style="text-align: justify;">article has been stated, the amendment shall be deemed to have been accepted as from the date specified</p><p style="text-align: justify;">below:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) if no Contracting Party has sent a communication to the Secretary-General in accordance with</p><p style="text-align: justify;">paragraph 2 (b) of this article, on the expiry of the period of six months referred to in that paragraph;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) if any Contracting Party has sent a communication to the Secretary-General in accordance</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8</p><p style="text-align: justify;">with paragraph 2 (b) of this article, on the earlier of the following two dates:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">– the date by which all the Contracting Parties which sent such communications have notified</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the Secretary-General of their acceptance of the proposal, subject to the proviso that, if all</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the acceptances were notified before the expiry of the period of six months referred to in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">paragraph 2, this date shall be taken to be the date of expiry of the said six-month period;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">– the date of expiry of the nine-month period referred to in paragraph 3 of this article.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. Any amendment deemed to be accepted shall enter into force six months after the date on which it</p><p style="text-align: justify;">was deemed to be accepted.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. The Secretary-General shall, as soon as possible, notify all Contracting Parties whether an objection</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to the proposed amendment has been stated in accordance with paragraph 2 (a) of this article and whether one</p><p style="text-align: justify;">or more Contracting Parties have sent him a communication in accordance with paragraph 2 (b) of this</p><p style="text-align: justify;">article. If one or more Contracting Parties have sent him such a communication, he shall subsequently inform</p><p style="text-align: justify;">all the Contracting Parties whether the Contracting Party or Parties which have sent such a communication</p><p style="text-align: justify;">raise an objection to the proposed amendment or accept it.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 15</p><p style="text-align: justify;">In addition to the notifications provided for in articles 13 and 14 of the present Convention, the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Secretary-General of the United Nations shall notify the countries referred to in article 6, paragraph 1, of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">present Convention and the countries which have become Contracting Parties under article 6, paragraph 2,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of the present Convention of: –</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) signatures, ratifications and accessions under article 6;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the dates of entry into force of the present Convention, in accordance with article 7;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) denunciations under article 8;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) the termination of the present Convention in accordance with article 9;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) notifications received in accordance with article 10;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) declarations and notifications received in accordance with article 12, paragraphs 1 and 2;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) the entry into force of any amendment in accordance with article 14.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 16</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9</p><p style="text-align: justify;">After 15 March 1961 the original of the present Convention shall be deposited with the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Secretary-General of the United Nations, who shall transmit certified true copies to each of the countries</p><p style="text-align: justify;">mentioned in article 6, paragraphs 1 and 2, of the present Convention.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the undersigned, being duly authorized thereto, have signed the present</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">DONE at Geneva, this ninth day of December one thousand nine hundred and sixty, in a single copy,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">in the English and French languages, the two texts being equally authentic.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p></div></div>
