29	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Geneva Convention Additional Protocol I</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p><strong>ADVISORY SERVICE</strong> ON INTERNATIONAL HUMANITARIAN LAW ____________________________________ <strong>1954 Convention on the</strong> <strong>Protection of Cultural Property</strong> <strong>in the Event of Armed Conflict</strong> <strong>and its Protocols</strong> Military operations have often resulted in the destruction of irreplaceable cultural property, a loss not only to the country of origin but also to the cultural heritage of all people. Recognizing the significance of this loss, the international community adopted the 1954 Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict (CCP). A Protocol dealing with cultural property during times of occupation (P1) was adopted at the same time as the 1954 Convention. Although the 1954 Convention strengthens protection for cultural property, its provisions have not been implemented consistently. To address thisproblem, a second Protocol to the 1954 Convention (P2) was adopted on 26 March 1999. In addition to these instruments, the 1977 Protocols additional to the Geneva Conventions include provisions protecting cultural property (Protocol I, Art. 38, 53 and 85, and Protocol II, Art. 16). Ratification of each of the above-mentioned instruments is essential to preserving objects precious to all humanity. <strong>Cultural Property</strong> Cultural property is any movable or immovable property of great importance to the cultural heritage of all people, such as monuments of architecture or history, archaeological sites, works of art, books or any building whose main and effectivepurpose is to contain cultural property (CCP, Art. 1). <strong>Identification</strong> Cultural property should be identified with the emblem of the 1954 Convention, pictured above (CCP, Art. 16, 17). <strong>Systems of Protection</strong> Parties to the Convention must protect all cultural property, whether their own or that situated in the territory of other States Parties. The various systems that provide protection for cultural property are described below: <strong><em>General Protection</em></strong> <em>All </em>cultural property must be afforded, at minimum, “general protection”, as described in the Convention. <em>Protection:</em> Parties to the Convention must safeguard their own cultural property against foreseeable effects of armed conflict (CCP, Art. 3). _ States Parties must also respect all cultural property by the following: (1) not using cultural property for any purpose likely to expose it to destruction or damage in the event of armed conflict; (2) not directing any act of hostility against cultural property (CCP, Art. 4). <em>Exception</em>: _ The obligation to respect a l l cultural property, described above, may be waived on the basis of “imperative military necessity” (CCP, Art. 4). _ This waiver may be invoked: (1) to <em>use </em>cultural property for purposes likely to endanger it, only if there is no feasible alternative available to obtain a similar military advantage. (P2, Art. 6); (2) to <em>attack </em>cultural property, only when that property has, by its function, been made into a military objective and there is no feasible alternative available to obtain a similar military advantage. Effective advance warning must be given, circumstances permitting (P2, Art. 6). <em>Precautions:</em> _ Parties to the Convention must, to the maximum extent feasible, either move cultural property away from military objectives or avoid placing military objectives near such property (P2, Art. 8). _ Parties to a conflict must do everything feasible to protect cultural property, including refraining from an attack that may cause incidental damage (P2, Art. 7). International Committee of the Red Cross <em>Occupied Territory</em> _ Under the Convention, States Parties occupying foreign territory must preserve cultural property in that territory (CCP, Art. 5). _ The 1954 Protocol requires States Parties occupying territory during armed conflict to prevent the exportation of cultural property from that territory (P1, Art. 1). However, if cultural property is exported, States Parties must return it atthe close of the hostilities (P1,Art. 3). <strong><em>Special protection</em></strong> The 1954 Convention provides a system of “special protection”, which resulted in only limited success. In response to the limitations of the 1954 system, the 1999 Protocol introduces a new system of <em>“</em>enhanced protection” <em>(see below</em>). If property has been granted both special and enhanced protection, only enhanced protection applies (P2, Art. 4). <strong><em>Enhanced protection</em></strong> The 1999 Protocol provides “enhanced protection” of certain cultural objects. <em>Criteria for Protection:</em> _ To be granted “enhanced protection”, cultural property must meet the following three criteria (P2, Art. 10): (1) it is cultural heritage of the greatest importance to humanity; (2) it is protected by domestic measures that recognize its cultural and historical value and ensure the highestlevel of protection; (3) it is not used for military purposes or to shield military sites, and the Party which has control over the property has formally declared that it will not be so used. _ Cultural property granted enhanced protection by the Committee for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict is placed on the “List of Cultural Property under Enhanced Protection” (P2, Art.11). <em>Protection:</em> _ Parties holding property included on the List must not <em>use </em>such property or its immediate surroundings in support of military action (P2, Art. 12). There is no exception to this obligation. _ Parties to the Convention must refrain from <em>attack </em>against property on the List (P2, Art.12). <em>Exception:</em> _ The obligation not to <em>attack </em>property on the List does not apply if such property has, by virtue of its use, become a military objective. Attack is permitted only if it is the only feasible means of terminating such use and if precautions are taken to minimize damage to the property. Effective advance warning must be given, circumstances permitting (P2,Art. 13). <strong>Criminal Responsibility and Jurisdiction</strong> Parties to the Convention must take all necessary steps to prosecute and impose sanctions on all persons who violate its provisions (CCP, Art.28). States party to the 1999 Protocol must ensure that the following are offences under domestic law (P2,Art. 15): (1) making cultural property under enhanced protection the object of attack; (2) using cultural property underenhanced protection or its immediate surroundings in support of military action; (3) extensive destruction or appropriation of protected cultural property; (4) making protected cultural property the object of attack; ( 5) theft, pillage or misappropriation of, or acts of vandalism directed against, protected cultural property. Each State Party must ensure that its legislation establishes jurisdiction when the offence is committed in its territory, when the alleged offender is a national of that State, and — in relation to the first three offences — when the offence is committed abroad by a non-national. <strong>Dissemination</strong> Parties to the 1954 Convention and its Protocols must disseminate the treaty provisions as widely as possible, seeking to strengthen appreciation and respect for cultural property among the general population (CCP, Art. 25; P2, Art. 30). Particular effort should be taken to disseminate information among the armed forces and personnel engaged in the protection of cultural property. <em>09/2002</em> International Committee of the Red Cross</p></div></div>
30	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">GENEVA CONVENTION (IV) RELATIVE TO THE  PROTECTION OF CIVILIAN PERSONS IN TIME OF  WAR (GENEVA CONVENTION IV)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/human-rights-conventions/geneva-convention-iv-relative-to-the-protection-of-civilian-persons-in-time-of-war-geneva-convention-iv/attachment/geneva-convention-4/" rel="attachment wp-att-6124">Geneva convention 4</a></p><p><strong>(</strong><strong>GENEVA</strong><strong> CONVENTION IV)</strong></p><p>Signed at Geneva, 12 August 1949</p><p>The undersigned Plenipotentiaries of the Governments represented at the Diplomatic Conference held at Geneva from 21 April to 12 August 1949, for the purpose of establishing a Convention for the Protection of Civilians in Time of War, have agreed as follows:</p><p><strong>PART I</strong></p><p><strong><em>GENERAL PROVISIONS</em></strong></p><p><strong>Article 1</strong></p><p>The High Contracting Parties undertake to respect and to ensure respect for the present Convention in all circumstances.</p><p><strong>Article 2</strong></p><p>In addition to the provisions which shall beimplemented in peace-time, the present Convention shall apply to all cases of declared war or of any other armed conflict which may arise between two or more of the High Contracting Parties, even if the state of war is not recognized by one of them.</p><p>The Convention shall also apply to all cases of partial or total occupation of the territory of a High Contracting Party, even if the said occupation meets with no armed resistance. Although one of the Powers in conflict may not bea party to the present Convention, the Powers who are parties thereto shall remain bound by it in their mutual relations. They shall furthermore be bound by the Convention in relation to the said Power, if the latter accepts and applies the provision thereof.</p><p><strong>Article 3</strong></p><p>In the case of armed conflict not of an international character occurring in the territory of one of the High Contracting Parties, each Party to the conflict shall be bound to apply, as a minimum, the following provisions:</p><p>(1) Persons taking no active part in the hostilities, including members of armed forces who have laid down their arms and those placed hors de combat by sickness, wounds, detention, or any other cause, shall in all circumstances be treated humanely, without any adverse distinction founded on race, colour, religion or faith, sex, birth or wealth, or any other similar criteria.</p><p>To this end the following acts are and shall remain prohibited at any time and in any place whatsoever with respect to the above-mentioned</p><p>persons:</p><p>(a) violence to life and person, in particular murder of all kinds, mutilation, cruel treatment and torture;</p><p>(b) taking of hostages;</p><p>(c) outrages upon personal dignity, in particular humiliating and degrading treatment;</p><p>(d) the passing of sentences and the carrying out of executions without previous judgment pronounced by a regularly constituted court, affording all the judicial guarantees which are recognized as indispensable by civilized</p><p>peoples.</p><p>(2) The wounded and sick shall be collected and cared for. An impartial humanitarian body, such as theInternational Committee of the Red Cross, mayoffer its services to the Parties to the conflict.</p><p>The Parties to the conflict should further endeavour to bring into force, by means of special agreements, all or part of the other provisions of the present Convention.</p><p>– 2 –</p><p>(GENEVA CONVENTION IV)</p><p>The application of the preceding provisions shall not affect the legal status of the Parties to the conflict.</p><p><strong>Article 4</strong></p><p>Persons protected by the Convention are those who, at a given moment and in any manner whatsoever, find themselves, in case of a conflict or occupation, in the hands of a Party to the conflict or Occupying Power of which they are not nationals.</p><p>Nationals of a State which is not bound by the Convention are not protected by it. Nationals of a neutral State who find themselves in the territory of a belligerent State, and nationals of a cobelligerent State, shall not be regarded as protected persons while the State of which they are nationals has normal diplomatic representation in the State in whose hands they are.</p><p>The provisions of Part II are, however, wider in application, as defined in Article 13. Persons protected by the Geneva Convention for the Amelioration of the Condition of the Wounded and Sick in Armed Forces in the Field of 12 August 1949, or by the Geneva Convention for the Amelioration of the Condition of Wounded, Sick and Shipwrecked Members of Armed Forces at Sea of 12  August 1949, or by the Geneva Convention relative to the Treatment of Prisoners of War of 12 August 1949, shall not be considered as protected persons within the meaning of the present Convention.</p><p><strong>Article 5</strong></p><p>Where in the territory of a Party to the conflict, the latter is satisfied that an individual protected person is definitely suspected of or engaged in activities hostile to the security of the State, such individual person shall not be entitled to claim such rights and privileges under the presentConvention as would, if exercised in the favour ofsuch individual person, be prejudicial to the security of such State. Where in occupied territory an individual protected person is detained as a spy or saboteur,  or as a person under definite suspicion of activity hostile to the security of the Occupying Power, such person shall, in those cases where absolute military security so r</p></div></div>
31	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">GENEVA CONVENTION RELATIVE TO THE  TREATMENT OF PRISONERS OF WAR OF AUGUST  12, 1949 (GENEVA CONVENTION III)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/human-rights-conventions/geneva-convention-relative-to-the-treatment-of-prisoners-of-war-of-august-12-1949-geneva-convention-iii/attachment/geneva-convention-iii/" rel="attachment wp-att-6127"><strong>G</strong><strong>eneva Convention III</strong></a></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Entry into Force: 21  October 1950</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The undersigned Plenipotentiaries of the Governments represented at the Diplomatic Conference</p><p style="text-align: justify;">held at Geneva from April 21 to August 12, 1949, for the purpose of revising the Convention</p><p style="text-align: justify;">concluded at Geneva on July 27, 1929 relative to the Treatment of Prisoners of War, have agreed as</p><p style="text-align: justify;">follows:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">PART I</p><p style="text-align: justify;">GENERAL PROVISIONS</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The High Contracting Parties undertake to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">respect and to ensure respect for the present</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention in all circumstances.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 2</p><p style="text-align: justify;">In addition to the provisions which shall be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">implemented in peace time, the present</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention shall apply to all cases of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">declared war or of any other armed conflict</p><p style="text-align: justify;">which may arise between two or more of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">High Contracting Parties, even if the state of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">war is not recognized by one of them.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The Convention shall also apply to all cases</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of partial or total occupation of the territory</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of a High Contracting Party, even if the said</p><p style="text-align: justify;">occupation meets with no armed resistance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Although one of the Powers in conflict may</p><p style="text-align: justify;">not be a party to the present Convention, the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Powers who are parties thereto shall remain</p><p style="text-align: justify;">bound by it in their mutual relations. They</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall furthermore be bound by the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention in relation to the said Power, if</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the latter accepts and applies the provisions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 3</p><p style="text-align: justify;">In the case of armed conflict not of an</p><p style="text-align: justify;">international character occurring in the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">territory of one of the High Contracting</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Parties, each Party to the conflict shall be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">bound to apply, as a minimum, the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">following provisions:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(1) Persons taking no active part in the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">hostilities, including members of armed</p><p style="text-align: justify;">forces who have laid down their arms and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">those placed hors de combat by sickness,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">wounds, detention, or any other cause, shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">in all circumstances be treated humanely,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">without any adverse distinction founded on</p><p style="text-align: justify;">race, colour, religion or faith, sex, birth or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">wealth, or any other similar criteria.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">To this end the following acts are and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall remain prohibited at any time and in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">any place whatsoever with respect to the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">above-mentioned persons:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) violence to life and person, in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">particular murder of all kinds, mutilation,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">cruel treatment and torture;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) taking of hostages;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) outrages upon personal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">dignity, in particular, humiliating and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">degrading treatment;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) he passing of sentences and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the carrying out of executions without</p><p style="text-align: justify;">previous judgment pronounced by a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">regularly constituted court affording all the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">judicial guarantees which are recognized as</p><p style="text-align: justify;">indispensable by civilized peoples.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The wounded and sick shall be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">collected and cared for.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An impartial humanitarian body, such as the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">International Committee of the Red Cross,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">may offer its services to the Parties to the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">conflict.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The Parties to the conflict should further</p><p style="text-align: justify;">endeavour to bring into force, by means of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">special agreements, all or part of the other</p><p style="text-align: justify;">provisions of the present Convention.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The application of the preceding provisions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall not affect the legal status of the Parties</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to the conflict.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 4</p><p style="text-align: justify;">A. Prisoners of war, in the sense of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">present Convention, are persons belonging</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to one of the following categories, who have</p><p style="text-align: justify;">fallen into the power of the enemy:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(1) Members of the armed forces of a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Party to the conflict, as well as members of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">militias or volunteer corps forming part of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">such armed forces.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Members of other militias and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">members of other volunteer corps, including</p><p style="text-align: justify;">those of organized resistance movements,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">belonging to a Party to the conflict and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">operating in or outside their own territory,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">even if this territory is occupied, provided</p><p style="text-align: justify;">that such militias or volunteer corps,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">including such organized resistance</p><p style="text-align: justify;">movements, fulfil the following conditions:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) that of being commanded by a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">person responsible for his subordinates;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) that of having a fixed</p><p style="text-align: justify;">distinctive sign recognizable at a distance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) that of carrying arms openly;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) that of conducting their</p><p style="text-align: justify;">operations in accordance with the laws and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">customs of war.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Members of regular armed forces</p><p style="text-align: justify;">who profess allegiance to a government or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">an authority not recognized by the Detaining</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) Persons who accompany the armed</p><p style="text-align: justify;">forces without actually being members</p><p style="text-align: justify;">thereof, such as civilian members of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">military aircraft crews, war correspondents,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">supply contractors, members of labour units</p><p style="text-align: justify;">or of services responsible for the welfare of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the armed forces, provided that they have</p><p style="text-align: justify;">received authorization, from the armed</p><p style="text-align: justify;">forces which they accompany, who shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">provide them for that purpose with an</p><p style="text-align: justify;">identity card similar to the annexed model.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) Members of crews, including</p><p style="text-align: justify;">masters, pilots and apprentices, of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">merchant marine and the crews of civil</p><p style="text-align: justify;">aircraft of the Parties to the conflict, who do</p><p style="text-align: justify;">not benefit by more favourable treatment</p><p style="text-align: justify;">under any other provisions of international</p><p style="text-align: justify;">law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) Inhabitants of a non-occupied</p><p style="text-align: justify;">territory, who on the approach of the enemy</p><p style="text-align: justify;">spontaneously take up arms to resist the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">invading forces, without having had time to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">form themselves into regular armed units,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">provided they carry arms openly and respect</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the laws and customs of war.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">B. The following shall likewise be treated</p><p style="text-align: justify;">as prisoners of war under the present</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(1) Persons belonging, or having</p><p style="text-align: justify;">belonged, to the armed forces of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">occupied country, if the occupying Power</p><p style="text-align: justify;">considers it necessary by reason of such</p><p style="text-align: justify;">allegiance to intern them, even though it has</p><p style="text-align: justify;">originally liberated them while hostilities</p><p style="text-align: justify;">were going on outside the territory it</p><p style="text-align: justify;">occupies, in particular where such persons</p><p style="text-align: justify;">have made an unsuccessful attempt to rejoin</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the armed forces to which they belong and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">which are engaged in combat, or where they</p><p style="text-align: justify;">fail to comply with a summons made to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">them with a view to internment.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The persons belonging to one of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the categories enumerated in the present</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article, who have been received by neutral</p><p style="text-align: justify;">or non-belligerent Powers on their territory</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and whom these Powers are required to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">intern under international law, without</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prejudice to any more favourable treatment</p><p style="text-align: justify;">which these Powers may choose to give and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">with the exception of Articles 8, 10, 15, 30,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">fifth paragraph, 58-67, 92, 126 and, where</p><p style="text-align: justify;">diplomatic relations exist between the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Parties to the conflict and the neutral or nonbelligerent</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power concerned, those Articles</p><p style="text-align: justify;">concerning the Protecting Power. Where</p><p style="text-align: justify;">such diplomatic relations exist, the Parties</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to a conflict on whom these persons depend</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be allowed to perform towards them</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the functions of a Protecting Power as</p><p style="text-align: justify;">provided in the present Convention, without</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prejudice to the functions which these</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Parties normally exercise in conformity with</p><p style="text-align: justify;">diplomatic and consular usage and treaties.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">C. This Article shall in no way affect the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">status of medical personnel and chaplains as</p><p style="text-align: justify;">provided for in Article 33 of the present</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 5</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The present Convention shall apply to the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">persons referred to in Article 4 from the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">time they fall into the power of the enemy</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and until their final release and repatriation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Should any doubt arise as to whether</p><p style="text-align: justify;">persons, having committed a belligerent act</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and having fallen into the hands of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">enemy, belong to any of the categories</p><p style="text-align: justify;">enumerated in Article 4, such persons shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">enjoy the protection of the present</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention until such time as their status</p><p style="text-align: justify;">has been determined by a competent</p><p style="text-align: justify;">tribunal.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">* * *</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 7</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war may in no circumstances</p><p style="text-align: justify;">renounce in part or in entirety the rights</p><p style="text-align: justify;">secured to them by the present Convention,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and by the special agreements referred to in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the foregoing Article, if such there be.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">* * *</p><p style="text-align: justify;">PART II</p><p style="text-align: justify;">GENERAL PROTECTION</p><p style="text-align: justify;">OF PRISONERS OF WAR</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 12</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war are in the hands of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">enemy Power, but not of the individuals or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">military units who have captured them.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Irrespective of the individual responsibilities</p><p style="text-align: justify;">that may exist, the Detaining Power is</p><p style="text-align: justify;">responsible for the treatment given them.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war may only be transferred by</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the Detaining Power to a Power which is a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">party to the Convention and after the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Detaining Power has satisfied itself of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">willingness and ability of such transferee</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power to apply the Convention. When</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners of war are transferred under such</p><p style="text-align: justify;">circumstances, responsibility for the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">application of the Convention rests on the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power accepting them while they are in its</p><p style="text-align: justify;">custody.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Nevertheless, if that Power fails to carry out</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the provisions of the Convention in any</p><p style="text-align: justify;">important respect, the Power by whom the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners of war were transferred shall,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">upon being notified by the Protecting</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power, take effective measures to correct</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the situation or shall request the return of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the prisoners of war. Such requests must be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">complied with.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 13</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war must at all times be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">humanely treated. Any unlawful act or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">omission by the Detaining Power causing</p><p style="text-align: justify;">death or seriously endangering the health of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">a prisoner of war in its custody is</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prohibited, and will be regarded as a serious</p><p style="text-align: justify;">breach of the present Convention. In</p><p style="text-align: justify;">particular, no prisoner of war may be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">subjected to physical mutilation or to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">medical or scientific experiments of any</p><p style="text-align: justify;">kind which are not justified by the medical,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">dental or hospital treatment of the prisoner</p><p style="text-align: justify;">concerned and carried out in his interest.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Likewise, prisoners of war must at all times</p><p style="text-align: justify;">be protected, particularly against acts of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">violence or intimidation and against insults</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and public curiosity.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Measures of reprisal against prisoners of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">war are prohibited.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 14</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war are entitled in all</p><p style="text-align: justify;">circumstances to respect for their persons</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and their honour.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Women shall be treated with all the regard</p><p style="text-align: justify;">due to their sex and shall in all cases benefit</p><p style="text-align: justify;">by treatment as favourable as that granted to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">men.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war shall retain the full civil</p><p style="text-align: justify;">capacity which they enjoyed at the time of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">their capture. The Detaining Power may not</p><p style="text-align: justify;">restrict the exercise, either within or without</p><p style="text-align: justify;">its own territory, of the rights such capacity</p><p style="text-align: justify;">confers except in so far as the captivity</p><p style="text-align: justify;">requires.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 15</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The Power detaining prisoners of war shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">be bound to provide free of charge for their</p><p style="text-align: justify;">maintenance and for the medical attention</p><p style="text-align: justify;">required by their state of health.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 16</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Taking into consideration the provisions of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the present Convention relating to rank and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">sex, and subject to any privileged treatment</p><p style="text-align: justify;">which may be accorded to them by reason</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of their state of health, age or professional</p><p style="text-align: justify;">qualifications, all prisoners of war shall be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">treated alike by the Detaining Power,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">without any adverse distinction based on</p><p style="text-align: justify;">race, nationality, religious belief or political</p><p style="text-align: justify;">opinions, or any other distinction founded</p><p style="text-align: justify;">on similar criteria.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">PART III</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CAPTIVITY</p><p style="text-align: justify;">SECTION I</p><p style="text-align: justify;">BEGINNING OF CAPTIVITY</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 17</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Every prisoner of war, when questioned on</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the subject, is bound to give only his</p><p style="text-align: justify;">surname, first names and rank, date of birth,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and army, regimental, personal or serial</p><p style="text-align: justify;">number, or failing this, equivalent</p><p style="text-align: justify;">information.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">If he wilfully infringes this rule, he may</p><p style="text-align: justify;">render himself liable to a restriction of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">privileges accorded to his rank or status.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Each Party to a conflict is required to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">furnish the persons under its jurisdiction</p><p style="text-align: justify;">who are liable to become prisoners of war,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">with an identity card showing the owner’s</p><p style="text-align: justify;">surname, first names, rank, army,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">regimental, personal or serial number or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">equivalent information, and date of birth.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The identity card may, furthermore, bear the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">signature or the fingerprints, or both, of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">owner, and may bear, as well, any other</p><p style="text-align: justify;">information the Party to the conflict may</p><p style="text-align: justify;">wish to add concerning persons belonging to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">its armed forces. As far as possible the card</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall measure 6.5 x 10 cm. and shall be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">issued in duplicate. The identity card shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">be shown by the prisoner of war upon</p><p style="text-align: justify;">demand, but may in no case be taken away</p><p style="text-align: justify;">from him.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">No physical or mental torture, nor any other</p><p style="text-align: justify;">form of coercion, may be inflicted on</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners of war to secure from them</p><p style="text-align: justify;">information of any kind whatever. Prisoners</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of war who refuse to answer may not be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">threatened, insulted, or exposed to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">unpleasant or disadvantageous treatment of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">any kind.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war who, owing to their</p><p style="text-align: justify;">physical or mental condition, are unable to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">state their identity, shall be handed over to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the medical service. The identity of such</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners shall be established by all possible</p><p style="text-align: justify;">means, subject to the provisions of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">preceding paragraph.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The questioning of prisoners of war shall be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">carried out in a language which they</p><p style="text-align: justify;">understand.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 18</p><p style="text-align: justify;">All effects and articles of personal use,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">except arms, horses, military equipment and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">military documents, shall remain in the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">possession of prisoners of war, likewise</p><p style="text-align: justify;">their metal helmets and gas masks and like</p><p style="text-align: justify;">articles issued for personal protection.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Effects and articles used for their clothing or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">feeding shall likewise remain in their</p><p style="text-align: justify;">possession, even if such effects and articles</p><p style="text-align: justify;">belong to their regulation military</p><p style="text-align: justify;">equipment.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">At no time should prisoners of war be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">without identity documents. The Detaining</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power shall supply such documents to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners of war who possess none.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Badges of rank and nationality, decorations</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and articles having above all a personal or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">sentimental value may not be taken from</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners of war.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Sums of money carried by prisoners of war</p><p style="text-align: justify;">may not be taken away from them except by</p><p style="text-align: justify;">order of an officer, and after the amount and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">particulars of the owner have been recorded</p><p style="text-align: justify;">in a special register and an itemized receipt</p><p style="text-align: justify;">has been given, legibly inscribed with the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">name, rank and unit of the person issuing</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the said receipt. Sums in the currency of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Detaining Power, or which are changed into</p><p style="text-align: justify;">such currency at the prisoner’s request, shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">be placed to the credit of the prisoner’s</p><p style="text-align: justify;">account as provided in Article 64.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The Detaining Power may withdraw articles</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of value from prisoners of war only for</p><p style="text-align: justify;">reasons of security; when such articles are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">withdrawn, the procedure laid down for</p><p style="text-align: justify;">sums of money impounded shall apply.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Such objects, likewise sums taken away in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">any currency other than that of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Detaining Power and the conversion of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">which has not been asked for by the owners,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be kept in the custody of the Detaining</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power and shall be returned in their initial</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shape to prisoners of war at the end of their</p><p style="text-align: justify;">captivity.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 19</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war shall be evacuated, as soon</p><p style="text-align: justify;">as possible after their capture, to camps</p><p style="text-align: justify;">situated in an area far enough from the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">combat zone for them to be out of danger.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Only those prisoners of war who, owing to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">wounds or sickness, would run greater risks</p><p style="text-align: justify;">by being evacuated than by remaining</p><p style="text-align: justify;">where they are, may be temporarily kept</p><p style="text-align: justify;">back in a danger zone.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war shall not be unnecessarily</p><p style="text-align: justify;">exposed to danger while awaiting</p><p style="text-align: justify;">evacuation from a fighting zone.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 20</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The evacuation of prisoners of war shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">always be effected humanely and in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">conditions similar to those for the forces of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the Detaining Power in their changes of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">station.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The Detaining Power shall supply prisoners</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of war who are being evacuated with</p><p style="text-align: justify;">sufficient food and potable water, and with</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the necessary clothing and medical</p><p style="text-align: justify;">attention. The Detaining Power shall take all</p><p style="text-align: justify;">suitable precautions to ensure their safety</p><p style="text-align: justify;">during evacuation, and shall establish as</p><p style="text-align: justify;">soon as possible a list of the prisoners of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">war who are evacuated.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">If prisoners of war must, during evacuation,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">pass through transit camps, their stay in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">such camps shall be as brief as possible.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">SECTION II</p><p style="text-align: justify;">INTERNMENT OF PRISONERS</p><p style="text-align: justify;">OF WAR</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER I</p><p style="text-align: justify;">GENERAL OBSERVATIONS</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 21</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The Detaining Power may subject prisoners</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of war to internment. It may impose on</p><p style="text-align: justify;">them the obligation of not leaving, beyond</p><p style="text-align: justify;">certain limits, the camp where they are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">interned, or if the said camp is fenced in, of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">not going outside its perimeter. Subject to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the provisions of the present Convention</p><p style="text-align: justify;">relative to penal and disciplinary sanctions,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners of war may not be held in close</p><p style="text-align: justify;">confinement except where necessary to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">safeguard their health and then only during</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the continuation of the circumstances which</p><p style="text-align: justify;">make such confinement necessary.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war may be partially or wholly</p><p style="text-align: justify;">released on parole or promise, in so far as is</p><p style="text-align: justify;">allowed by the laws of the Power on which</p><p style="text-align: justify;">they depend. Such measures shall be taken</p><p style="text-align: justify;">particularly in cases where this may</p><p style="text-align: justify;">contribute to the improvement of their state</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of health. No prisoner of war shall be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">compelled to accept liberty on parole or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">promise.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Upon the outbreak of hostilities, each Party</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to the conflict shall notify the adverse Party</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of the laws and regulations allowing or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">forbidding its own nationals to accept</p><p style="text-align: justify;">liberty on parole or promise. Prisoners of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">war who are paroled or who have given</p><p style="text-align: justify;">their promise in conformity with the laws</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and regulations so notified, are bound on</p><p style="text-align: justify;">their personal honour scrupulously to fulfil,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">both towards the Power on which they</p><p style="text-align: justify;">depend and towards the Power which has</p><p style="text-align: justify;">captured them, the engagements of their</p><p style="text-align: justify;">paroles or promises. In such cases, the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power on which they depend is bound</p><p style="text-align: justify;">neither to require nor to accept from them</p><p style="text-align: justify;">any service incompatible with the parole or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">promise given.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 22</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war may be interned only in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">premises located on land and affording</p><p style="text-align: justify;">every guarantee of hygiene and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">healthfulness. Except in particular cases</p><p style="text-align: justify;">which are justified by the interest of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners themselves, they shall not be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">interned in penitentiaries.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war interned in unhealthy areas,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">or where the climate is injurious for them,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be removed as soon as possible to a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">more favourable climate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The Detaining Power shall assemble</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners of war in camps or camp</p><p style="text-align: justify;">compounds according to their nationality,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">language and customs, provided that such</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners shall not be separated from</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners of war belonging to the armed</p><p style="text-align: justify;">forces with which they were serving at the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">time of their capture, except with their</p><p style="text-align: justify;">consent.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 23</p><p style="text-align: justify;">No prisoner of war may at any time be sent</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to, or detained in areas where he may be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">exposed to the fire of the combat zone, nor</p><p style="text-align: justify;">may his presence be used to render certain</p><p style="text-align: justify;">points or areas immune from military</p><p style="text-align: justify;">operations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war shall have shelters against</p><p style="text-align: justify;">air bombardment and other hazards of war,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to the same extent as the local civilian</p><p style="text-align: justify;">population. With the exception of those</p><p style="text-align: justify;">engaged in the protection of their quarters</p><p style="text-align: justify;">against the aforesaid hazards, they may</p><p style="text-align: justify;">enter such shelters as soon as possible after</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the giving of the alarm. Any other protective</p><p style="text-align: justify;">measure taken in favour of the population</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall also apply to them.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Detaining Powers shall give the Powers</p><p style="text-align: justify;">concerned, through the intermediary of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Protecting Powers, all useful information</p><p style="text-align: justify;">regarding the geographical location of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoner of war camps.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Whenever military considerations permit,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoner of war camps shall be indicated in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the day-time by the letters PW or PG,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">placed so as to be clearly visible from the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">air. The Powers concerned may, however,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">agree upon any other system of marking.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Only prisoner of war camps shall be marked</p><p style="text-align: justify;">as such.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 24</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Transit or screening camps of a permanent</p><p style="text-align: justify;">kind shall be fitted out under conditions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">similar to those described in the present</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Section, and the prisoners therein shall have</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the same treatment as in other camps.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER II</p><p style="text-align: justify;">QUARTERS, FOOD AND</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CLOTHING OF PRISONERS</p><p style="text-align: justify;">OF WAR</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 25</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war shall be quartered under</p><p style="text-align: justify;">conditions as favourable as those for the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">forces of the Detaining Power who are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">billeted in the same area. The said</p><p style="text-align: justify;">conditions shall make allowance for the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">habits and customs of the prisoners and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall in no case be prejudicial to their</p><p style="text-align: justify;">health.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The foregoing provisions shall apply in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">particular to the dormitories of prisoners of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">war as regards both total surface and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">minimum cubic space, and the general</p><p style="text-align: justify;">installations, bedding and blankets.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The premises provided for the use of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners of war individually or collectively,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be entirely protected from dampness</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and adequately heated and lighted, in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">particular between dusk and lights out. All</p><p style="text-align: justify;">precautions must be taken against the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">danger of fire.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">In any camps in which women prisoners of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">war, as well as men, are accommodated,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">separate dormitories shall be provided for</p><p style="text-align: justify;">them.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 26</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The basic daily food rations shall be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">sufficient in quantity, quality and variety to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">keep prisoners of war in good health and to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prevent loss of weight or the development</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of nutritional deficiencies. Account shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">also be taken of the habitual diet of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The Detaining Power shall supply prisoners</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of war who work with such additional</p><p style="text-align: justify;">rations as are necessary for the labour on</p><p style="text-align: justify;">which they are employed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Sufficient drinking water shall be supplied</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to prisoners of war. The use of tobacco shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">be permitted.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war shall, as far as possible, be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">associated with the preparation of their</p><p style="text-align: justify;">meals; they may be employed for that</p><p style="text-align: justify;">purpose in the kitchens. Furthermore, they</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be given the means of preparing,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">themselves, the additional food in their</p><p style="text-align: justify;">possession.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Adequate premises shall be provided for</p><p style="text-align: justify;">messing.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Collective disciplinary measures affecting</p><p style="text-align: justify;">food are prohibited.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 27</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Clothing, underwear and footwear shall be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">supplied to prisoners of war in sufficient</p><p style="text-align: justify;">quantities by the Detaining Power, which</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall make allowance for the climate of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">region where the prisoners are detained.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Uniforms of enemy armed forces captured</p><p style="text-align: justify;">by the Detaining Power should, if suitable</p><p style="text-align: justify;">for the climate, be made available to clothe</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners of war.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The regular replacement and repair of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">above articles shall be assured by the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Detaining Power. In addition, prisoners of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">war who work shall receive appropriate</p><p style="text-align: justify;">clothing, wherever the nature of the work</p><p style="text-align: justify;">demands.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 28</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Canteens shall be installed in all camps,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">where prisoners of war may procure</p><p style="text-align: justify;">foodstuffs, soap and tobacco and ordinary</p><p style="text-align: justify;">articles in daily use. The tariff shall never</p><p style="text-align: justify;">be in excess of local market prices.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The profits made by camp canteens shall be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">used for the benefit of the prisoners; a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">special fund shall be created for this</p><p style="text-align: justify;">purpose. The prisoners’ representative shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">have the right to collaborate in the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">management of the canteen and of this fund.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">When a camp is closed down, the credit</p><p style="text-align: justify;">balance of the special fund shall be handed</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to an international welfare organization, to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">be employed for the benefit of prisoners of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">war of the same nationality as those who</p><p style="text-align: justify;">have contributed to the fund. In case of a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">general repatriation, such profits shall be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">kept by the Detaining Power, subject to any</p><p style="text-align: justify;">agreement to the contrary between the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Powers concerned.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER III</p><p style="text-align: justify;">HYGIENE AND MEDICAL</p><p style="text-align: justify;">ATTENTION</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 29</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The Detaining Power shall be bound to take</p><p style="text-align: justify;">all sanitary measures necessary to ensure the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">cleanliness and healthfulness of camps and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to prevent epidemics.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war shall have for their use, day</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and night, conveniences which conform to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the rules of hygiene and are maintained in a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">constant state of cleanliness. In any camps</p><p style="text-align: justify;">in which women prisoners of war are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">accommodated, separate conveniences shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">be provided for them.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Also, apart from the baths and showers with</p><p style="text-align: justify;">which the camps shall be furnished</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners of war shall be provided with</p><p style="text-align: justify;">sufficient water and soap for their personal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">toilet and for washing their personal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">laundry; the necessary installations,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">facilities and time shall be granted them for</p><p style="text-align: justify;">that purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 30</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Every camp shall have an adequate</p><p style="text-align: justify;">infirmary where prisoners of war may have</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the attention they require, as well as</p><p style="text-align: justify;">appropriate diet. Isolation wards shall, if</p><p style="text-align: justify;">necessary, be set aside for cases of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">contagious or mental disease.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war suffering from serious</p><p style="text-align: justify;">disease, or whose condition necessitates</p><p style="text-align: justify;">special treatment, a surgical operation or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">hospital care, must be admitted to any</p><p style="text-align: justify;">military or civilian medical unit where such</p><p style="text-align: justify;">treatment can be given, even if their</p><p style="text-align: justify;">repatriation is contemplated in the near</p><p style="text-align: justify;">future. Special facilities shall be afforded for</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the care to be given to the disabled, in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">particular to the blind, and for their.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">rehabilitation, pending repatriation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war shall have the attention,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">preferably, of medical personnel of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power on which they depend and, if</p><p style="text-align: justify;">possible, of their nationality.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war may not be prevented from</p><p style="text-align: justify;">presenting themselves to the medical</p><p style="text-align: justify;">authorities for examination. The detaining</p><p style="text-align: justify;">authorities shall, upon request, issue to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">every prisoner who has undergone</p><p style="text-align: justify;">treatment, an official certificate indicating</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the nature of his illness or injury, and the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">duration and kind of treatment received. A</p><p style="text-align: justify;">duplicate of this certificate shall be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">forwarded to the Central Prisoners of War</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Agency.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The costs of treatment, including those of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">any apparatus necessary for the maintenance</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of prisoners of war in good health,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">particularly dentures and other artificial</p><p style="text-align: justify;">appliances, and spectacles, shall be borne by</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the Detaining Power.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 31</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Medical inspections of prisoners of war</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be held at least once a month. They</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall include the checking and the recording</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of the weight of each prisoner of war.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Their purpose shall be, in particular, to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">supervise the general state of health,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">nutrition and cleanliness of prisoners and to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">detect contagious diseases, especially</p><p style="text-align: justify;">tuberculosis, malaria and venereal disease.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">For this purpose the most efficient methods</p><p style="text-align: justify;">available shall be employed, e.g. periodic</p><p style="text-align: justify;">mass miniature radiography for the early</p><p style="text-align: justify;">detection of tuberculosis.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 32</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war who, though not attached</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to the medical service of their armed forces,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">are physicians, surgeons, dentists, nurses or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">medical orderlies, may be required by the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Detaining Power to exercise their medical</p><p style="text-align: justify;">functions in the interests of prisoners of war</p><p style="text-align: justify;">dependent on the same Power. In that case</p><p style="text-align: justify;">they shall continue to be prisoners of war,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">but shall receive the same treatment as</p><p style="text-align: justify;">corresponding medical personnel retained</p><p style="text-align: justify;">by the Detaining Power. They shall be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">exempted from any other work under</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 49.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">* * *</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER V</p><p style="text-align: justify;">RELIGIOUS, INTELLECTUAL</p><p style="text-align: justify;">AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITIES</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 34</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war shall enjoy complete</p><p style="text-align: justify;">latitude in the exercise of their religious</p><p style="text-align: justify;">duties, including attendance at the service of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">their faith, on condition that they comply</p><p style="text-align: justify;">with the disciplinary routine prescribed by</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the military authorities.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Adequate premises shall be provided where</p><p style="text-align: justify;">religious services may be held.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">* * *</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 38</p><p style="text-align: justify;">While respecting the individual preferences</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of every prisoner, the Detaining Power shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">encourage the practice of intellectual,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">educational, and recreational pursuits, sports</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and games amongst prisoners, and shall take</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the measures necessary to ensure the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">exercise thereof by providing them with</p><p style="text-align: justify;">adequate premises and necessary equipment.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners shall have opportunities for taking</p><p style="text-align: justify;">physical exercise, including sports and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">games, and for being out of doors.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Sufficient open spaces shall be provided for</p><p style="text-align: justify;">this purpose in all camps.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER VI</p><p style="text-align: justify;">DISCIPLINE</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 39</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Every prisoner of war camp shall be put</p><p style="text-align: justify;">under the immediate authority of a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">responsible commissioned officer belonging</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to the regular armed forces of the Detaining</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power. Such officer shall have in his</p><p style="text-align: justify;">possession a copy of the present</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention; he shall ensure that its</p><p style="text-align: justify;">provisions are known to the camp staff and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the guard and shall be responsible, under the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">direction of his government, for its</p><p style="text-align: justify;">application.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war, with the exception of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">officers, must salute and show to all officers</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of the Detaining Power the external marks</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of respect provided for by the regulations</p><p style="text-align: justify;">applying in their own forces.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Officer prisoners of war are bound to salute</p><p style="text-align: justify;">only officers of a higher rank of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Detaining Power; they must, however,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">salute the camp commander regardless of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">his rank.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 40</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The wearing of badges of rank and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">nationality, as well as of decorations, shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">be permitted.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 41</p><p style="text-align: justify;">In every camp the text of the present</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention and its Annexes and the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">contents of any special agreement provided</p><p style="text-align: justify;">for in Article 6, shall be posted, in the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners’ own language, in places where all</p><p style="text-align: justify;">may read them. Copies shall be supplied, on</p><p style="text-align: justify;">request, to the prisoners who cannot have</p><p style="text-align: justify;">access to the copy which has been posted.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Regulations, orders, notices and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">publications of every kind relating to the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">conduct of prisoners of war shall be issued</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to them in a language which they</p><p style="text-align: justify;">understand. Such regulations, orders and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">publications shall be posted in the manner</p><p style="text-align: justify;">described above and copies shall be handed</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to the prisoners’ representative. Every order</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and command addressed to prisoners of war</p><p style="text-align: justify;">individually must likewise be given in a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">language which they understand.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 42</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The use of weapons against prisoners of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">war, especially against those who are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">escaping or attempting to escape, shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">constitute an extreme measure, which shall</p><p style="text-align: justify;">always be preceded by warnings appropriate</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to the circumstances.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER VII</p><p style="text-align: justify;">RANK OF PRISONERS OF</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WAR</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 43</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Upon the outbreak of hostilities, the Parties</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to the conflict shall communicate to one</p><p style="text-align: justify;">another the titles and ranks of all the persons</p><p style="text-align: justify;">mentioned in Article 4 of the present</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention, in order to ensure equality of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">treatment between prisoners of equivalent</p><p style="text-align: justify;">rank. Titles and ranks which are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">subsequently created shall form the subject</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of similar communications.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The Detaining Power shall recognize</p><p style="text-align: justify;">promotions in rank which have been</p><p style="text-align: justify;">accorded to prisoners of war and which have</p><p style="text-align: justify;">been duly notified by the Power on which</p><p style="text-align: justify;">these prisoners depend.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 44</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Officers and prisoners of equivalent status</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be treated with the regard due to their</p><p style="text-align: justify;">rank and age.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">In order to ensure service in officers’ camps,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">other ranks of the same armed forces who,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">as far as possible, speak the same language,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be assigned in sufficient numbers,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">account being taken of the rank of officers</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and prisoners of equivalent status. Such</p><p style="text-align: justify;">orderlies shall not be required to perform</p><p style="text-align: justify;">any other work.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Supervision of the mess by the officers</p><p style="text-align: justify;">themselves shall be facilitated in every way.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 45</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war other than officers and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners of equivalent status shall be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">treated with the regard due to their rank and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">age.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Supervision of the mess by the prisoners</p><p style="text-align: justify;">themselves shall be facilitated in every way.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">* * *</p><p style="text-align: justify;">SECTION III</p><p style="text-align: justify;">LABOUR OF PRISONERS OF</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WAR</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 49</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The Detaining Power may utilize the labour</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of prisoners of war who are physically fit,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">taking into account their age, sex, rank and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">physical aptitude, and with a view</p><p style="text-align: justify;">particularly to maintaining them in a good</p><p style="text-align: justify;">state of physical and mental health.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Non-commissioned officers who are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners of war shall only be required to do</p><p style="text-align: justify;">supervisory work. Those not so required</p><p style="text-align: justify;">may ask for other suitable work which shall,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">so far as possible, be found for them.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">If officers or persons of equivalent status</p><p style="text-align: justify;">ask for suitable work, it shall be found for</p><p style="text-align: justify;">them, so far as possible, but they may in no</p><p style="text-align: justify;">circumstances be compelled to work.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 50</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Besides work connected with camp</p><p style="text-align: justify;">administration, installation or maintenance,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners of war may be compelled to do</p><p style="text-align: justify;">only such work as is included in the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">following classes:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) agriculture;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) industries connected with the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">production or the extraction of raw</p><p style="text-align: justify;">materials, and manufacturing industries,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">with the exception of metallurgical,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">machinery and chemical industries; public</p><p style="text-align: justify;">works and building operations which have</p><p style="text-align: justify;">no military character or purpose;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) transport and handling of stores</p><p style="text-align: justify;">which are not military in character or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">purpose;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) commercial business, and arts and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">crafts;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) domestic service;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) public utility services having no</p><p style="text-align: justify;">military character or purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Should the above provisions be infringed,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prisoners of war shall be allowed to exercise</p><p style="text-align: justify;">their right of complaint, in conformity with</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 78.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 51</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war must be granted suitable</p><p style="text-align: justify;">working conditions, especially as regards</p><p style="text-align: justify;">accommodation, food, clothing and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">equipment; such conditions shall not be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">inferior to those enjoyed by nationals of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Detaining Power employed in similar work;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">account shall also be taken of climatic</p><p style="text-align: justify;">conditions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The Detaining Power, in utilizing the labour</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of prisoners of war, shall ensure that in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">areas in which such prisoners are employed,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the national legislation concerning the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">protection of labour, and, more particularly,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the regulations for the safety of workers, are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">duly applied.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prisoners of war shall receive training and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">be provided with the means of protection</p><p style="text-align: justify;">suitable to the work they will have to do and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">similar to those accorded to the nationals of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the Detaining Power. Subject to the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">provisions of Article 52, prisoners may be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">submitted to the normal risks run by these</p><p style="text-align: justify;">civilian workers.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Conditions of labour shall in no case be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">rendered more arduous by disciplinary</p><p style="text-align: justify;">measures.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 52</p><p popular-posts="" style="te &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/article&gt;&lt;div class=" widget="" widget_categories=""></p><h3 class="widget-title"><span>Disclaimer:</span></h3><div class="widget-content" style="text-align:justify;"><p>The information contains in this web-site is prepared for educational purpose.
