It sets the stage for an examination</p><p>of how the United Nations human rights treaty system is currently accommodating the</p><p>rights of persons with disabilities.</p><p>Chapter 3 presents the United Nations human rights treaty system and provides the</p><p>bridge between so-called “soft law” and “hard law”. One important operating</p><p>principle of the study is that it is necessary to cross over this bridge and to make full</p><p>use of the human rights treaties in the context of disability.</p><p>Part 2 of the study is an evaluation of the current use of the United Nations human</p><p>rights instruments, providing a detailed analysis of the actual and potential relevance</p><p>of each of the six human rights treaties in the context of disability. This part is</p><p>composed of six chapters corresponding to the six treaties.</p><p>The analysis contained in Part 2 is intended to be part expository and part evaluative.</p><p>The expository dimension involves making the contents of the treaties transparently</p><p>relevant in the context of disability. Each of the rights protected is examined and its</p><p>relevance elucidated. The evaluative part is made up of a series of case studies on how</p><p>the provisions of the respective treaties are applied in general in the context of</p><p>disability.</p><p>Chapter 4 deals with freedom and disability under the ICCPR. This treaty is looked at</p><p>first because the key ethic of the worldwide disability rights movement is freedom and</p><p>participation. In other words, what people with disabilities aspire to most is to have</p><p>access to the same rights – and civic responsibilities – as all other persons. Consistent</p><p>respect for the ICCPR rights of the disabled would not merely protect people with</p><p>disabilities against abuses, but would also be a huge help in breaking down barriers to</p><p>the mainstream. In the sample of States parties’ reports surveyed, many States</p><p>continue to report on disability as a welfare issue and not as a rights issue under the</p><p>ICCPR. The authors found approximately nine individual complaints addressing</p><p>disability issues submitted to the Human Rights Committee under the first Optional</p><p>Protocol to the Covenant. Most were found to be inadmissible. At least one complaint</p><p>has led to very positive case law on the treatment of prisoners with disabilities. In</p><p>essence, the Committee held that it is the duty of States parties to accommodate</p><p>prisoners with special needs. This shows an awareness on the part of the Committee</p><p>that it is not enough to treat all persons the same, but that added allowance (or</p><p>“reasonable accommodation”) may be necessary to make rights “real” for people with</p><p>disabilities. This positive normative development offers great promise for persons</p><p>with disabilities.</p><p>Chapter 5 deals with the ethic of social justice and disability in the context of</p><p>disability. Disability is one of the best areas in which to assert and prove the</p><p>indivisibility and interdependence of civil, political, economic, social and cultural</p><p>rights. Using formal law to break down barriers to the mainstream is necessary but not</p><p>sufficient. People with disabilities must be afforded freedom, but also the means to</p><p>take advantage of it. This can be done by providing relevant social supports and, in</p><p><strong><em>Executive summary ______________________________________________________________ 5</em></strong></p><p>particular, by respecting economic, social and cultural rights. The authors decided to</p><p>place this chapter after the one on the ICCPR in view of the standing danger that</p><p>ICESCR rights will be viewed as being of primary importance in the context of</p><p>disability since they are so obviously connected with social support. In the admirable</p><p>General Comment No. 5 on persons with disabilities adopted by the Committee on</p><p>Economic, Social and Cultural Rights in 1994, the Committee views the rights in the</p><p>Covenant as providing the indispensable means of empowering people with</p><p>disabilities in their own lives and providing ongoing support for a life of active</p><p>participation in society. The right to health (art. 12), for example, is interpreted by the</p><p>Committee as having a direct link to participation in society. In the sample of States</p><p>parties’ reports surveyed, States parties tend not to draw the link between ICESCR</p><p>rights and the achievement of the goals of independence, autonomy and participation.</p><p>Notwithstanding this, General Comment No. 5 remains a landmark and the Covenant</p><p>in general has a hugely important role to play in sensitizing all stakeholders to how</p><p>appropriate social supports and rights can best be used to break down barriers and</p><p>enable people with disabilities to participate in all spheres of life.</p><p>Chapter 6 deals with the important question of protecting people with disabilities</p><p>against torture and cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment under the Convention</p><p>against Torture. This is especially relevant to the many millions of people with</p><p>disabilities who live in institutions or in other types of residential care. Disability</p><p>reinforces the imbalance of power in many such institutions and heightens the</p><p>vulnerability of people with disabilities to abuse. Disability issues tend not to figure</p><p>prominently in the sample of periodic reports surveyed. One individual complaint</p><p>concerning the situation of disabled prisoners that was submitted to the Committee</p><p>against Torture (CAT) was ruled inadmissible on the grounds that domestic remedies</p><p>had not been exhausted.</p><p>Chapter 7 deals with the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of</p><p>Discrimination against Women insofar as it is relevant to women with disabilities.</p><p>General Comment No. 5 refers to a tendency to think of people with disabilities as</p><p>genderless. The Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women</p><p>(CEDAW) has itself adopted General Recommendation No. 18 on women with</p><p>disabilities which requests States parties to include information on women with</p><p>disabilities in their periodic reports with respect to their exercise of several rights</p><p>contained in the Convention. In the sample of periodic reports surveyed there was</p><p>little consistent reporting on the double discrimination experienced by women with</p><p>disabilities.</p><p>Chapter 8 deals with the Convention on the Rights of the Child insofar as it is relevant</p><p>to children with disabilities. The Convention is unique among the human rights</p><p>treaties in that it contains a specific article on disabled children (art. 23). This article</p><p>is, of course, without prejudice to the general applicability of all of the Convention’s</p><p>provisions to children with disabilities. The Committee on the Rights of the Child</p><p>(CRC) has an impressively high level of awareness of disability issues. In 1997, it</p><p>held an important day of general discussion on disabled children which has had a very</p><p>positive impact on how the Committee addresses the situation pertaining to children</p><p>with disabilities. The Committee seems to be well on the way to developing a</p><p>coherent perspective on children with disabilities.</p><p><strong><em>6 ______________________________________________________________ Executive summary</em></strong></p><p>Chapter 9 deals with another sub-group of the disabled, namely disabled persons who</p><p>also belong to racial or other minority groups. While such persons may be</p><p>discriminated against largely on account of their race, the possibility of double</p><p>discrimination cannot be discounted. Indeed, the phenomenon of double</p><p>discrimination on the ground of race and disability was expressly acknowledged at the</p><p>World Conference against Racism, Racial Discrimination, Xenophobia and Related</p><p>Intolerance. Many States parties already include information on discrimination on the</p><p>ground of disability on a regular basis in their periodic reports to CERD, generally by</p><p>providing background information on their general anti-discrimination laws. This</p><p>provides CERD with a useful opportunity for dialogue with States parties on double</p><p>discrimination.</p><p>Part 3 of the study outlines options for the future. It is composed of four chapters.</p><p>Chapter 10 contains the authors’ analysis of a detailed questionnaire that was sent out</p><p>to disability NGOs around the world. There were about 80 responses from</p><p>international NGOs, regional NGOs and domestic NGOs from every part of the</p><p>world. The response rate was good given the time constraints. It had been decided to</p><p>send the questionnaire to disability NGOs and not to traditional human rights NGOs</p><p>in order to gauge whether and how they address the issues as human rights issues and</p><p>what their views on the existing treaty system are.</p><p>An analysis of the responses reveals the extent to which the disability NGOs have</p><p>themselves made the transition to the rights-based perspective on disability. Many of</p><p>the NGOs that responded to the questionnaire stated that they saw themselves</p><p>primarily as human rights NGOs. Many of them use United Nations human rights</p><p>doctrine in their work. Some of them already have some experience of engagement</p><p>with the United Nations human rights treaty system and generally had positive things</p><p>to say about this experience. Most of them felt inhibited by a general lack of material</p><p>and human resources and were deterred by the seeming inaccessibility of information</p><p>about how the human rights treaties work in the context of disability.</p><p>These findings are highly positive. They show how the shift to the human rights</p><p>perspective is being mirrored in the self-understanding of the disability NGOs, who</p><p>are interested in engaging with the United Nations human rights machinery. They also</p><p>reveal factors inhibiting such engagement. The analysis of the findings could usefully</p><p>be complemented in the future by an analysis of how traditional human rights NGOs</p><p>are themselves beginning to absorb disability as a mainstream human rights issue.</p><p>Doubtless a convergence of perspective is now under way.</p><p>Chapter 11 looks at the experiences and views of national human rights institutions</p><p>and factors in their views. It contains the authors’ analysis of a questionnaire sent to</p><p>national institutions and, again, the response rate was good given the time constraints.</p><p>An analysis of the responses reveals that national institutions are in fact acutely aware</p><p>of the human rights perspective on disability. Many of them have already produced</p><p>important studies and reports on the question of the human rights of persons with</p><p>disabilities. Some of these reports have been highly influential in helping to reform</p><p>domestic disability law and policy. All of the respondent national institutions</p><p>expressed a keen interest in the field and also a willingness to step up their activities</p><p>in this regard. This is a highly positive and encouraging finding and augurs well for</p><p>the future.</p><p><strong><em>Executive summary ______________________________________________________________ 7</em></strong></p><p>Chapter 12 sets out a range of observations, comments and recommendations</p><p>designed to enhance the future use of the United Nations human rights system in the</p><p>context of disability. For the sake of completeness, they are addressed to a wide</p><p>variety of stakeholders in the field.</p><p>State practice with respect to periodic reporting on disability is clearly improving.</p><p>This is, no doubt, due to the increasing attention paid to disability and human rights in</p><p>the United Nations system over the past two decades and especially under the</p><p>United Nations Standard Rules on the Equalization of Opportunities for People with</p><p>Disabilities. With respect to the States parties, the authors make three</p><p>recommendations designed to ensure heightened visibility for disability in the treaty</p><p>system. Specifically, they recommend: (a) that States parties step up their efforts to</p><p>report regularly on the situation affecting the rights of persons with disabilities; (b)</p><p>that they consult with disability NGOs when compiling their respective periodic</p><p>reports, it being understood that final responsibility for reports rests exclusively with</p><p>the States parties; and (c) that they consider nominating persons with disabilities for</p><p>membership in the six treaty monitoring bodies.</p><p>The treaty monitoring bodies do an excellent job overall on the issue of disability</p><p>given their limited resources and the obvious need to deal with a wide variety of</p><p>issues and groups. Again, the spirit and language of the United Nations Standard</p><p>Rules has had an impact in this regard. The following recommendations are made in</p><p>the spirit of assisting the treaty monitoring bodies to enhance further their treatment of</p><p>disability issues. Specifically, the authors recommend: (a) that they emulate the good</p><p>practice of the Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights and adopt general</p><p>comments on the nature of State obligations under the respective treaties in the</p><p>context of disability; (b) that they emulate the good practice of the Committee on the</p><p>Rights of the Child by setting aside a thematic day of discussion, or similar occasion,</p><p>on disability; (c) that the list of issues sent to States parties by those treaty monitoring</p><p>bodies that issue such documents more regularly request information on the</p><p>enjoyment of human rights by persons with disabilities, in keeping with the thematic</p><p>priorities to be set in general comments; (d) that the dialogue with States parties</p><p>feature disability issues on a more regular basis; (e) that concluding observations</p><p>contain references to disability, where necessary, in order to identify areas where</p><p>more sustained attention is required and to request more detailed information from</p><p>States parties in subsequent reports; (f) that concluding observations be used more</p><p>regularly to highlight good practice for the benefit of all the stakeholders.</p><p>The Commission on Human Rights and the Office of the High Commissioner for</p><p>Human Rights have demonstrated their engagement with the issue of human rights</p><p>and disability. This is important at the symbolic level, but it is also significant from a</p><p>practical point of view given the pivotal role played by the Office in the overall</p><p>United Nations human rights system. The authors’ recommendations in this regard are</p><p>geared towards enhancing this engagement. Specifically, they recommend that the</p><p>Commission on Human Rights encourage the Office: (a) to make knowledge</p><p>concerning the relevance and operation of the United Nations human rights system in</p><p>the specific context of disability more accessible by adding a disability-specific</p><p>dimension to its web site (with appropriate and extensive links to the relevant</p><p>activities of other sectors of the United Nations, the specialized agencies and national</p><p>institutions); (b) to plan, after consultation with the stakeholders, a series of more</p><p><strong><em>8 ______________________________________________________________ Executive summary</em></strong></p><p>focused thematic studies and practical manuals on subjects such as the human rights</p><p>of institutionalized persons, the right to education for disabled children, the principle</p><p>of non-discrimination and the value of human diversity in the context of genetics,</p><p>bioethics and disability, and the human rights issues connected with intellectual</p><p>disability; (c) to assign at least one staff member on a full-time basis to the question of</p><p>disability and human rights issues; (d) to indicate that it welcomes applications for</p><p>internships from disabled persons; (e) to play a role in stimulating university-based</p><p>human rights programmes to become more actively involved in human rights and</p><p>disability; (f) to take a leading role in advancing the cause of the human rights of</p><p>persons with disabilities within the wider United Nations system, with due regard to</p><p>the equal ownership of the issue by all relevant institutional stakeholders. It is</p><p>important that the human rights perspective on disability continue to be increasingly</p><p>mainstreamed throughout the United Nations system, including in the relevant</p><p>development activities. It is also important that the issue should be multi-tracked</p><p>among all the concerned entities. More guidance from OHCHR could aid</p><p>immeasurably in the process of mainstreaming, as well as enhance the contributions</p><p>of the various and diverse elements of the system. The authors also recommend that</p><p>the Office explore options for bringing together the treaty monitoring bodies to</p><p>discuss the relevance and the potential contribution of their respective treaties in the</p><p>context of disability.</p><p>With respect to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, the authors</p><p>recommend that it maintain and enhance the process of mainstreaming disability as a</p><p>human rights issue in its work and that it give active consideration to the appointment</p><p>of a special rapporteur on the human rights of persons with disabilities. The authors</p><p>believe that there is a need for such an entity to raise the visibility of the disability</p><p>issue as a human rights issue and to provide a focal point for disability in the human</p><p>rights system.</p><p>With respect to the national human rights institutions, the authors recommend that</p><p>they actively consider forming a forum or working group on disability and human</p><p>rights. Such a forum would enable the national institutions to develop a deeper</p><p>understanding of disability as a human rights issue and enable them to exchange</p><p>valuable experiences.</p><p>With respect to civil society, the authors recommend that the disability NGOs</p><p>combine their resources and form an international Disability Human Rights Watch or</p><p>similar body that could help raise levels of awareness as well as human rights</p><p>capacities within the disability sector. Such a grouping should develop close ties with</p><p>the mainstream human rights NGOs in order to learn from their experiences and also</p><p>in order to influence them to adopt disability as a human rights issue. The authors</p><p>highlight good practice in the form of funding from the Swedish International</p><p>Development Agency for a project on the human rights of children with disabilities.</p><p>Given that the majority of people with disabilities live in developing countries, the</p><p>authors believe that other donor countries should fund human rights projects in the</p><p>area of disability as part of their development, democratization and human rights</p><p>programmes.</p><p>Chapter 13 deals with the possibility of augmenting the existing human rights system</p><p>in the context of disability with the adoption of a thematic treaty on the rights of</p><p>persons with disabilities. In November 2001, the General Assembly adopted a historic</p><p><strong><em>Executive summary ______________________________________________________________ 9</em></strong></p><p>resolution to establish an ad hoc committee, open to the participation of all Member</p><p>States, to consider proposals for a comprehensive and integral international</p><p>convention to protect and promote the rights and dignity of persons with disabilities,</p><p>based on the holistic approach in the work done in the field of social development,</p><p>human rights and non-discrimination and taking into account the recommendations of</p><p>the Commission on Human Rights and the Commission for Social Development.</p><p>The authors find the arguments for such a convention to be highly persuasive. It</p><p>would enable attention to be focused on disability and would tailor general human</p><p>rights norms to meet the particular circumstances of persons with disabilities. It would</p><p>add visibility to the disability issue within the human rights system. It would have</p><p>practical advantages for all the stakeholders inasmuch as States parties would be</p><p>clearer on their precise obligations in the disability field, and civil society would also</p><p>be able to focus on one coherent set of norms rather than six different sets of norms.</p><p>These advantages were long ago spelled out by Leandro Despouy, the Special</p><p>Rapporteur of the Sub-Commission, in his study on disability, <em>Human Rights and</em></p><p><em>Disabled Persons</em>, published in 1992.</p><p>The authors view such a convention as underpinning – and not undermining – the web</p><p>of existing human rights treaties insofar as they relate to disability. That is, such a</p><p>convention should enable the relevant treaty monitoring body to develop normative</p><p>expertise in the field, and this should, in turn, help to stimulate the mainstreaming of</p><p>disability into the existing human rights system. A convention would address</p><p>collectively people with physical, sensory, mental or intellectual disabilities. The</p><p>drafting process should provide an occasion for considering how best to use all human</p><p>rights – civil, political, economic, social and cultural – to achieve the goal of full</p><p>participation in society of people with disabilities. The convention should include</p><p>appropriate protections, especially for those persons with disabilities who are</p><p>institutionalized.</p><p>All in all, the United Nations is entering an exciting phase of its activities in the field</p><p>of human rights and disabilities. Disability issues are being brought home into the</p><p>human rights domain. The authors are confident that the range of suggestions and</p><p>recommendations contained in the study and outlined above will lead to more and</p><p>better use of the six human rights treaties in the context of disability. They are also</p><p>confident that a thematic treaty would immeasurably advance the rights of persons</p><p>with disabilities, while at the same time enhancing the capacity of the existing</p><p>instruments to respond appropriately.</p><p>– – –</p><p><strong>Part 1</strong></p><p><strong>Background: The shift to a human rights framework</strong></p><p><strong>of reference</strong></p><p><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Chapter 1</strong></p><p><strong>The moral authority for change: human rights values and</strong></p><p><strong>the worldwide process of disability reform</strong></p><p>Gerard Quinn, Theresia Degener</p><p>Disability is a human rights issue! I repeat: disability is a human rights issue.</p><p>Those of us who happen to have a disability are fed up being treated by the society and our</p><p>fellow citizens as if we did not exist or as if we were aliens from outer space. We are human</p><p>beings with equal value, claiming equal rights…</p><p>If asked, most people, including politicians and other decision makers, agree with us. The</p><p>problem is that they do not realize the consequences of this principle and they are not ready to</p><p>take action accordingly.</p><p><strong><em>Speech by Bengt Lindqvist, Special Rapporteur on Disability of the United Nations</em></strong></p><p><strong><em>Commission for Social Development, at the nineteenth Congress of Rehabilitation</em></strong></p><p><strong><em>International, Rio de Janeiro, 25 – 30 August 2000</em></strong></p><p>A clear perception of the values that underlie the human rights mission is needed to</p><p>understand the nature and significance of the switch to a human rights perspective on</p><p>disability. These values form the bedrock of an elaborate system of basic freedoms</p><p>supported and advanced by international human rights law. Disability challenges</p><p>society to live up to its values and sets international law the task of engineering</p><p>positive change.</p><p>In this chapter we examine these values and explain the system of fundamental</p><p>freedoms to which they give rise. We also explore the core problem of putting these</p><p>values into practice in the context of disability, a problem that stems largely from the</p><p>relative invisibility of people with disabilities in the past. They tended to be viewed as</p><p>objects rather than subjects in their own right and the legal protections normally</p><p>associated with the rule of law were either not applied at all or were severely</p><p>curtailed.</p><p>Seeing people with disabilities as subjects rather than objects entails giving them</p><p>access to the full benefits of basic freedoms that most people take for granted and</p><p>doing so in a way that is respectful and accommodating of their difference. It means</p><p>abandoning the tendency to perceive people with disabilities as problems and viewing</p><p>them instead in terms of their rights.</p><p><strong><em>14 _____________________________________________________________ Part 1: Background</em></strong></p><p><strong>1.1 Human values – the human being as subject and not object</strong></p><p>The core values of the human rights mission underpin a system of basic freedoms that</p><p>affords protection against the abuse of power and creates space for the development of</p><p>the human spirit. Four values – dignity, autonomy, equality and solidarity – are of</p><p>particular importance, both in general terms and in the context of disability.</p><p><em>(a) Human dignity and the social construct of disability</em></p><p>Human dignity is the anchor norm of human rights. Each individual is deemed to be</p><p>of inestimable value and nobody is insignificant. People are to be valued not just</p><p>because they are economically or otherwise useful but because of their inherent selfworth.</p><p>Recognition of the value of human dignity serves as a powerful reminder that people</p><p>with disabilities have a stake in and a claim on society that must be honoured quite</p><p>apart from any considerations of social or economic utility. They are ends in</p><p>themselves and not means to the ends of others. This view militates strongly against</p><p>the contrary social impulse to rank people in terms of their usefulness and to screen</p><p>out those with significant differences.</p><p>Dignity as a value has been a crucial factor in the switch to a human rights perspective</p><p>on disability. Owing to their relative invisibility, people with disabilities were often</p><p>treated in the past as objects to be protected or pitied. The crucial change came when</p><p>they saw themselves (and were seen by others) as subjects and not as objects.</p><p>The seventeenth-century English historian William Blackstone described women’s</p><p>loss of full legal personality on marriage as a form of “civil death”. The main aim of</p><p>reform ever since has been to restore to women all the indicia of legal personhood on</p><p>genuinely equal terms with men – to change their status from object to subject. Much</p><p>the same can be said of people with disabilities except that civil death in their case has</p><p>occurred either at birth or at the moment of disablement later in life.</p><p>The “medical model” of disability has frequently been contrasted in recent years with</p><p>the “human rights” model. The medical model focuses on persons’ medical traits such</p><p>as their specific impairments. This has the effect of locating the “problem” of</p><p>disability within the person. The medical model encapsulates a broader and deeper</p><p>social attitude – a tendency to problematize the person and view him/her as an object</p><p>for clinical intervention.</p><p>The human rights model focuses on the inherent dignity of the human being and</p><p>subsequently, but only if necessary, on the person’s medical characteristics. It places</p><p>the individual centrestage in all decisions affecting him/her and, most importantly,</p><p>locates the main “problem” outside the person and in society. The “problem” of</p><p>disability under this model stems from a lack of responsiveness by the State and civil</p><p>society to the difference that disability represents. It follows that the State has a</p><p>responsibility to tackle socially created obstacles in order to ensure full respect for the</p><p>dignity and equal rights of all persons.</p><p>Another way of making the same point is to describe disability as a “social construct”.</p><p>This idea is quite simple and straightforward although it is often clouded by</p><p><strong><em>Chapter 1: Moral authority for change ____________________________________________ 15</em></strong></p><p>theoretical analysis. The first premise of the “social construct” model is that human</p><p>difference is not innate but something socially constructed and applied through labels</p><p>such as “the disabled”. Thus, one is not born “black” or “a woman” or “disabled”.</p><p>One is labelled as such in relation to some unstated norm such as maleness, being</p><p>white or being able-bodied (for want of a better expression).</p><p>The second premise is that the norm in relation to which one is evaluated and labelled</p><p>(maleness, whiteness, being able-bodied) is generally not selected through a neutral or</p><p>disinterested process. Selection usually occurs through an apparatus of power whose</p><p>minimum goal is to preserve that power. Indeed many disability rights advocates</p><p>consider that “the disabled” should be used instead of “persons with disabilities”</p><p>precisely in order to highlight the fact that it is society which disables the person.</p><p>The third premise of the social construct model is crucial, namely that the social</p><p>construct of disability is used not only to <strong><em>set people apart </em></strong>but also to <strong><em>keep people</em></strong></p><p><strong><em>apart</em></strong>. All points of access to the structures of everyday life – the world of education,</p><p>of work, of the family or of social interaction – are established largely by reference to</p><p>the dominant norm, in this instance that of the able-bodied. As deviations or</p><p>differences from the arbitrarily selected norm are generally not catered for, difference</p><p>serves as a ground for subtle (and sometimes not so subtle) exclusion. For example,</p><p>the built environment is constructed for those who can walk and not for those who use</p><p>wheelchairs. The communications environment generally assumes a capacity to listen</p><p>and to speak. The education environment makes little allowance for different ways of</p><p>learning and so on.</p><p>A powerful link can be forged between the “social construct” model of disability and</p><p>the human rights perspective on disability. Society has ignored or discounted the</p><p>difference of disability in regulating the terms of entry into and participation in the</p><p>mainstream, thus excluding – or effectively excluding –10 per cent of any given</p><p>population. This is not merely irrational from an economic point of view; it also</p><p>violates the inherent dignity of all human beings.</p><p>To state the matter in positive terms, the end goal from the perspective of the human</p><p>rights model is to build societies that are genuinely inclusive, societies that value</p><p>difference and respect the dignity and equality of all human beings regardless of</p><p>difference. In this regard, the disability rights movement is very much in tune with a</p><p>deeper and broader movement to create genuinely inclusive societies for all. It has</p><p>been described as the “next generation” civil rights movement.</p><p><em>(b) Autonomy and creation of space for the</em></p><p><em>development of the human spirit</em></p><p>Autonomy as a value associated with dignity derives from the ancient Greek</p><p>commitment to autonomy or self-governance. It entails opening up a free or</p><p>uncoerced space for voluntary action based on a person’s conscience and freely made</p><p>life choices, while preserving comparable liberty for others.</p><p>The value of autonomy is based on the presumption of a capacity for self-directed</p><p>action and behaviour. It thus rests on the implicit image of a “morally free” person –</p><p>an image that has long been deeply contested. There are two main problems with this</p><p>ideal image in the context of disability. One is that society seems over-inclined in</p><p><strong><em>16 _____________________________________________________________ Part 1: Background</em></strong></p><p>many instances to conflate disability – especially intellectual disability – with a lack</p><p>of capacity for moral freedom. This presumption often rests on sheer prejudice. The</p><p>human rights perspective on disability involves a much more nuanced approach, one</p><p>that is not over-inclined to detect incompetence and that places equal emphasis on the</p><p>need for effective protection of the rights and interests of those proclaimed legally</p><p>incompetent.</p><p>The other problem is that society often fails to take seriously the autonomy of persons</p><p>with disabilities who enjoy full legal competence. Their life choices are not perceived</p><p>to be as worthy of social support as those of the non-disabled. Low expectations have</p><p>led to neglect of the material conditions that people with disabilities need to take</p><p>control of their lives and live as they wish. For the most part, societies have not done</p><p>enough to <em>enable </em>those with disabilities who have a clear capacity for moral freedom</p><p>to exercise their right of self-determination. It is one thing to have the ability to study</p><p>astrophysics despite disability – it is another to be able to do so in the absence of</p><p>accessible transportation.</p><p><em>(c) Equality – valuing difference</em></p><p>Human equality, a related value, is also central to the system of basic freedoms</p><p>postulated by human rights law. Its core premise is that all persons not only possess</p><p>inestimable inherent self-worth but are also inherently equal in terms of self-worth,</p><p>regardless of their difference. Thus, distinctions between persons stemming from</p><p>factors that are arbitrary from a moral point of view (race, gender, age, disability)</p><p>should be treated as having no rational foundation and therefore invalid.</p><p>This is not to say that there are no differences between people. In positive terms, it</p><p>means that a genuinely equal society is one that has a positive approach to and</p><p>positively accommodates human difference. Valuing human difference is the aim of</p><p>the “social construct” approach and is also validated by the human rights perspective.</p><p>It is crucially important to an understanding of international developments to realize</p><p>that there are at least three ways of understanding the concept of equality. The</p><p>interpretation chosen affects what one identifies as “wrong” in contemporary social</p><p>arrangements and what remedies are deemed appropriate.</p><p>1. The first interpretation of equality focuses on the need for even-handedness by</p><p>parliaments when they create inevitable distinctions in law and policy. This</p><p>interpretation of formal or juridical equality is, of course, vital and will continue to</p><p>form the bedrock of any understanding of equality. However, it is not sufficiently</p><p>attuned to the concrete needs of those who are in fact “different” or who are not</p><p>similarly situated.</p><p>On the other hand, to insist on strict equality between persons with disabilities and</p><p>other persons would be to ignore real differences. A formal anti-discrimination law,</p><p>for instance, may proscribe disability discrimination but fail to move beyond the</p><p>“equality as neutrality” philosophy and take the further vital step of requiring</p><p>“reasonable accommodation” of the difference of disability. This kind of “equality” is</p><p>plainly hollow. It confers illusory benefits and invites cynicism vis-à-vis the law.</p><p>Although the endeavour to accommodate real differences within a theory of equality</p><p><strong><em>Chapter 1: Moral authority for change ____________________________________________ 17</em></strong></p><p>may result in paradox and pose its own set of problems, it seems necessary to make</p><p>equality meaningful and to produce real change.</p><p>2. A second interpretation of equality is “equality of opportunity”. Most modern</p><p>thinking accepts the “equal opportunity model” as the most appropriate one in the</p><p>context of disability. According to this philosophy, factors over which a person has no</p><p>control and which are thus “arbitrary from a moral point of view” should not be</p><p>allowed to dictate that person’s life chances. Familiar examples are social status,</p><p>colour, gender and disability.</p><p>Taking the ethic of “equality of opportunity” seriously in the context of disability</p><p>implies calling for several forms of governmental action or intervention.</p><p>(i) Equality of opportunity entails tackling structural exclusion in such areas as</p><p>transport, social amenities, public services and communications. No</p><p>meaningful change is conceivable unless the social and economic processes of</p><p>civil society are structured more inclusively and opened up to persons with</p><p>disabilities on a genuinely equal basis. Such changes necessarily take time but</p><p>the main thing is to inaugurate an irreversible process of structural change</p><p>with clear goals and timetables.</p><p>(ii) Equality of o</p></div></div>
36	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">ICRC publication 1988 ref. 0365  Basic rules of the Geneva Conventions and their Additional  Protocols</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p><strong><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/human-rights-conventions/icrc-publication-1988-ref-0365-basic-rules-of-the-geneva-conventions-and-their-additional-protocols/attachment/icrc-basic-rules-in-the-1949-geneva-conventions-and-1977-additional-protocols/" rel="attachment wp-att-6132">ICRC-Basic-Rules-in-the-1949-Geneva-Conventions-and-1977-Additional-Protocols</a></strong></p><p>Basic rules of the Geneva Conventions and their Additional Protocols</p><p>Page 1 of 2</p><p><strong>Foreword</strong></p><p>The aim of this document, “The Geneva Conventions and the Additional Protocols-Basic Rules”, is to provide</p><p>a condensed synthesis of the rules of international humanitarian law in armed conflicts as contained in these</p><p>legal instruments. This presentation itself is preceded by a summary which sets out, as simply and briefly as</p><p>possible, the fundamental rules which are the basis of these treaties and the law of armed conflicts as a</p><p>whole. Prepared for dissemination purposes, this work cannot in any circumstances serve as a substitute for</p><p>the complete provisions of the international agreements to which the marginal notes refer.</p><p><strong>Summary: Basic rules of international humanitarian law in armed conflicts</strong></p><p>1. Persons <em>hors de combat </em>and those who do not take a direct part in hostilities are entitled to respect for</p><p>their</p><p>lives and their moral and physical integrity. They shall in all circumstances be protected and treated</p><p>humanely</p><p>without any adverse distinction.</p><p>2. It is forbidden to kill or injure an enemy who surrenders or who is <em>hors de combat.</em></p><p>3. The wounded and sick shall be collected and cared for by the party to the conflict which has them in its</p><p>power.</p><p>Protection also covers medical personnel, establishments, transports and equipment. The emblem of the red</p><p>cross or the red crescent is the sign of such protection and must be respected.</p><p>4. Captured combatants and civilians under the authority of an adverse party are entitled to respect for their</p><p>lives,dignity, personal rights and convictions. They shall be protected against all acts of violence and</p><p>reprisals. They shall have the right to correspond with their families and to receive relief.</p><p>5. Everyone shall be entitled to benefit from fundamental judicial guarantees. No one shall be held</p><p>responsible for an act he has not committed. No one shall be subjected to physical or mental torture,</p><p>corporal punishment or cruel or degrading treatment.</p><p>6. Parties to a conflict and members of their armed forces do not have an unlimited choice of methods and</p><p>means of warfare. It is prohibited to employ weapons or methods of warfare of a nature to cause</p><p>unnecessary losses or excessive suffering.</p><p>7. Parties to a conflict shall at all times distinguish between the civilian population and combatants in order</p><p>to</p><p>spare civilian population and property. Neither the civilian population as such nor civilian persons shall be</p><p>the</p><p>object of attack. Attacks shall be directed solely against military objectives.</p><p>International Committee of the Red Cross</p><p>Basic rules of the Geneva Conventions and their Additional Protocols</p><p>Page 2 of 2</p><p><strong>Note</strong></p><p>1. This text constitutes the quintessence of the provisions of international humanitarian law which are</p><p>summarized in the following pages. It does not have the force of an international legal instrument and is in</p><p>no way intended to replace the treaties in force. It is designed, as is this whole work, to facilitate</p><p>dissemination of international humanitarian law.</p><p><strong>CONTENTS (I-VI)</strong></p><p><strong>Chapter I</strong></p><p>Provisions common to the four Conventions and to Protocol I</p><p><strong>Chapter II</strong></p><p><strong>Protection of the wounded, sick and shipwrecked</strong></p><p>Geneva Convention for the Amelioration of the Condition of the Wounded and Sick in Armed Forces in the</p><p>Field (Convention I of 12 August 1949)</p><p>Geneva Convention for the Amelioration of the Condition of Wounded, Sick and Shipwrecked Members of</p><p>Armed Forces at Sea (Convention 11 of 12 August 1949)</p><p>Additional Protocol I, Part II</p><p><strong>Chapter III</strong></p><p><strong>Regulations relating to the conduct of combatants and the protection of prisoners of war</strong></p><p>Geneva Convention relative to the Treatment of Prisoners of War (Convention III of 12 August 1949)</p><p>Additional Protocol I, Part III</p><p><strong>Chapter IV</strong></p><p><strong>Protection of civilian persons and populations in time of war</strong></p><p>Additional Protocol I, Part IV</p><p>Geneva Convention relative to the protection of civilian persons in time of war (Convention IV of 12 August</p><p>1949)</p><p><strong>Chapter V</strong></p><p><strong>Protection of victims of non-international armed conflicts</strong></p><p>Article 3 common to the four Conventions and additional Protocol II</p><p>31-12-1988</p><p>Provisions common to the four Conventions and to Protocol I</p><p>Page 1 of 3</p><p>International Committee of the Red Cross</p><p><strong>31-12-1988</strong><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Provisions common to the four Conventions and to Protocol I</strong></p><p>1. Field of application, duration of application, general principles of law</p><p>2. Prohibition of reprisals</p><p>3. Non-renunciation of rights</p><p>4. Supervision</p><p>a) Protecting Powers</p><p>b) International Committee of the Red Cross</p><p>5. Sanctions</p><p>6. Dissemination</p><p><em>(Please note: Roman numerals indicate the number of the Convention or the Protocol (designated by the</em></p><p><em>letter</em></p><p><em>P), Arabic numerals refer to the articles of these instruments.)</em></p><p><strong>1. Field of application, duration of application, general principles of law</strong></p><p>The Conventions and the Protocol are applicable in case of declared war or of any other armed conflict</p><p>arising between two or more of the Parties to the Conventions and Protocol I from the beginning of such a</p><p>situation, even if the state of war is not recognized by one of them. These agreements also cover armed</p><p>conflicts in which people are fighting against colonial domination and alien occupation and against racist</p><p>regimes in the exercise of their right of self-determination.[I, 2; II, 2; III, 2; IV, 2; P. I, 1]</p><p>The application ceases at the general close of military operations and, in occupied territories, at the end of</p><p>the occupation except for those categories of people whose final release, repatriation or settlement takes</p><p>place at a later date. These people shall continue to benefit from the relevant provisions of the Conventions</p><p>and the Protocol until their final release, repatriation or settlement. [I, 5; III, 5; IV, 6; P. I, 3]</p><p>In cases not covered by the Conventions, the Protocol or other international agreements, or in the case of</p><p>denunciation of these agreements, <em>civilians and combatants remain under the protection and authority of</em></p><p><em>the principles of international law derived from established custom, from the principles of humanity and</em></p><p><em>from the dictates of public conscience.</em>[P. I, 1 ; I, 63; II, 62; III, 142; IV, 158]</p><p><strong>2. Prohibition of reprisals</strong></p><p>Reprisals, violations of the law in response to other violations of the law and to make them cease, are</p><p>prohibited against the wounded, sick and shipwrecked, medical services and personnel, civil defence</p><p>services and personnel, prisoners of war, civilians, civilian and cultural property, the natural environment</p><p>and works and installations containing dangerous forces. They are admitted only in the conduct of the</p><p>hostilities.[I, 46; II, 47; III, 13; IV, 33; P. I, 20, 51-56]</p><p><strong>3. Non-renunciation of rights</strong></p><p>The Geneva Conventions having as their aim the protection of war victims, these persons must be placed,</p><p>as far as is possible, out of the reach of any pressures to make them renounce their rights. This is why</p><p>these persons may in no circumstances renounce, in part or totally, the rights ensured them by the</p><p>Conventions and the Protocol. The people mainly concerned are military and civilian medical personnel and</p><p>the wounded, military and civilian sick and shipwrecked persons, as well as prisoners of war, civilian</p><p>internees, inhabitants of occupied territories and foreigners on the territory of a Party to the conflict. The</p><p><strong>Extract from “Basic rules of the </strong><strong>Geneva</strong><strong> Conventions and their Additional Protocols”</strong></p><p>Provisions common to the four Conventions and to Protocol I</p><p>Page 2 of 3</p><p>principle of non-renunciation applies to all the rights which protect war victims.[I, 7; II, 7; III, 7; IV, 8; P.</p><p>I, 1]</p><p><strong>4. Supervision</strong></p><p><strong>a) Protecting Powers</strong></p><p>To ensure that the Geneva Conventions are respected, the Parties to the conflict should secure the</p><p>cooperation</p><p>and admit the supervision of Protecting Powers, in other words neutral States appointed to safeguard the</p><p>interests</p><p>of the Parties to the conflict in enemy countries. If such appointments have not been made, the</p><p>International</p><p>Committee of the Red Cross will offer the Parties to the conflict its help in the designation of Protecting</p><p>Powers.[I,</p><p>8; II, 8; III, 8; IV, 9; P. I, 5]</p><p><strong>b) International Committee of the Red Cross</strong></p><p>The presence of the Protecting Powers does not stand in the way of humanitarian activities which the ICRC</p><p>or any other impartial humanitarian organization undertakes for the protection of war victims.[I, 9; II, 9;</p><p>III, 9; IV, 10]</p><p>This is an application of the provision that governments may at any time agree to entrust to an organization</p><p>offering every guarantee of impartiality and efficiency the humanitarian duties incumbent on the Protecting</p><p>Powers by virtue of the Conventions.[I, 10; II, 10; III, 10; IV, 11]</p><p>ICRC delegates are, in particular, authorized to go to all places where there are protected persons, prisoners</p><p>of war or civil internees and to talk to them without witnesses. The ICRC will be granted all the necessary</p><p>facilities to carry out its humanitarian work.[III, 126; IV, 143; P. I, 81]</p><p><strong>5. Sanctions</strong></p><p>These articles have particular significance. They relate both to offences which are subject only to</p><p>administrative or disciplinary sanctions as well as to grave breaches, against which they constitute an</p><p>embryonic international penal law by elevating them to the rank of international crimes and designating</p><p>them as “war crimes”. These articles lay before the conscience of the world the list of especially grave</p><p>violations of the Conventions and the Protocol which, were they to remain unpunished, would signify the</p><p>degradation of human values and the regression of the entire concept of humanity.</p><p>These <em>grave breaches </em>are those involving any of the following acts, if committed against persons or</p><p>property protected by the Conventions, as supplemented by the Protocol: wilful killing, torture or inhuman</p><p>treatment, including biological experiments, wilfully causing great suffering or serious injury to body or</p><p>health, any wilful omission seriously endangering the physical or mental health or integrity of a person in</p><p>the power of a Party other than the one on which he depends, unlawful deportation or transfer, illegal</p><p>detention, compelling a protected person to serve in the armed forces of a hostile Power, or wilfully</p><p>depriving a protected person of the right to a fair and regular trial as prescribed in the Conventions and the</p><p>Protocol, the taking of hostages, the destruction and appropriation of property not justified by military</p><p>necessity and carried out on a large scale in an arbitrary and unlawful way.[I, 50; II, 51; III, 130; IV, 174;</p><p>P. I, 11]</p><p>The following wilful acts are also grave breaches when they result in death or cause serious injury to body</p><p>or health: attacks on the civilian population, civilians, civilian property, attacks launched indiscriminately or</p><p>attacks on works and installations containing dangerous forces, in the knowledge that such attacks will</p><p>cause loss of lives, injury to civilians or damage to civilian property which are excessive in relation to the</p><p>actual and direct military advantage expected; attacks on non-defended localities and demilitarized zones,</p><p>attacks on people known to be <em>hors de combat </em>and the perfidious use of the emblem of the red cross or red</p><p>crescent and other recognized protective signs.</p><p>The following are also grave breaches of the Conventions and the Protocol: any transfer by an Occupying</p><p>Power of part of its own civilian population into the territory it occupies, the deportation or transfer of all or</p><p>Provisions common to the four Conventions and to Protocol I</p><p>Page 3 of 3</p><p>part of the population of this territory, any unjustifiable delay in the repatriation of prisoners of war or</p><p>civilians, apartheid and similar practices, attacks directed against clearly recognizable historical monuments,</p><p>works of art or places of worship.</p><p>The Conventions and the Protocol require governments to enact any legislation necessary to provide</p><p>effective penal sanctions for persons committing or ordering the commission of any of the grave breaches;</p><p>they will search for persons alleged to have committed, or to have ordered the commission of such</p><p>breaches, including those resulting from a failure to act when under a duty to do so. Military commanders</p><p>must be watchful to prevent breaches of the Conventions and the Protocol, will suppress them and, if</p><p>necessary, report them to the competent authorities.[I, 49; II, 50; III, 129; IV, 146]</p><p>As we have seen, each contracting Party must also take the necessary steps to stop actions contrary to the</p><p>Conventions other than grave breaches. But the Conventions accord the greatest importance to grave</p><p>breaches because they provide for them to come under the criminal jurisdiction of all Parties to the</p><p>Conventions. It is also possible for the offender to be brought before an international tribunal, if such a</p><p>tribunal has been set up.</p><p>Because of the universality of such sanctions, extradition will be required whenever a State concerned has</p><p>not summoned the accused to appear before its own courts. Being subject to so many different forms of</p><p>possible jurisdiction, these crimes are not likely to go unpunished.</p><p><strong>6. Dissemination</strong></p><p>In time of peace as in time of war, the Parties are obliged to include the study of the Conventions and the</p><p>Protocol in their programmes of military instruction and to encourage the civilian population to study them.</p><p>Military and civil authorities must be fully acquainted with these texts and military commanders must ensure</p><p>that members of the armed forces under their command are aware of their obligations under the</p><p>Conventions and the Protocol.[I, 47; II, 48; III, 127; IV, 144; P. I, 83, 87]</p><p>In addition, Parties to a conflict are obliged to ensure that legal advisers are available to advise military</p><p>commanders on the application of the Conventions and the Protocol and on appropriate instructions to the</p><p>armed forces on this subject.[P. I, 82]</p><p>31-12-1988</p><p>Protection of the wounded, sick and shipwrecked</p><p>Page 1 of 4</p><p>International Committee of the Red Cross</p><p><strong>31-12-1988</strong><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>Protection of the wounded, sick and shipwrecked</strong></p><p><strong>Geneva Convention for the amelioration of the condition of the wounded and sick in armed forces in the field</strong></p><p>(Convention I of 12 August 1949)</p><p><strong>Geneva Convention for the amelioration of the condition of wounded, sick and shipwrecked members of</strong></p><p><strong>armed forces at sea </strong>(Convention II of 12 August 1949)</p><p><strong>Additional Protocol I, Part II</strong></p><p>1. Field of application of the two Conventions and the Protocol</p><p>2. Definition of protected persons</p><p>3. Protection, treatment and care</p><p>4. Search for the wounded, dead and missing</p><p>5. Recording and forwarding of information</p><p>6. Role of the civilian population and relief organizations; role of neutral ships</p><p>7. Medical units</p><p>8. Medical transport</p><p>9. Medical personnel</p><p>10. Medical mission</p><p>11. Emblem and signals</p><p><em>(Please note: Roman numerals indicate the number of the Convention or the Protocol (designated by the letter</em></p><p><em>P), Arabic numerals refer to the articles of these instruments.)</em></p><p><strong>1. Field of application of the two Conventions and the Protocol</strong></p><p>Generally speaking, the Second Geneva Convention of 12 August 1949 is almost identical with the First. The</p><p>main difference between the two is that the second concerns the wounded, sick and shipwrecked members of</p><p>armed forces at sea while the first relates to the wounded and sick in armed forces in the field. Otherwise, the</p><p>principles underlying the two Conventions are identical and the same rules apply to protected persons and</p><p>property, taking into account the different conditions prevailing on land and at sea.[I, 13; II, 13]</p><p>Protocol I, Part 11, extends this protection to all wounded, sick and shipwrecked persons, whether they be</p><p>civilians or members of the armed forces.[P. I, 8, 34]</p><p><strong>2. Definition of protected persons I</strong>(1)</p><p>The terms “wounded” and “sick” mean military or civilian persons in need of medical care and who refrain from any act of</p><p>hostility.[P. I, 8]</p><p>The term “shipwrecked” means military or civilian persons in a perilous situation at sea or on any other waters following a</p><p>misfortune which has befallen them and who refrain from any act of hostility.</p><p><strong>3. Protection, treatment and care</strong></p><p><em>All wounded, sick and shipwrecked, to whichever Party they belong, shall be respected and protected.</em>[P. I, 10]</p><p>In all circumstances, they shall be treated humanely and shall receive, to the fullest possible extent and with the least</p><p>possible delay, the medical care and attention required by their condition. There shall be no distinction between them on</p><p>any other grounds. Women shall be treated with all the particular consideration due to their sex.[I, 12; II, 12; P. I, 10]</p><p>Wounded, sick and shipwrecked combatants who are captured become prisoners of war. Until their recovery or their</p><p>disembarkation they will benefit from the provisions of Conventions I or II and III.</p><p><strong>4. Search for the wounded, dead and missing</strong></p><p>The general principle governing this section is, first and foremost, <em>the right of families to know the fate of their</em></p><p><em>relatives.</em>[P. I, 32]</p><p><strong>Extract from “Basic rules of the </strong><strong>Geneva</strong><strong> Conventions and their Additional Protocols”</strong></p><p>Protection of the wounded, sick and shipwrecked</p><p>Page 2 of 4</p><p>At all times, and particularly after an engagement, Parties to a conflict must immediately take all possible measures to</p><p>search for and collect the wounded, sick and shipwrecked, to protect them against pillage and ill-treatment and ensure</p><p>their adequate care, as well as to search for the dead and prevent their being despoiled.[I, 15; II, 18; IV, 16]</p><p>The Conventions specify that Parties to a conflict must ensure that burial, cremation or burial at sea of the dead, carried</p><p>out individually as far as circumstances permit, is preceded by a careful and, if possible, medical examination of the</p><p>bodies with a view to confirming death, establishing identity and making possible a report.[I, 17; II, 20]</p><p>In addition, as soon as circumstances permit, and at the latest from the end of active hostilities, each Party to the conflict</p><p>must search for persons who have been reported missing by an adverse Party.[P. I, 33]</p><p><strong>5. Recording and forwarding of information</strong></p><p><em>Parties to a conflict must record all available particulars which could help to identify the wounded, sick and dead who have</em></p><p><em>fallen into their hands: </em>the Power on which they depend or nationality, regimental number, surname and first name, date</p><p>of birth, date and place of capture and the nature of actions taken with regard to the individuals concerned, etc. This</p><p>information is to be forwarded as soon as possible to the Information Bureau provided for in Convention III for</p><p>transmission to the adverse Party, particularly through the intermediary of the <em>Central Tracing Agency of the International</em></p><p><em>Committee of the Red Cross </em>(CTA). When this information is not channelled through the ICRC and its central Agency,</p><p>each Party to the conflict will ensure that this information is also supplied to the Central Agency provided for in</p><p>Convention III. [I, 16; II, 19; P. I, 33; III, 122; IV, 136]</p><p><strong>6. Role of the civilian population and relief organizations; role of neutral ships</strong></p><p><em>The civilian Population must respect the wounded, sick and shipwrecked, even if they belong to the adverse Party, and</em></p><p><em>shall commit no act of violence against them. </em>The civilian population and relief organizations, such as National Red Cross</p><p>and Red Crescent Societies, will be authorized, even in invaded or occupied regions, to collect and care for the wounded,</p><p>sick and ship wrecked, even if they are enemy parachutists or guerillas. Nobody may be harassed, prosecuted or convicted</p><p>for such humanitarian action.[I, 18; P. I, 17]</p><p>Furthermore, the competent authority may appeal to the civilian population and the relief organizations to collect the</p><p>wounded, sick and shipwrecked, to search for the dead and report where they were found.</p><p>The same applies in naval warfare to neutral merchant vessels, yachts or other craft which may be called upon, by the</p><p>Parties to the conflict, to take on board and care for the wounded, sick and shipwrecked and also to collect the dead.[II,</p><p>21]</p><p><strong>7. Medical units</strong></p><p><em>Military(2) or civilian medical units are protected by the Conventions and the Protocol. </em>Such units comprise all buildings or</p><p>fixed installations (hospitals and other similar units, blood transfusion and preventive medicine centres, medical depots</p><p>and stores) and mobile units (quarantine stations, tents, open air installations, vehicles assigned to medical purposes) [I,</p><p>19; P. I, 8, 9, 12] :</p><p><em>a) which belong to a Party to the conflict or which are recognized and authorized by a Party to the conflict</em></p><p><em>(naturally including the National Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies and other authorized Societies);</em></p><p><em>b) which are placed at the disposal of a Party to the conflict</em></p><p><em>– by a neutral State,</em></p><p><em>– by an impartial international organization of a humanitarian nature.</em></p><p><em>Assigned to medical purposes </em>means units devoted to searching for evacuating, transporting, diagnosing or</p><p>treating the wounded, sick and shipwrecked, as well as to disease prevention.</p><p>It is however specified that the protection to which these medical units are entitled may cease if they are used to</p><p>commit acts harmful to the enemy (for example, sheltering unwounded soldiers or installing a military observation</p><p>post). Protection may only cease, however, after a warning has been given, setting a reasonable time limit, and</p><p>after such warning has remained unheeded.[I, 21, 22;P, I, 13]</p><p><em>The equipment </em>(stretchers, surgical apparatus, medicines, dressings, etc.) of mobile military units seized by the</p><p>army will be reserved for the care of the wounded and sick.[I, 33]</p><p><em>In occupied territory, </em>the occupant cannot requisition civilian medical units, their equipment, material or personnel</p><p>so long as these resources are required for the needs of the civilian population and the wounded and sick already</p><p>under treatment.[P. I, 14]</p><p><em>The real and personal property of Red Cross Societies </em>and other authorized aid Societies will always be regarded</p><p>as private property. The army or the occupant can, however, requisition them in case of urgent necessity, but only</p><p>Protection of the wounded, sick and shipwrecked</p><p>Page 3 of 4</p><p>after the welfare of the sick and wounded has been assured.[I, 34]</p><p><strong>8. Medical transport</strong></p><p>“Medical transport” means the conveyance by land, water or air of the wounded, sick and shipwrecked, medical</p><p>and religious personnel and medical equipment protected by the Conventions and the Protocol. <em>Any means of</em></p><p><em>transport may be used, whether military or civilian, permanent or temporary, assigned exclusively to this purpose</em></p><p><em>and placed under the control of a Party to the conflict.</em>[P. I, 8]</p><p><em>Medical transport by land </em>(ambulances) must be respected and protected in the same way as mobile medical</p><p>units. Military ambulances falling into enemy hands are subject to the laws of war on condition that the Party</p><p>capturing them assumes responsibility for the sick and wounded they contain.[I, 35; P. I, 21]</p><p><em>Medical transport by water </em>is carried out either by hospital ships or other medical ships and craft. The following</p><p>vessels are protected by the Conventions and the Protocol on condition that their names and descriptions have</p><p>been notified to the Parties to the conflict:[II, 22]</p><p>– military hospital ships of the Parties to the conflict;</p><p>– hospital ships used by National Red Cross Societies or other officially recognized aid Societies or by private</p><p>persons, including those from neutral countries;[II, 24, 25]</p><p>– hospital ships made available to a Party to the conflict by a neutral State or by an impartial international</p><p>organization of a humanitarian nature.[P. I, 22]</p><p>Hospital ships may not be attacked and may not be captured. The same applies to ships chartered for the</p><p>transport of medical equipment. However, the Parties to the conflict have the right to board and inspect these</p><p>ships.[II, 22, 31, 38]</p><p>Any hospital ship in a port which falls into enemy hands will be authorized to leave the port.[II, 29]</p><p>Other medical ships and craft shall be respected and protected in the same way as mobile medical units.[P. I, 23]</p><p><em>Medical transport by air </em>(medical aircraft) carried out in areas not controlled by an adverse Party shall be</p><p>respected and protected. In contact or similar zones, medical aircraft operate at their own risk, unless prior</p><p>agreement has been reached between the Parties concerned. They must, however, be respected, even in the</p><p>absence of such agreement, after they have been recognized as medical aircraft. When flying over an area</p><p>controlled by an adverse Party, protection is subject to the prior agreement of this Party.[P. I, 24, 25, 26, 27]</p><p>Medical aircraft must not be used to attempt to acquire a military advantage over an adverse Party nor, without the</p><p>prior agreement of this Party, to search for the wounded, sick and shipwrecked.[P. I, 28]</p><p>Medical aircraft flying over areas not controlled by the Party to which they belong may be ordered to land or to</p><p>alight on water and must obey such an order. If inspection reveals that the aircraft has not infringed any rule of the</p><p>law of armed conflicts, it must be authorized to continue its flight without delay.[P. I, 30]</p><p><em>Medical aircraft must not fly over the territory of neutral States </em>except by previous agreement or in an emergency.</p><p>In the latter case, the medical aircraft will make every effort to identify itself and the neutral State will refrain from</p><p>attacking it as soon as it has recognized it as such. If wounded, sick or shipwrecked persons are collected or</p><p>disembarked on neutral territory, they will be cared for and detained by this State if they belong to the fighting</p><p>armed forces of a Party to the conflict, so that they cannot again take part in the hostilities.[II, 40; P. I, 31]</p><p><strong>9. Medical personnel</strong></p><p><em>Medical and religious personnel of the Parties to the conflict, whether military or civilian, shall be respected and</em></p><p><em>protected.</em>[I, 24, 25; P, I, 15]</p><p>Such personnel (doctors, nurses, stretcher-bearers, etc.) should be assigned, either on a permanent or</p><p>temporary basis, exclusively to medical purposes (see Point 7, Medical Units) or to the administration and</p><p>operation of medical units or medical transport facilities (administrators, drivers, cooks, etc.). Religious personnel</p><p>comprise military or civilian persons, such as chaplains, who are exclusively engaged in the work of their ministry.</p><p>Medical and religious personnel benefit from special protection and are designated as “protected personnel”.(3) [I,</p><p>24, 25, 26, 27; II, 36, 42; P. I, 8]</p><p><em>Protected personnel </em>are the following:</p><p><em>a) Military or civilian medical personnel of the Parties to the conflict, including those belonging to civil defence</em></p><p><em>organizations;</em></p><p>b) <em>medical personnel of National Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies and other national aid Societies</em></p><p><em>recognized by a Party to the conflict;</em></p><p>Protection of the wounded, sick and shipwrecked</p><p>Page 4 of 4</p><p>c) <em>religious personnel attached, either permanently or temporarily, to the armed forces, to medical units or</em></p><p><em>transport, or to civil defence organizations.</em></p><p>If military medical personnel fall into enemy hands, they may be retained so as to care for prisoners of war. They will not</p><p>themselves be regarded as prisoners of war. They will nevertheless benefit at least from all the provisions of the Geneva</p><p>Convention of 12 August 1949 relative to the treatment of prisoners of war.[I, 28; II, 37; III, 33]</p><p><em>In occupied territory, </em>civilian medical personnel may not be requisitioned if their services are necessary to provide for the</p><p>medical needs of the civilian population and the care of the wounded and sick already under treatment.[P. I, 14]</p><p><strong>10. Medical mission</strong></p><p>Finally, the Protocol provides that nobody may be punished for having carried out medical activities compatible with</p><p>medical ethics, regardless of the beneficiaries of this activity, nor be compelled to carry out acts contrary to the rules of</p><p>medical ethics or to refrain from carrying out acts required by these rules.[P. I, 16]</p><p><strong>11. Emblem and signals</strong></p><p>The sign of the red cross(4) or red crescent must be displayed on the flags, buildings, installations and mobile formations</p><p>of medical units, on their means of transport, as well as on armlets, clothes and headgear of medical and religious</p><p>personnel. It will be as large as the circumstances require.[I, 39; P. I, 18]</p><p>An important regulation: the distinctive emblem of the Convention and the Protocol <em>may be displayed only on medical</em></p><p><em>units and by medical personnel protected by the Convention and the Protocol, and only with the consent of the competent</em></p><p><em>authority. </em>Strict observance of this rule is essential to respect the Convention the Protocol.[I, 42; P. II, 18]</p><p>In naval warfare, ships and craft entitled to the protection the Convention will be marked as follows:[II, 43]</p><p>a) <em>all exterior surfaces must be white,.</em></p><p><em>b) one or more dark red crosses, as large as possible, must painted on each side of the hull as well as on</em></p><p><em>horizontal surfaces, so as to afford the greatest possible visibility from the sea and from the air. A white flag with a</em></p><p><em>red cross shall be flown at the mainmast, as high as possible.</em></p><p><em>The international Red Cross organizations and their duly authorized personnel are permitted to use the emblem of the red</em></p><p><em>cross on a white ground at all times.</em>[I, 44]</p><p>Apart from these regulations, the use of the emblem or the designation “red cross” or “Geneva cross”, or any sign or</p><p>designation constituting an imitation, shall be prohibited at all times; the necessary measures will be taken to prevent and</p><p>repress any abuse of these distinctive signs. The perfidious use of the emblem of the red cross (and other protective signs</p><p>or signals) is a grave breach.[I, 53, 54; II, 45; P. I, 18, 85]</p><p>In addition to the distinctive emblem, the Parties to the conflict may authorize the use of distinctive signals (light, radio</p><p>and secondary radar signals, internationally recognized codes and signals).[P. I, 18 and Annex I]</p><p><strong>Notes</strong></p><p>1. For protected medical personnel, see point 9.</p><p>2. As far as Possible, military medical units and especially civilian medical units should be placed</p><p>well out of the way of military objectives.</p><p>3. Protected personnel must carry identity cards and make themselves known by means of the</p><p>distinctive emblem of the red cross or red crescent (1, 40, 41; 11, 42; P. 1, 18 and Annex 1, Chapter I</p><p>and II). They may be armed for their own defence and that of the wounded in their charge (I, 22; II, 35; P. 1, 13).</p><p>4. The form of the cross is not specified but it has become customary to use a so-called Greek cross, i.e. a cross with four</p><p>arms of equal length not touching the edge of the shield, comprising the inverted colours of the Swiss flag. Instead of the</p><p>red cross, some countries use the red crescent. The red lionand-sun emblem is no longer in use.</p><p>31-12-1988</p><p>Rules relating to the conduct of combatants and the protection of prisoners of war</p><p>Page 1 of 9</p><p>International Committee of the Red Cross</p><p><strong>31-12-1988</strong><strong></strong></p><p><strong>Rules relating to the conduct of combatants and the protection of</strong></p><p><strong>prisoners of war</strong></p><p><strong>Geneva Convention relative to the treatment of prisoners of war </strong>(Convention III of 12 August 1949)</p><p><strong>Additional Protocol I, Part II</strong></p><p><strong>Contents:</strong></p><p><strong>Section I</strong></p><p>Status</p><p><strong>Section II</strong></p><p>Regulations relating to the conduct of combatants</p><p><strong>Section III</strong></p><p>Protection of prisoners of war</p><p>1. Rights and obligations</p><p>2. Protection and treatment</p><p>3. Physical conditions of internment</p><p>4. Moral and psychological conditions of internment</p><p>5. Aid</p><p>6. Discipline</p><p>a) General observations</p><p>b) Escapes or attempts to escape</p><p>c) Prisoners’ representatives</p><p>d) Sanctions</p><p>7. Repatriation</p><p>a) Direct repatriation and hospitalization in a neutral country</p><p>b) Release and repatriation at the end of hostilities</p><p>8. Death</p><p>9. Information bureaux and Central Tracing Agency</p><p>10. Assistance by relief societies and the ICRC</p><p>11. The right of Protecting Powers and the ICRC to visit</p><p><em>(Please note: Roman numerals indicate the number of the Convention or the Protocol (designated by the</em></p><p><em>letter</em></p><p><em>P), Arabic numerals refer to the articles of these instruments.)</em></p><p><strong>Section I</strong></p><p><strong>Status</strong></p><p>The status of prisoner of War is governed jointly by article 4 of the Third Convention and by articles 43 and</p><p>44 of</p><p>the Protocol. The general principle is the following: <em>any member of the armed forces of a Party to a conflict</em></p><p><em>is a</em></p><p><em>combatant and any combatant captured by the adverse Party is a prisoner of war.</em>[III, 4; P. I, 43, 44]</p><p>This general rule is supplemented by three types of provisions which specify the conditions in which armed</p><p>forces are recognized as such, to extend the qualification (or the treatment) of prisoner of war to categories</p><p>of persons not covered by the general rule, and finally to deprive, in a specific case, a captured combatant</p><p>of his qualification as a combatant and hence of his status of prisoner of war.</p><p><strong>Extract from “Basic rules of the </strong><strong>Geneva</strong><strong> Conventions and their Additional Protocols”</strong></p><p>Rules relating to the conduct of combatants and the protection of prisoners of war</p><p>Page 2 of 9</p><p>a) <em>To be recognized as such, the armed forces of a Party to a conflict must be organized and placed under a</em></p><p><em>command responsible to that Party for the conduct of its subordinates, even if that Party is represented by</em></p><p><em>a government or other authority not recognized by the adverse Party. In addition, these armed forces must</em></p><p><em>be subject to an internal disciplinary system which, </em>inter alia, <em>enforces compliance with the rules of</em></p><p><em>internationallaw applicable in armed conflicts. In particular, this compliance requires combatants to</em></p><p><em>distinguish themselves from civilians, except in particular circumstances (see point c below) by a uniform or</em></p><p><em>other distinctive sign, visible and recognizable at a distance, while they are engaged in an attack or in a</em></p><p><em>military operation preparatory to an attack. Violation by a combatant of the rules applicable in armed</em></p><p><em>conflict is punishable but if this combatant at least carries his arms openly during the engagement, he is not</em></p><p><em>deprived of his right to the status of prisoner of war in case of capture. If the Party to which these armed</em></p><p><em>forces belong omits or deliberately refuses to enforce compliance with these rules, it can result in all</em></p><p><em>members of these forces losing their status of combatant and prisoner of war</em>. (1)</p><p><em>b) The status or treatment of prisoner of war is </em>extended to <em>various categories of persons who do not come</em></p><p><em>under</em></p><p><em>the definition of combatants as given below, or who are not combatants. The following are thus also entitled</em></p><p><em>to the</em></p><p><em>status </em>of <em>prisoner of war:</em></p><p>– those taking part in a levy en masse, that is, when the inhabitants of a non-occupied territory</p><p>spontaneously take</p><p>up arms on the approach of the enemy to combat invasion without having had time to organize themselves</p><p>as laid down under point a) above, if they carry their arms openly and respect the laws and customs of war;</p><p>-persons authorized to follow the armed forces without being directly part of them;</p><p>-crews of the merchant marine and civil aviation;</p><p>-members of military personnel serving in civil defence organizations.[P. I, 67]</p><p>The following are entitled only to the <em>treatment </em>of prisoner of war:</p><p>– persons arrested in occupied territory because they belong to the armed forces of the occupied country;</p><p>– military internees in a neutral country;</p><p>– members of non-combatant medical and religious personnel who are part of the armed forces.</p><p>c) <em>In exceptional cases, when required by the nature of the hostilities, a combatant can be released from</em></p><p><em>the</em></p><p><em>obligation to distinguish himself from the civilian population by wearing a uniform or distinctive sign</em></p><p><em>recognizable at</em></p><p><em>a distance during military operations. However, in such situations, these combatants must distinguish</em></p><p><em>themselves</em></p><p><em>by carrying arms openly during the engagement and during such time as they are visible to the adversary</em></p><p><em>while</em></p><p><em>engaged in a military deployment preceding the launching of an attack in which they are to participate.
