Even</em></p><p><em>failing</em></p><p><em>to comply with the obligation of carrying arms openly can deprive a combatant of his status, but not of the</em></p><p><em>guarantees relating to it, in the case of his being prosecuted for carrying arms illegally either with or</em></p><p><em>without other</em></p><p><em>offences. </em>(2)</p><p>These provisions are not intended to modify the generally accepted practice of uniforms being worn by</p><p>members of regular armed units of the Parties to conflicts.</p><p>To avoid uncertainty and prevent any arbitrary measures at the time of capture, the Protocol specifies that</p><p>any person taking part in hostilities and captured is presumed to be a prisoner of war and is treated as a</p><p>prisoner of war, <em>even in case of doubt </em>as to his status. In the latter case, the question will be decided by a</p><p>tribunal at a later date. A person who, having taken part in hostilities, is eventually deprived of his right to</p><p>the status of prisoner of war, benefits not only from the provisions of the Fourth Convention applicable in his</p><p>case but also from the fundamental guarantees laid down in article 75 of the Protocol (see Section Ill, point</p><p>6 at end, below page 31).[III, 5; P. I, 45]</p><p><em>Spies and mercenaries </em>are not entitled to the status of prisoner of war. <em>Children </em>under the age of fifteen</p><p>shall not be recruited into the armed forces.(3) [P. I, 46, 47]</p><p>Rules relating to the conduct of combatants and the protection of prisoners of war</p><p>Page 3 of 9</p><p><em>Children </em>under the age of fifteen shall not be recruited into the armed forces.[P. I, 77]</p><p><strong>Section II</strong></p><p><strong>Rules relating to the conduct of combatants</strong></p><p>Part III of the Protocol does not confine itself to stating the rules relating to the status and treatment of</p><p>prisoners of war. It also recalls the correct conduct of combatants in the course of hostilities. The</p><p>fundamental principle forming the basis of these rules is that <em>the right of the Parties to the conflict to choose</em></p><p><em>methods or means of warfare is not unlimited.</em>[P. I, 35]</p><p>For example, it is prohibited to employ weapons, projectiles and methods and materials of warfare of a</p><p>nature to cause superfluous injury, particularly those which are intended to cause, or can be expected to</p><p>cause widespread, long-term and severe damage to the natural environment. Neither may the presence of</p><p>civilian persons be used to render certain points or areas immune from military operations.[P. I, 51; IV, 28]</p><p><em>It is prohibited to kill, injure or capture an adversary by resort to perfidy. </em>Acts inviting the confidence of an</p><p>adversary to lead him to believe that he is entitled to receive, or is obliged to accord protection under the</p><p>rules of international law applicable in armed conflict, with intent to betray that confidence, shall constitute</p><p>perfidy. The recognized emblems (the white flag, the emblem of cultural property, other recognized</p><p>protective signs) and in particular the sign of the red cross or red crescent must not be used improperly.</p><p>The use of the national insignia of States not Parties to the conflict is forbidden. The national insignia of the</p><p>adverse Party must not be used during attacks or in order to shield, favour, protect or impede military</p><p>operations.[P. I, 37; P. I, 38; P, I, 39]</p><p>The Protocol thus asserts that the law of armed conflicts demands a minimum of honesty on the part of the</p><p>combatants. Other rules of conduct of combatants are summarized either in Section I of this chapter or in</p><p>the relevant chapters of this manual (see in particular Chapter 1, points 2 and 5, Chapter 11, points 3-4 and</p><p>7-11 and Chapter IV, Section 1). But it should be stressed here, once again, that it is prohibited to declare</p><p>that no <em>quarter </em>will be given, to threaten the adversary with this and to conduct hostilities in such a way</p><p>that there are no survivors. The enemy who is hors de combat, or who has surrendered, or who shows his</p><p>intention to surrender, or who has parachuted from an aircraft in distress, shall not be made the object of</p><p>attack. If the capturing Party is unable to evacuate its prisoners from the fighting zone, it must release</p><p>them and take all feasible precautions to ensure their safety.[P. I, 40, 41, 42]</p><p><strong>Section III</strong></p><p><strong>Protection of prisoners of war</strong></p><p><strong>1. Rights and obligations</strong></p><p>Regarding the rights of prisoners of war, the principle specifying that prisoners of war are in the hands of</p><p>the enemy Power, but not of the individuals or military units who have captured them, should be borne in</p><p>mind. Prisoners of war are entitled in all circumstances to respect for their persons and their honour. [III,</p><p>12, 14]</p><p>Women must be treated with all the regard due to their sex and shall in all cases benefit from treatment at</p><p>least as favourable as that granted to men. Finally, it should be noted that prisoners of war retain the full</p><p>civil capacity they had at the time of their capture. Within the limits imposed by captivity, they therefore</p><p>continue to enjoy their civil rights according to the law of their country of origin. In particular, they can</p><p>marry by proxy.[III, 14]</p><p>As for the duties of prisoners, they are generally derived from the laws of war and the rules of military</p><p>discipline.</p><p>Some of these duties are formally stated in the Convention; thus article 17, relating to <em>questioning </em>of the</p><p>prisoner, specifies that he is bound to give his name, first names and rank, date of birth and army,</p><p>regimental, personal or serial number or, failing this, equivalent information.(4) However, the same article</p><p>adds that no physical or mental torture, nor any other form of coercion may be inflicted on prisoners of war</p><p>to obtain from them information of any kind whatever.[III, 17]</p><p>Rules relating to the conduct of combatants and the protection of prisoners of war</p><p>Page 4 of 9</p><p>The Convention also provides for the case – which is not excluded, if the laws of the Power on which</p><p>prisoners depend allow it – for the <em>release on parole </em>or promise. Article 21 states that prisoners released</p><p>under these conditions will be bound, on their personal honour, scrupulously to fulfil, both towards the</p><p>Power on which they depend and the Power which has captured them, the engagements of their paroles or</p><p>promises.[III, 21]</p><p>This mention is important for it shows that honesty is essential to the successful application of humanitarian</p><p>rules.</p><p><strong>2. Protection and treatment</strong></p><p>The Protocol prohibits declaring that no quarter will be given, threatening the adversary with this, and</p><p>conducting hostilities in such a way that there are no survivors. The enemy who is hors de combat, who has</p><p>surrendered or who shows his intention of surrendering, or who has parachuted from an aircraft in distress</p><p>shall not be the object of attack.[P. I, 40, 41, 42]</p><p>In these articles, the Convention states that <em>prisoners of war must at all times be treated humanely </em>and</p><p>that subject to any privileged treatment on account of rank, sex, state of health, age or professional</p><p>qualifications, all prisoners of war shall be treated alike. The Protocol specifies that no prisoner may be</p><p>subjected to physical mutilation or to medical and scientific experiments of any nature whatever, which are</p><p>not justified by the medical treatment of the prisoner concerned and which are not in his interest. It</p><p>nevertheless allows for exceptions in the case of donations of blood for transfusion or of skin for grafting,</p><p>providing that these are voluntary.[III, 13, 16; P. I, 11]</p><p>Among the <em>general principles </em>protecting prisoners of war, the following should also be mentioned: they shall</p><p>not be unnecessarily exposed to danger while awaiting evacuation from a fighting zone. When they have</p><p>been captured under unusual conditions of combat which prevent their being evacuated in the normal way,</p><p>they shall be released and all feasible precautions shall be taken to ensure their safety.[III, 19; P. I, 41]</p><p>Prisoners of war may be interned only in premises located on land and affording every guarantee of hygiene</p><p>and wholesomeness. No prisoner of war may at any time be sent to or detained in an area where he may be</p><p>exposed to the fire of the combat zone, nor may his presence be used to render certain points or areas</p><p>immune from military operations.[III, 22,23]</p><p><em>Prisoners without the recognized status of prisoner of war are at all times entitled to the fundamental</em></p><p><em>guarantees (see Chapter </em>IV, Section II, Point 2, letter g, page 43 and point 6 below, guarantees of judicial</p><p>procedure).</p><p><strong>3. Physical conditions of internment</strong></p><p>The Detaining Power assumes general responsibility for the life and welfare of prisoners of war, who must be</p><p>kept in good health. Women and children under the age of fifteen becoming prisoners of war must be</p><p>treated with special respect and protected against any form of indecent assault. Other information</p><p>concerning the application of these principles can be found under the following headings: [P. I 76, 77]</p><p><strong>Quarters </strong>[III, 25]</p><p><strong>Food </strong>[III, 26, 28]</p><p><strong>Clothing </strong>[III, 27]</p><p><strong>Hygiene and medical attention </strong>[III, 29, 30, 31]</p><p>Under all circumstances, prisoners of war will receive any medical care they may need and will preferably be</p><p>treated by medical personnel of the Power on which they depend and, if possible, of their nationality.</p><p><strong>Transfers </strong>[III, 12, 46, 48]</p><p>Prisoners of war may only be transferred to a Power which is a party to the Convention and after the</p><p>Detaining Power has satisfied itself that the Power in question is willing and able to apply the Convention.</p><p>Transfer within the territory of the Detaining Power will always be carried out humanely and in conditions no</p><p>less favourable than those enjoyed by the troops of the Detaining Power during their movements.</p><p>Rules relating to the conduct of combatants and the protection of prisoners of war</p><p>Page 5 of 9</p><p><strong>4. Moral and psychological conditions of internment</strong></p><p>The Convention is not only concerned with the physical conditions of internment. A great number of articles</p><p>are devoted to moral and psychological conditions. They deal not only with religion, intellectual and sports</p><p>activities but also with the kind of work considered suitable to maintain prisoners’ self-respect and mental</p><p>well-being and protect them from boredom and idleness. In application of these principles, the Convention</p><p>includes a number of provisions on the following matters:</p><p><strong>Religion </strong>[III, 34, 35]</p><p><strong>Intellectual and sports activities </strong>[III, 38]</p><p><strong>Work </strong>[III, 49, 50, 51, 57]</p><p>In order to prevent the work carried out by prisoners from degenerating into inhumane exploitation or</p><p>participation in the war effort of the Detaining Power, such work is limited by a series of very strict rules.</p><p><strong>Property and working pay </strong>[III, 18, 28, 59, 60, 61, 62]</p><p><strong>Correspondence </strong>[III, 71, 74, 76]</p><p>Prisoners of war shall be allowed to send and receive letters and cards free of postage.(5)</p><p><strong>5. Aid</strong></p><p>The Convention affirms the right of prisoners of war to receive relief.</p><p>Relief supplies may be individual or collective but the Convention indicates a preference to relief parcels of a</p><p>standard model, intended for all the prisoners in a camp and shared out among them by prisoners’</p><p>representatives.(6) [III, 72]</p><p>All relief shipments are exempt from import, customs and other dues and the experience acquired by the</p><p>ICRC and National Red Cross Societies in the course of the two World Wars is implicitly recognized.[III, 74,</p><p>75]</p><p><strong>6. Discipline</strong></p><p><strong>a) General observations</strong></p><p>To ensure discipline in accordance with military honour, every prisoner of war camp is placed under the</p><p>immediate authority responsible commissioned officer belonging to the regular at forces of the Detaining</p><p>Power.[III, 39]</p><p>This officer must be fully acquainted with the <em>text of the Convention </em>and the relevant provisions of the</p><p>Protocol. These texts must also be posted in each camp, in the prisoners’ own language, in places where all</p><p>may read them. The wearing of badges of rank and nationality, as well as decorations, shall be permitted, in</p><p>due respect for the dignity of the persons concerned.[III, 41; P. I, 83; III, 40]</p><p>Military commanders must ensure that members of the armed forces under their command are aware of</p><p>their obligations under the Conventions and the Protocol. They are responsible for preventing any breaches</p><p>of these provisions, for suppressing them and, if necessary, reporting them to the competent authorities.[P.</p><p>I, 87]</p><p><strong>b) Escapes or attempts to escape</strong></p><p>The Convention has several provisions relating to escapes or attempts to escape. These are accepted as</p><p>being consistent with military honour and patriotic courage. Punishments incurred in cases of escape are</p><p>consequently limited. Weapons may be used against prisoners who escape or attempt to escape, but such</p><p>use should only be made as a last resort and must always be preceded by warnings appropriate to the</p><p>circumstances.[III, 91, 92, 93; III, 42]</p><p><strong>c) Prisoners’ representatives</strong></p><p>Article 79 stipulates that in all places where there are prisoners of war, except in those where there are</p><p>officers, the prisoners shall freely elect by secret ballot, every six months, and in case of vacancies,</p><p>representatives entrusted with representing them before the military authorities, the Protecting Powers, the</p><p>ICRC and any other organization which may assist them. These prisoners’ representatives shall be eligible</p><p>Rules relating to the conduct of combatants and the protection of prisoners of war</p><p>Page 6 of 9</p><p>for re-election. In camps for officers and persons of equivalent status or in mixed camps, the senior-ranking</p><p>officer among the prisoners of war shall be recognized as the camp prisoners’ representative.[III, 79]</p><p>This institution is very important. Benefiting from various prerogatives and facilities enumerated in article</p><p>81, the prisoners’ representative is the intermediary qualified to further the physical, spiritual and</p><p>intellectual well-being of prisoners of war.[III, 80, 81]</p><p>He not only supervises the <em>distribution of relief supplies </em>but also does all he can to mitigate the severities of</p><p>discipline, to <em>help prisoners </em>in their difficulties with the detaining authority.</p><p>Finally, it should be stressed that prisoners must have the unrestricted right to apply to the representatives</p><p>of the Protecting Powers, either through their prisoners’ representative or, if they consider it necessary,</p><p>direct, in order to draw their attention to any points on which they may have complaints about their</p><p>conditions of captivity.[III, 78]</p><p><strong>d) Sanctions</strong></p><p>The Convention specifies that <em>prisoners of war shall be subject to the laws, regulations and orders in force in</em></p><p><em>the armed forces of the Detaining Power.</em>[III, 82]</p><p>A general leniency clause protects prisoners of war against excessively severe interpretation of the laws and</p><p>regulations. In deciding whether an offence committed by a prisoner of war should be subject to disciplinary</p><p>or judicial punishment, the Detaining Power shall ensure that the competent authorities exercise the</p><p>greatest leniency and adopt, wherever possible, disciplinary rather than judicial measures.[III, 83]</p><p><em>Disciplinary sanctions </em>may only be ordered by the camp commander or an officer appointed by him, and in</p><p>no case by a prisoner of war. Moreover, certain concessions are granted to prisoners undergoing disciplinary</p><p>punishment: permission to take exercise and to be in the open air for at least two hours daily, permission to</p><p>read and write, as well as to send and receive letters.[III, 96, 98]</p><p>Finally, in no case shall disciplinary punishments be inhuman, brutal or dangerous to the health of prisoners</p><p>of war and the duration of any single punishment shall never exceed thirty days.[III, 89, 90]</p><p>As far as <em>judicial sanctions </em>are concerned, a prisoner of war may only be tried by a military court, except</p><p>under specified circumstances. Furthermore, prisoners of war may not be sentenced to any penalties other</p><p>than those imposed for the same acts committed by members of the armed forces of the Detaining Power.</p><p>Collective punishment for individual acts is forbidden, as are corporal punishment, imprisonment in premises</p><p>without daylight and, in general, torture or cruelty in any form whatsoever.[III, 84, 87]</p><p>It is important to note that prisoners who are prosecuted shall still benefit from the Convention, even if they</p><p>are convicted.[III,85]</p><p><em>The death penalty </em>can be imposed, in principle, for offences liable to capital punishment in the armed forces</p><p>of the Detaining Power. Since the accused is not a national of the Detaining Power, owes it no allegiance,</p><p>and is in its power as a result of circumstances beyond his control, the court must take these facts into</p><p>account before pronouncing a death sentence.[III, 100]</p><p>As far as possible, the death penalty shall not be pronounced on pregnant women or mothers having</p><p>dependent infants. If it is pronounced, it will not be carried out. The same will apply to prisoners under the</p><p>age of eighteen at the time the offence was committed.[P. I, 76; P. I, 77]</p><p>Article 101 extends to at least six months the <em>period that must elapse </em>between the time the death penalty</p><p>is pronounced and the time the sentence is executed. Furthermore, Article 107 provides an opportunity for</p><p>the Protecting Power to intervene in the case of a death sentence being pronounced.[III, 101, 107]</p><p><em>The guarantees of judicial procedure form part of the fundamental guarantees, which means that they must</em></p><p><em>be accorded even to prisoners whose status of prisoner of war is not recognized.</em></p><p><em>Judicial procedure must be regular, i.e. it must include at least the following guarantees: the accused to be</em></p><p><em>informed without delay of the particulars of the offence he is alleged to have committed, which must have</em></p><p><em>constituted an offence at the time it was committed; presumption of innocence; no coercion on a prisoner to</em></p><p>Rules relating to the conduct of combatants and the protection of prisoners of war</p><p>Page 7 of 9</p><p><em>force him to confess judgement to be pronounced in the presence of the accused and, in principle, publicly.</em></p><p><em>The prisoner cannot be punished more than once for the same act or on the same charge if it is based on</em></p><p><em>the same law and the same judicial procedure.</em>[III, 86, 99; P. I, 75]</p><p><em>The rights of defence are recognized and guaranteed </em>and, accordingly, the prisoner of war shall be entitled</p><p>to be assisted by one of his fellow prisoners, to be defended by a qualified attorney of his own choice, to</p><p>call witnesses and, if he thinks it necessary, to employ the services of a competent interpreter. On the same</p><p>conditions as members of the armed forces of the Detaining Power, he will have the right of appeal with a</p><p>view to quashing or revising the sentence pronounced on him; any judgement and sentence shall be</p><p>immediately reported to the Protecting Power.[III, 105,106; P. I, 75]</p><p><strong>7. Repatriation</strong></p><p><strong>a) Direct repatriation and hospitalization in a neutral country</strong></p><p>Even during hostilities, the Convention prescribes the direct return to their own countries of the wounded</p><p>and sick</p><p>whose mental or physical fitness seems to have been seriously impaired, and hospitalization in neutral</p><p>countries of</p><p>specific categories of those less seriously sick or wounded.[III, 109]</p><p>A model agreement, annexed to Convention 111 (Annex 1, referred to in Article I 10) cites numerous cases</p><p>which</p><p>can give rise to application of this principle. <em>Mixed Medical Commissions, set </em>up at the outbreak of</p><p>hostilities, are</p><p>called upon to decide what prisoners are to be repatriated. The Parties to the conflict must send back to</p><p>their own</p><p>country, regardless of number or rank, seriously wounded and sick prisoners of war, after caring for them</p><p>until they</p><p>are able to travel.[III, 112]</p><p>No sick or injured prisoner of war may be repatriated against his will during hostilities.</p><p>No repatriated person may be employed on active military service.[III, 117]</p><p><strong>b) Release and repatriation at the end of hostilities</strong></p><p>Situations which can arise at the end of a war have shown that the way in which the principle of the Code</p><p>for</p><p>prisoners of war of 1929 was worded, requiring the repatriation of prisoners on the conclusion of peace,</p><p>could be</p><p>detrimental to them, because experience has shown that a very long time can elapse between the time</p><p>hostilities</p><p>cease and the time peace is concluded. To remedy this, the Convention states that <em>repatriation will take</em></p><p><em>place</em></p><p><em>“without delay after the cessation of active hostilities”, </em>i.e. after the cease-fire.[III, 118]</p><p>One exception to immediate repatriation is provided in the case of prisoners convicted or prosecuted for</p><p>criminal</p><p>offences, who may be detained until the end of legal proceedings and, if necessary, until they have</p><p>completed their</p><p>sentences.[III, 119]</p><p><strong>8. Death</strong></p><p>Prisoners of war are entitled to make wills. The Convention prescribes that wills of prisoners of war shall be</p><p>drawn up so as to satisfy the conditions of validity required by legislation in their countries of origin, which</p><p>will take the necessary steps to inform the Detaining Power of its requirements in this respect.[III, 120]</p><p>The Convention specifies the conditions of burial (or, in certain cases cremation) appropriate to ensure</p><p>respect for the dead and to safeguard the interests of their families. The Protocol supplements these</p><p>Rules relating to the conduct of combatants and the protection of prisoners of war</p><p>Page 8 of 9</p><p>provisions.[III, 120; P. I, 35]</p><p>In case of death from suspicious causes, an enquiry is opened in order to determine responsibility,</p><p>particularly with a view to possible compensation for beneficiaries.[III, 121]</p><p>Death certificates must be forwarded as rapidly as possible to the Prisoner of War Information Bureaux.</p><p><strong>9. Information bureaux and Central Tracing Agency</strong></p><p>The services rendered to prisoners and their families by the Central Prisoner of War Agency (now known as</p><p>the Central Tracing Agency) during the two World Wars and the numerous conflicts since 1945 are well</p><p>known.</p><p>Created under the auspices of the ICRC, this Agency keeps in its archives over fifty million cards which</p><p>constitute a unique information system to establish the rights of prisoners or their families. In particular, it</p><p>contains all the information it can obtain through private or official sources concerning prisoners of war with</p><p>a view to determining their identity, and any particulars about them relating to transfers, releases,</p><p>repatriations, escapes, hospitalization and death.</p><p>These results have been consolidated by the Convention, which not only requires Governments to set up</p><p>official bureaux to collect and transmit information about prisoners of war, but provides for establishment of</p><p>a Central Prisoner of War Information Agency in a neutral country.[III, 122, 123; P. I, 34]</p><p>To facilitate the work of the national Bureaux and the Central Information Agency, States must grant them</p><p>free postage for mail, as well as all exemptions provided for in Article 74 and, as far as possible, exemption</p><p>from telegraphic charges or, at least, greatly reduced rates.(7) [III, 124]</p><p>Families have the right to know what has become of their relatives. <em>As soon as circumstances permit and, at</em></p><p><em>the latest, from the end of hostilities, the Parties to the conflict should therefore search for persons reported</em></p><p><em>missing by an adverse Party and transmit all relevant information concerning such persons in order to</em></p><p><em>facilitate the search.</em>[P. I, 33; III, 119]</p><p><strong>10. Assistance by relief societies and the ICRC</strong></p><p>Relief societies, the ICRC and the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies have played such an important role</p><p>in helping prisoners of war during the two World Wars that the Convention devotes an article to them, to</p><p>facilitate and encourage their activity.</p><p>This provision requires the Powers to grant them and their duly accredited delegates, all the necessary</p><p>facilitates to visit prisoners, distribute relief supplies and material from any source, for religious, educational</p><p>or recreative purposes, and help them organize their leisure activities within camps. The special status of</p><p>the ICRC in this sphere must be recognized and respected.[III, 125]</p><p><strong>11. The right of Protecting Powers and the ICRC to visit</strong></p><p>Furthermore, the Convention provides that representatives of the Protecting Powers shall have permission to</p><p>go to all places where prisoners of war may be, particularly to places of internment, imprisonment and</p><p>labour. </p></div></div>
37	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">IMPLEMENTATION OF MULTIMODAL TRANSPORT RULES</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/customes-conventions/implementation-of-multimodal-transport-rules/attachment/posdtetlbd2-en/" rel="attachment wp-att-6081">IMPLEMENTATION OF MULTIMODAL TRANSPORT RULES</a></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">CONTENTS</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Chapter Paragraphs</p><p style="text-align: justify;">INTRODUCTION . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 1 – 3</p><p style="text-align: justify;">I. MULTIMODAL TRANSPORT _ GENERAL OVERVIEW . . . 4 – 46</p><p style="text-align: justify;">A. Previous attempts to achieve uniformity . . . . . . . . 16 – 40</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) United Nations Convention on International</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Multimodal Transport of Goods 1980 . . . . . . 18 – 28</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) UNCTAD/ICC Rules for Multimodal Transport</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Documents . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 29</p><p style="text-align: justify;">– 40</p><p style="text-align: justify;">E.
