REGIONAL/SUBREGIONAL LAWS AND REGULATIONS . . 47 – 122</p><p style="text-align: justify;">A. Andean Community . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 47 – 69</p><p style="text-align: justify;">B. MERCOSUR . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 70 – 88</p><p style="text-align: justify;">C. ALADI . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 89 – 105</p><p style="text-align: justify;">D. Draft ASEAN Framework Agreement on</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Multimodal Transport . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 106 – 122</p><p style="text-align: justify;">III. NATIONAL LAWS AND REGULATIONS . . . . . . . . . . 123 – 245</p><p style="text-align: justify;">A. Argentina . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 123 – 142</p><p style="text-align: justify;">B. Austria . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 143 – 144</p><p style="text-align: justify;">C. Brazil . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 145 – 158</p><p style="text-align: justify;">D. China . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 159 – 194</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3</p><p style="text-align: justify;">E. Colombia . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .</p><p style="text-align: justify;">195</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Paragraphs</p><p style="text-align: justify;">F. Ecuador . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 196</p><p style="text-align: justify;">G. Egypt . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 197</p><p style="text-align: justify;">H. Germany . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 198 – 214</p><p style="text-align: justify;">I. India . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 215 – 229</p><p style="text-align: justify;">J. Mexico . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 230 – 234</p><p style="text-align: justify;">K. Netherlands . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 235 –</p><p style="text-align: justify;">244</p><p style="text-align: justify;">L. Paraguay . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 245</p><p style="text-align: justify;">IV. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS . . . . . . . . . . . . . 246 – 254</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>INTRODUCTION</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. The Plan of Action (TD/386) adopted by UNCTAD X, in Bangkok in February 2000,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">states in paragraph 152, that: “In close cooperation with other relevant international</p><p style="text-align: justify;">organizations, UNCTAD should continue to undertake studies on the implementation of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">multimodal transport rules.”</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. To prepare the requested study, the secretariat conducted an inquiry into the existing</p><p style="text-align: justify;">rules and legislation applicable to multimodal transport of goods. A note verbale (dated 14</p><p style="text-align: justify;">April 2000) was sent to all member States of UNCTAD inviting them to provide the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">secretariat with a copy of their national laws/regulations, if any, including other relevant</p><p style="text-align: justify;">information and documentation which may be used in practice. This document attempts to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">provide an overview of the existing laws and regulations governing multimodal transportation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It reflects the information received from Governments in response to the note verbale as well</p><p style="text-align: justify;">as documentation that the secretariat could otherwise obtain from various countries and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">regional or subregional organizations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. In order to provide a clear picture as to the nature and basis of various legislation</p><p style="text-align: justify;">adopted at the national and regional/subregional level, it may be appropriate to provide a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">general background for the subject, including problems associated with present practice as</p><p style="text-align: justify;">well as previous attempts to provide a uniform international legal framework for multimodal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">transport of goods. As will be seen from the report, the long desired uniformity of law</p><p style="text-align: justify;">governing the international multimodal transport of goods has not yet been achieved. The</p><p style="text-align: justify;">subject still occupies the attention of various international and intergovernmental organizations</p><p style="text-align: justify;">as well as individual Governments. The search for uniformity of law in this important area</p><p style="text-align: justify;">continues and clearly requires treatment in a global forum on a priority basis.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Chapter I</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>MULTIMODAL TRANSPORT _ GENERAL OVERVIEW</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>A. What is multimodal transport?</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. The most authoritative definition of the term “international multimodal transport” is</p><p style="text-align: justify;">provided in article 1 (1) of the United Nations Convention on International Multimodal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Transport of Goods 1980 (hereinafter referred to as the MT Convention) which reads as</p><p style="text-align: justify;">follows:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">“ ‘International multimodal transport’ means the carriage of goods by at least two</p><p style="text-align: justify;">different modes of transport on the basis of a multimodal transport contract from a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">place in one country at which the goods are taken in charge by the multimodal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">transport operator to a place designated for delivery situated in a different country…”</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. This definition should be read in conjunction with the definition of the term</p><p style="text-align: justify;">“multimodal transport operator” (MTO) provided in article 1(2) of the MT Convention, which</p><p style="text-align: justify;">provides:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">“ ‘Multimodal transport operator’ means any person who on his own behalf or through</p><p style="text-align: justify;">another person acting on his behalf concludes a multimodal transport contract and who</p><p style="text-align: justify;">acts as a principal, not as an agent or on behalf of the consignor or of the carriers</p><p style="text-align: justify;">participating in the multimodal transport operations, and who assumes responsibility</p><p style="text-align: justify;">for the performance of the contract.”</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. Thus, the main features of a multimodal transport are: the carriage of goods by two or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">more modes of transport, under one contract, one document and one responsible party (MTO)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">for the entire carriage, who might subcontract the performance of some, or all modes, of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">carriage to other carriers.1 The terms “combined transport” and “intermodal transport” are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">often used interchageably to describe the carriage of goods by two or more modes of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">transport.2</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>B. Background</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 The glossary of the terms used in combined transport and related field issued by the United Nations</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Economic Commission for Europe (UN/ECE), defines “multimodal transport”as “carriage of goods by two or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">more modes of transport.” The glossary is intended for the work of the three intergovernmental organizations,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">namely the European Community, the European Conference of Ministers of Transport (ECMT) and the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">UN/ECE. It is, however, specified that the “definitions are not applicable in their strictest sense to the legal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and statistical fields, whose relevant documents of reference exist already.” See document:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">TRANS/WP.24/2000/1.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 “Intermodal Transport” has been defined as “the movement of goods in one and the same loading</p><p style="text-align: justify;">unit or road vehicle, which uses successively two or more modes of transport without handling the goods</p><p style="text-align: justify;">themselves in changing modes.” “Combined Transport” is defined as “intermodal transport where the major</p><p style="text-align: justify;">part of the European journey is by rail, inland and waterways or sea and any initial or final legs carried out by</p><p style="text-align: justify;">road are as short as possible.” See document TRANS/WP.24/2000/1.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. The development of new transportation techniques, such as containerization and other</p><p style="text-align: justify;">means of unitization of goods in the 1960s, also introduced a significant need for modification</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of commercial and traditional legal approaches to transport. Goods stowed in a container</p><p style="text-align: justify;">could be transported by different means of transport, such as ships, railway wagons, road</p><p style="text-align: justify;">vehicles or aircrafts, from the point of origin to the final place of destination, without being</p><p style="text-align: justify;">unpacked for sorting or verification when being transferred from one means of transport to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">another. Gradually, more and more operators took responsibility for the whole transport chain</p><p style="text-align: justify;">under one single transport contract. Shippers/consignees needed to pursue one single</p><p style="text-align: justify;">operator, in the event of loss of, or damage to, the goods involved in multimodal transport,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">who would be responsible for the overall transport, rather than against several unimodal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">carriers involved. There was a need for an international legal framework for multimodal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">transport of goods.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. In spite of various attempts to establish a uniform legal framework governing multimodal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">transport3 no such international regime is in force. The MT Convention has failed to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">attract sufficient ratifications to enter into force. The UNCTAD/ICC Rules for Multimodal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Transport Documents, which came into force in January 1992, do not have the force of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">They are standard contract terms for incorporation into multimodal transport documents. The</p><p style="text-align: justify;">rules, being contractual in nature, will have no effect in the event of conflict with mandatory</p><p style="text-align: justify;">law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. The lack of a widely acceptable international legal framework on the subject has</p><p style="text-align: justify;">resulted in individual governments and regional/subregional intergovernmental bodies4 taking</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the initiative of enacting legislation in order to overcome the uncertainties and problems which</p><p style="text-align: justify;">presently exist. Concerns have been expressed regarding the proliferation of individual and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">possibly divergent legal approaches which would add to already existing confusion and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">uncertainties pertaining to the legal regime of multimodal transport.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. A multimodal operation is made up of a number of unimodal stages of transport, such</p><p style="text-align: justify;">as sea, road, rail or air. Each of these is subject to a mandatory international convention or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">national law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>C. International conventions applicable to unimodal transportation</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. International conventions applicable to unimodal transport include:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Transport by sea</strong>:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">– International Convention for the Unification of Certain Rules of Law Relating to Bills</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of Lading, 1924 (Hague Rules);</p><p style="text-align: justify;">– Protocol to Amend the International Convention for the Unification of Certain Rules</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Relating to Bills of Lading 1924, (Hague/Visby Rules) 1968;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 See paragraphs 16-40.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 See chapters II and III.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7</p><p style="text-align: justify;">– Protocol Amending the International Convention for the Unification of Certain Rules</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of Law Relating to Bills of Lading, 1924, as Amended by the Protocol of 1968, 1979;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">– United Nations Convention on the Carriage of Goods by Sea, 1978 (Hamburg Rules).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Transport by road:</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">– Convention on the Contract for the International Carriage of Goods by Road (CMR)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1956.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Transport by rail:</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">– Uniform Rules Concerning the Contract for International Carriage of Goods by Rail</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(CIM), Appendix B to the Convention Concerning International Carriage by Rail</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(COTIF), May 1980.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">– Protocol to amend CIM-COTIF, 1999.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Transport by air:</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">– Convention for the Unification of Certain Rules Relating to International Carriage by</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Air (Warsaw Convention), 1929;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">– The   Hague Protocol, 1955;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">– Montreal Protocol No. 4, 1975;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">– The Montreal Convention, 1999.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. The problem which arises is the extent to which these mandatory conventions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">applicable to unimodal transportation would also influence contracts where more than one</p><p style="text-align: justify;">mode of transport is involved,5 bearing in mind that some of these unimodal conventions also</p><p style="text-align: justify;">extend their scope into multimodal transport.6 For example the CMR (article 2), CIM (article</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 See Ramberg J., UNCTAD/ICC Rules for Multimodal Transport Documents: Origins and Contents,</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Simposio Maritimo: El Transporte Multimodal Internacional y su Impacto en las Actividades del Transporte</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Maritimo</em>. International Chamber of Commerce, Barcelona 2-3 April 1992. See also Mankabady S., The</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Multimodal Transport of Goods Convention: A Challenge to Unimodal Transport Conventions, <em>The</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>International and Comparative Law Quarterly</em>, Vol. 32, Part I, January 1983: 123-124.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6 At a seminar held in London, United Kingdom Law Commissioner Faber D., concluded her</p><p style="text-align: justify;">presentation by saying: “The multimodal transport industry is investing heavily in improving its services. It is</p><p style="text-align: justify;">a very sophisticated industry but the same cannot be said of its legal infrastructure. There is a large number of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">transports conventions which are potentially applicable to any contract. This means that enormous sums,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">which would be better applied commercially, are spent in legal disputes as to whether the contract terms or a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">convention and, if so which convention, should apply to govern relations between contracting parties. The best</p><p style="text-align: justify;">way forward would be to abolish all the individual conventions and introduce one which would govern all</p><p style="text-align: justify;">transport contracts, by whatever means of transport and whether unimodal or multimodal. This may mean</p><p style="text-align: justify;">legal expenditure in the short term, while precedents are established for the construction of such a convention,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2) and Montreal Conventions specifically include provisions dealing with transport of goods</p><p style="text-align: justify;">by more than one mode. In any event, in the absence of a uniform liability system for</p><p style="text-align: justify;">multimodal transport, the liability for each stage of transport is determined by the relevant</p><p style="text-align: justify;">unimodal convention or national laws which adopt varying approaches to issues such as the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">liability questions. Therefore, the liability of the multimodal transport operator for loss or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">damage to goods can differ depending on which stage of transport the loss has occurred. The</p><p style="text-align: justify;">question becomes even more complicated if the loss or damage cannot be localized, or the loss</p><p style="text-align: justify;">occurs gradually during the entire transport.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. Thus, the greatest shortcomings of transport law are considered to be: “the vast</p><p style="text-align: justify;">differences between the rules governing the different transport modes. Different grounds of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">liability, different limitations of liability, different documents with a different legal value,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">different time bars. Where it may perhaps be said that this particularism did not constitute</p><p style="text-align: justify;">such a formidable problem when unimodal transport was still predominant, its drawbacks</p><p style="text-align: justify;">become glaringly obvious when attempts are made to combine different transport modes, and,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">inevitably, their different legal regimes into a single transport operation governed by a single</p><p style="text-align: justify;">contract.”7</p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. These differences were also singled out by the Commission of the European</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Communities as one of the main obstacles in the field of trade facilitation. Thus, a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Communication to the Council for Trade in Goods of the World Trade Organization state</p><p style="text-align: justify;">that:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">“The consequence of current arrangements is therefore a patchwork of régimes which</p><p style="text-align: justify;">fails to capitalize on modern IT-based communications systems and practices, which</p><p style="text-align: justify;">impedes the introduction and use of a single multimodal waybill/transport document,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and which does not reflect fully the increased use of containerized transportation</p><p style="text-align: justify;">operating across different modes, making mode-specific liability arrangements</p><p style="text-align: justify;">inappropriate. In cases of loss or damage to goods, this creates uncertainty as to the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">time of loss/damage, uncertainty as to mode and identity of the carrier; and uncertainty</p><p style="text-align: justify;">as to the applicable legal regime for liability and its effects.”8</p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. Again, a recent study by the European Commission9 describes the current legal ability</p><p style="text-align: justify;">framework in the following terms:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">“The present legal framework determining a carrier’s liability consists of a confused</p><p style="text-align: justify;">jigsaw of international conventions designed to regulate unimodal carriage, diverse national</p><p style="text-align: justify;">laws and standard term contracts. ….As every intermodal transaction is made up of unimodal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">but in the long term it would obviate many of the current problems and save costs.” The Problems Arising</p><p style="text-align: justify;">From Multimodal Transport Law Seminar, 5-7 December 1994, Churchill Inter-Continental, London.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7 De Wit R., <em>Multimodal Transport: Carrier Liability and Documentation</em>. Lloyd’s of London Press,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1995, 7.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8 See Issues Relating to the Physical Movement of Consignments (Transport and Transit) &amp; Payment,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Insurance and other Financial Questions Affecting Cross-border Trade in Goods, G/C/W/133, 2 December</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1998, 3.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9 “International Transportation and Carrier Liability”, June 1999, section 1.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9</p><p style="text-align: justify;">stages, there are a number of mandatory international liability regimes which are potentially</p><p style="text-align: justify;">applicable, depending on their scope of application and the stage of transport where a damage</p><p style="text-align: justify;">or loss occurs. Accordingly, two different regimes may apply to the same claim or the regime</p><p style="text-align: justify;">which applies can only be identified when it is clear during which stage of the transport a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">loss/damage occurred. Where the stage of transport during which a loss or damage occurred</p><p style="text-align: justify;">cannot be identified, where loss or damage occur gradually, or in the course of (value-added)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">services ancillary to transportation (e.g. warehousing), a carrier’s liability will often depend on</p><p style="text-align: justify;">national laws and/or contractual agreement. As a result, both the applicable liability rules and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the degree and extent of a carrier’s liability vary greatly from case to case and are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">unpredictable. Liability for delay in delivery is not always covered by the same rules as liability</p><p style="text-align: justify;">for loss of or damage to the goods.”</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>D. Previous attempts to achieve uniformity</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. The establishment of a widely acceptable legal framework for multimodal transport has</p><p style="text-align: justify;">proved to be a difficult task. The first attempt was made by the International Institute for the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Unification of Private Law (UNIDROIT) and dates back as far as to the 1930s. The work</p><p style="text-align: justify;">within UNIDROIT resulted in the approval, by its Governing Council in 1963, of a “draft</p><p style="text-align: justify;">convention on the international combined transport of goods”,10 which was later revised by an</p><p style="text-align: justify;">ad hoc committee of experts. This was followed by the preparation and adoption by the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Comité Maritime International (CMI) of a “draft Convention on Combined Transport-Tokyo</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Rules” in 1969. The draft conventions prepared by UNIDROIT and CMI were combined into</p><p style="text-align: justify;">a single text in 1970, under the auspices of the Inland Transport Committee of the UN</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Economic Commission for Europe (UN/ECE), known as the “Rome Draft.” This draft was</p><p style="text-align: justify;">further modified by meetings of the UN/ECE and the Intergovernmental Consultative</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Organization (IMCO) during 1970 and 1971, and came to be known as the “Draft Convention</p><p style="text-align: justify;">on the International Combined Transport of Goods”, better known as the “TCM draft ”, using</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the French acronym for “Transport Combiné de Marchandises.” The TCM draft never went</p><p style="text-align: justify;">beyond the drafting stage. Its provisions were, however, subsequently reflected in standard</p><p style="text-align: justify;">bills of lading such as the Baltic and International Maritime Conference’s (BIMCO)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Combiconbill and in the “Uniform Rules for a Combined Transport Document” of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">International Chamber of Commerce (ICC).11</p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. The UN/IMCO Container Conference, which was to finalize the TCM draft in 1972,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">recommended that the subject be further studied, particularly its economic implications and the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">needs of developing countries. UNCTAD was proposed to undertake this task. The</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Intergovernmental Preparatory Group (IPG) was then set up by the Trade and Development</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Board (Decision 96 (XII) of May 1973) and, following an extensive investigation, eventually</p><p style="text-align: justify;">prepared the draft convention leading to the adoption of the United Nations Convention on</p><p style="text-align: justify;">International Multimodal Transport of Goods 1980.12</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10 UDP 1963, ET.XL.II.DOC.29</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11 The ICC Uniform Rules were first issued in 1973 as publication No. 273. They were slightly revised</p><p style="text-align: justify;">in October 1975 to overcome practical difficulties of application concerning the combined transport operator’s</p><p style="text-align: justify;">liability for delay (ICC Publication No.298). The ICC Rules were conceived as an essential measure to avoid a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">multiplicity of documents for combined transport operations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12 For further information see Selvig E., The background to the multimodal convention, paper delivered</p><p style="text-align: justify;">at a seminar in Southampton University, Faculty of Law, 12  September 1980; See also UNCTAD, The</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>(i) United Nations Convention on International Multimodal Transport</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>of Goods 1980</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. Although the Convention has not succeeded in attracting sufficient ratifications to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">enter into force13, its provisions have significantly influenced the type of legislation enacted in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">a number of countries/regions.14 The following are some of the main features of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">19. The Convention applies to all contracts of multimodal transport 15 between places in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">two States, if the place of taking in charge or delivery of the goods as provided for in the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">multimodal transport contract is located in a contracting State (article 2). While the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention recognizes the right of the consignee to choose between multimodal and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">segmented transport, its provisions are to apply mandatorily to all contracts of multimodal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">transport falling within the provisions of the Convention (article 3).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">20. The liability of the multimodal transport operator (MTO)16 for loss of, or damage to,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">goods as well as delay in delivery is based on the principle of “presumed fault or neglect.”</p><p style="text-align: justify;">That is to say that the MTO is liable if the occurrence which caused the loss, damage or delay</p><p style="text-align: justify;">in delivery took place while the goods were in his charge, unless the MTO proves that he, his</p><p style="text-align: justify;">servants or agents or any other person of whose services he makes use for the performance of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the contract, took all measures that could reasonably be required to avoid the occurrence and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">its consequences.17 This provision is modelled on article 5 (1) of the Hamburg Rules.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">21. A key issue in the context of establishing the liability of the MTO for loss of, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">damage to, goods has been the choice between the “uniform” or “network” system of liability.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Under the “uniform” system the same liability regime is applied to the entire multimodal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">transport, irrespective of the stage at which the loss or damage occurred. Under the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">“network” system, the liability of the MTO for localized damage (i.e. damage known to have</p><p style="text-align: justify;">occurred during a particular stage of transport) is determined by reference to the international</p><p style="text-align: justify;">convention or national law applicable to the unimodal stage of transport during which the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">damage occurred.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Economic and Commercial Implications of Entry into Force of the Hamburg Rules and Multimodal Transport</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convention, TD/B/C.4/3/5/Rev. 1, 1991, paragraphs. 39-45.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13 The Convention was to enter into force one year after ratification or accession by 30 States. As of 15</p><p style="text-align: justify;">June 2001 only the following ten States have ratified or acceded to the Convention: Burundi, Chile, Georgia,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Lebanon, Malawi, Mexico, Morocco, Rwanda, Senegal and Zambia. See http://untreaty.un.org/.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">14 See chapters II and III.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">15 “Multimodal transport contract” has been defined in article 1 (3) to mean “a contract whereby a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">multimodal transport operator undertakes, against payment of freight, to perform or to procure the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">performance of international multimodal transport.”</p><p style="text-align: justify;">16 Article 1 (2) defines “MTO” as “any person who on his own behalf or through another person acting</p><p style="text-align: justify;">on his behalf concludes a multimodal transport contract and who acts as a principal, not as an agent or on</p><p style="text-align: justify;">behalf of the consignor or of the carriers participating in the multimodal transport operations, and who</p><p style="text-align: justify;">assumes responsibility for the performance of the contract.”</p><p style="text-align: justify;">17 Article 16 (1).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11</p><p style="text-align: justify;">22. The Convention adopts a uniform system of liability of the MTO for both localized and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">non-localized damage (article 16 (1)), except that in cases of localized damage the limits of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">liability are to be determined by reference to the applicable international convention or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">mandatory national law which provide a higher limit of liability than that of the Convention</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(article 19). This approach, which is not entirely the “uniform”, is known as the “modified</p><p style="text-align: justify;">network” system.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">23. The period of responsibility of the MTO includes the entire period during which he is</p><p style="text-align: justify;">in charge of the goods, that is from the time he takes the goods in his charge to the time of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">delivery (article 14). The MTO is also liable for the acts and omissions of his servant or agent</p><p style="text-align: justify;">or any other person of whose services he makes use for the performance of the contract</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(article 15).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">24. The MTO’s liability for loss of, or damage to, goods is to be limited to an amount not</p><p style="text-align: justify;">exceeding 920 units of account per package or other shipping unit, or 2.75 units of account</p><p style="text-align: justify;">per kilogram of gross weight of the goods lost or damaged, whichever is the higher. If,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">however, the multimodal transport does not, according to the contract, include carriage by sea</p><p style="text-align: justify;">or by inland waterway, the limitation amount is raised to a higher level of 8.33 units of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">account (identical to that of the CMR) per kilogram of gross weight of the goods lost or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">damaged, without alternative package limitation (article 18 (1) and (3)). The limitation of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">liability of the MTO for loss resulting from delay in delivery is calculated by reference to the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">rate of freight, that is an amount equivalent to two and a half times the freight payable for the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">goods delayed, but without exceeding the total freight payable under the multimodal transport</p><p style="text-align: justify;">contract (article 18 (4)). The MTO, however, is not entitled to limit his liability if it is proved</p><p style="text-align: justify;">that the loss, damage or delay in delivery resulted from an act or omission of the MTO done</p><p style="text-align: justify;">with the intent to cause such loss, damage or delay or recklessly and with knowledge that such</p><p style="text-align: justify;">loss, damage or delay would probably result (article 21).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">25. The Convention provides for a period of two years within which legal proceedings</p><p style="text-align: justify;">relating to international multimodal transport have to be instituted in order to prevent the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">claim from being time-barred. A recourse action by the MTO for indemnity against subcontractors,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">however, is possible even after the expiry of limitation period, provided that it is</p><p style="text-align: justify;">permitted under the law of the State where proceedings are instituted and that it is not</p><p style="text-align: justify;">contrary to the provisions of another applicable international convention (article 25).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">26. The Convention includes extensive provisions on documentation covering negotiable</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and non-negotiable multimodal transport documents, their contents, reservations and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">evidentiary effect (articles 5 to 10).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">27. Concerning jurisdiction, the Convention gives a wide option to the claimant to institute</p><p style="text-align: justify;">an action for claims relating to international multimodal transport. It clearly provides that the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">plaintiff may sue in one of the following places:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) The principal place of business or residence of the defendant;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) The place where the MT contract was made;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) The place of taking the goods in charge or the place of delivery; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) Any other place agreed upon and evidenced in the MT document (Article 26).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">28. Following the growing trend in international commercial disputes, the Convention also</p><p style="text-align: justify;">recognizes arbitration as an alternative to judicial proceedings. It provides that the parties</p><p style="text-align: justify;">may agree, in writing, to submit their disputes under the Convention to arbitration. As to the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">place of arbitration, the options available to the claimant for jurisdiction are also available in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">case of arbitration (article 27).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>(ii) UNCTAD/ICC Rules for Multimodal Transport Documents</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">29. Pending the entry into force of the UN Convention on International Transport of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Goods 1980, the UNCTAD’s Committee on Shipping, by resolution 60 (XII) of November</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1986, instructed the secretariat to elaborate model provisions for multimodal transport</p><p style="text-align: justify;">documents, in close collaboration with the competent commercial parties and international</p><p style="text-align: justify;">bodies, based on the Hague and Hague/Visby Rules as well as existing documents such as the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">FBL (FIATA Bill of Lading) of the International Federation of Freight Forwarders</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Association (FIATA) and the ICC Uniform Rules for a Combined Transport Document.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Following this resolution a joint UNCTAD/ICC working group was created to elaborate a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">new set of rules for multimodal transport documents. During a series of meetings the joint</p><p style="text-align: justify;">UNCTAD/ICC working group completed the preparation of the UNCTAD/ICC Rules for</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Multimodal Transport Documents in 1991. The Rules entered into force on 1 January 1992.18</p><p style="text-align: justify;">30. The UNCTAD/ICC Rules for Multimodal Transport Documents have been</p><p style="text-align: justify;">incorporated in widely used multimodal transport documents such as the FIATA FBL</p><p style="text-align: justify;">199219and the “MULTIDOC 95” of the Baltic and International Maritime Council</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(BIMCO).20 The main features of the UNCTAD/ICC Rules are the following:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">31. The Rules do not have the force of the law but are of purely contractual nature and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">apply only if they are incorporated into a contract of carriage, without any formal requirement</p><p style="text-align: justify;">for “writing” and irrespective of whether it is a contract for unimodal or multimodal transport</p><p style="text-align: justify;">18 The text of the Rules can be found in ICC publication No. 481. They replaced the previous ICC Rules</p><p style="text-align: justify;">for a Combined Transport Document, 1973 (modified 1975) which were based on the “Tokyo Rules” and the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">“TCM” draft.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">19 See FBL Negotiable FIATA Multimodal Transport Bill of Lading, issued subject to UNCTAD/ICC</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Rules for Multimodal Transport Documents. The first FIATA FBL, called the FIATA Uniform Bill of Lading,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">was introduced in 1971 and was based on the Tokyo Rules developed by the CMI. A revised FIATA FBL was</p><p style="text-align: justify;">issued after the ICC introduced its Uniform Rules for a Combined Transport Document in 1975. See Öhl K.,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Development of the FIATA Multimodal Transport Bill of Lading based on the UNCTAD/ICC Rules for</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Multimodal Transport Documents, ICC seminar on the UNCTAD/ICC Rules for Multimodal Transport</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Documents, London, 28 January 1994. For a detailed study of the 1992 FIATA Multimodal Transport Bill of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Lading, see Ramberg J., <em>The Law of Freight Forwarding and the 1992 </em><em>FIA</em><em>TA Multimodal Bill of Lading</em>,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">FIATA Publication, 1993.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">20 See the Negotiable Multimodal Transport Bill of Lading issued by the BIMCO subject to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">UNCTAD/ICC Rules for Multimodal Transport Documents. The BIMCO’s previous Multimodal Transport</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Document known as the “COMBIDOC” was based on the previous ICC Rules for a Combined Transport</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Document 1975.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13</p><p style="text-align: justify;">involving one or several modes of transport, or whether or not a document has been issued</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(Rule 1). Once they are incorporated into a contract, they override any conflicting contractual</p><p style="text-align: justify;">provisions, except in so far as they increase the responsibility or obligations of the multimodal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">transport operator. The Rules, however, can only take effect to the extent that they are not</p><p style="text-align: justify;">contrary to the mandatory provisions of international conventions or national law applicable to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the multimodal transport contract (article 13).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">32. Similar to the MT Convention, the liability of the MTO under the Rules is based on the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">principle of presumed fault or neglect. That is to say that the MTO is liable for loss of, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">damage to, the goods and for delay in delivery, if the occurrence which caused the loss,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">damage or delay in delivery took place while the goods were in his charge, unless he can prove</p><p style="text-align: justify;">that no fault or neglect of his own, his servants or agents or any other person of whose</p><p style="text-align: justify;">services he made use of for the performance of the contract, caused or contributed to the loss</p><p style="text-align: justify;">or delay in delivery (Rule 5.1). Although the basis of liability of the MTO under the Rules is</p><p style="text-align: justify;">similar to that under the MT Convention, there are significant differences between them.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Firstly, unlike the MT Convention, under Rule 5.1, the MTO is not liable for loss following</p><p style="text-align: justify;">delay in delivery unless the consignor has made a declaration of interest in timely delivery</p><p style="text-align: justify;">which has been accepted by the MTO. Secondly, if the multimodal transport involves carriage</p><p style="text-align: justify;">by sea or inland waterways, the MTO will not be liable for “loss, damage or delay in delivery</p><p style="text-align: justify;">with respect to goods carried by sea or inland waterways when such loss, damage or delay</p><p style="text-align: justify;">during such carriage has been caused by:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">– act, neglect, or default of the master, mariner, pilot or the servants of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">carrier in the navigation or in the management of the ship;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">– fire, unless caused by the actual fault or privity of the carrier” (Rule 5.4).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">33. These defences, however, are made subject to an overriding requirement that</p><p style="text-align: justify;">whenever loss or damage resulted from unseaworthiness of the vessel, the MTO must prove</p><p style="text-align: justify;">that due diligence was exercised to make the ship seaworthy at the beginning of the voyage</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(Rule 5.4). The provisions of the Rule 5.4 are intended to make the liability of the MTO</p><p style="text-align: justify;">compatible with the Hague/Visby Rules for carriage by sea or inland waterways.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">34. Similar to the MT Convention, the period of responsibility of the MTO includes the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">period from the time he takes the goods in his charge until the time of their delivery.21</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Furthermore the MTO is also liable for the acts and omissions of his servants, agents or any</p><p style="text-align: justify;">other person of whose services he makes use for the performance of the contract (Rule 4.2).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">35. The limitation amounts established by the Rules for loss of, or damage to, goods are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">clearly lower than those of the MT Convention. They are based on the limits set by the SDR</p><p style="text-align: justify;">protocol of 1979 amending the limits of the Hague/Visby Rules. Thus, according to Rule 6.1,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">unless the nature and value of the goods have been declared by the consignor and inserted in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the MT document, the MTO shall not be liable for any loss of, or damage to, the goods in an</p><p style="text-align: justify;">amount exceeding the equivalent of 666.67 SDR (Special Drawing Rights) per package or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">unit, or 2 SDR per kilogram of gross weight of the goods lost or damaged, whichever is the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">higher. In the same way as the MT Convention, a higher limit is provided for cases where the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">21 Rule 4.1. As to the definition of “delivery” see Rule 2.8.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">14</p><p style="text-align: justify;">multimodal transport does not, according to the contract, include carriage by sea or inland</p><p style="text-align: justify;">navigation. In such a case the liability of the MTO is limited to an amount not exceeding 8.33</p><p style="text-align: justify;">SDR per kilogram of gross weight of the goods lost or damaged (Rule 6.3), without any</p><p style="text-align: justify;">reference to package limitation which is more appropriate for sea transport.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">36. Similar to the MT Convention, specific provisions on limitation of liability of the MTO</p><p style="text-align: justify;">are made for cases of localized damage. Under Rule 6.4, when the loss or damage occurs</p><p style="text-align: justify;">during one stage of transport, in respect of which an applicable international convention or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">mandatory national law would have provided another limit (and not a higher limit as provided</p><p style="text-align: justify;">by the MT Convention) of liability if a separate contract had been made for that particular</p><p style="text-align: justify;">stage of transport, then the limit of liability of the MTO for such loss or damage should be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">determined by reference to the provisions of such convention or mandatory national law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">37. The liability of the MTO for delay in delivery of the goods or consequential loss or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">damage is limited to an amount not exceeding the equivalent of the freight under the multimodal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">transport contract (Rule 6.5). Finally, the MTO is not entitled to limit his liability if it is</p><p style="text-align: justify;">proved that the loss, damage or delay resulted from a personal act or omission of the MTO</p><p style="text-align: justify;">done with the intent to cause such loss, damage or delay, or recklessly and with knowledge</p><p style="text-align: justify;">that such loss, damage or delay would probably result (Rule 7).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">38. Rule 10 sets the period of time-bar at 9 months. Thus, the MTO will be relieved from</p><p style="text-align: justify;">liability unless the suit is brought within 9 months after delivery of the cargo, or of the date</p><p style="text-align: justify;">when the cargo should have been delivered. This is to allow the MTO possibility of instituting</p><p style="text-align: justify;">recourse action against the performing carrier, as most unimodal conventions such as the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Hague/Visby Rules set the time-bar period at 1 year. The MT Convention provides for a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">period of two years.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">39. The Rules envisage the possibility of issuing both “negotiable” and “non-negotiable”</p><p style="text-align: justify;">multimodal transport documents, including evidentiary effect of information contained in the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">document (Rules 2.6 and 3). However, the Rules, being of purely contractual nature, it is</p><p style="text-align: justify;">doubtful whether their incorporation into MT documents would have the effect of creating a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">negotiable document in all jurisdictions.22 Rule 3, concerning evidentiary effect of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">information contained in the multimodal transport document, provides that such information</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be <em>prima facie </em>evidence of the taking in charge by the MTO of the goods as described in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the document unless contrary indications, such as “shipper’s weight, load and count”,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">“shipper-packed container” or similar expressions, have been included in the printed text or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">superimposed on the document. This would mean that such pre-printed clauses would destroy</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the evidentiary value of the document which is clearly undesirable. The Rule further provides</p><p style="text-align: justify;">22 In a majority of countries a document of title can only be created by custom, the law merchant or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">statute, but not through the agreement of the parties. This seems to be the case in German law, where a system</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of so-called Typenzwang–numerus clausus–excludes from the status of negotiable transport document any</p><p style="text-align: justify;">document not enumerated in the relevant commercial code and, from the status of document of title any</p><p style="text-align: justify;">document not expressly recognized as such by statute. Some continental law countries do, however, permit the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">parties to create negotiable documents of title by agreement through an “open system of negotiable documents</p><p style="text-align: justify;">of title.” De Wit R., Multimodal Transport, 318; Recalde Castells A., <em>El Conocimiento de Embarque y otros</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Documentos del Transporte, editorial Civitas</em>, 1992, 346-348; See for a different view as to the creation of new</p><p style="text-align: justify;">documents of title Bools M., <em>The Bill of Lading: A Document of Title to Goods-An Anglo-American</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Comparison</em>, Lloyd’s of London Press, 1997, 184-186. See as well Tantin G., Les Documents de Transport</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Combiné, <em>European Transport Law</em>, Vol. XV No. 4, 1980, 382-383.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">15</p><p style="text-align: justify;">that proof to the contrary shall not be admissible when the MT document has been transferred</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to the consignee, who in good faith has relied and acted on such information.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">40. Unlike the MT Convention, the Rules do not include any provisions dealing with</p><p style="text-align: justify;">jurisdiction and arbitration. Multimodal transport documents currently used in practice usually</p><p style="text-align: justify;">provide for any dispute to be determined by the courts in accordance with the law at the place</p><p style="text-align: justify;">where the MTO has his principal place of business.23</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>E. Related activities of other organizations</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">41. The lack of a uniform liability regime governing maritime and multimodal transport</p><p style="text-align: justify;">operations and the proliferation of diverse national approaches, prompted a number of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">organizations to initiate investigations into the subject with the aim of establishing possible</p><p style="text-align: justify;">solution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">42. Following mandates from the UN/ECE Inland Transport Committee and the Working</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Party on Combined Transport (WP. 24) to consider the possibilities for reconciliation and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">harmonization of civil liability regimes governing combined transport, the UN/ECE secretariat</p><p style="text-align: justify;">convened two informal ad hoc expert group meetings,24 to hear the views of the industry</p><p style="text-align: justify;">including the relevant international organizations.25 The subject was considered by the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">UN/ECE Working Party on Combined Transport at its thirty-fourth and thirty-fifth sessions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">held in September 2000 and April 2001 respectively. It was also discussed by the UN/ECE</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Inland Transport Committee in February 2001, and the Committee, having endorsed the work</p><p style="text-align: justify;">carried out so far by the ad hoc expert group, requested the group to pursue the complex task</p><p style="text-align: justify;">towards a harmonized civil liability regime covering multimodal transport operations.26</p><p style="text-align: justify;">43. The Commission of the European Communities has identified the current intermodal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">arrangements in its communication on “Intermodality and Intermodal Freight Transport in the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">European Union”27 as “an area of friction costs.” Modally oriented cargo liability</p><p style="text-align: justify;">arrangements, which do not provide the shippers with a transparent and uniform liability</p><p style="text-align: justify;">regime, are considered to result in uncertainty and higher costs due to claims handling and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">litigation. With a view to making an inventory of the present liability arrangements and to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">identify possible approaches to solve the current deadlock, the Commission has sponsored a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">study on “intermodal transportation and carrier liability” (June 1999), which examines the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">problems associated with lack of coherent liability regime, including possible future regulatory</p><p style="text-align: justify;">options. It is understood that, as a follow-up, the Commission has launched an investigation</p><p style="text-align: justify;">into the economic impact of intermodal liability arrangements, the results of which could help</p><p style="text-align: justify;">in defining a possible new approach.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">23 See “MULTIDOC” 95, article 5, and FIATA FBL 92, article 19.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">24 12-13 July 1999, and 24-25 January 2000.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">25 See TRANS/WP.24/2000/3.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">26 See ECE/TRANS/136.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">27 Com (97) 243.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">16</p><p style="text-align: justify;">44. The Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development’s (OECD) Maritime</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Transport Committee has considered the need for investigation into the existing cargo liability</p><p style="text-align: justify;">regimes with a view to finding a workable solution. The objective of the OECD project was to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">identify those elements of the existing cargo liability regimes governing maritime transport for</p><p style="text-align: justify;">which there is no general agreement, and attempt to find workable formulations that will allow</p><p style="text-align: justify;">them to be broadly acceptable to all parties. It was envisaged that such possible compromise</p><p style="text-align: justify;">formulations could form the basis of a widely acceptable set of common rules for further</p><p style="text-align: justify;">international consideration in an appropriate forum.28 A workshop on cargo liability, organized</p><p style="text-align: justify;">by the OECD’s Maritime Transport committee (MTC)29, considered the issues identified in a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">report prepared by a consultant at the initiative of the MTC, in order to establish whether</p><p style="text-align: justify;">there might be some common ground or convergence that may provide some guidance to a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">future diplomatic conference. The report of the workshop is “offered to interested parties, be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">they governments, industry or international organizations that may in the future consider</p><p style="text-align: justify;">hosting or participating in diplomatic conferences to review cargo liability, as representing the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">end result of deliberations between these parties.” Thus, while the outcome is not binding on</p><p style="text-align: justify;">any party, it is nevertheless intended to “offer some guidance as to the policy outcome that</p><p style="text-align: justify;">may be necessary to maximise the formulation of a more comprehensive, and generally</p><p style="text-align: justify;">acceptable form of cargo liability regime.”30</p><p style="text-align: justify;">45. In the context of the work of the United Nation’s Commission on International Trade</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Law (UNCITRAL) on electronic commerce, it was pointed out by some delegations that</p><p style="text-align: justify;">fragmented and disparate national laws and legislation regarding certain aspects of transport</p><p style="text-align: justify;">law other than issues of liability, as well as significant gaps left by national laws and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">international conventions regarding issues such as the functioning of bills of lading and sea</p><p style="text-align: justify;">waybills, did not facilitate transition of trade practices to electronic alternatives. The</p><p style="text-align: justify;">UNCITRAL Commission, at its twenty-ninth session, in 1996, therefore, requested the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">secretariat to be the focal point for gathering information, ideas and opinions as to problems in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">transport law that arose in practice and possible solutions to those problems. Upon a request</p><p style="text-align: justify;">from the UNCITRAL secretariat, the CMI began investigation of the subject. Following a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">report on the progress of work within the CMI to the UNCITRAL Commission at its thirtythird</p><p style="text-align: justify;">session in June 2000, the Commission requested the UNCITRAL secretariat to continue</p><p style="text-align: justify;">cooperating with the CMI in order to present a report at its next session, identifying possible</p><p style="text-align: justify;">future work in the area of transport law.31 In the meantime, the CMI had been preparing a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">draft text of an outline instrument on transport law issues covering various aspects of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">transport law including liability for loss of, or damage to, cargo. The core principles and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">issues involved were discussed at the 37th CMI Conference,32 following which the Outline</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Instrument is to be redrafted. It is proposed to extend the period of responsibility of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">28 See DSTI/DOT/MTC (99) 19, October 1999.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">29 In January 25-26, 2001 in Paris.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">30 See the report of the Workshop on Cargo Liability Regimes: http://www.oecd.org/</p><p style="text-align: justify;">dsti/sti/transpor/sea/index.htm</p><p style="text-align: justify;">31 See the report of the Commission at its thirty-third Session, 2 June-7 July 2000, General Assembly</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Official Records, fifty-fifth session, Supplement No. 17 (A/55/17).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">32 Held in Singapore in February 2001.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">17</p><p style="text-align: justify;">carrier to cover inland carriage preceding or subsequent to sea carriage during which he is in</p><p style="text-align: justify;">charge of the goods. The outcome of the work is to be submitted to UNCITRAL.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">46. The ICC ad hoc Working Group on Multimodal Transport Law and Practice, having</p><p popular-posts="" style="text-align: justify; &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/article&gt;&lt;div class=" widget="" widget_categories=""></p><h3 class="widget-title"><span>Disclaimer:</span></h3><div class="widget-content" style="text-align:justify;"><p>The information contains in this web-site is prepared for educational purpose. 38	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">International convention for the suppression of Acts of Nuclear Terrorism,2005</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/international-crimes-conventions/international-convention-for-the-suppression-of-acts-of-nuclear-terrorism2005/attachment/international-convention-for-the-suppression-of-the-circulation-of-and-traffic-in/" rel="attachment wp-att-6206"><strong>International convention for the suppression of Acts of Nuclear Terrorism,2005</strong><br/></a></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Miscellaneous Series No. 9 (2007)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">International Convention</p><p style="text-align: justify;">for the Suppression of Acts of Nuclear Terrorism</p><p style="text-align: justify;">New York, 13 April 2005</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Presented to Parliament</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>by the Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>by Command of Her Majesty</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>January 2008</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Cm 7301 £5.15</p><p style="text-align: justify;">_ <strong>Crown Copyright 2008</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">The text in this document (excluding the Royal Arms and departmental logos) may be</p><p style="text-align: justify;">reproduced</p><p style="text-align: justify;">free of charge in any format or medium providing that it is reproduced accurately and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">not used in a misleading context. The material must be acknowledged as Crown</p><p style="text-align: justify;">copyright and the title of the document specified.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Any enquiries relating to the copyright in this document should be addressed to The</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Licensing Division, HMSO, St Clements House, 2-16 Colegate, Norwich, NR3 1BQ.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Fax: 01603 723000 or e-mail: licensing@cabinet-office.x.gsi.gov.uk</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>INTERNATIONAL CONVENTION FOR THE SUPPRESSION OF ACTS OF</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>NUCLEAR TERRORISM</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>International Convention for the Suppression of Acts of Nuclear Terrorism</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>The States Parties to this Convention</em>,</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Having in mind </em>the purposes and principles of the Charter of the United Nations</p><p style="text-align: justify;">concerning the maintenance of international peace and security and the promotion of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">good-neighbourliness and friendly relations and cooperation among States,</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Recalling </em>the Declaration on the Occasion of the Fiftieth Anniversary of the United</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Nations of 24 October 1995,</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Recognizing </em>the right of all States to develop and apply nuclear energy for peaceful</p><p style="text-align: justify;">purposes and their legitimate interests in the potential benefits to be derived from the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">peaceful application of nuclear energy,</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Bearing in mind </em>the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">19801,</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Deeply concerned </em>about the worldwide escalation of acts of terrorism in all its forms</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and manifestations,</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Recalling </em>the Declaration on Measures to Eliminate International Terrorism annexed to</p><p style="text-align: justify;">General Assembly resolution 49/60 of 9 December 1994, in which, inter alia, the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">States Members of the United Nations solemnly reaffirm their unequivocal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">condemnation of all acts, methods and practices of terrorism as criminal and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">unjustifiable, wherever and by whomever committed, including those which jeopardize</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the friendly relations among States and peoples and threaten the territorial integrity and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">security of States,</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Noting </em>that the Declaration also encouraged States to review urgently the scope of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">existing international legal provisions on the prevention, repression and elimination of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">terrorism in all its forms and manifestations, with the aim of ensuring that there is a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">comprehensive legal framework covering all aspects of the matter,</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Recalling </em>General Assembly resolution 51/210 of 17  December 1996 and the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Declaration to Supplement the 1994 Declaration on Measures to Eliminate</p><p style="text-align: justify;">International Terrorism annexed thereto,</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Recalling also </em>that, pursuant to General Assembly resolution 51/210, an ad hoc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">committee was established to elaborate, inter alia, an international convention for the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Treaty Series No.061 (1995) Cm 2945</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4</p><p style="text-align: justify;">suppression of acts of nuclear terrorism to supplement related existing international</p><p style="text-align: justify;">instruments,</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Noting </em>that acts of nuclear terrorism may result in the gravest consequences and may</p><p style="text-align: justify;">pose a threat to international peace and security,</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Noting also </em>that existing multilateral legal provisions do not adequately address those</p><p style="text-align: justify;">attacks,</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Being convinced </em>of the urgent need to enhance international cooperation between</p><p style="text-align: justify;">States in devising and adopting effective and practical measures for the prevention of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">such acts of terrorism and for the prosecution and punishment of their perpetrators,</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Noting </em>that the activities of military forces of States are governed by rules of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">international law outside of the framework of this Convention and that the exclusion of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">certain actions from the coverage of this Convention does not condone or make lawful</p><p style="text-align: justify;">otherwise unlawful acts, or preclude prosecution under other laws,</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Have agreed </em>as follows:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">ARTICLE 1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">For the purposes of this Convention:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. “Radioactive material” means nuclear material and other radioactive substances</p><p style="text-align: justify;">which contain nuclides which undergo spontaneous disintegration (a process</p><p style="text-align: justify;">accompanied by emission of one or more types of ionizing radiation, such as alpha-,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">beta-, neutron particles and gamma rays) and which may, owing to their radiological or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">fissile properties, cause death, serious bodily injury or substantial damage to property</p><p style="text-align: justify;">or to the environment.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. “Nuclear material” means plutonium, except that with isotopic concentration</p><p style="text-align: justify;">exceeding 80 per cent in plutonium-238; uranium-233; uranium enriched in the isotope</p><p style="text-align: justify;">235 or 233; uranium containing the mixture of isotopes as occurring in nature other</p><p style="text-align: justify;">than in the form of ore or ore residue; or any material containing one or more of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">foregoing;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Whereby “uranium enriched in the isotope 235 or 233” means uranium containing the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">isotope 235 or 233 or both in an amount such that the abundance ratio of the sum of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">these isotopes to the isotope 238 is greater than the ratio of the isotope 235 to the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">isotope 238 occurring in nature.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. “Nuclear facility” means:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(<em>a</em>) Any nuclear reactor, including reactors installed on vessels, vehicles,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">aircraft or space objects for use as an energy source in order to propel</p><p style="text-align: justify;">such vessels, vehicles, aircraft or space objects or for any other purpose;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(<em>b</em>) Any plant or conveyance being used for the production, storage,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">processing or transport of radioactive material.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. “Device” means:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(<em>a</em>) Any nuclear explosive device; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(<em>b</em>) Any radioactive material dispersal or radiation-emitting device which may,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">owing to its radiological properties, cause death, serious bodily injury or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">substantial damage to property or to the environment.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. “State or government facility” includes any permanent or temporary facility or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">conveyance that is used or occupied by representatives of a State, members of a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Government, the legislature or the judiciary or by officials or employees of a State or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">any other public authority or entity or by employees or officials of an</p><p style="text-align: justify;">intergovernmental organization in connection with their official duties.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. “Military forces of a State” means the armed forces of a State which are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">organized, trained and equipped under its internal law for the primary purpose of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">national defence or security and persons acting in support of those armed forces who</p><p style="text-align: justify;">are under their formal command, control and responsibility.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">ARTICLE 2</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Any person commits an offence within the meaning of this Convention if that</p><p style="text-align: justify;">person unlawfully and intentionally:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(<em>a</em>) Possesses radioactive material or makes or possesses a device:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) With the intent to cause death or serious bodily injury; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) With the intent to cause substantial damage to property or to the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">environment;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(<em>b</em>) Uses in any way radioactive material or a device, or uses or damages a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">nuclear facility in a manner which releases or risks the release of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">radioactive material:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) With the intent to cause death or serious bodily injury; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) With the intent to cause substantial damage to property or to the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">environment; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii) With the intent to compel a natural or legal person, an international</p><p style="text-align: justify;">organization or a State to do or refrain from doing an act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Any person also commits an offence if that person:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(<em>a</em>) Threatens, under circumstances which indicate the credibility of</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the threat, to commit an offence as set forth in paragraph 1 (<em>b</em>) of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">present article; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(<em>b</em>) Demands unlawfully and intentionally radioactive material, a device or a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">nuclear facility by threat, under circumstances which indicate the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">credibility of the threat, or by use of force.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Any person also commits an offence if that person attempts to commit an offence</p><p style="text-align: justify;">as set forth in paragraph 1 of the present article.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. Any person also commits an offence if that person:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(<em>a</em>) Participates as an accomplice in an offence as set forth in paragraph 1, 2 or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 of the present article; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(<em>b</em>) Organizes or directs others to commit an offence as set forth in paragraph</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1, 2 or 3 of the present article; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(<em>c</em>) In any other way contributes to the commission of one or more offences as</p><p style="text-align: justify;">set forth in paragraph 1, 2 or 3 of the present article by a group of persons</p><p style="text-align: justify;">acting with a common purpose; such contribution shall be intentional and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">either be made with the aim of furthering the general criminal activity or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">purpose of the group or be made in the knowledge of the intention of the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">group to commit the offence or offences concerned.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">ARTICLE 3</p><p style="text-align: justify;">This Convention shall not apply where the offence is committed within a single State,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the alleged offender and the victims are nationals of that State, the alleged offender is</p><p style="text-align: justify;">found in the territory of that State and no other State has a basis under article 9,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">paragraph 1 or 2, to exercise jurisdiction, except that the provisions of articles 7, 12,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">14, 15, 16 and 17 shall, as appropriate, apply in those cases.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7</p><p style="text-align: justify;">ARTICLE 4</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Nothing in this Convention shall affect other rights, obligations and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">responsibilities of States and individuals under international law, in particular the</p><p style="text-align: justify;">purposes and principles of the Charter of the United Nations and international</p><p style="text-align: justify;">humanitarian law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The activities of armed forces during an armed conflict, as those terms are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">understood under international humanitarian law, which are governed by that law are</p><p style="text-align: justify;">not governed by this Convention, and the activities undertaken by military forces of a</p><p style="text-align: justify;">State in the exercise of their official duties, inasmuch as they are governed by other</p><p style="text-align: justify;">rules of international law, are not governed by this Convention.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. The provisions of paragraph 2 of the present article shall not be interpreted as</p><p style="text-align: justify;">condoning or making lawful otherwise unlawful acts, or precluding prosecution under</p><p style="text-align: justify;">other laws.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4.
