While making the rights and interests of the child paramount, it also respects and protects the rights of families of origin and adoptive families.</p><p>The Convention makes clear that Receiving States and States of origin must share the burdens and benefits of regulating intercountry adoptions. It sets out clearly which functions within the adoption process are to be performed by each State.</p><p><strong>Principal features of the Convention </strong></p><p><strong><em>The best interests of the child are paramount </em></strong></p><p>The Convention contains certain rules to ensure that adoptions take place in the best interests of the child and with respect for his or her fundamental rights. For example, States, must: consider national solutions first (implement the principle of subsidiarity); ensure the child is adoptable; preserve information about the child and his/her parents; evaluate thoroughly the prospective adoptive parents; match the child with a suitable family; impose additional safeguards where needed. This fundamental principle of the child’s best interests should guide the development of an integrated national child care and protection system, of which one part is an ethical, child-centred approach to intercountry adoption.</p><p><sup>1 </sup><em>See </em>Explanatory Report to the <em>Hague Convention of 29 May 1993 on Protection of Children and Co-operation in respect of Intercountry Adoption, </em>by G. Parra-Aranguren, at paragraph 6. Available on the Hague Conference website, <span style="text-decoration: underline;">www.hcc.net </span>under Intercountry Adoption Section/Explanatory Documents.</p><p><sup>2 </sup><em>United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child</em>, G.A. Res. 44/25, UN GAOR, 61<sup>st </sup>Plenary Meeting, Annex. Available at <span style="text-decoration: underline;">www.ohchr.org </span></p><p>Subsidiarity principle</p><p>‘Subsidiarity’ in the Convention means that Contracting States recognise that a child should be raised by his or her birth family or extended family whenever possible. If that is not possible or practicable, other forms of permanent care in the country of origin should be considered. Only after due consideration has been given to national solutions should intercountry adoption be considered, and then only if it is in the child’s best interests. As a general rule, institutional care should be considered as a last resort for a child in need of a family.</p><p>Safeguards to protect children from abduction, sale and trafficking</p><p>States should establish safeguards to prevent abduction, sale and trafficking in children for adoption by: protecting birth families from exploitation and undue pressure; ensuring only children in need of a family are adoptable and adopted; preventing improper financial gain and corruption; regulating agencies and individuals involved in adoptions by accrediting them in accordance with Convention standards.</p><p>Co-operation between States and within States</p><p>The Convention envisages a system in which all Contracting States work together to ensure the protection of children. Co-operation between Contracting States is essential to ensure the effectiveness of any safeguards put in place (Article 1 b)). In practice, this principle is implemented first through international co-operation between Central Authorities, and between other public authorities and accredited bodies performing the functions of Central Authorities (Article 7); second, through intra-State co-operation between authorities and agencies regarding Convention procedures (Article 7(1)); and third, through co-operation to prevent abuses and avoidance of the Convention (Article 33).</p><p>Automatic recognition of adoption decisions</p><p>The 1993 Convention achieved a major breakthrough in establishing a system of automatic recognition of adoptions made in accordance with the Convention. Every adoption, whether a simple or full adoption, which is certified to be made in accordance with Convention procedures, is recognised “by operation of law” in all other Contracting States (Article 23). In other words, the Convention gives immediate certainty to the status of the child, and eliminates the need for a procedure for recognition of orders, or re-adoption, in the receiving country.</p><p>Competent authorities, Central Authorities and Accredited Bodies</p><p>The Convention requires that only competent authorities should perform Convention functions. Competent authorities may be Central Authorities, public authorities including judicial or administrative authorities, and accredited bodies. The Convention provides for a system of Central Authorities in all Contracting States and imposes certain general obligations on them, such as: co-operation with one another through the exchange of general information concerning intercountry adoption; the elimination of any obstacles to the application of the Convention (Article 7(2) b)); and a responsibility to deter all practices contrary to the objects of the Convention (Article 8). Central Authorities also have specific obligations in Chapter IV in respect of individual adoptions.</p><p>Accredited Bodies may perform some of the functions of Central Authorities. The process of accreditation of bodies is one of the Convention’s safeguards to protect children in adoption. Any private adoption body or agency must be accountable to a supervising or accrediting authority (see Articles 6-13). They must play an effective role in upholding the principles of the Convention and preventing illegal and improper practices in adoption. If accredited bodies are to be used, the Convention sets out a regulatory framework of minimum standards for their operation in Articles 10, 11 and 32. Additional standards may be imposed by Contracting States.</p><p>September 2008 Page 2 of 3 September  2008 Page 3 of 3</p><p>Guide to Good Practice for the 1993 Hague Intercountry Adoption Convention</p><p>The Implementation and Operation of the 1993 Hague Intercountry Adoption Convention: A Guide to Good Practice is the 1st Guide to Good Practice for the 1993 Hague Intercountry Adoption Convention. The new Guide identifies important matters related to planning, establishing and operating the legal and administrative framework to implement the Convention. It will assist policy makers involved in short term and long term planning to implement the Convention in their country, as well as judges, lawyers, administrators, caseworkers, accredited bodies and other professionals needing guidance on some practical or legal aspects of implementing the Convention. An outline of the procedure for a Convention adoption is found in the Guide at Chapter 7.1. The Guide is on the Hague Conference website at <span style="text-decoration: underline;">www.hcch.net </span></p><p>The Intercountry Adoption Technical Assistance Programme (ICATAP)</p><p>In order for the 1993 Hague Convention to operate successfully, the initial steps necessary for its effective implementation in each Contracting State must be carefully planned. The Convention places heavy burdens of responsibility on States, and implementation and technical assistance may be particularly vital in some countries that have few resources available for this purpose. The ICATAP was designed to provide assistance directly to the governments of certain States which are planning ratification of, or accession to, the Convention, or which have ratified or acceded but are experiencing difficulties with implementation of the Convention. The ICATAP is operated directly by the Permanent Bureau, using staff and resources dedicated to this project, as well as international consultants and experts. The Hague approach takes full account of the need to integrate the intercountry adoption process within the broader child care and protection system. For more information on this programme, please refer to the website of the Hague Conference.</p><p>The Intercountry Adoption Section on the website of the Hague Conference contains the latest information about the status of the 1993 Convention, and the contact details of Central Authorities. For this, and much more information about the 1993 Convention, see &lt;</p></div></div>

rel="attachment wp-att-6250">PROCEDURAL PROTOCOL FOR THE HANDLING OF RETURN APPLICATIONS UNDER THE 1980 HAGUE CONVENTION ON THE CIVIL ASPECTS OF INTERNATIONAL CHILD ABDUCTION, MANITOBA COURT OF QUEEN’S BENCH, FAMILY DIVISION</a>(full taxt pdf file)</p><p>Preamble</p><p>1) The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of</p><p>International Child Abduction (“the 1980 Hague Convention”) became</p><p>the law in Manitoba on December  1, 1983 pursuant to ss. 17(2) of</p><p>The Child Custody Enforcement Act.</p><p>2) Article 1 of the 1980 Hague Convention provides the following</p><p>objectives:</p><p>a) to secure the prompt return of children wrongfully</p><p>removed to or retained in any contracting state; and</p><p>b) to ensure that rights of custody and of access under</p><p>the law of one contracting state are effectively</p><p>respected in the other contracting states.</p><p>3) Article 11 of the 1980 Hague Convention provides in part as</p><p>follows:</p><p>The judicial or administrative authorities of contracting</p><p>states shall act expeditiously in proceedings for the</p><p>return of children.</p><p>4) The Family Law Branch of the Manitoba Department of</p><p>Justice fulfills the responsibilities of Central Authority pursuant to the</p><p>1980 Hague Convention for Manitoba.</p><p>5) To ensure that return applications under the 1980 Hague</p><p>Convention are dealt with expeditiously the attached procedural</p><p>protocol has been developed by the Court of Queen’s Bench in</p><p>Manitoba.</p><p><strong>PROCEDURAL PROTOCOL</strong></p><p>1) The Chief Justice of the Court of Queen’s Bench will ask</p><p>Manitoba’s Central Authority to advise the Associate Chief</p><p>Justice of the Family Division or in his absence the Family</p><p>duty judge when they intend to initiate proceedings in</p><p>Manitoba for the return of a child pursuant to the 1980</p><p>Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child</p><p>Abduction (“the 1980 Hague Convention”).</p><p>2) Article 16 of the 1980 Hague Convention1 provides that</p><p>where a court has notice of the alleged wrongful removal or</p><p>retention of a child, the Court shall not deal with the merits</p><p>of rights of custody until an application for return pursuant</p><p>to the Convention (“return application”) has been</p><p>determined, unless a return application is not filed within a</p><p>reasonable time after notice is given to the Court.</p><p>3) When Article 16 is invoked and the Court of Queen’s Central</p><p>Authority filing a Requisition notifying the Court of the case.</p><p>The filing of a Requisition giving notice under Article 16 will</p><p>be sufficient to open a Court file where no file exists. This</p><p>1 Article 16 of the 1980 Hague Convention provides: After receiving notice of a wrongful removal</p><p>or retention of a child in the sense of Article 3, the judicial or administrative authorities of the</p><p>Contracting State to which the child has been removed or in which it has been retained shall not</p><p>decide on the merits of rights of custody until it has been determined that the child is not to be</p><p>returned under this Convention or unless an application under this Convention is not lodged</p><p>within a reasonable time following receipt of the notice.</p><p>would subsequently be followed in the normal course by the</p><p>filing of a return application.</p><p>4) (a) The return application will be commenced in the Court</p><p>as a Notice of Application (Form 70E) and the existing Rules</p><p>of Court, with respect to notice, service, evidence and</p><p>procedure will apply.</p><p>(b) Where the Applicant or Central Authority seeks to</p><p>abridge time or to proceed on an urgent or without notice</p><p>basis, the Court may permit this where the circumstances</p><p>warrant proceeding in this way.</p><p>(c) When the return application first comes before the Court</p><p>the presiding judge or stand-by judge, as the case may be,</p><p>will undertake the responsibility of:</p><p>i) establishing appropriate timelines for the filing</p><p>and service of further materials; and</p><p>ii) setting the application down for hearing</p><p>and in carrying out these responsibilities will have regard to</p><p>the requirement for an expeditious determination of the</p><p>matter. 42	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">PROTOCOL FOR THE PROHIBITION OF THE USE IN WAR OF ASPHYXIATING, POISONOUS, OR OTHER GASES, AND OF BACTERIOLOGICAL METHODS OF WARFARE (GENEVA PROTOCOL)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/customes-conventions/protocol-for-the-prohibition-of-the-use-in-war-of-asphyxiating-poisonous-or-other-gases-and-of-bacteriological-methods-of-warfare-geneva-protocol/attachment/genev/" rel="attachment wp-att-6295">PROTOCOL FOR THE PROHIBITION OF THE USE IN WAR OF ASPHYXIATING, POISONOUS, OR OTHER GASES, AND OF BACTERIOLOGICAL METHODS OF WARFARE (GENEVA PROTOCOL)</a>(full pdf file )</p><p><strong>Opened for Signature: </strong>17 June 1925. <strong>Entered into force: </strong>For each signatory as from the date of deposit of its instrument of ratification or ac-cession.</p><p><strong>Number of Parties</strong><strong>: </strong>133 States. <strong>Depositary: </strong>France.</p><p>Treaty Text <strong>Protocol Obligations: </strong>The Geneva Protocol prohi-bits the use in war of asphyxiating, poisonous, or other gases, and of bacteriological methods of war-fare.</p><p><strong>Verification and Compliance: </strong>The Protocol recog-nizes the significance of bringing together controls on chemical and biological weapons. While it prohibits the use of such weapons, it does not prohibit their production, development, and stockpiling, gaps cov-ered by later treaties such as the 1972 Biological and Toxin Weapons Convention (BTWC) and the 1993 Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC). There is no verification mechanism contained within the Geneva Protocol and compliance is voluntary. The Geneva Protocol, implicitly, does not cover in-ternal or civil conflicts. Moreover, a sizeable fraction of its parties have reserved a right to retaliate in kind if chemical and/or biological weapons should ever be used against them by enemies or allies of enemies. This, and the contractual character of the Protocol, has rendered it a no-first-use agreement. <strong>Background: </strong>The Geneva Protocol of 1925 was drawn up and signed at the Conference for the Super-vision of the International Trade in Arms and Am-munition, which was held in Geneva under the aus-pices of the League  of Nations from 4 May to 17 June 1925. The conference adopted a Convention for the Supervision of the International Trade in Arms, Munitions and Implements of War, which has not entered into force and, as a separate document, a Pro-tocol on the use of gases. The earlier treaties prohibit-ing the use of gases to which the Protocol refers are in particular the Hague Declaration concerning as-phyxiating gases of 1899 and the Treaty of Versailles of 1919. Responding to the extensive use of chemical weapons between belligerents in the Iran-Iraq War and the increasing number of chemical weapon-capable states, a Conference on Chemical Weapons Use was held in Paris in January 1989. At the conference the States recognized the importance of the Geneva Pro-tocol, reaffirmed the prohibitions as established in it, and called upon all States which had not yet done so to accede to the Protocol.</p><p>The Protocol provided the basis for the BTWC and the 1993 CWC as well as some regional arms control agreements. <strong>Reservations: </strong>Upon ratification or accession to the Protocol, some States declared that the provisions of the Protocol would cease to be binding on them if their enemies, or the allies of their enemies, failed to respect the prohibitions of the Protocol. In recent years, however, many of the reservations have been withdrawn, especially following the entry into force of the BTWC and the CWC. Countries that continue to hold reservations to the Protocol include: Algeria, Angola, Bahrain, Bangla-desh, Cambodia, China, Fiji, India, Iraq, Israel, Jor-dan, Democratic People’s Republic of Korea, Repub-lic of Korea, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Papua New Guinea, Serbia, Solomon Islands, Syria, Thailand, the United States, and Viet Nam.</p></div></div>
43	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Regional Cooperation Agreement on Combating Piracy  and Armed Robbery against Ships in Asia</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/international-crimes-conventions/regional-cooperation-agreement-on-combating-piracy-and-armed-robbery-against-ships-in-asia/attachment/kyotei_s/" rel="attachment wp-att-6214">Regional Cooperation Agreement on Combating Piracy  and Armed Robbery against Ships in Asia </a></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">The Contracting Parties to this Agreement,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Concerned about the increasing number of incidents of piracy and armed robbery against ships in Asia,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Mindful of the complex nature of the problem of piracy and armed robbery against ships,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Recognizing the importance of safety of ships, including their crew, exercising the right of navigation provided for in the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea of 10 December 1982, hereinafter referred to as “the UNCLOS”,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Reaffirming the duty of States to cooperate in the prevention and suppression of piracy under the UNCLOS,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Recalling “Tokyo Appeal” of March 2000, “Asia Anti-Piracy Challenges 2000” of April 2000 and “Tokyo Model Action Plan” of April 2000,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Noting the relevant resolutions adopted by the United Nations General Assembly and the relevant resolutions and recommendations adopted by the International Maritime Organization,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Conscious of the importance of international cooperation as well as the urgent need for greater regional cooperation and coordination of all States affected within Asia, to prevent and suppress piracy and armed robbery against ships effectively,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Convinced that information sharing and capacity building among the Contracting Parties will significantly contribute towards the prevention and suppression of piracy and armed robbery against ships in Asia,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Affirming that, to ensure greater effectiveness of this Agreement, it is indispensable for each Contracting Party to strengthen its measures aimed at preventing and suppressing piracy and armed robbery against ships,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Determined to promote further regional cooperation and to enhance the effectiveness of such cooperation,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Have agreed as follows:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Part I</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Introduction</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 1</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Definitions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. For the purposes of this Agreement, “piracy” means any of the following acts:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) any illegal act of violence or detention, or any act of depredation, committed for private ends by the crew or the passengers of a private ship or a private aircraft, and directed:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) on the high seas, against another ship, or against persons or property on board such ship;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) against a ship, persons or property in a place outside the jurisdiction of any State;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) any act of voluntary participation in the operation of a ship or of an aircraft with knowledge of facts making it a pirate ship or aircraft;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) any act of inciting or of intentionally facilitating an act described in subparagraph (a) or (b).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. For the purposes of this Agreement, “armed robbery against ships” means any of the following acts:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) any illegal act of violence or detention, or any act of depredation, committed for private ends and directed against a ship, or against persons or property on board such ship, in a place within a Contracting Party’s jurisdiction over such offences;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) any act of voluntary participation in the operation of a ship with knowledge of facts making it a ship for armed robbery against ships;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) any act of inciting or of intentionally facilitating an act described in subparagraph (a) or (b).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 2</p><p style="text-align: justify;">General Provisions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. The Contracting Parties shall, in accordance with their respective national laws and regulations and subject to their available resources or capabilities, implement this Agreement, including preventing and suppressing piracy and armed robbery against ships, to the fullest extent possible.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Nothing in this Agreement shall affect the rights and obligations of any Contracting Party under the international agreements to which that Contracting Party is party, including the UNCLOS, and the relevant rules of international law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Nothing in this Agreement shall affect the immunities of warships and other government ships operated for non-commercial purposes.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. Nothing in this Agreement, nor any act or activity carried out under this Agreement shall prejudice the position of any Contracting Party with regard to any dispute concerning territorial sovereignty or any issues related to the law of the sea.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. Nothing in this Agreement entitles a Contracting Party to undertake in the territory of another Contracting Party the exercise of jurisdiction and performance of functions which are exclusively reserved for the authorities of that other Contracting Party by its national law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. In applying paragraph 1 of Article 1, each Contracting Party shall give due regard to the relevant provisions of the UNCLOS without prejudice to the rights of the third Parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 3</p><p style="text-align: justify;">General Obligations</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Each Contracting Party shall, in accordance with its national laws and regulations and applicable rules of international law, make every effort to take effective measures in respect of the following:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) to prevent and suppress piracy and armed robbery against ships;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) to arrest pirates or persons who have committed armed robbery against ships;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) to seize ships or aircraft used for committing piracy or armed robbery against ships, to seize ships taken by and under the control of pirates or persons who have committed armed robbery against ships, and to seize the property on board such ships; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) to rescue victim ships and victims of piracy or armed robbery against ships.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Nothing in this Article shall prevent each Contracting Party from taking additional measures in respect of subparagraphs (a) to (d) above in its land territory.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Part II</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Information Sharing Center</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 4</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Composition</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. An Information Sharing Center, hereinafter referred to as “the Center”, is hereby established to promote close cooperation among the Contracting Parties in preventing and suppressing piracy and armed robbery against ships.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The Center shall be located in Singapore.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. The Center shall be composed of the Governing Council and the Secretariat.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. The Governing Council shall be composed of one representative from each Contracting Party. The Governing Council shall meet at least once every year in Singapore, unless otherwise decided by the Governing Council.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. The Governing Council shall make policies concerning all the matters of the Center and shall adopt its own rules of procedure, including the method of selecting its Chairperson.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. The Governing Council shall take its decisions by consensus.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. The Secretariat shall be headed by the Executive Director who shall be assisted by the staff. The Executive Director shall be chosen by the Governing Council.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. The Executive Director shall be responsible for the administrative, operational and financial matters of the Center in accordance with the policies as determined by the Governing Council and the provisions of this Agreement, and for such other matters as determined by the Governing Council.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. The Executive Director shall represent the Center. The Executive Director shall, with the approval of the Governing Council, make rules and regulations of the Secretariat.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 5</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Headquarters Agreement</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. The Center, as an international organization whose members are the Contracting Parties to this Agreement, shall enjoy such legal capacity, privileges and immunities in the Host  State of the Center as are necessary for the fulfillment of its functions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The Executive Director and the staff of the Secretariat shall be accorded, in the Host  State, such privileges and immunities as are necessary for the fulfillment of their functions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. The Center shall enter into an agreement with the Host State on matters including those specified in paragraphs 1 and 2 of this Article.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 6</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Financing</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. The expenses of the Center, as provided for in the budget decided by the Governing Council, shall be provided by the following sources:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) Host State financing and support;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) Voluntary contributions from the Contracting Parties;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) Voluntary contributions from international organizations and other entities, in accordance with relevant criteria adopted by the Governing Council; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) Any other voluntary contributions as may be agreed upon by the Governing Council.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Financial matters of the Center shall be governed by a Financial Regulation to be adopted by the Governing Council.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. There shall be an annual audit of the accounts of the Center by an independent auditor appointed by the Governing Council. The audit report shall be submitted to the Governing Council and shall be made public, in accordance with the Financial Regulation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 7</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Functions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The functions of the Center shall be:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) to manage and maintain the expeditious flow of information relating to incidents of piracy and armed robbery against ships among the Contracting Parties;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) to collect, collate and analyze the information transmitted by the Contracting Parties concerning piracy and armed robbery against ships, including other relevant information, if any, relating to individuals and transnational organized criminal groups committing acts of piracy and armed robbery against ships;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) to prepare statistics and reports on the basis of the information gathered and analyzed under subparagraph (b), and to disseminate them to the Contracting Parties;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) to provide an appropriate alert, whenever possible, to the Contracting Parties if there is a reasonable ground to believe that a threat of incidents of piracy or armed robbery against ships is imminent;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) to circulate requests referred to in Article 10 and relevant information on the measures taken referred to in Article 11 among the Contracting Parties;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) to prepare non-classified statistics and reports based on information gathered and analyzed under subparagraph (b) and to disseminate them to the shipping community and the International Maritime Organization; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) to perform such other functions as may be agreed upon by the Governing Council with a view to preventing and suppressing piracy and armed robbery against ships.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 8</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Operation</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. The daily operation of the Center shall be undertaken by the Secretariat.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In carrying out its functions, the Center shall respect the confidentiality of information provided by any Contracting Party, and shall not release or disseminate such information unless the consent of that Contracting Party is given in advance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. The Center shall be operated in an effective and transparent manner, in accordance with the policies made by the Governing Council, and shall avoid duplication of existing activities between the Contracting Parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Part III</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Cooperation through the Information Sharing Center</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 9</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Information Sharing</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Each Contracting Party shall designate a focal point responsible for its communication with the Center, and shall declare its designation of such focal point at the time of its signature or its deposit of an instrument of notification provided for in Article 18.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Each Contracting Party shall, upon the request of the Center, respect the confidentiality of information transmitted from the Center.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Each Contracting Party shall ensure the smooth and effective communication between its designated focal point, and other competent national authorities including rescue coordination centers, as well as relevant non-governmental organizations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. Each Contracting Party shall make every effort to require its ships, ship owners, or ship operators to promptly notify relevant national authorities including focal points, and the Center when appropriate, of incidents of piracy or armed robbery against ships.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. Any Contracting Party which has received or obtained information about an imminent threat of, or an incident of, piracy or armed robbery against ships shall promptly notify relevant information to the Center through its designated focal point.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. In the event that a Contracting Party receives an alert from the Center as to an imminent threat of piracy or armed robbery against ships pursuant to subparagraph (d) of Article 7, that Contracting Party shall promptly disseminate the alert to ships within the area of such an imminent threat.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 10</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Request for Cooperation</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. A Contracting Party may request any other Contracting Party, through the Center or directly, to cooperate in detecting any of the following persons, ships, or aircraft:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) pirates;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) persons who have committed armed robbery against ships;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) ships or aircraft used for committing piracy or armed robbery against ships, and ships taken by and under the control of pirates or persons who have committed armed robbery against ships; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) victim ships and victims of piracy or armed robbery against ships.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. A Contracting Party may request any other Contracting Party, through the Center or directly, to take appropriate measures, including arrest or seizure, against any of the persons or ships mentioned in subparagraph (a), (b), or (c) of paragraph 1 of this Article, within the limits permitted by its national laws and regulations and applicable rules of international law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. A Contracting Party may also request any other Contracting Party, through the Center or directly, to take effective measures to rescue the victim ships and the victims of piracy or armed robbery against ships.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. The Contracting Party which has made a direct request for cooperation pursuant to paragraphs 1, 2 and 3 of this Article shall promptly notify the Center of such request.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. Any request by a Contracting Party for cooperation involving extradition or mutual legal assistance in criminal matters shall be made directly to any other Contracting Party.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 11</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Cooperation by the Requested Contracting Party</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. A Contracting Party, which has received a request pursuant to Article 10, shall, subject to paragraph 1 of Article 2, make every effort to take effective and practical measures for implementing such request.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. A Contracting Party, which has received a request pursuant to Article 10, may seek additional information from the requesting Contracting Party for the implementation of such request.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. A Contracting Party, which has taken measures referred to in paragraph 1 of this Article, shall promptly notify the Center of the relevant information on the measures taken.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Part IV</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Cooperation</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 12</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Extradition</p><p style="text-align: justify;">A Contracting Party shall, subject to its national laws and regulations, endeavor to extradite pirates or persons who have committed armed robbery against ships, and who are present in its territory, to the other Contracting Party which has jurisdiction over them, at the request of that Contracting Party.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 13</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Mutual Legal Assistance</p><p style="text-align: justify;">A Contracting Party shall, subject to its national laws and regulations, endeavor to render mutual legal assistance in criminal matters, including the submission of evidence related to piracy and armed robbery against ships, at the request of another Contracting Party.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 14</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Capacity  Building</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. For the purpose of enhancing the capacity of the Contracting Parties to prevent and suppress piracy and armed robbery against ships, each Contracting Party shall endeavor to cooperate to the fullest possible extent with other Contracting Parties which request cooperation or assistance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The Center shall endeavor to cooperate to the fullest possible extent in providing capacity building assistance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Such capacity building cooperation may include technical assistance such as educational and training programs to share experiences and best practices.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 15</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Cooperative Arrangements</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Cooperative arrangements such as joint exercises or other forms of cooperation, as appropriate, may be agreed upon among the Contracting Parties concerned.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 16</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Protection Measures for Ships</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Each Contracting Party shall encourage ships, ship owners, or ship operators, where appropriate, to take protective measures against piracy and armed robbery against ships, taking into account the relevant international standards and practices, in particular, recommendations adopted by the International Maritime Organization.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Part V</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Final Provisions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 17</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Settlement of Disputes</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Disputes arising out of the interpretation or application of this Agreement, including those relating to liability for any loss or damage caused by the request made under paragraph 2 of Article 10 or any measure taken under paragraph 1 of Article 11, shall be settled amicably by the Contracting Parties concerned through negotiations in accordance with applicable rules of international law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 18</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Signature and Entry into Force</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Agreement shall be open for signature at the depositary referred to in paragraph 2 below by the People’s Republic of Bangladesh, Brunei Darussalam, the Kingdom of Cambodia, the People’s Republic of China, the Republic of India, the Republic of Indonesia, Japan, the Republic of Korea, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Malaysia, the Union of Myanmar, the Republic of the Philippines, the Republic of Singapore, the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka, the Kingdom of Thailand, the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The Government of Singapore is the depositary of this Agreement.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. This Agreement shall enter into force 90 days after the date on which the tenth instrument of notification by a State listed in paragraph 1, indicating the completion of its domestic requirements, is submitted to the depositary. Subsequently it shall enter into force in respect of any other State listed in paragraph 1 above 30 days after its deposit of an instrument of notification to the depositary.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. The depositary shall notify all the States listed in paragraph 1 of the entry into force of this Agreement pursuant to paragraph 3 of this Article.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. After this Agreement has entered into force, it shall be open for accession by any State not listed in paragraph 1. Any State desiring to accede to this Agreement may so notify the depositary, which shall promptly circulate the receipt of such notification to all other Contracting Parties. In the absence of a written objection by a Contracting Party within 90 days of the receipt of such notification by the depositary, that State may deposit an instrument of accession with the depositary, and become a party to this Agreement 60 days after such deposit of instrument of accession.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 19</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Amendment</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Any Contracting Party may propose an amendment to this Agreement, any time after the Agreement enters into force. Such amendment shall be adopted with the consent of all Contracting Parties.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. Any amendment shall enter into force 90 days after the acceptance by all Contracting Parties. The instruments of acceptance shall be deposited with the depositary, which shall promptly notify all other Contracting Parties of the deposit of such instruments.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 20</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Withdrawal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. Any Contracting Party may withdraw from this Agreement at any time after the date of its entry into force.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The withdrawal shall be notified by an instrument of withdrawal to the depositary.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. The withdrawal shall take effect 180 days after the receipt of the instrument of withdrawal by the depositary.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. The depositary shall promptly notify all other Contracting Parties of any withdrawal.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 21</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Authentic Text</p><p style="text-align: justify;">This Agreement shall be authentic in the English language.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Article 22</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Registration</p><p style="text-align: justify;">This Agreement shall be registered by the depositary pursuant to Article 102 of the Charter of the United Nations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the undersigned, being duly authorized thereto by their respective Governments, have signed this Agreement.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p></div></div>
44	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs,1961</h2>

45	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The Hague Protocol,1955</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/air-space-conventions/the-hague-protocol1955/attachment/chap_vii-2/" rel="attachment wp-att-6034">The Hague Protocol,1955</a></p><p><strong>THE PROTOCOL SIGNED AT THE HAGUE ON 28TH SEPTEMBER, 1955 TO AMEND THE CONVENTION FOR THE UNIFICATION OF CERTAIN RULES RELATINGTO INTERNATIONAL CARRIAGE BY AIRSIGNED AT WARSAW ON 12 OCTOBER, 1929<br/>(THE HAGUE PROTOCOL, 1955)</strong><br/>57<br/>58<br/>[Intentionally left blank]<br/>59<br/>THE GOVERNMENTS UNDERSIGNED<br/>CONSIDERING that it is desirable to amend<br/>the Convention for the Unification of Certain<br/>Rules Relating to International Carriage by Air<br/>signed at Warsaw on 12 October,<br/>HAVE AGREED as follows:<br/>CHAPTER I<br/>AMENDMENTS TO THE<br/>CONVENTION<br/>Article I<br/>Article 1 of the Convention —<br/>(a) paragraph 2 shall be deleted and replaced<br/>by the following:—<br/>“2. For the purpose of this Convention, the<br/>expression international carriage means any<br/>carriage in which, according to the agreement<br/>between the parties, the place of departure and<br/>the place of destination, whether or not there<br/>be a break in the carriage or a transshipment,<br/>are situated either within the territories of two<br/>High Contracting Parities or within the territory<br/>of a single High Contracting Party if there is an<br/>agreed stopping place within the territory of<br/>another State, even if that State is not a High<br/>Contracting Party. Carriage between two points<br/>within the territory of a single High Contracting<br/>Party without an agreed stopping place within<br/>the territory of another State is not international<br/>carriage for the purposes of this Convention.”<br/>(b) paragraph 3 shall be deleted and replaced<br/>by the following:—<br/>“3. Carriage to be performed by several<br/>successive air carriers is deemed, for the<br/>purposes of this Convention, to be one<br/>undivided carriage if it has been regarded by<br/>the parties as a single operation, whether it had<br/>been agreed upon under the form of a single<br/>contract or of a series of contracts, and it does<br/>not lose its international character merely<br/>because one contract or a series of contracts is<br/>to be performed entirely within the territory of<br/>the same State.”<br/>Article II<br/>In Article 2 of the Convention —<br/>paragraph 2 shall be deleted and replaced<br/>by the following:—<br/>“2. This Convention shall not apply to<br/>carriage of mail and postal packages.”<br/>Article III<br/>In Article 3 of the Convention —<br/>(a) paragraph 1 shall be deleted and replaced<br/>by the following :—<br/>CHAPTER VII<br/>THE PROTOCOL SIGNED AT THE HAGUE ON 28TH<br/>SEPTEMBER, 1955 TO AMEND THE CONVENTION FOR<br/>THE UNIFICATION OF CERTAIN RULES RELATING TO<br/>INTERNATIONAL CARRIAGE BY AIR<br/>SIGNED AT WARSAW ON 12 OCTOBER, 1929<br/>(THE HAGUE PROTOCOL, 1955) *<br/>* Treaty Series No.11 (1933), Cmd. 4284. Entered into force on 1 January, 1963<br/>As on 30 June, 2002 there were 133 States party to it.<br/>India has ratified it<br/>THE HAGUE PROTOCOL, 1955 CHAP. VII<br/>60<br/>“1. In respect of the carriage of passengers<br/>a ticket shall be delivered containing:<br/>(a) an indication of the places of departure<br/>and destination;<br/>(b) if the places of departure and destination<br/>are within the territory of a single High<br/>Contracting Party, one or more agreed<br/>stopping places being within the territory<br/>of another State, an indication of at<br/>least one such stopping place;<br/>(c) a notice to the effect that, if the<br/>passenger’s journey involves an ultimate<br/>destination or stop in a country other<br/>than the country of departure, the<br/>Warsaw Convention may be applicable<br/>and that the Convention governs and in<br/>most cases limits the liability of carriers<br/>for death or personal injury and in<br/>respect of loss of or damage to baggage”.<br/>(b) paragraph 2 shall be deleted and replaced<br/>by the following:—<br/>“2. The passenger ticket shall constitute<br/>prima facie evidence of the conclusion<br/>and conditions of the contract of carriage.<br/>The absence, irregularity or loss of the<br/>passenger ticket does not affect the<br/>existence or the validity of the contract<br/>of carriage which shall, none the less, be<br/>subject to the rules of this Convention.<br/>Nevertheless, if with the consent of the<br/>carrier, the passenger embarks without a<br/>passenger ticket having been delivered,<br/>or if the ticket does no include the notice<br/>required by paragraph 1(c) of this Article,<br/>the carrier shall not be entitled to avail<br/>him-self of the provisions of Article 22.”<br/>Article IV<br/>In Article 4 of the Convention —<br/>(a) paragraphs 1,2 and 3 shall be deleted<br/>and replaced by the following :—<br/>“1. In respect of the carriage of registered<br/>baggage, a baggage check shall be delivered,<br/>which, unless combined with or incorporated<br/>in a passenger ticket which complies with the<br/>provison of Article 3, paragraph 1, shall contain:<br/>(a) an indication of the places of departure<br/>and destination;<br/>(b) if the places of departure and destination<br/>are within the territory of a single High<br/>Contracting Party, one or more agreed<br/>stopping places being within the territory<br/>of another State, an indication of at<br/>least one such stopping place;<br/>(c) a notice to the effect that, if the carriage<br/>involves an ultimate destination or stop<br/>in a country other than the country of<br/>departure, the Warsaw Convention may<br/>be applicable and that the Convention<br/>governs and in most cases limits the<br/>liability of carriers in respect of loss of<br/>or damage to baggage.”<br/>(b) paragraph 4 shall be deleted and replaced<br/>by the following :—<br/>“2. The baggage check shall constitute<br/>prima facie evidence of the registration<br/>of the baggage and of the conditions<br/>of the contract of carriage. The absence,<br/>irregularity or loss of the baggage check<br/>does not affect the existence or<br/>the validity of the contract of carriage<br/>which shall, none the less, be subject to<br/>the rules of this Convention.<br/>Nevertheless, if the carrier takes charge<br/>of the baggage without a baggage check<br/>having been delivered or if the baggage<br/>check (unless combined with or<br/>incorporated in the passenger ticket<br/>which complies with the provisions of<br/>Article 3, paragraph 1(c) does not<br/>include the notice required by paragraph<br/>1(c) of this Article, he shall not be<br/>entitled to avail himself of the provisions<br/>of Article 22, paragraph 2.”<br/>Article V<br/>In Article 6 of the Convention —<br/>paragraph 3 shall be deleted and replaced<br/>by the following :—<br/>“3. The carrier shall sign prior to the loading<br/>of the cargo on board the aircraft.”<br/>CHAP. VII THE HAGUE PROTOCOL, 1955<br/>61<br/>Article VI<br/>Article 8 of the Convention shall be deleted<br/>and replaced by the following:—<br/>“The air way bill shall contain;<br/>(a) an indication of the places of departure<br/>and destination;<br/>(b) if the places of departure and destination<br/>are within the territory of a single High<br/>Contracting Party, one or more agreed<br/>stopping places being within the territory<br/>of another State, an indication of at<br/>least one such stopping place;<br/>(c) a notice to the consignor to the effect<br/>that, if the carriage involves an ultimate<br/>destination or stop in a country other<br/>than the country of departure, the<br/>Warsaw Convention may be applicable<br/>and that the Convention governs and in<br/>most cases limits the liability of carriers<br/>in respects of loss of or damage to<br/>cargo.”<br/>Article VII<br/>Article 9 of the Convention shall be deleted<br/>and replaced by the following:—<br/>“If, with the consent of the carrier, cargo<br/>is loaded on board the aircraft without an<br/>air waybill having been made out, or if<br/>the air waybill does not include the notice<br/>required by Article 8, paragraph (c), the<br/>carrier shall not be entitled to avail himself<br/>of the previsions of Article 22, paragraph<br/>2.”<br/>Article VIII<br/>In Article 10 of the Convention —<br/>paragraph 2 shall be deleted and replaced<br/>by the following :—<br/>“2.
