…………………………………………………………………………. 21</p><p>Tables (Please see <strong>Red List </strong>among <strong>Controlled Substances</strong>, at:</p><p>http://www.incb.org/e/index.htm)</p><p><strong>U</strong><strong>NITED </strong><strong>N</strong><strong>ATIONS </strong><strong>C</strong><strong>ONVENTION AGAINST </strong><strong>I</strong><strong>LICIT </strong><strong>T</strong><strong>RAFFIC IN</strong></p><p><strong>N</strong><strong>ARCOTIC </strong><strong>D</strong><strong>RUGS </strong><strong>A</strong><strong>ND </strong><strong>P</strong><strong>SYCHOTROPIC </strong><strong>S</strong><strong>UBSTANCES</strong></p><p><em>The Parties to this Convention,</em></p><p><em>Deeply concerned </em>by the magnitude of and rising trend in the illicit production of, demand for and</p><p>traffic in narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances, which pose a serious threat to the health and</p><p>welfare of human beings and adversely affect the economic, cultural and political foundations of society,</p><p><em>Deeply concerned also </em>by the steadily increasing inroads into various social groups made by illicit</p><p>traffic in narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances, and particularly by the fact that children are used in</p><p>many parts of the world as an illicit drug consumers market and for purposes of illicit production,</p><p>distribution and trade in narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances, which entails a danger of</p><p>incalculable gravity,</p><p><em>Recognizing </em>the links between illicit traffic and other related organized criminal activities which</p><p>undermine the legitimate economies and threaten the stability, security and sovereignty of States,</p><p><em>Recognizing also </em>that illicit traffic is an international criminal activity, the suppression of which</p><p>demands urgent attention and the highest priority,</p><p><em>Aware </em>that illicit traffic generates large financial profits and wealth enabling transnational criminal</p><p>organizations to penetrate, contaminate and corrupt the structures of government, legitimate commercial</p><p>and financial business, and society at all its levels,</p><p><em>Determined </em>to deprive persons engaged in illicit traffic of the proceeds of their criminal activities</p><p>and thereby eliminate their main incentive for so doing,</p><p><em>Desiring </em>to eliminate the root causes of the problem of abuse of narcotic drugs and psychotropic</p><p>substances, including the illicit demand for such drugs and substances and the enormous profits derived</p><p>from illicit traffic,</p><p><em>Considering </em>that measures are necessary to monitor certain substances, including precursors,</p><p>chemicals and solvents, which are used in the manufacture of narcotic drugs and psychotropic</p><p>substances, the ready availability of which has led to an increase in the clandestine manufacture of such</p><p>drugs and substances,</p><p><em>Determined </em>to improve international co-operation in the suppression of illicit traffic by sea,</p><p><em>Recognizing </em>that eradication of illicit traffic is a collective responsibility of all States and that, to</p><p>that end, co-ordinated action within the framework of international co-operation is necessary,</p><p><em>Acknowledging </em>the competence of the United Nations in the field of control of narcotic drugs and</p><p>psychotropic substances and desirous that the international organs concerned with such control should be</p><p>within the framework of that Organization,</p><p><em>Reaffirming </em>the guiding principles of existing treaties in the field of narcotic drugs and psychotropic</p><p>substances and the system of control which they embody,</p><p><em>Recognizing </em>the need to reinforce and supplement the measures provided in the Single Convention</p><p>on Narcotic Drugs, 1961, that Convention as amended by the 1972 Protocol Amending the Single</p><p>Convention on Narcotic Drugs, 1961, and the 1971 Convention on Psychotropic Substances, in order to</p><p>counter the magnitude and extent of illicit traffic and its grave consequences,</p><p><em>Recognizing also </em>the importance of strengthening and enhancing effective legal means for</p><p>international co-operation in criminal matters for suppressing the international criminal activities of illicit</p><p>traffic,</p><p><em>Desiring </em>to conclude a comprehensive, effective and operative international convention that is</p><p>directed specifically against illicit traffic and that considers the various aspects of the problem as a whole,</p><p>in particular those aspects not envisaged in the existing treaties in the field of narcotic drugs and</p><p>psychotropic substances,</p><p><em>Hereby agree </em>as follows:</p><p>1</p><p><em>Article 1</em></p><p>DEFINITIONS</p><p>Except where otherwise expressly indicated or where the context otherwise requires, the following</p><p>definitions shall apply throughout this Convention:</p><p>a) “Board” means the International Narcotics Control Board established by the Single</p><p>Convention on Narcotic Drugs, 1961, and that Convention as amended by the 1972 Protocol</p><p>Amending the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, 1961;</p><p>b) “Cannabis plant” means any plant of the genus Cannabis;</p><p>c) “Coca bush” means the plant of any species of the genus Erythroxylon;</p><p>d) “Commercial carrier” means any person or any public, private or other entity engaged</p><p>in transporting persons, goods or mails for remuneration, hire or any other benefit;</p><p>e) “Commission” means the Commission on Narcotic Drugs of the Economic and Social</p><p>Council of the United Nations;</p><p>f) “Confiscation”, which includes forfeiture where applicable, means the permanent</p><p>deprivation of property by order of a court or other competent authority;</p><p>g) “Controlled delivery” means the technique of allowing illicit or suspect consignments of</p><p>narcotic drugs, psychotropic substances, substances in Table I and Table II annexed to this</p><p>Convention, or substances substituted for them, to pass out of, through or into the territory</p><p>of one or more countries, with the knowledge and under the supervision of their competent</p><p>authorities, with a view to identifying persons involved in the commission of offences</p><p>established in accordance with article 3, paragraph 1 of the Convention;</p><p>h) “1961 Convention” means the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, 1961;</p><p>i) “1961 Convention as amended” means the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, 1961,</p><p>as amended by the 1972 Protocol Amending the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, 1961;</p><p>j) “1971 Convention” means the Convention on Psychotropic Substances, 1971;</p><p>k) “Council” means the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations;</p><p>l) “Freezing” or “seizure” means temporarily prohibiting the transfer, conversion,</p><p>disposition or movement of property or temporarily assuming custody or control of property</p><p>on the basis of an order issued by a court or a competent authority;</p><p>m) “Illicit traffic” means the offences set forth in article 3, paragraphs 1 and 2, of this</p><p>Convention;</p><p>n) “Narcotic drug” means any of the substances, natural or synthetic, in Schedules I and</p><p>II of the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, 1961, and that Convention as amended by the</p><p>1972 Protocol Amending the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, 1961;</p><p>o) “Opium poppy” means the plant of the species <em>Papaver somniferum L</em>;</p><p>p) “Proceeds” means any property derived from or obtained, directly or indirectly,</p><p>through the commission of an offence established in accordance with article 3, paragraph 1;</p><p>q) “Property” means assets of every kind, whether corporeal or incorporeal, movable or</p><p>immovable, tangible or intangible, and legal documents or instruments evidencing title to, or</p><p>interest in, such assets;</p><p>r) “Psychotropic substance” means any substance, natural or synthetic, or any natural</p><p>material in Schedules I, II, III and IV of the Convention on Psychotropic Substances, 1971;</p><p>s) “Secretary-General” means the Secretary-General of the United Nations;</p><p>t) “Table I” and “Table II” mean the correspondingly numbered lists of substances</p><p>annexed to this Convention, as amended from time to time in accordance with article 12,</p><p>u) “Transit State” means a State through the territory of which illicit narcotic drugs,</p><p>psychotropic substances and substances in Table I and Table II are being moved, which is</p><p>neither the place of origin nor the place of ultimate destination thereof.</p><p><em>Article 2</em></p><p>SCOPE OF THE CONVENTION</p><p>1. The purpose of this Convention is to promote co-operation among the Parties so that they may</p><p>address more effectively the various aspects of illicit traffic in narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances</p><p>having an international dimension. In carrying out their obligations under the Convention, the Parties</p><p>shall take necessary measures, including legislative and administrative measures, in conformity with the</p><p>fundamental provisions of their respective domestic legislative systems.</p><p>2. The Parties shall carry out their obligations under this Convention in a manner consistent with the</p><p>principles of sovereign equality and territorial integrity of States and that of non-intervention in the</p><p>domestic affairs of other States.</p><p>2</p><p>3. A Party shall not undertake in the territory of another Party the exercise of jurisdiction and</p><p>performance of functions which are exclusively reserved for the authorities of that other Party by its</p><p>domestic law.</p><p><em>Article 3</em></p><p>OFFENCES AND SANCTIONS</p><p>1. Each Party shall adopt such measures as may be necessary to establish as criminal offences under</p><p>its domestic law, when committed intentionally:</p><p>a) i) The production, manufacture, extraction; preparation, offering, offering for sale,</p><p>distribution, sale, delivery on any terms whatsoever, brokerage, dispatch,</p><p>dispatch in transit, transport, importation or exportation of any narcotic drug or</p><p>any psychotropic substance contrary to the provisions of the 1961 Convention,</p><p>the 1961 Convention as amended or the 1971 Convention;</p><p>ii) The cultivation of opium poppy, coca bush or cannabis plant for the purpose of</p><p>the production of narcotic drugs contrary to the provisions of the 1961</p><p>Convention and the 1961 Convention as amended;</p><p>iii) The possession or purchase of any narcotic drug or psychotropic substance for</p><p>the purpose of any of the activities enumerated in i) above;</p><p>iv) The manufacture, transport or distribution of equipment, materials or of</p><p>substances listed in Table I and Table II, knowing that they are to be used in or</p><p>for the illicit cultivation, production or manufacture of narcotic drugs or</p><p>psychotropic substances;</p><p>v) The organization, management or financing of any of the offences enumerated</p><p>in i), ii), iii) or iv) above;</p><p>b) i) The conversion or transfer of property, knowing that such property is derived</p><p>from any offence or offences established in accordance with subparagraph <em>a) </em>of</p><p>this paragraph, or from an act of participation in such offence or offences, for</p><p>the purpose of concealing or disguising the illicit origin of the property or of</p><p>assisting any person who is involved in the commission of such an offence or</p><p>offences to evade the legal consequences of his actions;</p><p>ii) The concealment or disguise of the true nature, source, location, disposition,</p><p>movement, rights with respect to, or ownership of property, knowing that such</p><p>property is derived from an offence or offences established in accordance with</p><p>subparagraph <em>a) </em>of this paragraph or from an act of participation in such an</p><p>offence or offences;</p><p>c) Subject to its constitutional principles and the basic concepts of its legal system:</p><p>i) The acquisition, possession or use of property, knowing, at the time of receipt,</p><p>that such property was derived from an offence or offences established in</p><p>accordance with subparagraph a) of this paragraph or from an act of</p><p>participation in such offence or offences;</p><p>ii) The possession of equipment or materials or substances listed in Table I and</p><p>Table II, knowing that they are being or are to be used in or for the illicit</p><p>cultivation, production or</p><p>iii) Publicly inciting or inducing others, by any means, to commit any of the offences</p><p>established in accordance with this article or to use narcotic drugs or</p><p>psychotropic substances illicitly;</p><p>iv) Participation in, association or conspiracy to commit, attempts to commit and</p><p>aiding, abetting, facilitating and counselling the commission of any of the</p><p>offences established in accordance with this article.</p><p>2. Subject to its constitutional principles and the basic concepts of its legal system, each Party shall</p><p>adopt such measures as may be necessary to establish as a criminal offence under its domestic law,</p><p>when committed intentionally, the possession, purchase or cultivation of narcotic drugs or psychotropic</p><p>substances for personal consumption contrary to the provisions of the 1961 Convention, the 1961</p><p>Convention as amended or the 1971 Convention.</p><p>3. Knowledge, intent or purpose required as an element of an offence set forth in paragraph 1 of this</p><p>article may be inferred from objective factual circumstances.</p><p>3</p><p>4. a) Each Party shall make the commission of the offences established in accordance with</p><p>paragraph 1 of this article liable to sanctions which take into account the grave nature of</p><p>these offences, such as imprisonment or other forms of deprivation of liberty, pecuniary</p><p>sanctions and confiscation.</p><p>b) The Parties may provide, in addition to conviction or punishment, for an offence</p><p>established in accordance with paragraph 1 of this article, that the offender shall undergo</p><p>measures such as treatment, education, aftercare, rehabilitation or social reintegration.</p><p>c) Notwithstanding the preceding subparagraphs, in appropriate cases of a minor nature,</p><p>the Parties may provide, as alternatives to conviction or punishment, measures such as</p><p>education, rehabilitation or social reintegration, as well as, when the offender is a drug</p><p>abuser, treatment and aftercare.</p><p>d) The Parties may provide, either as an alternative to conviction or punishment, or in</p><p>addition to conviction or punishment of an offence established in accordance with paragraph</p><p>2 of this article, measures for the treatment, education, aftercare, rehabilitation or social</p><p>reintegration of the offender.</p><p>5. The Parties shall ensure that their courts and other competent authorities having jurisdiction can</p><p>take into account factual circumstances which make the commission of the offences established in</p><p>accordance with paragraph l of this article particularly serious, such as:</p><p>a) The involvement in the offence of an organized criminal group to which the offender</p><p>belongs;</p><p>b) The involvement of the offender in other international organized criminal activities;</p><p>c) The involvement of the offender in other illegal activities facilitated by commission of</p><p>the offence;</p><p>d) The use of violence or arms by the offender;</p><p>e) The fact that the offender holds a public office and that the offence is connected with</p><p>the office in question;</p><p>f) The victimization or use of minors;</p><p>g) The fact that the offence is committed in a penal institution or in an educational</p><p>institution or social service facility or in their immediate vicinity or in other places to which</p><p>school children and students resort for educational, sports and social activities;</p><p>h) Prior conviction, particularly for similar offences, whether foreign or domestic, to the</p><p>extent permitted under the domestic law of a Party.</p><p>6. The Parties shall endeavour to ensure that any discretionary legal powers under their domestic law</p><p>relating to the prosecution of persons for offences established in accordance with this article are</p><p>exercised to maximize the effectiveness of law enforcement measures in respect of those offences, and</p><p>with due regard to the need to deter the commission of such offences.</p><p>7. The Parties shall, ensure that their courts or other competent authorities bear in mind the serious</p><p>nature of the offences enumerated in paragraph l of this article and the circumstances enumerated in</p><p>paragraph 5 of this article when considering the eventuality of early release or parole of persons</p><p>convicted of such offences.</p><p>8. Each Party shall, where appropriate, establish under its domestic law a long statute of limitations</p><p>period in which to commence proceedings for any offence established in accordance with paragraph 1 of</p><p>this article, and a longer period where the alleged offender has evaded the administration of justice.</p><p>9. Each Party shall take appropriate measures, consistent with its legal system, to ensure that a</p><p>person charged with or convicted of an offence established in accordance with paragraph 1 of this article,</p><p>who is found within its territory, is present at the necessary criminal proceedings.</p><p>10. For the purpose of co-operation among the Parties under this Convention, including, in particular,</p><p>co-operation under articles 5, 6, 7 and 9, offences established in accordance with this article shall not be</p><p>considered as fiscal offences or as political offences or regarded as politically motivated, without prejudice</p><p>to the constitutional limitations and the fundamental domestic law of the Parties.</p><p>11. Nothing contained in this article shall affect the principle that the description of the offences to</p><p>which it refers and of legal defences thereto is reserved to the domestic law of a Party and that such</p><p>offences shall be prosecuted and punished in conformity with that law.</p><p>4</p><p><em>Article 4</em></p><p>JURISDICTION</p><p>1. Each Party:</p><p>a) Shall take such measures as may be necessary to establish its jurisdiction over the</p><p>offences it has established in accordance with article 3, paragraph 1, when:</p><p>i) The offence is committed in its territory;</p><p>ii) The offence is committed on board a vessel flying its flag or an aircraft which is</p><p>registered under its laws at the time the offence is committed;</p><p>b) May take such measures as maybe necessary to establish its jurisdiction over the</p><p>offences it has established in accordance with article 3, paragraph 1, when:</p><p>i) The offence is committed by one of its nationals or by a person who has his</p><p>habitual residence in its territory;</p><p>ii) The offence is committed on board a vessel concerning which that Party has</p><p>been authorized to take appropriate action pursuant to article 17, provided that</p><p>such jurisdiction shall be exercised only on the basis of agreements or</p><p>arrangements referred to in paragraphs 4 and 9 of that article;</p><p>iii) The offence is one of those established in accordance with article 3, paragraph</p><p>1, subparagraph c) iv), and is committed outside its territory with a view to the</p><p>commission, within its territory, of an offence established in accordance with</p><p>article 3, paragraph 1.</p><p>2. Each Party:</p><p>a) Shall also take such measures as may be necessary to establish its jurisdiction over</p><p>the offences it has established in accordance with article 3, paragraph 1, when the alleged</p><p>offender is present in its territory and it does not extradite him to another Party on the</p><p>ground:</p><p>i) That the offence has been committed in its territory or on board a vessel flying</p><p>its flag or an aircraft which was registered under its law at the time the offence</p><p>was committed; or</p><p>ii) That the offence has been committed by one of its nationals;</p><p>b) May also take such measures as may be necessary to establish its jurisdiction over the</p><p>offences it has established in accordance with article 3, paragraph 1, when the alleged</p><p>offender is present in its territory and it does not extradite him to another Party.</p><p>3. This Convention does not exclude the exercise of any criminal jurisdiction established by a Party in</p><p>accordance with its domestic law.</p><p><em>Article 5</em></p><p>CONFISCATION</p><p>1. Each Party shall adopt such measures as may be necessary to enable confiscation of:</p><p>a) Proceeds derived from offences established in accordance with article 3, paragraph 1,</p><p>or property the value of which corresponds to that of such proceeds;</p><p>b) Narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances, materials and equipment or other</p><p>instrumentalities used in or intended for use in any manner in offences established in</p><p>accordance with article 3, paragraph 1.</p><p>2. Each Party shall also adopt such measures as may be necessary to enable its competent authorities</p><p>to identify, trace, and freeze or seize proceeds, property, instrumentalities or any other things referred to</p><p>in paragraph 1 of this article, for the purpose of eventual confiscation.</p><p>3. In order to carry out the measures referred to in this article, each Party shall empower its courts or</p><p>other competent authorities to order that bank, financial or commercial records be made available or be</p><p>seized. A Party shall not decline to act under the provisions of this paragraph on the ground of bank</p><p>secrecy.</p><p>5</p><p>4. a) Following a request made pursuant to this article by another Party having jurisdiction</p><p>over an offence established in accordance with article 3, paragraph 1, the Party in whose</p><p>territory proceeds, property, instrumentalities or any other things referred to in paragraph 1</p><p>of this article are situated shall:</p><p>i) Submit the request to its competent authorities for the purpose of obtaining an</p><p>order of confiscation and, if such order is granted, give effect to it; or</p><p>ii) Submit to its competent authorities, with a view to giving effect to it to the</p><p>extent requested, an order of confiscation issued by the requesting Party in</p><p>accordance with paragraph 1 of this article, in so far as it relates to proceeds,</p><p>property, instrumentalities or any other things referred to in paragraph 1</p><p>situated in the territory of the requested Party.</p><p>b) Following a request made pursuant to this article by another Party having jurisdiction</p><p>over an offence established in accordance with article 3, paragraph 1, the requested Party</p><p>shall take measures to identify, trace, and freeze or seize proceeds, property,</p><p>instrumentalities or any other things referred to in paragraph l of this article for the purpose</p><p>of eventual confiscation to be ordered either by the requesting Party or, pursuant to a</p><p>request under subparagraph a) of this paragraph, by the requested Party.</p><p>c) The decisions or actions provided for in subparagraphs a) and b) of this paragraph</p><p>shall be taken by the requested Party, in accordance with and subject to the provisions of its</p><p>domestic law and its procedural rules or any bilateral or multilateral treaty, agreement or</p><p>arrangement to which it may be bound in relation to the requesting Party.</p><p>d) The provisions of article 7, paragraphs 6 to 19 are applicable mutatis mutandis. In</p><p>addition to the information specified in article 7, paragraph 10, requests made pursuant to</p><p>this article shall contain the following:</p><p>i) In the case of a request pertaining to subparagraph a) i) of this paragraph, a</p><p>description of the property to be confiscated and a statement of the facts relied</p><p>upon by the requesting Party sufficient to enable the requested Party to seek the</p><p>order under its domestic law;</p><p>ii) In the case of a request pertaining to subparagraph a) ii), a legally admissible</p><p>copy of an order of confiscation issued by the requesting Party upon which the</p><p>request is based, a statement of the facts and information as to the extent to</p><p>which the execution of the order is requested;</p><p>iii) In the case of a request pertaining to subparagraph b), a statement of the facts</p><p>relied upon by the requesting Party and a description of the actions requested.</p><p>e) Each Party shall furnish to the Secretary-General the text of any of its laws and</p><p>regulations which give effect to this paragraph and the text of any subsequent changes to</p><p>such laws and regulations.</p><p>f) If a Party elects to make the taking of the measures referred to in subparagraphs a)</p><p>and b) of this paragraph conditional on the existence of a relevant treaty, that Party shall</p><p>consider this Convention as the necessary and sufficient treaty basis.</p><p>g) The Parties shall seek to conclude bilateral and multilateral treaties, agreements or</p><p>arrangements to enhance the effectiveness of international co-operation pursuant to this</p><p>article.</p><p>5. a) Proceeds or property confiscated by a Party pursuant to paragraph 1 or paragraph 4 of</p><p>this article shall be disposed of by that Party according to its domestic law and administrative</p><p>procedures.</p><p>b) When acting on the request of another Party in accordance with this article, a Party</p><p>may give special consideration to concluding agreements on:</p><p>i) Contributing the value of such proceeds and property, or funds derived from the</p><p>sale of such proceeds or property, or a substantial part thereof, to</p><p>intergovernmental bodies specializing in the fight against illicit traffic in and</p><p>abuse of narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances;</p><p>ii) Sharing with other Parties, on a regular or case-by-case basis, such proceeds or</p><p>property, or funds derived from the sale of such proceeds or property, in</p><p>accordance with its domestic law, administrative procedures or bilateral or</p><p>multilateral agreements entered into for this purpose.</p><p>6. a) If proceeds have been transformed or converted into other property, such property</p><p>shall be liable to the measures referred to in this article instead of the proceeds.</p><p>6</p><p>b) If proceeds have been intermingled with property acquired from legitimate sources,</p><p>such property shall, without prejudice to any powers relating to seizure or freezing, be liable</p><p>to confiscation up to the assessed value of the intermingled proceeds.</p><p>c) Income or other benefits derived from:</p><p>i) Proceeds;</p><p>ii) Property into which proceeds have been transformed or converted; or</p><p>iii) Property with which proceeds have been intermingled shall also be liable to the</p><p>measures referred to in this article, in the same manner and to the same extent</p><p>as proceeds.</p><p>7. Each Party may consider ensuring that the onus of proof be reversed regarding the lawful origin of</p><p>alleged proceeds or other property liable to confiscation, to the extent that such action is consistent with</p><p>the principles of its domestic law and with the nature of the judicial and other proceedings.</p><p>8. The provisions of this article shall not be construed as prejudicing the rights of bona fide third</p><p>parties.</p><p>9. Nothing contained in this article shall affect the principle that the measures to which it refers shall</p><p>be defined and implemented in accordance with and subject to the provisions of the domestic law of a</p><p>Party.</p><p><em>Article 6</em></p><p>EXTRADITION</p><p>1. This article shall apply to the offences established by the Parties in accordance with article 3,</p><p>paragraph 1.</p><p>2. Each of the offences to which this article applies shall be deemed to be included as an extraditable</p><p>offence in any extradition treaty existing between Parties. The Parties undertake to include such offences</p><p>as extraditable offences in every extradition treaty to be concluded between them.</p><p>3. If a Party which makes extradition conditional on the existence of a treaty receives a request for</p><p>extradition from another Party with which it has no extradition treaty, it may consider this Convention as</p><p>the legal basis for extradition in respect of any offence to which this article applies. The Parties which</p><p>require detailed legislation in order to use this Convention as a legal basis for extradition shall consider</p><p>enacting such legislation as may be necessary.</p><p>4. The Parties which do not make extradition conditional on the existence of a treaty shall recognize</p><p>offences to which this article applies as extraditable offences between themselves.</p><p>5. Extradition shall be subject to the conditions provided for by the law of the requested Party or by</p><p>applicable extradition treaties, including the grounds upon which the requested Party may refuse</p><p>extradition.</p><p>6. In considering requests received pursuant to this article, the requested State may refuse to comply</p><p>with such requests where there are substantial grounds leading its judicial or other competent authorities</p><p>to believe that compliance would facilitate the prosecution or punishment of any person on account of his</p><p>race, religion, nationality or political opinions, or would cause prejudice for any of those reasons to any</p><p>person affected by the request.</p><p>7. The Parties shall endeavour to expedite extradition procedures and to simplify evidentiary</p><p>requirements relating thereto in respect of any offence to which this article applies.</p><p>8. Subject to the provisions of its domestic law and its extradition treaties, the requested Party may,</p><p>upon being satisfied that the circumstances so warrant and are urgent, and at the request of the</p><p>requesting Party, take a person whose extradition is sought and who is present in its territory into</p><p>custody or take other appropriate measures to ensure his presence at extradition proceedings.</p><p>7</p><p>9. Without prejudice to the exercise of any criminal jurisdiction established in accordance with its</p><p>domestic law, a Party in whose territory an alleged offender is found shall:</p><p>a) If it does not extradite him in respect of an offence established in accordance with</p><p>article 3, paragraph l, on the grounds set forth in article 4, paragraph 2, subparagraph a),</p><p>submit the case to its competent authorities for the purpose of prosecution, unless otherwise</p><p>agreed with the requesting Party;</p><p>b) If it does not extradite him in respect of such an offence and has established its</p><p>jurisdiction in relation to that offence in accordance with article 4, paragraph 2,</p><p>subparagraph b), submit the case to its competent authorities for the purpose of</p><p>prosecution, unless otherwise requested by the requesting Party for the purposes of</p><p>preserving its legitimate jurisdiction.</p><p>10. If extradition, sought for purposes of enforcing a sentence, is refused because the person sought is</p><p>a national of the requested Party, the requested Party shall, if its law so permits and in conformity with</p><p>the requirements of such law, upon application of the requesting Party, consider, the enforcement of the</p><p>sentence which has been imposed under the law of the requesting Party, or the remainder thereof.</p><p>11. The Parties shall seek to conclude bilateral and multilateral agreements to carry out or to enhance</p><p>the effectiveness of extradition.</p><p>12. The Parties may consider entering into bilateral or multilateral agreements, whether <em>ad hoc </em>or</p><p>general, on the transfer to their country of persons sentenced to imprisonment and other forms of</p><p>deprivation of liberty for offences to which this article applies, in order that they may complete their</p><p>sentences there.</p><p><em>Article 7</em></p><p>MUTUAL LEGAL ASSISTANCE</p><p>1. The Parties shall afford one another, pursuant to this article, the widest measure of mutual legal</p><p>assistance in investigations, prosecutions and judicial proceedings in relation to criminal offences</p><p>established in accordance with article 3, paragraph 1.</p><p>2. Mutual legal assistance to be afforded in accordance with this article may be requested for any of</p><p>the following purposes:</p><p>a) Taking evidence or statements from persons;</p><p>b) Effecting service of judicial documents;</p><p>c) Executing searches and seizures;</p><p>d) Examining objects and sites;</p><p>e) Providing information and evidentiary items;</p><p>f) Providing originals or certified copies of relevant documents and records, including</p><p>bank, financial, corporate or business records;</p><p>g) Identifying or tracing proceeds, property, instrumentalities or other things for</p><p>evidentiary purposes.</p><p>3. The Parties may afford one another any other forms of mutual legal assistance allowed by the</p><p>domestic law of the requested Party.</p><p>4. Upon request, the Parties shall facilitate or encourage, to the extent consistent with their domestic</p><p>law and practice, the presence or availability of persons, including persons in custody, who consent to</p><p>assist in investigations or participate in proceedings.</p><p>5. A Party shall not decline to render mutual legal assistance under this article on the ground of bank</p><p>secrecy.</p><p>6. The provisions of this article shall not affect the obligations under any other treaty, bilateral or</p><p>multilateral, which governs or will govern, in whole or in part, mutual legal assistance in criminal matters.</p><p>7. Paragraphs 8 to 19 of this article shall apply to requests made pursuant to this article if the Parties</p><p>in question are not bound by a treaty of mutual legal assistance. If these Parties are bound by such a</p><p>treaty, the corresponding provisions of that treaty shall apply unless the Parties agree to apply</p><p>paragraphs 8 to 19 of this article in lieu thereof.</p><p>8</p><p>8. Parties shall designate an authority, or when necessary authorities, which shall have the</p><p>responsibility and power to execute requests for mutual legal assistance or to transmit them to the</p><p>competent authorities for execution. The authority or the authorities designated for this purpose shall be</p><p>notified to the Secretary-General. Transmission of requests for mutual legal assistance and any</p><p>communication related thereto shall be effected between the authorities designated by the Parties; this</p><p>requirement shall be without prejudice to the right of a Party to require that such requests and</p><p>communications be addressed to it through the diplomatic channel and, in urgent circumstances, where</p><p>the Parties agree, through channels of the International Criminal Police Organization, if possible.</p><p>9. Requests shall be made in writing in a language acceptable to the requested Party. The language</p><p>or languages acceptable to each Party shall be notified to the Secretary-General. In urgent</p><p>circumstances, and where agreed by the Parties, requests may be made orally, but shall be confirmed in</p><p>writing forthwith.</p><p>10. A request for mutual legal assistance shall contain:</p><p>a) The identity of the authority making the request;</p><p>b) The subject matter and nature of the investigation, prosecution or proceeding to which</p><p>the request relates, and the name and the functions of the authority conducting such</p><p>investigation, prosecution or proceeding;</p><p>c) A summary of the relevant facts, except in respect of requests for the purpose of</p><p>service of judicial documents;</p><p>d) A description of the assistance sought and details of any particular procedure the</p><p>requesting Party wishes to be followed;</p><p>e) Where possible, the identity, location and nationality of any person concerned;</p><p>f) The purpose for which the evidence, information or action is sought.</p><p>11. The requested Party may request additional information when it appears necessary for the</p><p>execution of the request in accordance with its domestic law or when it can facilitate such execution.</p><p>12. A request shall be executed in accordance with the domestic law of the requested Party and, to the</p><p>extent not contrary to the domestic law of the requested Party and where possible, in accordance with</p><p>the procedures specified in the request.</p><p>13. The requesting Party shall not transmit nor use information or evidence furnished by the requested</p><p>Party for investigations, prosecutions or proceedings other than those stated in the request without the</p><p>prior consent of the requested Party.</p><p>14. The requesting Party may require that the requested Party keep confidential the fact and substance</p><p>of the request, except to the extent necessary to execute the request. If the requested Party cannot</p><p>comply with the requirement of confidentiality, it shall promptly inform the requesting Party.</p><p>15. Mutual legal assistance may be refused:</p><p>a) If the request is not made in conformity with the provisions of this article;</p><p>b) If the requested Party considers that execution of the request is likely to prejudice its</p><p>sovereignty, security, ordre public or other essential interests;</p><p>c) If the authorities of the requested Party would be prohibited by its domestic law from</p><p>carrying out the action requested with regard to any similar offence, had it been subject to</p><p>investigation, prosecution or proceedings under their own jurisdiction;</p><p>d) If it would be contrary to the legal system of the requested Party relating to mutual</p><p>legal assistance for the request to be granted.</p><p>16. Reasons shall be given for any refusal of mutual legal assistance.</p><p>17. Mutual legal assistance may be postponed by the requested Party on the ground that it interferes</p><p>with an ongoing investigation, prosecution or proceeding. In such a case, the requested Party shall</p><p>consult with the requesting Party to determine if the assistance can still be given subject to such terms</p><p>and conditions as the requested Party deems necessary.</p><p>18. A witness, expert or other person who consents to give evidence in a proceeding or to assist in an</p><p>investigation, prosecution or judicial proceeding in the territory of the requesting Party, shall not be</p><p>prosecuted, detained, punished or subjected to any other restriction of his personal liberty in that</p><p>territory in respect of acts, omissions or convictions prior to his departure from the territory of the</p><p>requested Party. Such safe conduct shall cease when the witness, expert or other person having had, for</p><p>a period of fifteen consecutive days, or for any period agreed upon by the Parties, from the date on which</p><p>9</p><p>he has been officially informed that his presence is no longer required by the judicial authorities, an</p><p>opportunity of leaving, has nevertheless remained voluntarily in the territory or, having left it, has</p><p>returned of his own free will.</p><p>19. The ordinary costs of executing a request shall be borne by the requested Party, unless otherwise</p><p>agreed by the Parties concerned. If expenses of a substantial or extraordinary nature are or will be</p><p>required to fulfil the request, the Parties shall consult to determine the terms and conditions under which</p><p>the request will be executed as well as the manner in which the costs shall be borne.</p><p>20. The Parties shall consider, as may be necessary, the possibility of concluding bilateral or</p><p>multilateral agreements or arrangements that would serve the purposes of, give practical effect to, or</p><p>enhance the provisions of this article.</p><p><em>Article 8</em></p><p>TRANSFER OF PROCEEDINGS</p><p>The Parties shall give consideration to the possibility of transferring to one another proceedings for</p><p>criminal prosecution of offences established in accordance with article 3, paragraph 1, in cases where</p><p>such transfer is considered to be in the interests of a proper administration of justice.</p><p><em>Article 9</em></p><p>OTHER FORMS OF CO-OPERATION AND TRAINING</p><p>1. The Parties shall co-operate closely with one another, consistent with their respective domestic</p><p>legal and administrative systems, with a view to enhancing the effectiveness of law enforcement action to</p><p>suppress the commission of offence</p></div></div>

Seizure of a pirate ship or</p><p>aircraft . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 58</p><p>Article 106. Liability for seizure without</p><p>adequate grounds . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 58</p><p>Article 107. 53	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">UNITED NATIONS CONVENTION AGAINST  TRANSNATIONAL ORGANIZED CRIME  AND THE PROTOCOLS THERETO  UNITED NATIONS  UNITED NATIONS OFFICE ON DRUGS AND CRIME  Vienna  UNITED NATIONS CONVENTION AGAINST  TRANSNATIONAL ORGANIZED CRIME  AND THE PROTOCOLS THERETO  UN</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p><a href="http://www.lawyersnjurists.com/legal-documentations-litigations/international-conventions-treaties/international-crimes-conventions/united-nations-convention-against-transnational-organized-crime-and-the-protocols-thereto-united-nations-united-nations-office-on-drugs-and-crime-vienna-united-nations-convention-against-transn/attachment/tocebook-e/" rel="attachment wp-att-6228">UNITED NATIONS CONVENTION AGAINST TRANSNATIONAL ORGANIZED CRIME AND THE PROTOCOLS THERETO(Full pdf File)</a></p><p>iii</p><p><strong>Foreword</strong></p><p>With the signing of the United Nations Convention against Transnational</p><p>Organized Crime in Palermo, Italy, in December 2000, the international community</p><p>demonstrated the political will to answer a global challenge with a</p><p>global response. If crime crosses borders, so must law enforcement. If the rule of</p><p>law is undermined not only in one country, but in many, then those who</p><p>defend it cannot limit themselves to purely national means. If the enemies of</p><p>progress and human rights seek to exploit the openness and opportunities of</p><p>globalization for their purposes, then we must exploit those very same factors to</p><p>defend human rights and defeat the forces of crime, corruption and trafficking</p><p>in human beings.</p><p>One of the starkest contrasts in our world today is the gulf that exists</p><p>between the civil and the uncivil. By “civil” I mean civilization: the accumulated</p><p>centuries of learning that form our foundation for progress. By “civil” I also</p><p>mean tolerance: the pluralism and respect with which we accept and draw</p><p>strength from the world’s diverse peoples. And finally, I mean civil society: the</p><p>citizens’ groups, businesses, unions, professors, journalists, political parties and</p><p>others who have an essential role to play in the running of any society.</p><p>Arrayed against these constructive forces, however, in ever greater numbers</p><p>and with ever stronger weapons, are the forces of what I call “uncivil society”.</p><p>They are terrorists, criminals, drug dealers, traffickers in people and others who</p><p>undo the good works of civil society. They take advantage of the open borders,</p><p>free markets and technological advances that bring so many benefits to the</p><p>world’s people. They thrive in countries with weak institutions, and they show</p><p>no scruple about resorting to intimidation or violence. Their ruthlessness is the</p><p>very antithesis of all we regard as civil. They are powerful, representing entrenched</p><p>interests and the clout of a global enterprise worth billions of dollars,</p><p>but they are not invincible.</p><p>The Millennium Declaration adopted by the Heads of State meeting at the</p><p>United Nations in September 2000 reaffirmed the principles underlying our</p><p>efforts and should serve to encourage all who struggle for the rule of law. The</p><p>Declaration states that “men and women have the right to live their lives and</p><p>raise their children in dignity, free from hunger and from the fear of violence,</p><p>oppression or injustice”.</p><p>At the Millennium Summit, world leaders proclaimed freedom—from fear</p><p>and from want—as one of the essential values in the twenty-first century. Yet</p><p>the right to live in dignity, free from fear and want, is still denied to millions</p><p>iv</p><p>of people around the world. It is denied to the child who is working as an</p><p>indentured labourer in a sweatshop; to the father who must pay a bribe to get</p><p>medical care for his son or daughter; to the woman who is condemned to a life</p><p>of forced prostitution.</p><p>I believe the trafficking of persons, particularly women and children, for</p><p>forced and exploitative labour, including for sexual exploitation, is one of the</p><p>most egregious violations of human rights that the United Nations now confronts.</p><p>It is widespread and growing. It is rooted in social and economic conditions</p><p>in the countries from which the victims come, facilitated by practices that</p><p>discriminate against women and driven by cruel indifference to human suffering</p><p>on the part of those who exploit the services that the victims are forced to</p><p>provide. The fate of these most vulnerable people in our world is an affront to</p><p>human dignity and a challenge to every State, every people and every community.</p><p>I therefore urge the Member States to ratify not only the United Nations</p><p>Convention against Transnational Organized Crime, but also the Protocol to</p><p>Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, Especially Women and</p><p>Children, which can make a real difference in the struggle to eliminate this</p><p>reprehensible trade in human beings.</p><p>Criminal groups have wasted no time in embracing today’s globalized</p><p>economy and the sophisticated technology that goes with it. But our efforts to</p><p>combat them have remained up to now very fragmented and our weapons</p><p>almost obsolete. The Convention gives us a new tool to address the scourge of</p><p>crime as a global problem. With enhanced international cooperation, we can</p><p>have a real impact on the ability of international criminals to operate successfully</p><p>and can help citizens everywhere in their often bitter struggle for safety and</p><p>dignity in their homes and communities.</p><p>The signing of the Convention in Palermo in December 2000 was a watershed</p><p>event in the reinforcement of our fight against organized crime. I urge all</p><p>States to ratify the Convention and the Protocols thereto at the earliest possible</p><p>date and to bring these instruments into force as a matter of urgency.</p><p><em>Kofi A. Annan</em></p><p><em>Secretary-General</em></p><p>v</p><p><strong>Contents</strong></p><p><em>Page</em></p><p>General Assembly resolution 55/25 of 15 November 2000 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 1</p><p>Annexes</p><p>I. United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime . 5</p><p>II. Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons,</p><p>Especially Women and Children, supplementing the United Nations</p><p>Convention against Transnational Organized Crime . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 41</p><p>III. Protocol against the Smuggling of Migrants by Land, Sea and Air,</p><p>supplementing the United Nations Convention against Transnational</p><p>Organized Crime . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 53</p><p>General Assembly resolution 55/255 of 31 May 2001 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 69</p><p>Annex. Protocol against the Illicit Manufacturing of and Trafficking in</p><p>Firearms, Their parts and Components and Ammunition,</p><p>supplementing the United Nations Convention against</p><p>Transnational Organized Crime . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 71</p><p>1</p><p><strong>General Assembly resolution 55/25</strong></p><p><strong>of </strong><strong>15 November 2000</strong><strong> </strong></p><p><strong>United Nations Convention against</strong></p><p><strong>Transnational Organized Crime</strong></p><p><em>The General Assembly</em>,</p><p><em>Recalling </em>its resolution 53/111 of 9 December 1998, in which it decided</p><p>to establish an open-ended intergovernmental ad hoc committee for the purpose</p><p>of elaborating a comprehensive international convention against transnational</p><p>organized crime and of discussing the elaboration, as appropriate, of international</p><p>instruments addressing trafficking in women and children, combating</p><p>the illicit manufacturing of and trafficking in firearms, their parts and components</p><p>and ammunition, and illegal trafficking in and transporting of migrants,</p><p>including by sea,</p><p><em>Recalling also </em>its resolution 54/126 of 17 December 1999, in which it</p><p>requested the Ad Hoc Committee on the Elaboration of a Convention against</p><p>Transnational Organized Crime to continue its work, in accordance with resolutions</p><p>53/111 and 53/114 of 9 December 1998, and to intensify that work in</p><p>order to complete it in 2000,</p><p><em>Recalling further </em>its resolution 54/129 of 17 December 1999, in which it</p><p>accepted with appreciation the offer of the Government of Italy to host a highlevel</p><p>political signing conference in Palermo for the purpose of signing the</p><p>United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime (Palermo</p><p>Convention) and the protocols thereto, and requested the Secretary-General to</p><p>schedule the conference for a period of up to one week before the end of the</p><p>Millennium Assembly in 2000,</p><p><em>Expressing its appreciation </em>to the Government of Poland for submitting to</p><p>it at its fifty-first session a first draft United Nations convention against</p><p>transnational organized crime1 and for hosting the meeting of the inter-sessional</p><p>open-ended intergovernmental group of experts, established pursuant to resolution</p><p>52/85 of 12 December 1997, on the elaboration of a preliminary draft of</p><p>1A/C.3/51/7, annex.</p><p>2</p><p>a possible comprehensive international convention against transnational organized</p><p>crime, held in Warsaw from 2 to 6 February 1998,</p><p><em>Expressing its appreciation </em>to the Government of Argentina for hosting the</p><p>informal preparatory meeting of the Ad Hoc Committee, held in Buenos Aires</p><p>from 31 August to 4 September 1998,</p><p><em>Expressing its appreciation </em>to the Government of Thailand for hosting the</p><p>Asia-Pacific Ministerial Seminar on Building Capacities for Fighting Transnational</p><p>Organized Crime, held in Bangkok on 20 and 21 March 2000,</p><p><em>Deeply concerned </em>by the negative economic and social implications related</p><p>to organized criminal activities, and convinced of the urgent need to strengthen</p><p>cooperation to prevent and combat such activities more effectively at the</p><p>national, regional and international levels,</p><p><em>Noting with deep concern </em>the growing links between transnational organized</p><p>crime and terrorist crimes, taking into account the Charter of the United</p><p>Nations and the relevant resolutions of the General Assembly,</p><p><em>Determined </em>to deny safe havens to those who engage in transnational organized</p><p>crime by prosecuting their crimes wherever they occur and by cooperating</p><p>at the international level,</p><p><em>Strongly convinced </em>that the United Nations Convention against Transnational</p><p>Organized Crime will constitute an effective tool and the necessary</p><p>legal framework for international cooperation in combating, inter alia, such</p><p>criminal activities as money-laundering, corruption, illicit trafficking in endangered</p><p>species of wild flora and fauna, offences against cultural heritage and</p><p>the growing links between transnational organized crime and terrorist crimes,</p><p>1. <em>Takes note </em>of the report of the Ad Hoc Committee on the Elaboration</p><p>of a Convention against Transnational Organized Crime,2 which carried out its</p><p>work at the headquarters of the United Nations Office for Drug Control and</p><p>Crime Prevention in Vienna, and commends the Ad Hoc Committee for its</p><p>work;</p><p>2. <em>Adopts </em>the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized</p><p>Crime and the Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in</p><p>Persons, Especially Women and Children, supplementing the United Nations</p><p>Convention against Transnational Organized Crime, and the Protocol against</p><p>2A/AC.254/34.</p><p>3</p><p>the Smuggling of Migrants by Land, Sea and Air, supplementing the United</p><p>Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime annexed to the</p><p>present resolution, and opens them for signature at the High-level Political</p><p>Signing Conference to be held in Palermo, Italy, from 12 to 15 December 2000</p><p>in accordance with resolution 54/129;</p><p>3. <em>Requests </em>the Secretary-General to prepare a comprehensive report on</p><p>the High-level Political Signing Conference to be held in Palermo in accordance</p><p>with resolution 54/129;</p><p>4. <em>Notes </em>that the Ad Hoc Committee has not yet completed its work on</p><p>the draft Protocol against the Illicit Manufacturing of and Trafficking in Firearms,</p><p>Their Parts and Components and Ammunition, supplementing the</p><p>United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime;</p><p>5. <em>Requests </em>the Ad Hoc Committee to continue its work in relation to</p><p>this draft Protocol, in accordance with resolutions 53/111, 53/114 and 54/126,</p><p>and to finalize such work as soon as possible;</p><p>6. <em>Calls upon </em>all States to recognize the links between transnational organized</p><p>criminal activities and acts of terrorism, taking into account the relevant</p><p>General Assembly resolutions, and to apply the United Nations Convention</p><p>against Transnational Organized Crime in combating all forms of criminal</p><p>activity, as provided therein;</p><p>7. <em>Recommends </em>that the Ad Hoc Committee established by the General</p><p>Assembly in its resolution 51/210 of 17 December 1996, which is beginning its</p><p>deliberations with a view to developing a comprehensive convention on international</p><p>terrorism, pursuant to resolution 54/110 of 9 December 1999, should</p><p>take into consideration the provisions of the United Nations Convention</p><p>against Transnational Organized Crime;</p><p>8. <em>Urges </em>all States and regional economic organizations to sign and ratify</p><p>the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime and</p><p>the protocols thereto as soon as possible in order to ensure the speedy entry into</p><p>force of the Convention and the protocols thereto;</p><p>9. <em>Decides </em>that, until the Conference of the Parties to the Convention</p><p>established pursuant to the United Nations Convention against Transnational</p><p>Organized Crime decides otherwise, the account referred to in article 30 of the</p><p>Convention will be operated within the United Nations Crime Prevention and</p><p>Criminal Justice Fund, and encourages Member States to begin making</p><p>adequate voluntary contributions to the above-mentioned account for the</p><p>4</p><p>provision to developing countries and countries with economies in transition of</p><p>the technical assistance that they might require for implementation of the Convention</p><p>and the protocols thereto, including for the preparatory measures</p><p>needed for that implementation;</p><p>10. <em>Decides also </em>that the Ad Hoc Committee on the Elaboration of a</p><p>Convention against Transnational Organized Crime will complete its tasks</p><p>arising from the elaboration of the United Nations Convention against</p><p>Transnational Organized Crime by holding a meeting well before the convening</p><p>of the first session of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention, in order</p><p>to prepare the draft text of the rules of procedure for the Conference of the</p><p>Parties and other rules and mechanisms described in article 32 of the Convention,</p><p>which will be communicated to the Conference of the Parties at its first</p><p>session for consideration and action;</p><p>11. <em>Requests </em>the Secretary-General to designate the Centre for International</p><p>Crime Prevention of the United Nations Office for Drug Control and</p><p>Crime Prevention to serve as the secretariat for the Conference of the Parties to</p><p>the Convention in accordance with article 33 of the Convention;</p><p>12. <em>Also requests </em>the Secretary-General to provide the Centre for International</p><p>Crime Prevention with the resources necessary to enable it to promote in</p><p>an effective manner the expeditious entry into force of the United Nations</p><p>Convention against Transnational Organized Crime and to discharge the functions</p><p>of secretariat of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention, and to</p><p>support the Ad Hoc Committee in its work pursuant to paragraph 10 above.</p><p>5</p><p><em>Article 1. Statement of purpose</em></p><p>The purpose of this Convention is to promote cooperation to prevent and</p><p>combat transnational organized crime more effectively.</p><p><em>Article 2. Use of terms</em></p><p>For the purposes of this Convention:</p><p><em>(a) </em>“Organized criminal group” shall mean a structured group of three or</p><p>more persons, existing for a period of time and acting in concert with the aim</p><p>of committing one or more serious crimes or offences established in accordance</p><p>with this Convention, in order to obtain, directly or indirectly, a financial or</p><p>other material benefit;</p><p><em>(b) </em>“Serious crime” shall mean conduct constituting an offence punishable</p><p>by a maximum deprivation of liberty of at least four years or a more serious</p><p>penalty;</p><p><em>(c) </em>“Structured group” shall mean a group that is not randomly formed</p><p>for the immediate commission of an offence and that does not need to have</p><p>formally defined roles for its members, continuity of its membership or a</p><p>developed structure;</p><p><em>(d) </em>“Property” shall mean assets of every kind, whether corporeal or</p><p>incorporeal, movable or immovable, tangible or intangible, and legal documents</p><p>or instruments evidencing title to, or interest in, such assets;</p><p><em>(e) </em>“Proceeds of crime” shall mean any property derived from or</p><p>obtained, directly or indirectly, through the commission of an offence;</p><p><em>(f) </em>“Freezing” or “seizure” shall mean temporarily prohibiting the transfer,</p><p>conversion, disposition or movement of property or temporarily assuming</p><p>custody or control of property on the basis of an order issued by a court or</p><p>other competent authority;</p><p><em>Annex I</em></p><p><strong>United Nations Convention against</strong></p><p><strong>Transnational Organized Crime</strong></p><p>6</p><p><em>(g) </em>“Confiscation”, which includes forfeiture where applicable, shall mean</p><p>the permanent deprivation of property by order of a court or other competent</p><p>authority;</p><p><em>(h) </em>“Predicate offence” shall mean any offence as a result of which proceeds</p><p>have been generated that may become the subject of an offence as defined</p><p>in article 6 of this Convention;</p><p><em>(i) </em>“Controlled delivery” shall mean the technique of allowing illicit or</p><p>suspect consignments to pass out of, through or into the territory of one or</p><p>more States, with the knowledge and under the supervision of their competent</p><p>authorities, with a view to the investigation of an offence and the identification</p><p>of persons involved in the commission of the offence;</p><p><em>(j) </em>“Regional economic integration organization” shall mean an organization</p><p>constituted by sovereign States of a given region, to which its member</p><p>States have transferred competence in respect of matters governed by this Convention</p><p>and which has been duly authorized, in accordance with its internal</p><p>procedures, to sign, ratify, accept, approve or accede to it; references to “States</p><p>Parties” under this Convention shall apply to such organizations within the</p><p>limits of their competence.</p><p><em>Article 3. Scope of application</em></p><p>1. This Convention shall apply, except as otherwise stated herein, to the</p><p>prevention, investigation and prosecution of:</p><p><em>(a) </em>The offences established in accordance with articles 5, 6, 8 and 23 of</p><p>this Convention; and</p><p><em>(b) </em>Serious crime as defined in article 2 of this Convention;</p><p>where the offence is transnational in nature and involves an organized criminal</p><p>group.</p><p>2. For the purpose of paragraph 1 of this article, an offence is transnational</p><p>in nature if:</p><p><em>(a) </em>It is committed in more than one State;</p><p><em>(b) </em>It is committed in one State but a substantial part of its preparation,</p><p>planning, direction or control takes place in another State;</p><p><em>(c) </em>It is committed in one State but involves an organized criminal group</p><p>that engages in criminal activities in more than one State; or</p><p><em>(d) </em>It is committed in one State but has substantial effects in another</p><p>State.</p><p>7</p><p><em>Article 4. Protection of sovereignty</em></p><p>1. States Parties shall carry out their obligations under this Convention</p><p>in a manner consistent with the principles of sovereign equality and territorial</p><p>integrity of States and that of non-intervention in the domestic affairs of other</p><p>States.</p><p>2. Nothing in this Convention entitles a State Party to undertake in the</p><p>territory of another State the exercise of jurisdiction and performance of functions</p><p>that are reserved exclusively for the authorities of that other State by its</p><p>domestic law.</p><p><em>Article 5. Criminalization of participation in an</em></p><p><em>organized criminal group</em></p><p>1. Each State Party shall adopt such legislative and other measures as</p><p>may be necessary to establish as criminal offences, when committed intentionally:</p><p><em>(a) </em>Either or both of the following as criminal offences distinct from</p><p>those involving the attempt or completion of the criminal activity:</p><p>(i) Agreeing with one or more other persons to commit a serious</p><p>crime for a purpose relating directly or indirectly to the obtaining</p><p>of a financial or other material benefit and, where required</p><p>by domestic law, involving an act undertaken by one of the</p><p>participants in furtherance of the agreement or involving an</p><p>organized criminal group;</p><p>(ii) Conduct by a person who, with knowledge of either the aim and</p><p>general criminal activity of an organized criminal group or its</p><p>intention to commit the crimes in question, takes an active part</p><p>in:</p><p>a. Criminal activities of the organized criminal group;</p><p>b. Other activities of the organized criminal group in the</p><p>knowledge that his or her participation will contribute to the</p><p>achievement of the above-described criminal aim;</p><p><em>(b) </em>Organizing, directing, aiding, abetting, facilitating or counselling the</p><p>commission of serious crime involving an organized criminal group.</p><p>2. The knowledge, intent, aim, purpose or agreement referred to in paragraph</p><p>1 of this article may be inferred from objective factual circumstances.</p><p>3. States Parties whose domestic law requires involvement of an organized</p><p>criminal group for purposes of the offences established in accordance with</p><p>8</p><p>paragraph 1 <em>(a) </em>(i) of this article shall ensure that their domestic law covers all</p><p>serious crimes involving organized criminal groups. Such States Parties, as well</p><p>as States Parties whose domestic law requires an act in furtherance of the</p><p>agreement for purposes of the offences established in accordance with paragraph</p><p>1 <em>(a) </em>(i) of this article, shall so inform the Secretary-General of the United</p><p>Nations at the time of their signature or of deposit of their instrument of</p><p>ratification, acceptance or approval of or accession to this Convention.</p><p><em>Article 6. Criminalization of the laundering of proceeds of crime</em></p><p>1. Each State Party shall adopt, in accordance with fundamental principles</p><p>of its domestic law, such legislative and other measures as may be necessary</p><p>to establish as criminal offences, when committed intentionally:</p><p><em>(a) </em>(i) The conversion or transfer of property, knowing that such property</p><p>is the proceeds of crime, for the purpose of concealing or</p><p>disguising the illicit origin of the property or of helping any</p><p>person who is involved in the commission of the predicate</p><p>offence to evade the legal consequences of his or her action;</p><p>(ii) The concealment or disguise of the true nature, source, location,</p><p>disposition, movement or ownership of or rights with respect to</p><p>property, knowing that such property is the proceeds of crime;</p><p><em>(b) </em>Subject to the basic concepts of its legal system:</p><p>(i) The acquisition, possession or use of property, knowing, at the</p><p>time of receipt, that such property is the proceeds of crime;</p><p>(ii) Participation in, association with or conspiracy to commit,</p><p>attempts to commit and aiding, abetting, facilitating and</p><p>counselling the commission of any of the offences established in</p><p>accordance with this article.</p><p>2. For purposes of implementing or applying paragraph 1 of this article:</p><p>(<em>a</em>) Each State Party shall seek to apply paragraph 1 of this article to the</p><p>widest range of predicate offences;</p><p>(<em>b</em>) Each State Party shall include as predicate offences all serious crime</p><p>as defined in article 2 of this Convention and the offences established in accordance</p><p>with articles 5, 8 and 23 of this Convention. In the case of States Parties</p><p>whose legislation sets out a list of specific predicate offences, they shall, at a</p><p>minimum, include in such list a comprehensive range of offences associated</p><p>with organized criminal groups;</p><p>(<em>c</em>) For the purposes of subparagraph <em>(b), </em>predicate offences shall include</p><p>offences committed both within and outside the jurisdiction of the State Party</p><p>9</p><p>in question. However, offences committed outside the jurisdiction of a State</p><p>Party shall constitute predicate offences only when the relevant conduct is a</p><p>criminal offence under the domestic law of the State where it is committed and</p><p>would be a criminal offence under the domestic law of the State Party implementing</p><p>or applying this article had it been committed there;</p><p><em>(d) </em>Each State Party shall furnish copies of its laws that give effect to this</p><p>article and of any subsequent changes to such laws or a description thereof to</p><p>the Secretary-General of the United Nations;</p><p><em>(e) </em>If required by fundamental principles of the domestic law of a State</p><p>Party, it may be provided that the offences set forth in paragraph 1 of this article</p><p>do not apply to the persons who committed the predicate offence;</p><p><em>(f) </em>Knowledge, intent or purpose required as an element of an offence set</p><p>forth in paragraph 1 of this article may be inferred from objective factual</p><p>circumstances.</p><p><em>Article 7. Measures to combat money-laundering</em></p><p>1. Each State Party:</p><p><em>(a) </em>Shall institute a comprehensive domestic regulatory and supervisory</p><p>regime for banks and non-bank financial institutions and, where appropriate,</p><p>other bodies particularly susceptible to money-laundering, within its competence,</p><p>in order to deter and detect all forms of money-laundering, which regime</p><p>shall emphasize requirements for customer identification, record-keeping and</p><p>the reporting of suspicious transactions;</p><p><em>(b) </em>Shall, without prejudice to articles 18 and 27 of this Convention,</p><p>ensure that administrative, regulatory, law enforcement and other authorities</p><p>dedicated to combating money-laundering (including, where appropriate under</p><p>domestic law, judicial authorities) have the ability to cooperate and exchange</p><p>information at the national and international levels within the conditions</p><p>prescribed by its domestic law and, to that end, shall consider the establishment</p><p>of a financial intelligence unit to serve as a national centre for the collection,</p><p>analysis and dissemination of information regarding potential moneylaundering.</p><p>2. States Parties shall consider implementing feasible measures to detect</p><p>and monitor the movement of cash and appropriate negotiable instruments</p><p>across their borders, subject to safeguards to ensure proper use of information</p><p>and without impeding in any way the movement of legitimate capital. Such</p><p>measures may include a requirement that individuals and businesses report the</p><p>cross-border transfer of substantial quantities of cash and appropriate negotiable</p><p>instruments.</p><p>10</p><p>3. In establishing a domestic regulatory and supervisory regime under</p><p>the terms of this article, and without prejudice to any other article of this</p><p>Convention, States Parties are called upon to use as a guideline the relevant</p><p>initiatives of regional, interregional and multilateral organizations against</p><p>money-laundering.</p><p>4. States Parties shall endeavour to develop and promote global, regional,</p><p>subregional and bilateral cooperation among judicial, law enforcement and</p><p>financial regulatory authorities in order to combat money-laundering.</p><p><em>Article 8. Criminalization of corruption</em></p><p>1. Each State Party shall adopt such legislative and other measures as</p><p>may be necessary to establish as criminal offences, when committed intentionally:</p><p><em>(a) </em>The promise, offering or giving to a public official, directly or indirectly,</p><p>of an undue advantage, for the official himself or herself or another</p><p>person or entity, in order that the official act or refrain from acting in the</p><p>exercise of his or her official duties;</p><p><em>(b) </em>The solicitation or acceptance by a public official, directly or indirectly,</p><p>of an undue advantage, for the official himself or herself or another</p><p>person or entity, in order that the official act or refrain from acting in the</p><p>exercise of his or her official duties.</p><p>2. Each State Party shall consider adopting such legislative and other</p><p>measures as may be necessary to establish as criminal offences conduct referred</p><p>to in paragraph 1 of this article involving a foreign public official or international</p><p>civil servant. Likewise, each State Party shall consider establishing as</p><p>criminal offences other forms of corruption.</p><p>3. Each State Party shall also adopt such measures as may be necessary</p><p>to establish as a criminal offence participation as an accomplice in an offence</p><p>established in accordance with this article.</p><p>4. For the purposes of paragraph 1 of this article and article 9 of this</p><p>Convention, “public official” shall mean a public official or a person who</p><p>provides a public service as defined in the domestic law and as applied in the</p><p>criminal law of the State Party in which the person in question performs that</p><p>function.</p><p><em>Article 9. Measures against corruption</em></p><p>1. In addition to the measures set forth in article 8 of this Convention,</p><p>each State Party shall, to the extent appropriate and consistent with its legal</p><p>11</p><p>system, adopt legislative, administrative or other effective measures to promote</p><p>integrity and to prevent, detect and punish the corruption of public officials.</p><p>2. Each State Party shall take measures to ensure effective action by its</p><p>authorities in the prevention, detection and punishment of the corruption of</p><p>public officials, including providing such authorities with adequate independence</p><p>to deter the exertion of inappropriate influence on their actions.</p><p><em>Article 10. Liability of legal persons</em></p><p>1. Each State Party shall adopt such measures as may be necessary, consistent</p><p>with its legal principles, to establish the liability of legal persons for</p><p>participation in serious crimes involving an organized criminal group and for</p><p>the offences established in accordance with articles 5, 6, 8 and 23 of this</p><p>Convention.</p><p>2. Subject to the legal principles of the State Party, the liability of legal</p><p>persons may be criminal, civil or administrative.</p><p>3. Such liability shall be without prejudice to the criminal liability of the</p><p>natural persons who have committed the offences.</p><p>4. Each State Party shall, in particular, ensure that legal persons held</p><p>liable in accordance with this article are subject to effective, proportionate and</p><p>dissuasive criminal or non-criminal sanctions, including monetary sanctions.</p><p><em>Article 11. Prosecution, adjudication and sanctions</em></p><p>1. Each State Party shall make the commission of an offence established</p><p>in accordance with articles 5, 6, 8 and 23 of this Convention liable to sanctions</p><p>that take into account the gravity of that offence.</p><p>2. Each State Party shall endeavour to ensure that any discretionary legal</p><p>powers under its domestic law relating to the prosecution of persons for offences</p><p>covered by this Convention are exercised to maximize the effectiveness of law</p><p>enforcement measures in respect of those offences and with due regard to the</p><p>need to deter the commission of such offences.</p><p>3. In the case of offences established in accordance with articles 5, 6, 8</p><p>and 23 of this Convention, each State Party shall take appropriate measures, in</p><p>accordance with its domestic law and with due regard to the rights of the</p><p>defence, to seek to ensure that conditions imposed in connection with decisions</p><p>on release pending trial or appeal take into consideration the need to ensure the</p><p>presence of the defendant at subsequent criminal proceedings.</p><p>12</p><p>4. Each State Party shall ensure that its courts or other competent</p><p>authorities bear in mind the grave nature of the offences covered by this Convention</p><p>when considering the eventuality of early release or parole of persons</p><p>convicted of such offences.</p><p>5. Each State Party shall, where appropriate, establish under its domestic</p><p>law a long statute of limitations period in which to commence proceedings for</p><p>any offence covered by this Convention and a longer period where the alleged</p><p>offender has evaded the administration of justice.</p><p>6. Nothing contained in this Convention shall affect the principle that</p><p>the description of the offences established in accordance with this Convention</p><p>and of the applicable legal defences or other legal principles controlling the</p><p>lawfulness of conduct is reserved to the domestic law of a State Party and that</p><p>such offences shall be prosecuted and punished in accordance with that law.</p><p><em>Article 12. Confiscation and seizure</em></p><p>1. States Parties shall adopt, to the greatest extent possible within their</p><p>domestic legal systems, such measures as may be necessary to enable confiscation</p><p>of:</p><p><em>(a) </em>Proceeds of crime derived from offences covered by this Convention</p><p>or property the value of which corresponds to that of such proceeds;</p><p><em>(b) </em>Property, equipment or other instrumentalities used in or destined for</p><p>use in offences covered by this Convention.</p><p>2. States Parties shall adopt such measures as may be necessary to enable</p><p>the identification, tracing, freezing or seizure of any item referred to in paragraph</p><p>1 of this article for the purpose of eventual confiscation.</p><p>3. If proceeds of crime have been transformed or converted, in part or</p><p>in full, into other property, such property shall be liable to the measures referred</p><p>to in this article instead of the proceeds.</p><p>4. If proceeds of crime have been intermingled with property acquired</p><p>from legitimate sources, such property shall, without prejudice to any powers</p><p>relating to freezing or seizure, be liable to confiscation up to the assessed value</p><p>of the intermingled proceeds.</p><p>5. Income or other benefits derived from proceeds of crime, from</p><p>property into which proceeds of crime have been transformed or converted or</p><p>from property with which proceeds of crime have been intermingled shall also</p><p>13</p><p>be liable to the measures referred to in this article, in the same manner and to</p><p>the same extent as proceeds of crime.</p><p>6. For the purposes of this article and article 13 of this Convention, each</p><p>State Party shall empower its courts or other competent authorities to order that</p><p>bank, financial or commercial records be made available or be seized. States</p><p>Parties shall not decline to act under the provisions of this paragraph on the</p><p>ground of bank secrecy.</p><p>7. States Parties may consider the possibility of requiring that an offender</p><p>demonstrate the lawful origin of alleged proceeds of crime or other</p><p>property liable to confiscation, to the extent that such a requirement is consistent</p><p>with the principles of their domestic law and with the nature of the judicial</p><p>and other proceedings.</p><p>8. The provisions of this article shall not be construed to prejudice the</p><p>rights of bona fide third parties.</p><p>9. Nothing contained in this article shall affect the principle that the</p><p>measures to which it refers shall be defined and implemented in accordance</p><p>with and subject to the provisions of the domestic law of a State Party.</p><p><em>Article 13. International cooperation for purposes of confiscation</em></p><p>1.
