A State Party that has received a request from another State Party</p><p>having jurisdiction over an offence covered by this Convention for confiscation</p><p>of proceeds of crime, property, equipment or other instrumentalities referred to</p><p>in article 12, paragraph 1, of this Convention situated in its territory shall, to</p><p>the greatest extent possible within its domestic legal system:</p><p><em>(a) </em>Submit the request to its competent authorities for the purpose of</p><p>obtaining an order of confiscation and, if such an order is granted, give effect</p><p>to it; or</p><p><em>(b) </em>Submit to its competent authorities, with a view to giving effect to it</p><p>to the extent requested, an order of confiscation issued by a court in the territory</p><p>of the requesting State Party in accordance with article 12, paragraph 1, of</p><p>this Convention insofar as it relates to proceeds of crime, property, equipment</p><p>or other instrumentalities referred to in article 12, paragraph 1, situated in the</p><p>territory of the requested State Party.</p><p>2. Following a request made by another State Party having jurisdiction</p><p>over an offence covered by this Convention, the requested State Party shall take</p><p>measures to identify, trace and freeze or seize proceeds of crime, property,</p><p>14</p><p>equipment or other instrumentalities referred to in article 12, paragraph 1, of</p><p>this Convention for the purpose of eventual confiscation to be ordered either</p><p>by the requesting State Party or, pursuant to a request under paragraph 1 of this</p><p>article, by the requested State Party.</p><p>3. The provisions of article 18 of this Convention are applicable, mutatis</p><p>mutandis, to this article. In addition to the information specified in article 18,</p><p>paragraph 15, requests made pursuant to this article shall contain:</p><p><em>(a) </em>In the case of a request pertaining to paragraph 1 <em>(a) </em>of this article,</p><p>a description of the property to be confiscated and a statement of the facts relied</p><p>upon by the requesting State Party sufficient to enable the requested State Party</p><p>to seek the order under its domestic law;</p><p><em>(b) </em>In the case of a request pertaining to paragraph 1 <em>(b) </em>of this article,</p><p>a legally admissible copy of an order of confiscation upon which the request is</p><p>based issued by the requesting State Party, a statement of the facts and information</p><p>as to the extent to which execution of the order is requested;</p><p><em>(c) </em>In the case of a request pertaining to paragraph 2 of this article, a</p><p>statement of the facts relied upon by the requesting State Party and a description</p><p>of the actions requested.</p><p>4. The decisions or actions provided for in paragraphs 1 and 2 of this</p><p>article shall be taken by the requested State Party in accordance with and subject</p><p>to the provisions of its domestic law and its procedural rules or any bilateral or</p><p>multilateral treaty, agreement or arrangement to which it may be bound in</p><p>relation to the requesting State Party.</p><p>5. Each State Party shall furnish copies of its laws and regulations that</p><p>give effect to this article and of any subsequent changes to such laws and</p><p>regulations or a description thereof to the Secretary-General of the United</p><p>Nations.</p><p>6. If a State Party elects to make the taking of the measures referred to</p><p>in paragraphs 1 and 2 of this article conditional on the existence of a relevant</p><p>treaty, that State Party shall consider this Convention the necessary and</p><p>sufficient treaty basis.</p><p>7. Cooperation under this article may be refused by a State Party if</p><p>the offence to which the request relates is not an offence covered by this</p><p>Convention.</p><p>8. The provisions of this article shall not be construed to prejudice the</p><p>rights of bona fide third parties.</p><p>15</p><p>9. States Parties shall consider concluding bilateral or multilateral</p><p>treaties, agreements or arrangements to enhance the effectiveness of international</p><p>cooperation undertaken pursuant to this article.</p><p><em>Article 14. Disposal of confiscated proceeds of crime or property</em></p><p>1. Proceeds of crime or property confiscated by a State Party pursuant</p><p>to articles 12 or 13, paragraph 1, of this Convention shall be disposed of by that</p><p>State Party in accordance with its domestic law and administrative procedures.</p><p>2. When acting on the request made by another State Party in accordance</p><p>with article 13 of this Convention, States Parties shall, to the extent permitted</p><p>by domestic law and if so requested, give priority consideration to returning</p><p>the confiscated proceeds of crime or property to the requesting State</p><p>Party so that it can give compensation to the victims of the crime or return such</p><p>proceeds of crime or property to their legitimate owners.</p><p>3. When acting on the request made by another State Party in accordance</p><p>with articles 12 and 13 of this Convention, a State Party may give special</p><p>consideration to concluding agreements or arrangements on:</p><p><em>(a) </em>Contributing the value of such proceeds of crime or property or funds</p><p>derived from the sale of such proceeds of crime or property or a part thereof</p><p>to the account designated in accordance with article 30, paragraph 2 <em>(c), </em>of this</p><p>Convention and to intergovernmental bodies specializing in the fight against</p><p>organized crime;</p><p><em>(b) </em>Sharing with other States Parties, on a regular or case-by-case basis,</p><p>such proceeds of crime or property, or funds derived from the sale of such</p><p>proceeds of crime or property, in accordance with its domestic law or administrative</p><p>procedures.</p><p><em>Article 15. Jurisdiction</em></p><p>1. Each State Party shall adopt such measures as may be necessary to</p><p>establish its jurisdiction over the offences established in accordance with</p><p>articles 5, 6, 8 and 23 of this Convention when:</p><p><em>(a) </em>The offence is committed in the territory of that State Party; or</p><p><em>(b) </em>The offence is committed on board a vessel that is flying the flag of</p><p>that State Party or an aircraft that is registered under the laws of that State Party</p><p>at the time that the offence is committed.</p><p>16</p><p>2. Subject to article 4 of this Convention, a State Party may also establish</p><p>its jurisdiction over any such offence when:</p><p><em>(a) </em>The offence is committed against a national of that State Party;</p><p><em>(b) </em>The offence is committed by a national of that State Party or a stateless</p><p>person who has his or her habitual residence in its territory; or</p><p><em>(c) </em>The offence is:</p><p>(i) One of those established in accordance with article 5, paragraph</p><p>1, of this Convention and is committed outside its territory</p><p>with a view to the commission of a serious crime within its</p><p>territory;</p><p>(ii) One of those established in accordance with article 6, paragraph</p><p>1 <em>(b) </em>(ii), of this Convention and is committed outside its</p><p>territory with a view to the commission of an offence established</p><p>in accordance with article 6, paragraph 1 <em>(a) </em>(i) or (ii) or <em>(b) </em>(i),</p><p>of this Convention within its territory.</p><p>3. For the purposes of article 16, paragraph 10, of this Convention, each</p><p>State Party shall adopt such measures as may be necessary to establish its jurisdiction</p><p>over the offences covered by this Convention when the alleged offender</p><p>is present in its territory and it does not extradite such person solely on the</p><p>ground that he or she is one of its nationals.</p><p>4. Each State Party may also adopt such measures as may be necessary to</p><p>establish its jurisdiction over the offences covered by this Convention when the</p><p>alleged offender is present in its territory and it does not extradite him or her.</p><p>5. If a State Party exercising its jurisdiction under paragraph 1 or 2 of</p><p>this article has been notified, or has otherwise learned, that one or more other</p><p>States Parties are conducting an investigation, prosecution or judicial proceeding</p><p>in respect of the same conduct, the competent authorities of those States</p><p>Parties shall, as appropriate, consult one another with a view to coordinating</p><p>their actions.</p><p>6. Without prejudice to norms of general international law, this Convention</p><p>does not exclude the exercise of any criminal jurisdiction established by</p><p>a State Party in accordance with its domestic law.</p><p><em>Article 16. Extradition</em></p><p>1. This article shall apply to the offences covered by this Convention or</p><p>in cases where an offence referred to in article 3, paragraph 1 <em>(a) </em>or <em>(b), </em>involves</p><p>17</p><p>an organized criminal group and the person who is the subject of the request</p><p>for extradition is located in the territory of the requested State Party, provided</p><p>that the offence for which extradition is sought is punishable under the domestic</p><p>law of both the requesting State Party and the requested State Party.</p><p>2. If the request for extradition includes several separate serious crimes,</p><p>some of which are not covered by this article, the requested State Party may</p><p>apply this article also in respect of the latter offences.</p><p>3. Each of the offences to which this article applies shall be deemed to</p><p>be included as an extraditable offence in any extradition treaty existing between</p><p>States Parties. States Parties undertake to include such offences as extraditable</p><p>offences in every extradition treaty to be concluded between them.</p><p>4. If a State Party that makes extradition conditional on the existence of</p><p>a treaty receives a request for extradition from another State Party with which</p><p>it has no extradition treaty, it may consider this Convention the legal basis for</p><p>extradition in respect of any offence to which this article applies.</p><p>5. States Parties that make extradition conditional on the existence of a</p><p>treaty shall:</p><p><em>(a) </em>At the time of deposit of their instrument of ratification, acceptance,</p><p>approval of or accession to this Convention, inform the Secretary-General of the</p><p>United Nations whether they will take this Convention as the legal basis for</p><p>cooperation on extradition with other States Parties to this Convention; and</p><p><em>(b) </em>If they do not take this Convention as the legal basis for cooperation</p><p>on extradition, seek, where appropriate, to conclude treaties on extradition with</p><p>other States Parties to this Convention in order to implement this article.</p><p>6. States Parties that do not make extradition conditional on the existence</p><p>of a treaty shall recognize offences to which this article applies as extraditable</p><p>offences between themselves.</p><p>7. Extradition shall be subject to the conditions provided for by the</p><p>domestic law of the requested State Party or by applicable extradition treaties,</p><p>including, inter alia, conditions in relation to the minimum penalty requirement</p><p>for extradition and the grounds upon which the requested State Party may</p><p>refuse extradition.</p><p>8. States Parties shall, subject to their domestic law, endeavour to expedite</p><p>extradition procedures and to simplify evidentiary requirements relating</p><p>thereto in respect of any offence to which this article applies.</p><p>18</p><p>9. Subject to the provisions of its domestic law and its extradition</p><p>treaties, the requested State Party may, upon being satisfied that the circumstances</p><p>so warrant and are urgent and at the request of the requesting State</p><p>Party, take a person whose extradition is sought and who is present in its</p><p>territory into custody or take other appropriate measures to ensure his or her</p><p>presence at extradition proceedings.</p><p>10. A State Party in whose territory an alleged offender is found, if it does</p><p>not extradite such person in respect of an offence to which this article applies</p><p>solely on the ground that he or she is one of its nationals, shall, at the request</p><p>of the State Party seeking extradition, be obliged to submit the case without</p><p>undue delay to its competent authorities for the purpose of prosecution. Those</p><p>authorities shall take their decision and conduct their proceedings in the same</p><p>manner as in the case of any other offence of a grave nature under the domestic</p><p>law of that State Party. The States Parties concerned shall cooperate with each</p><p>other, in particular on procedural and evidentiary aspects, to ensure the</p><p>efficiency of such prosecution.</p><p>11. Whenever a State Party is permitted under its domestic law to extradite</p><p>or otherwise surrender one of its nationals only upon the condition that the</p><p>person will be returned to that State Party to serve the sentence imposed as a</p><p>result of the trial or proceedings for which the extradition or surrender of the</p><p>person was sought and that State Party and the State Party seeking the extradition</p><p>of the person agree with this option and other terms that they may deem</p><p>appropriate, such conditional extradition or surrender shall be sufficient to</p><p>discharge the obligation set forth in paragraph 10 of this article.</p><p>12. If extradition, sought for purposes of enforcing a sentence, is refused</p><p>because the person sought is a national of the requested State Party, the requested</p><p>Party shall, if its domestic law so permits and in conformity with the</p><p>requirements of such law, upon application of the requesting Party, consider the</p><p>enforcement of the sentence that has been imposed under the domestic law of</p><p>the requesting Party or the remainder thereof.</p><p>13. Any person regarding whom proceedings are being carried out in</p><p>connection with any of the offences to which this article applies shall be guaranteed</p><p>fair treatment at all stages of the proceedings, including enjoyment of all</p><p>the rights and guarantees provided by the domestic law of the State Party in the</p><p>territory of which that person is present.</p><p>14. Nothing in this Convention shall be interpreted as imposing an obligation</p><p>to extradite if the requested State Party has substantial grounds for</p><p>believing that the request has been made for the purpose of prosecuting or</p><p>19</p><p>punishing a person on account of that person’s sex, race, religion, nationality,</p><p>ethnic origin or political opinions or that compliance with the request would</p><p>cause prejudice to that person’s position for any one of these reasons.</p><p>15. States Parties may not refuse a request for extradition on the sole</p><p>ground that the offence is also considered to involve fiscal matters.</p><p>16. Before refusing extradition, the requested State Party shall, where</p><p>appropriate, consult with the requesting State Party to provide it with ample</p><p>opportunity to present its opinions and to provide information relevant to its</p><p>allegation.</p><p>17. States Parties shall seek to conclude bilateral and multilateral agreements</p><p>or arrangements to carry out or to enhance the effectiveness of extradition.</p><p><em>Article 17. Transfer of sentenced persons</em></p><p>States Parties may consider entering into bilateral or multilateral agreements</p><p>or arrangements on the transfer to their territory of persons sentenced to</p><p>imprisonment or other forms of deprivation of liberty for offences covered by</p><p>this Convention, in order that they may complete their sentences there.</p><p><em>Article 18. Mutual legal assistance</em></p><p>1. States Parties shall afford one another the widest measure of mutual</p><p>legal assistance in investigations, prosecutions and judicial proceedings in relation</p><p>to the offences covered by this Convention as provided for in article 3 and</p><p>shall reciprocally extend to one another similar assistance where the requesting</p><p>State Party has reasonable grounds to suspect that the offence referred to in</p><p>article 3, paragraph 1 <em>(a) </em>or <em>(b), </em>is transnational in nature, including that victims,</p><p>witnesses, proceeds, instrumentalities or evidence of such offences are</p><p>located in the requested State Party and that the offence involves an organized</p><p>criminal group.</p><p>2. Mutual legal assistance shall be afforded to the fullest extent possible</p><p>under relevant laws, treaties, agreements and arrangements of the requested</p><p>State Party with respect to investigations, prosecutions and judicial proceedings</p><p>in relation to the offences for which a legal person may be held liable in</p><p>accordance with article 10 of this Convention in the requesting State Party.</p><p>3. Mutual legal assistance to be afforded in accordance with this article</p><p>may be requested for any of the following purposes:</p><p>20</p><p><em>(a) </em>Taking evidence or statements from persons;</p><p><em>(b) </em>Effecting service of judicial documents;</p><p><em>(c) </em>Executing searches and seizures, and freezing;</p><p><em>(d) </em>Examining objects and sites;</p><p><em>(e) </em>Providing information, evidentiary items and expert evaluations;</p><p><em>(f) </em>Providing originals or certified copies of relevant documents and</p><p>records, including government, bank, financial, corporate or business records;</p><p><em>(g) </em>Identifying or tracing proceeds of crime, property, instrumentalities or</p><p>other things for evidentiary purposes;</p><p><em>(h) </em>Facilitating the voluntary appearance of persons in the requesting</p><p>State Party;</p><p><em>(i) </em>Any other type of assistance that is not contrary to the domestic law</p><p>of the requested State Party.</p><p>4. Without prejudice to domestic law, the competent authorities of a</p><p>State Party may, without prior request, transmit information relating to criminal</p><p>matters to a competent authority in another State Party where they believe</p><p>that such information could assist the authority in undertaking or successfully</p><p>concluding inquiries and criminal proceedings or could result in a request</p><p>formulated by the latter State Party pursuant to this Convention.</p><p>5. The transmission of information pursuant to paragraph 4 of this</p><p>article shall be without prejudice to inquiries and criminal proceedings in the</p><p>State of the competent authorities providing the information. The competent</p><p>authorities receiving the information shall comply with a request that said information</p><p>remain confidential, even temporarily, or with restrictions on its use.</p><p>However, this shall not prevent the receiving State Party from disclosing in its</p><p>proceedings information that is exculpatory to an accused person. In such a</p><p>case, the receiving State Party shall notify the transmitting State Party prior to</p><p>the disclosure and, if so requested, consult with the transmitting State Party. If,</p><p>in an exceptional case, advance notice is not possible, the receiving State Party</p><p>shall inform the transmitting State Party of the disclosure without delay.</p><p>6. The provisions of this article shall not affect the obligations under any</p><p>other treaty, bilateral or multilateral, that governs or will govern, in whole or</p><p>in part, mutual legal assistance.</p><p>7. Paragraphs 9 to 29 of this article shall apply to requests made pursuant</p><p>to this article if the States Parties in question are not bound by a treaty of</p><p>mutual legal assistance. If those States Parties are bound by such a treaty, the</p><p>21</p><p>corresponding provisions of that treaty shall apply unless the States Parties agree</p><p>to apply paragraphs 9 to 29 of this article in lieu thereof. States Parties are</p><p>strongly encouraged to apply these paragraphs if they facilitate cooperation.</p><p>8. States Parties shall not decline to render mutual legal assistance pursuant</p><p>to this article on the ground of bank secrecy.</p><p>9. States Parties may decline to render mutual legal assistance pursuant</p><p>to this article on the ground of absence of dual criminality. However, the</p><p>requested State Party may, when it deems appropriate, provide assistance, to the</p><p>extent it decides at its discretion, irrespective of whether the conduct would</p><p>constitute an offence under the domestic law of the requested State Party.</p><p>10. A person who is being detained or is serving a sentence in the territory</p><p>of one State Party whose presence in another State Party is requested for</p><p>purposes of identification, testimony or otherwise providing assistance in obtaining</p><p>evidence for investigations, prosecutions or judicial proceedings in relation</p><p>to offences covered by this Convention may be transferred if the following</p><p>conditions are met:</p><p><em>(a) </em>The person freely gives his or her informed consent;</p><p><em>(b) </em>The competent authorities of both States Parties agree, subject to such</p><p>conditions as those States Parties may deem appropriate.</p><p>11. For the purposes of paragraph 10 of this article:</p><p><em>(a) </em>The State Party to which the person is transferred shall have the</p><p>authority and obligation to keep the person transferred in custody, unless otherwise</p><p>requested or authorized by the State Party from which the person was</p><p>transferred;</p><p><em>(b) </em>The State Party to which the person is transferred shall without delay</p><p>implement its obligation to return the person to the custody of the State Party</p><p>from which the person was transferred as agreed beforehand, or as otherwise</p><p>agreed, by the competent authorities of both States Parties;</p><p><em>(c) </em>The State Party to which the person is transferred shall not require the</p><p>State Party from which the person was transferred to initiate extradition proceedings</p><p>for the return of the person;</p><p><em>(d) </em>The person transferred shall receive credit for service of the sentence</p><p>being served in the State from which he or she was transferred for time spent</p><p>in the custody of the State Party to which he or she was transferred.</p><p>12. Unless the State Party from which a person is to be transferred in</p><p>accordance with paragraphs 10 and 11 of this article so agrees, that person,</p><p>22</p><p>whatever his or her nationality, shall not be prosecuted, detained, punished or</p><p>subjected to any other restriction of his or her personal liberty in the territory</p><p>of the State to which that person is transferred in respect of acts, omissions or</p><p>convictions prior to his or her departure from the territory of the State from</p><p>which he or she was transferred.</p><p>13. Each State Party shall designate a central authority that shall have the</p><p>responsibility and power to receive requests for mutual legal assistance and</p><p>either to execute them or to transmit them to the competent authorities for</p><p>execution. Where a State Party has a special region or territory with a separate</p><p>system of mutual legal assistance, it may designate a distinct central authority</p><p>that shall have the same function for that region or territory. Central authorities</p><p>shall ensure the speedy and proper execution or transmission of the requests</p><p>received. Where the central authority transmits the request to a competent</p><p>authority for execution, it shall encourage the speedy and proper execution of</p><p>the request by the competent authority. The Secretary-General of the United</p><p>Nations shall be notified of the central authority designated for this purpose at</p><p>the time each State Party deposits its instrument of ratification, acceptance or</p><p>approval of or accession to this Convention. Requests for mutual legal assistance</p><p>and any communication related thereto shall be transmitted to the central</p><p>authorities designated by the States Parties. This requirement shall be without</p><p>prejudice to the right of a State Party to require that such requests and communications</p><p>be addressed to it through diplomatic channels and, in urgent</p><p>circumstances, where the States Parties agree, through the International</p><p>Criminal Police Organization, if possible.</p><p>14. Requests shall be made in writing or, where possible, by any means</p><p>capable of producing a written record, in a language acceptable to the requested</p><p>State Party, under conditions allowing that State Party to establish authenticity.</p><p>The Secretary-General of the United Nations shall be notified of the language</p><p>or languages acceptable to each State Party at the time it deposits its instrument</p><p>of ratification, acceptance or approval of or accession to this Convention. In</p><p>urgent circumstances and where agreed by the States Parties, requests may be</p><p>made orally, but shall be confirmed in writing forthwith.</p><p>15. A request for mutual legal assistance shall contain:</p><p><em>(a) </em>The identity of the authority making the request;</p><p><em>(b) </em>The subject matter and nature of the investigation, prosecution or</p><p>judicial proceeding to which the request relates and the name and functions of</p><p>the authority conducting the investigation, prosecution or judicial proceeding;</p><p><em>(c) </em>A summary of the relevant facts, except in relation to requests for the</p><p>purpose of service of judicial documents;</p><p>23</p><p><em>(d) </em>A description of the assistance sought and details of any particular</p><p>procedure that the requesting State Party wishes to be followed;</p><p><em>(e) </em>Where possible, the identity, location and nationality of any person</p><p>concerned; and</p><p><em>(f) </em>The purpose for which the evidence, information or action is sought.</p><p>16. The requested State Party may request additional information when</p><p>it appears necessary for the execution of the request in accordance with its</p><p>domestic law or when it can facilitate such execution.</p><p>17. A request shall be executed in accordance with the domestic law of</p><p>the requested State Party and, to the extent not contrary to the domestic law</p><p>of the requested State Party and where possible, in accordance with the procedures</p><p>specified in the request.</p><p>18. Wherever possible and consistent with fundamental principles of</p><p>domestic law, when an individual is in the territory of a State Party and has to</p><p>be heard as a witness or expert by the judicial authorities of another State Party,</p><p>the first State Party may, at the request of the other, permit the hearing to take</p><p>place by video conference if it is not possible or desirable for the individual in</p><p>question to appear in person in the territory of the requesting State Party. States</p><p>Parties may agree that the hearing shall be conducted by a judicial authority of</p><p>the requesting State Party and attended by a judicial authority of the requested</p><p>State Party.</p><p>19. The requesting State Party shall not transmit or use information or</p><p>evidence furnished by the requested State Party for investigations, prosecutions</p><p>or judicial proceedings other than those stated in the request without the prior</p><p>consent of the requested State Party. Nothing in this paragraph shall prevent the</p><p>requesting State Party from disclosing in its proceedings information or evidence</p><p>that is exculpatory to an accused person. In the latter case, the requesting</p><p>State Party shall notify the requested State Party prior to the disclosure and, if</p><p>so requested, consult with the requested State Party. If, in an exceptional case,</p><p>advance notice is not possible, the requesting State Party shall inform the</p><p>requested State Party of the disclosure without delay.</p><p>20. The requesting State Party may require that the requested State Party</p><p>keep confidential the fact and substance of the request, except to the extent</p><p>necessary to execute the request. If the requested State Party cannot comply with</p><p>the requirement of confidentiality, it shall promptly inform the requesting State</p><p>Party.</p><p>21. Mutual legal assistance may be refused:</p><p>24</p><p><em>(a) </em>If the request is not made in conformity with the provisions of this</p><p>article;</p><p><em>(b) </em>If the requested State Party considers that execution of the request is</p><p>likely to prejudice its sovereignty, security, <em>ordre public </em>or other essential</p><p>interests;</p><p><em>(c) </em>If the authorities of the requested State Party would be prohibited by</p><p>its domestic law from carrying out the action requested with regard to any</p><p>similar offence, had it been subject to investigation, prosecution or judicial</p><p>proceedings under their own jurisdiction;</p><p><em>(d) </em>If it would be contrary to the legal system of the requested State Party</p><p>relating to mutual legal assistance for the request to be granted.</p><p>22. States Parties may not refuse a request for mutual legal assistance on</p><p>the sole ground that the offence is also considered to involve fiscal matters.</p><p>23. Reasons shall be given for any refusal of mutual legal assistance.</p><p>24. The requested State Party shall execute the request for mutual legal</p><p>assistance as soon as possible and shall take as full account as possible of any</p><p>deadlines suggested by the requesting State Party and for which reasons are</p><p>given, preferably in the request. The requested State Party shall respond to</p><p>reasonable requests by the requesting State Party on progress of its handling of</p><p>the request. The requesting State Party shall promptly inform the requested</p><p>State Party when the assistance sought is no longer required.</p><p>25. Mutual legal assistance may be postponed by the requested State</p><p>Party on the ground that it interferes with an ongoing investigation, prosecu</p></div></div>
54	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Vienna Convention on Consular Relations 1963</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p>Done at Vienna on 24 April 1963. Entered into force on 19 March 1967. United Nations, <em>Treaty Series</em>, vo1. 596, p. 261 Copyright © United Nations 2005 2 Vienna Convention on Consular Relations Done at Vienna on 24 April 1963 <em>The States Parties to the present Convention</em>, <em>Recalling </em>that consular relations have been established between peoples since ancient times, <em>Having in mind </em>the Purposes and Principles of the Charter of the United Nations concerning the sovereign equality of States, the maintenance of international peace and security, and the promotion of friendly relations among nations, <em>Considering </em>that the United Nations Conference on Diplomatic Intercourse and Immunities adopted the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations which was opened for signature on 18 April 1961, <em>Believing </em>that an international convention on consular relations, privileges and immunities would also contribute to the development of friendly relations among nations, irrespective of their differing constitutional and social systems, <em>Realizing </em>that the purpose of such privileges and immunities is not to benefit individuals but to ensure the efficient performance of functions by consular posts on behalf of their respective States, <em>Affirming </em>that the rules of customary international law continue to govern matters not expressly regulated by the provisions of the present Convention, <em>Have agreed </em>as follows: <em>Article 1</em> <em>Definitions</em> 1.For the purposes of the present Convention, the following expressions shall have the meanings hereunder assigned to them: (<em>a</em>) “consular post” means any consulate-general, consulate, vice-consulate or consular agency; (<em>b</em>) “consular district” means the area assigned to a consular post for the exercise of consular functions; (<em>c</em>) “head of consular post” means the person charged with the duty of acting in that capacity; (<em>d</em>) “consular officer” means any person, including the head of a consular post, entrusted in that capacity with the exercise of consular functions; (<em>e</em>) “consular employee” means any person employed in the administrative or technical service of a consular post; 3 (<em>f</em>) “member of the service staff” means any person employed in the domestic service of a consular post; (<em>g</em>) “members of the consular post” means consular officers, consular employees and members of the service staff; (<em>h</em>) “members of the consular staff” means consular officers, other than the head of a consular post, consular employees and members of the service staff; (<em>i</em>) “member of the private staff” means a person who is employed exclusively in the private service of a member of the consular post; (<em>j</em>) “consular premises” means the buildings or parts of buildings and the land ancillary thereto, irrespective of ownership, used exclusively for the purposes of the consular post; (<em>k</em>) “consular archives” includes all the papers, documents, correspondence, books, films, tapes and registers of the consular post, together with the ciphers and codes, the card-indexes and any article of furniture intended for their protection or safe keeping. 2.Consular officers are of two categories, namely career consular officers and honorary consular officers. The provisions of Chapter II of the present Convention apply to consular posts headed by career consular officers, the provisions of Chapter III govern consular posts headed by honorary consular officers. 3.The particular status of members of the consular posts who are nationals or permanent residents of the receiving State is governed by article 71 of the present Convention. CHAPTER I. CONSULAR RELATIONS IN GENERAL SECTION I. ESTABLISHMENT AND CONDUCT OF CONSULAR RELATIONS <em>Article 2</em> <em>Establishment of consular relations</em> 1.The establishment of consular relations between States takes place by mutual consent. 2. The consent given to the establishment of diplomatic relations between two States implies, unless otherwise stated, consent to the establishment of consular relations. 3.The severance of diplomatic relations shall not ipso facto involve the severance of consular relations. 4 <em>Article 3</em> <em>Exercise of consular functions</em> Consular functions are exercised by consular posts. They are also exercised by diplomatic missions in accordance with the provisions of the present Convention. <em>Article 4</em> <em>Establishment of a consular post</em> 1.A consular post may be established in the territory of the receiving State only with that State’s consent. 2.The seat of the consular post, its classification and the consular district shall be established by the sending State and shall be subject to the approval of the receiving State. 3.Subsequent changes in the seat of the consular post, its classification or the consular district may be made by the sending State only with the consent of the receiving State. 4.The consent of the receiving State shall also be required if a consulate-general or a consulate desires to open a vice-consulate or a consular agency in a locality other than that in which it is itself established. 5.The prior express consent of the receiving State shall also be required for the opening of an office forming part of an existing consular post elsewhere than at the seat thereof. <em>Article 5</em> <em>Consular functions</em> Consular functions consist in: (<em>a</em>) protecting in the receiving State the interests of the sending State and of its nationals, both individuals and bodies corporate, within the limits permitted by international law; (<em>b</em>) furthering the development of commercial, economic, cultural and scientific relations between the sending State and the receiving State and otherwise promoting friendly relations between them in accordance with the provisions of the present Convention; (<em>c</em>) ascertaining by all lawful means conditions and developments in the commercial, economic, cultural and scientific life of the receiving State, reporting thereon to the Government of the sending State and giving information to persons interested; (<em>d</em>) issuing passports and travel documents to nationals of the sending State, and visas or appropriate documents to persons wishing to travel to the sending State; (<em>e</em>) helping and assisting nationals, both individuals and bodies corporate, of the sending State; 5 (<em>f</em>) acting as notary and civil registrar and in capacities of a similar kind, and performing certain functions of an administrative nature, provided that there is nothing contrary thereto in the laws and regulations of the receiving State; (<em>g</em>) safeguarding the interests of nationals, both individuals and bodies corporate, of the sending States in cases of succession <em>mortis causa </em>in the territory of the receiving State, in accordance with the laws and regulations of the receiving State; (<em>h</em>) safeguarding, within the limits imposed by the laws and regulations of the receiving State, the interests of minors and other persons lacking full capacity who are nationals of the sending State, particularly where any guardianship or trusteeship is required with respect to such persons; (<em>i</em>) subject to the practices and procedures obtaining in the receiving State, representing or arranging appropriate representation for nationals of the sending State before the tribunals and other authorities of the receiving State, for the purpose of obtaining, in accordance with the laws and regulations of the receiving State, provisional measures for the preservation of the rights and interests of these nationals, where, because of absence or any other reason, such nationals are unable at the proper time to assume the defence of their rights and interests; (<em>j</em>) transmitting judicial and extrajudicial documents or executing letters rogatory or commissions to take evidence for the courts of the sending State in accordance with international agreements in force or, in the absence of such international agreements, in any other manner compatible with the laws and regulations of the receiving State; (<em>k</em>) exercising rights of supervision and inspection provided for in the laws and regulations of the sending State in respect of vessels having the nationality of the sending State, and of aircraft registered in that State, and in respect of their crews; (<em>l</em>) extending assistance to vessels and aircraft mentioned in subparagraph (<em>k</em>) of this article, and to their crews, taking statements regarding the voyage of a vessel, examining and stamping the ship’s papers, and, without prejudice to the powers of the authorities of the receiving State, conducting investigations into any incidents which occurred during the voyage, and settling disputes of any kind between the master, the officers and the seamen insofar as this may be authorized by the laws and regulations of the sending State; (<em>m</em>) performing any other functions entrusted to a consular post by the sending State which are not prohibited by the laws and regulations of the receiving State or to which no objection is taken by the receiving State or which are referred to in the international agreements in force between the sending State and the receiving State. <em>Article 6</em> <em>Exercise of consular functions outside the consular district</em> A consular officer may, in special circumstances, with the consent of the receiving State, exercise his functions outside his consular district. 6 <em>Article 7</em> <em>Exercise of consular functions in a third State</em> The sending State may, after notifying the States concerned, entrust a consular post established in a particular State with the exercise of consular functions in another State, unless there is express objection by one of the States concerned. <em>Article 8</em> <em>Exercise of consular functions on behalf of a third State</em> Upon appropriate notification to the receiving State, a consular post of the sending State may, unless the receiving State objects, exercise consular functions in the receiving State on behalf of a third State. <em>Article 9</em> <em>Classes of heads of consular posts</em> 1.Heads of consular posts are divided into four classes, namely (<em>a</em>) consuls-general; (<em>b</em>) consuls; (<em>c</em>) vice-consuls; (<em>d</em>) consular agents. 2.Paragraph 1 of this article in no way restricts the right of any of the Contracting Parties to fix the designation of consular officers other than the heads of consular posts. <em>Article 10</em> <em>Appointment and admission of heads of consular posts</em> 1.Heads of consular posts are appointed by the sending State and are admitted to the exercise of their functions by the receiving State. 2.Subject to the provisions of the present Convention, the formalities for the appointment and for the admission of the head of a consular post are determined by the laws, regulations and usages of the sending State and of the receiving State respectively. <em>Article 11</em> <em>The consular commission or notification of appointment</em> 1.The head of a consular post shall be provided by the sending State with a document, in the form of a commission or similar instrument, made out for each appointment, certifying his capacity and 7 showing, as a general rule, his full name, his category and class, the consular district and the seat of the consular post. 2.The sending State shall transmit the commission or similar instrument through the diplomatic or other appropriate channel to the Government of the State in whose territory the head of a consular post is to exercise his functions. 3. If the receiving State agrees, the sending State may, instead of a commission or similar instrument, send to the receiving State a notification containing the particulars required by paragraph 1 of this article. <em>Article 12</em> <em>The exequatur</em> 1.The head of a consular post is admitted to the exercise of his functions by an authorization from the receiving State termed an <em>exequatur</em>, whatever the form of this authorization. 2.A State which refused to grant an <em>exequatur </em>is not obliged to give to the sending State reasons for such refusal. 3.Subject to the provisions of articles 13 and 15, the head of a consular post shall not enter upon his duties until he has received an <em>exequatur</em>. <em>Article 13</em> <em>Provisional admission of heads of consular posts</em> Pending delivery of the <em>exequatur</em>, the head of a consular post may be admitted on a provisional basis to the exercise of his functions. In that case, the provisions of the present Convention shall apply. <em>Article 14</em> <em>Notification to the authorities of the consular district</em> As soon as the head of a consular post is admitted even provisionally to the exercise of his functions, the receiving State shall immediately notify the competent authorities of the consular district. It shall also ensure that the necessary measures are taken to enable the head of a consular post to carry out the duties of his office and to have the benefit of the provisions of the present Convention. <em>Article 15</em> <em>Temporary exercise of the functions of the</em> <em>head of a consular post</em> 1. If the head of a consular post is unable to carry out his functions or the position of head of consular post is vacant, an acting head of post may act provisionally as head of the consular post. 2.The full name of the acting head of post shall be notified either by the diplomatic mission of the sending State or, if that State has no such mission in the receiving State, by the head of the consular 8 post, or, if he is unable to do so, by any competent authority of the sending State, to the Ministry for Foreign Affairs of the receiving State or to the authority designated by that Ministry. As a general rule, this notification shall be given in advance. The receiving State may make the admission as acting head of post of a person who is neither a diplomatic agent nor a consular officer of the sending State in the receiving State conditional on its consent. 3.The competent authorities of the receiving State shall afford assistance and protection to the acting head of post. While he is in charge of the post, the provisions of the present Convention shall apply to him on the same basis as to the head of the consular post concerned. The receiving State shall not, however, be obliged to grant to an acting head of post any facility, privilege or immunity which the head of the consular post enjoys only subject to conditions not fulfilled by the acting head of post. 4.When, in the circumstances referred to in paragraph 1 of this article, a member of the diplomatic staff of the diplomatic mission of the sending State in the receiving State is designated by the sending State as an acting head of post, he shall, if the receiving State does not object thereto, continue to enjoy diplomatic privileges and immunities. <em>Article 16</em> <em>Precedence as between heads of consular posts</em> 1.Heads of consular posts shall rank in each class according to the date of the grant of the <em>exequatur</em>. 2. If, however, the head of a consular post before obtaining the <em>exequatur </em>is admitted to the exercise of his functions provisionally, his precedence shall be determined according to the date of the provisional admission; this precedence shall be maintained after the granting of the <em>exequatur</em>. 3.The order of precedence as between two or more heads of consular posts who obtained the <em>exequatur </em>or provisional admission on the same date shall be determined according to the dates on which their commissions or similar instruments or the notifications referred to in paragraph 3 of article 11 were presented to the receiving State. 4.Acting heads of posts shall rank after all heads of consular posts and, as between themselves, they shall rank according to the dates on which they assumed their functions as acting heads of posts as indicated in the notifications given under paragraph 2 of article 15. 5.Honorary consular officers who are heads of consular posts shall rank in each class after career heads of consular posts, in the order and according to the rules laid down in the foregoing paragraphs. 6.Heads of consular posts shall have precedence over consular officers not having that status. <em>Article 17</em> <em>Performance of diplomatic acts by consular officers</em> 1. In a State where the sending State has no diplomatic mission and is not represented by a diplomatic mission of a third State, a consular officer may, with the consent of the receiving State, and 9 without affecting his consular status, be authorized to perform diplomatic acts. The performance of such acts by a consular officer shall not confer upon him any right to claim diplomatic privileges and immunities. 2.A consular officer may, after notification addressed to the receiving State, act as representative of the sending State to any intergovernmental organization. When so acting, he shall be entitled to enjoy any privileges and immunities accorded to such a representative by customary international law or by international agreements; however, in respect of the performance by him of any consular function, he shall not be entitled to any greater immunity from jurisdiction than that to which a consular officer is entitled under the present Convention. <em>Article 18</em> <em>Appointment of the same person by two or more States</em> <em>as a consular officer</em> Two or more States may, with the consent of the receiving State, appoint the same person as a consular officer in that State. <em>Article 19</em> <em>Appointment of members of consular staff</em> 1.Subject to the provisions of articles 20, 22 and 23, the sending State may freely appoint the members of the consular staff. 2.The full name, category and class of all consular officers, other than the head of a consular post, shall be notified by the sending State to the receiving State in sufficient time for the receiving State, if it so wishes, to exercise its rights under paragraph 3 of article 23. 3.The sending State may, if required by its laws and regulations, request the receiving State to grant an <em>exequatur </em>to a consular officer other than the head of a consular post. 4.The receiving State may, if required by its laws and regulations, grant an <em>exequatur </em>to a consular officer other than the head of a consular post. <em>Article 20</em> <em>Size of the consular staff</em> In the absence of an express agreement as to the size of the consular staff, the receiving State may require that the size of the staff be kept within limits considered by it to be reasonable and normal, having regard to circumstances and conditions in the consular district and to the needs of the particular consular post. 10 <em>Article 21</em> <em>Precedence as between consular officers of a consular post</em> The order of precedence as between the consular officers of a consular post and any change thereof shall be notified by the diplomatic mission of the sending State or, if that State has no such mission in the receiving State, by the head of the consular post, to the Ministry for Foreign Affairs of the receiving State or to the authority designated by that Ministry. <em>Article 22</em> <em>Nationality of consular officers</em> 1.Consular officers should, in principle, have the nationality of the sending State. 2.Consular officers may not be appointed from among persons having the nationality of the receiving State except with the express consent of that State which may be withdrawn at any time. 3.The receiving State may reserve the same right with regard to nationals of a third State who are not also nationals of the sending State. <em>Article 23</em> <em>Persons declared “</em>non grata<em>”</em> 1.The receiving State may at any time notify the sending State that a consular officer is persona non grata or that any other member of the consular staff is not acceptable. In that event, the sending State shall, as the case may be, either recall the person concerned or terminate his functions with the consular post. 2. If the sending State refuses or fails within a reasonable time to carry out its obligations under paragraph 1 of this article, the receiving State may, as the case may be, either withdraw the <em>exequatur</em> from the person concerned or cease to consider him as a member of the consular staff. 3.A person appointed as a member of a consular post may be declared unacceptable before arriving in the territory of the receiving State or, if already in the receiving State, before entering on his duties with the consular post. In any such case, the sending State shall withdraw his appointment. 4. In the cases mentioned in paragraphs 1 and 3 of this article, the receiving State is not obliged to give to the sending State reasons for its decision. <em>Article 24</em> <em>Notification to the receiving State of appointments,</em> <em>arrivals and departures</em> 1.The Ministry for Foreign Affairs of the receiving State or the authority designated by that Ministry shall be notified of: 11 (<em>a</em>) the appointment of members of a consular post, their arrival after appointment to the consular post, their final departure or the termination of their functions and any other changes affecting their status that may occur in the course of their service with the consular post; (<em>b</em>) the arrival and final departure of a person belonging to the family of a member of a consular post forming part of his household and, where appropriate, the fact that a person becomes or ceases to be such a member of the family; (<em>c</em>) the arrival and final departure of members of the private staff and, where appropriate, the termination of their service as such; (<em>d</em>) the engagement and discharge of persons resident in the receiving State as members of a consular post or as members of the private staff entitled to privileges and immunities. 2.When possible, prior notification of arrival and final departure shall also be given. SECTION II. END OF CONSULAR FUNCTIONS <em>Article 25</em> <em>Termination of the functions of a member of a consular post</em> The functions of a member of a consular post shall come to an end, inter alia: (<em>a</em>) on notification by the sending State to the receiving State that his functions have come to an end; (<em>b</em>) on withdrawal of the <em>exequatur</em>; (<em>c</em>) on notification by the receiving State to the sending State that the receiving State has ceased to consider him as a member of the consular staff. <em>Article 26</em> <em>Departure from the territory of the receiving State</em> The receiving State shall, even in case of armed conflict, grant to members of the consular post and members of the private staff, other than nationals of the receiving State, and to members of their families forming part of their households irrespective of nationality, the necessary time and facilities to enable them to prepare their departure and to leave at the earliest possible moment after the termination of the functions of the members concerned. In particular, it shall, in case of need, place at their disposal the necessary means of transport for themselves and their property other than property acquired in the receiving State the export of which is prohibited at the time of departure. 12 <em>Article 27</em> <em>Protection of consular premises and archives and of the</em> <em>interests of the sending State in exceptional circumstances</em> 1. In the event of the severance of consular relations between two States: (<em>a</em>) the receiving State shall, even in case of armed conflict, respect and protect the consular premises, together with the property of the consular post and the consular archives; (<em>b</em>) the sending State may entrust the custody of the consular premises, together with the property contained therein and the consular archives, to a third State acceptable to the receiving State; (<em>c</em>) the sending State may entrust the protection of its interests and those of its nationals to a third State acceptable to the receiving State. 2. In the event of the temporary or permanent closure of a consular post, the provisions of subparagraph (<em>a</em>) of paragraph 1 of this article shall apply. In addition, (<em>a</em>) if the sending State, although not represented in the receiving State by a diplomatic mission, has another consular post in the territory of that State, that consular post may be entrusted with the custody of the premises of the consular post which has been closed, together with the property contained therein and the consular archives, and, with the consent of the receiving State, with the exercise of consular functions in the district of that consular post; or (<em>b</em>) if the sending State has no diplomatic mission and no other consular post in the receiving State, the provisions of subparagraphs (<em>b</em>) and (<em>c</em>) of paragraph 1 of this article shall apply. CHAPTER II. FACILITIES, PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES RELATING TO CONSULAR POSTS, CAREER CONSULAR OFFICERS AND OTHER MEMBERS OF A CONSULAR POST SECTION I. FACILITIES, PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES RELATING TO A CONSULAR POST <em>Article 28</em> <em>Facilities for the work of the consular post</em> The receiving State shall accord full facilities for the performance of the functions of the consular post. <em>Article 29</em> <em>Use of national flag and coat-of-arms</em> 1.The sending State shall have the right to the use of its national flag and coat-of-arms in the receiving State in accordance with the provisions of this article. 13 2.The national flag of the sending State may be flown and its coat-of-arms displayed on the building occupied by the consular post and at the entrance door thereof, on the residence of the head of the consular post and on his means of transport when used on official business. 3. In the exercise of the right accorded by this article regard shall be had to the laws, regulations and usages of the receiving State. <em>Article 30</em> <em>Accommodation</em> 1.The receiving State shall either facilitate the acquisition on its territory, in accordance with its laws and regulations, by the sending State of premises necessary for its consular post or assist the latter in obtaining accommodation in some other way. 2. It shall also, where necessary, assist the consular post in obtaining suitable accommodation for its members. <em>Article 31</em> <em>Inviolability of the consular premises</em> 1.Consular premises shall be inviolable to the extent provided in this article. 2.The authorities of the receiving State shall not enter that part of the consular premises which is used exclusively for the purpose of the work of the consular post except with the consent of the head of the consular post or of his designee or of the head of the diplomatic mission of the sending State. The consent of the head of the consular post may, however, be assumed in case of fire or other disaster requiring prompt protective action. 3.Subject to the provisions of paragraph 2 of this article, the receiving State is under a special duty to take all appropriate steps to protect the consular premises against any intrusion or damage and to prevent any disturbance of the peace of the consular post or impairment of its dignity. 4.The consular premises, their furnishings, the property of the consular post and its means of transport shall be immune from any form of requisition for purposes of national defence or public utility. If expropriation is necessary for such purposes, all possible steps shall be taken to avoid impeding the performance of consular functions, and prompt, adequate and effective compensation shall be paid to the sending State. <em>Article 32</em> <em>Exemption from taxation of consular premises</em> 1.Consular premises and the residence of the career head of consular post of which the sending State or any person acting on its behalf is the owner or lessee shall be exempt from all national, regional or municipal dues and taxes whatsoever, other than such as represent payment for specific services rendered. 14 2.The exemption from taxation referred to paragraph 1 of this article shall not apply to such dues and taxes if, under the law of the receiving State, they are payable by the person who contracted with the sending State or with the person acting on its behalf. <em>Article 33</em> <em>Inviolability of the consular archives and documents</em> The consular archives and documents shall be inviolable at all times and wherever they may be. <em>Articl</em>e <em>34</em> <em>Freedom of movement</em> Subject to its laws and regulations concerning zones entry into which is prohibited or regulated for reasons of national security, the receiving State shall ensure freedom of movement and travel in its territory to all members of the consular post. <em>Article 35</em> <em>Freedom of communication</em> 1.The receiving State shall permit and protect freedom of communication on the part of the consular post for all official purposes. In communicating with the Government, the diplomatic missions and other consular posts, wherever situated, of the sending State, the consular post may employ all appropriate means, including diplomatic or consular couriers, diplomatic or consular bags and messages in code or cipher. However, the consular post may install and use a wireless transmitter only with the consent of the receiving State. 2.The official correspondence of the consular post shall be inviolable. Official correspondence means all correspondence relating to the consular post and its functions. 3.The consular bag shall be neither opened nor detained. Nevertheless, if the competent authorities of the receiving State have serious reason to believe that the bag contains something other than the correspondence, documents or articles referred to in paragraph 4 of this article, they may request that the bag be opened in their presence by an authorized representative of the sending State. If this request is refused by the authorities of the sending State, the bag shall be returned to its place of origin. 4.The packages constituting the consular bag shall bear visible external marks of their character and may contain only official correspondence and documents or articles intended exclusively for official use. 5.The consular courier shall be provided with an official document indicating his status and the number of packages constituting the consular bag. Except with the consent of the receiving State he shall be neither a national of the receiving State, nor, unless he is a national of the sending State, a permanent resident of the receiving State. In the performance of his functions he shall be protected by the receiving State. He shall enjoy personal inviolability and shall not be liable to any form of arrest or detention. 15 6.The sending State, its diplomatic missions and its consular posts may designate consular couriers ad hoc. In such cases the provisions of paragraph 5 of this article shall also apply except that the immunities therein mentioned shall cease to apply when such a courier has delivered to the consignee the consular bag in his charge. 7.A consular bag may be entrusted to the captain of a ship or of a commercial aircraft scheduled to land at an authorized port of entry. He shall be provided with an official document indicating the number of packages constituting the bag, but he shall not be considered to be a consular courier. By arrangement with the appropriate local authorities, the consular post may send one of its members to take possession of the bag directly and freely from the captain of the ship or of the aircraft. <em>Article 36</em> <em>Communication and contact with nationals</em> <em>of the sending State</em> 1.With a view to facilitating the exercise of consular functions relating to nationals of the sending State: <em>(a) </em>consular officers shall be free to communicate with nationals of the sending State and to have access to them. Nationals of the sending State shall have the same freedom with respect to communication with and access to consular officers of the sending State; (<em>b</em>) if he so requests, the competent authorities of the receiving State shall, without delay, inform the consular post of the sending State if, within its consular district, a national of that State is arrested or committed to prison or to custody pending trial or is detained in any other manner. Any communication addressed to the consular post by the person arrested, in prison, custody or detention shall be forwarded by the said authorities without delay. The said authorities shall inform the person concerned without delay of his rights under this subparagraph; (<em>c</em>) consular officers shall have the right to visit a national of the sending State who is in prison, custody or detention, to converse and correspond with him and to arrange for his legal representation. They shall also have the right to visit any national of the sending State who is in prison, custody or detention in their district in pursuance of a judgement. Nevertheless, consular officers shall refrain from taking action on behalf of a national who is in prison, custody or detention if he expressly opposes such action. 2.The rights referred to in paragraph 1 of this article shall be exercised in conformity with the laws and regulations of the receiving State, subject to the proviso, however, that the said laws and regulations must enable full effect to be given to the purposes for which the rights accorded under this article are intended. 16 <em>Article 37</em> <em>Information in cases of deaths, guardianship or trusteeship,</em> <em>wrecks and air accidents</em> If the relevant information is available to the competent authorities of the receiving State, such authorities shall have the duty: (<em>a</em>) in the case of the death of a national of the sending State, to inform without delay the consular post in whose district the death occurred; (<em>b</em>) to inform the competent consular post without delay of any case where the appointment of a guardian or trustee appears to be in the interests of a minor or other person lacking full capacity who is a national of the sending State. The giving of this information shall, however, be without prejudice to the operation of the laws and regulations of the receiving State concerning such appointments; (<em>c</em>) if a vessel, having the nationality of the sending State, is wrecked or runs aground in the territorial sea or internal waters of the receiving State, or if an aircraft registered in the sending State suffers an accident on the territory of the receiving State, to inform without delay the consular post nearest to the scene of the occurrence. <em>Article 38</em> <em>Communication with the authorities of the receiving State</em> In the exercise of their functions, consular officers may address: (<em>a</em>) the competent local authorities of their consular district; (<em>b</em>) the competent central authorities of the receiving State if and to the extent that this is allowed by the laws, regulations and usages of the receiving State or by the relevant international agreements. <em>Article 39</em> <em>Consular fees and charges</em> 1.The consular post may levy in the territory of the receiving State the fees and charges provided by the laws and regulations of the sending State for consular acts. 2.The sums collected in the form of the fees and charges referred to in paragraph 1 of this article, and the receipts for such fees and charges, shall be exempt from all dues and taxes in the receiving State. 17 SECTION II. FACILITIES, PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES RELATING TO CAREER CONSULAR OFFICERS AND OTHER MEMBERS OF A CONSULAR POST <em>Article 40</em> <em>Protection of consular officers</em> The receiving State shall treat consular officers with due respect and shall take all appropriate steps to prevent any attack on their person, freedom or dignity. <em>Article 41</em> <em>Personal inviolability of consular officers</em> 1.Consular officers shall not be liable to arrest or detention pending trial, except in the case of a grave crime and pursuant to a decision by the competent judicial authority. 2.Except in the case specified in paragraph 1 of this article, consular officers shall not be committed to prison or be liable to any other form of restriction on their personal freedom save in execution of a judicial decision of final effect. 3. If criminal proceedings are instituted against a consular officer, he must appear before the competent authorities. Nevertheless, the proceedings shall be conducted with the respect due to him by reason of his official position and, except in the case specified in paragraph 1 of this article, in a manner which will hamper the exercise of consular functions as little as possible. When, in the circumstances mentioned in paragraph 1 of this article, it has become necessary to detain a consular officer, the proceedings against him shall be instituted with the minimum of delay. <em>Article 42</em> <em>Notification of arrest, detention or prosecution</em> In the event of the arrest or detention, pending trial, of a member of the consular staff, or of criminal proceedings being instituted against him, the receiving State shall promptly notify the head of the consular post. Should the latter be himself the object of any such measure, the receiving State shall notify the sending State through the diplomatic channel. <em>Article 43</em> <em>Immunity from jurisdiction</em> 1.Consular officers and consular employees shall not be amenable to the jurisdiction of the judicial or administrative authorities of the receiving State in respect of acts performed in the exercise of consular functions. 2.The provisions of paragraph 1 of this article shall not, however, apply in respect of a civil action either: 18 (<em>a</em>) arising out of a contract concluded by a consular officer or a consular employee in which he did not contract expressly or impliedly as an agent of the sending State; or (<em>b</em>) by a third party for damage arising from an accident in the receiving State caused by a vehicle, vessel or aircraft. <em>Article 44</em> <em>Liability to give evidence</em> 1.Members of a consular post may be called upon to attend as witnesses in the course of judicial or administrative proceedings. A consular employee or a member of the service staff shall not, except in the cases mentioned in paragraph 3 of this article, decline to give evidence. If a consular officer should decline to do so, no coercive measure or penalty may be applied to him. 2.The authority requiring the evidence of a consular officer shall avoid interference with the performance of his functions. It may, when possible, take such evidence at his residence or at the consular post or accept a statement from him in writing. 3.Members of a consular post are under no obligation to give evidence concerning matters connected with the exercise of their functions or to produce official correspondence and documents relating thereto. They are also entitled to decline to give evidence as expert witnesses with regard to the law of the sending State. <em>Article 45</em> <em>Waiver of privileges and immunities</em> 1.The sending State may waive, with regard to a member of the consular post, any of the privileges and immunities provided for in articles 41, 43 and 44. 2.The waiver shall in all cases be express, except as provided in paragraph 3 of this article, and shall be communicated to the receiving State in writing. 3.The initiation of proceedings by a consular officer or a consular employee in a matter where he might enjoy immunity from jurisdiction under article 43 shall preclude him from invoking immunity from jurisdiction in respect of any counterclaim directly connected with the principal claim. 4.The waiver of immunity from jurisdiction for the purposes of civil or administrative proceedings shall not be deemed to imply the waiver of immunity from the measures of execution resulting from the judicial decision; in respect of such measures, a separate waiver shall be necessary. 19 <em>Article 46</em> <em>Exemption from registration of aliens and residence permits</em> 1.Consular officers and consular employees and members of their families forming part of their households shall be exempt from all obligations under the laws and regulations of the receiving State in regard to the registration of aliens and residence permits. 2.The provisions of paragraph 1 of this article shall not, however, apply to any consular employee who is not a permanent employee of the sending State or who carries on any private gainful occupation in the receiving State or to any member of the family of any such employee. <em>Article 47</em> <em>Exemption from work permits</em> 1.Members of the consular post shall, with respect to services rendered for the sending State, be exempt from any obligations in regard to work permits imposed by the laws and regulations of the receiving State concerning the employment of foreign labour. 2.Members of the private staff of consular officers and of consular employees shall, if they do not carry on any other gainful occupation in the receiving State, be exempt from the obligations referred to in paragraph 1 of this article. <em>Article 48</em> <em>Social security exemption</em> 1.Subject to the provisions of paragraph 3 of this article, members of the consular post with respect to services rendered by them for the sending State, and members of their families forming part of their households, shall be exempt from social security provisions which may be in force in the receiving State. 2.The exemption provided for in paragraph 1 of this article shall apply also to members of the private staff who are in the sole employ of members of the consular post, on condition: (<em>a</em>) that they are not nationals of or permanently resident in the receiving State; and (<em>b</em>) that they are covered by the social security provisions which are in force in the sending State or a third State. 3.Members of the consular post who employ persons to whom the exemption provided for in paragraph 2 of this article does not apply shall observe the obligations which the social security provisions of the receiving State impose upon employers. 4.The exemption provided for in paragraphs 1 and 2 of this article shall not preclude voluntary participation in the social security system of the receiving State, provided that such participation is permitted by that State. 20 <em>Article 49</em> <em>Exemption from taxation</em> 1.Consular officers and consular employees and members of their families forming part of their households shall be exempt from all dues and taxes, personal or real, national, regional or municipal, except: (<em>a</em>) indirect taxes of a kind which are normally incorporated in the price of goods or services; (<em>b</em>) dues or taxes on private immovable property situated in the territory of the receiving State, subject to the provisions of article 32; (<em>c</em>) estate, succession or inheritance duties, and duties on transfers, levied by the receiving State, subject to the provisions of paragraph (<em>b</em>) of article 51; (<em>d</em>) dues and taxes on private income, including capital gains, having its source in the receiving State and capital taxes relating to investments made in commercial or financial undertakings in the receiving State; (<em>e</em>) charges levied for specific services rendered; (<em>f</em>) registration, court or record fees, mortgage dues and stamp duties, subject to the provisions of article 32. 2.Members of the service staff shall be exempt from dues and taxes on the wages which they receive for their services. 3.Members of the consular post who employ persons whose wages or salaries are not exempt from income tax in the receiving State shall observe the obligations which the laws and regulations of that State impose upon employers concerning the levying of income tax. <em>Article 50</em> <em>Exemption from customs duties and inspection</em> 1.The receiving State shall, in accordance with such laws and regulations as it may adopt, permit entry of and grant exemption from all customs duties, taxes, and related charges other than charges for storage, cartage and similar services, on: (<em>a</em>) articles for the official use of the consular post; (<em>b</em>) articles for the personal use of a consular officer or members of his family forming part of his household, including articles intended for his establishment. The articles intended for consumption shall not exceed the quantities necessary for direct utilization by the persons concerned. 2.Consular employees shall enjoy the privileges and exemptions specified in paragraph 1 of this article in respect of articles imported at the time of first installation. 21 3.Personal baggage accompanying consular officers and members of their families forming part of their households shall be exempt from inspection. It may be inspected only if there is serious reason to believe that it contains articles other than those referred to in subparagraph (<em>b</em>) of paragraph 1 of this article, or articles the import or export of which is prohibited by the laws and regulations of the receiving State or which are subject to its quarantine laws and regulations. Such inspection shall be carried out in the presence of the consular officer or member of his family concerned. <em>Article 51</em> <em>Estate of a member of the consular post</em> <em>or of a member of his family</em> In the event of the death of a member of the consular post or of a member of his family forming part of his household, the receiving State: (<em>a</em>) shall permit the export of the movable property of the deceased, with the exception of any such property acquired in the receiving State the export of which was prohibited at the time of his death; (<em>b</em>) shall not levy national, regional or municipal estate, succession or inheritance duties, and duties on transfers, on movable property the presence of which in the receiving State was due solely to the presence in that State of the deceased as a member of the consular post or as a member of the family of a member of the consular post. <em>Article 52</em> <em>Exemption from personal services and contributions</em> The receiving State shall exempt members of the consular post and members of their families forming part of their households from all personal services, from all public service of any kind whatsoever, and from military obligations such as those connected with requisitioning, military contributions and billeting. <em>Article 53</em> <em>Beginning and end of consular privileges and immunities</em> 1.Every member of the consular post shall enjoy the privileges and immunities provided in the present Convention from the moment he enters the territory of the receiving State on proceeding to take up his post or, if already in its territory, from the moment when he enters on his duties with the consular post. 2.Members of the family of a member of the consular post forming part of his household and members of his private staff shall receive the privileges and immunities provided in the present Convention from the date from which he enjoys privileges and immunities in accordance with paragraph 1 of this article or from the date of their entry into the territory of the receiving State or from the date of their becoming a member of such family or private staff, whichever is the latest. 3.When the functions of a member of the consular post have come to an end, his privileges and immunities and those of a member of his family forming part of his household or a member of his 22 private staff shall normally cease at the moment when the person concerned leaves the receiving State or on the expiry of a reasonable period in which to do so, whichever is the sooner, but shall subsist until that time, even in case of armed conflict. In the case of the persons referred to in paragraph 2 of this article, their privileges and immunities shall come to an end when they cease to belong to the household or to be in the service of a member of the consular post provided, however, that if such persons intend leaving the receiving State within a reasonable period thereafter, their privileges and immunities shall subsist until the time of their departure. 4.However, with respect to acts performed by a consular officer or a consular employee in the exercise of his functions, immunity from jurisdiction shall continue to subsist without limitation of time. 5.
