In the event of the death of a member of the consular post, the members of his family forming part of his household shall continue to enjoy the privileges and immunities accorded to them until they leave the receiving State or until the expiry of a reasonable period enabling them to do so, whichever is the sooner. <em>Article 54</em> <em>Obligations of third States</em> 1. If a consular officer passes through or is in the territory of a third State, which has granted him a visa if a visa was necessary, while proceeding to take up or return to his post or when returning to the sending State, the third State shall accord to him all immunities provided for by the other articles of the present Convention as may be required to ensure his transit or return. The same shall apply in the case of any member of his family forming part of his household enjoying such privileges and immunities who are accompanying the consular officer or travelling separately to join him or to return to the sending State. 2. In circumstances similar to those specified in paragraph 1 of this article, third States shall not hinder the transit through their territory of other members of the consular post or of members of their families forming part of their households. 3.Third States shall accord to official correspondence and to other official communications in transit, including messages in code or cipher, the same freedom and protection as the receiving State is bound to accord under the present Convention. They shall accord to consular couriers who have been granted a visa, if a visa was necessary, and to consular bags in transit, the same inviolability and protection as the receiving State is bound to accord under the present Convention. 4.The obligations of third States under paragraphs 1, 2 and 3 of this article shall also apply to the persons mentioned respectively in those paragraphs, and to official communications and to consular bags, whose presence in the territory of the third State is due to force majeure. 23 <em>Article 55</em> <em>Respect for the laws and regulations of the receiving State</em> 1.Without prejudice to their privileges and immunities, it is the duty of all persons enjoying such privileges and immunities to respect the laws and regulations of the receiving State. They also have a duty not to interfere in the internal affairs of the State. 2.The consular premises shall not be used in any manner incompatible with the exercise of consular functions. 3.The provisions of paragraph 2 of this article shall not exclude the possibility of offices of other institutions or agencies being installed in part of the building in which the consular premises are situated, provided that the premises assigned to them are separate from those used by the consular post. In that event, the said offices shall not, for the purposes of the present Convention, be considered to form part of the consular premises. <em>Article 56</em> <em>Insurance against third party risks</em> Members of the consular post shall comply with any requirements imposed by the laws and regulations of the receiving State, in respect of insurance against third party risks arising from the use of any vehicle, vessel or aircraft. <em>Article 57</em> <em>Special provisions concerning private gainful occupation</em> 1.Career consular officers shall not carry on for personal profit any professional or commercial activity in the receiving State. 2.Privileges and immunities provided in this chapter shall not be accorded: (<em>a</em>) to consular employees or to members of the service staff who carry on any private gainful occupation in the receiving State; (<em>b</em>) to members of the family of a person referred to in subparagraph (<em>a</em>) of this paragraph or to members of his private staff; (c) to members of the family of a member of a consular post who themselves carry on any private gainful occupation in the receiving State. 24 CHAPTER III. REGIME RELATING TO HONORARY CONSULAR OFFICERS AND CONSULAR POSTS HEADED BY SUCH OFFICERS <em>Article 58</em> <em>General provisions relating to facilities, privileges</em> <em>and immunities</em> 1.Articles 28, 29, 30, 34, 35, 36, 37, 38 and 39, paragraph 3 of article 54 and paragraphs 2 and 3 of article 55 shall apply to consular posts headed by an honorary consular officer. In addition, the facilities, privileges and immunities of such consular posts shall be governed by articles 59, 60, 61 and 62. 2.Articles 42 and 43, paragraph 3 of article 44, articles 45 and 53 and paragraph 1 of article 55 shall apply to honorary consular officers. In addition, the facilities, privileges and immunities of such consular officers shall be governed by articles 63, 64, 65, 66 and 67. 3.Privileges and immunities provided in the present Convention shall not be accorded to members of the family of an honorary consular officer or of a consular employee employed at a consular post headed by an honorary consular officer. 4.The exchange of consular bags between two consular posts headed by honorary consular officers in different States shall not be allowed without the consent of the two receiving States concerned. <em>Article 59</em> <em>Protection of the consular premises</em> The receiving State shall take such steps as may be necessary to protect the consular premises of a consular post headed by an honorary consular officer against any intrusion or damage and to prevent any disturbance of the peace of the consular post or impairment of its dignity. <em>Article 60</em> <em>Exemption from taxation of consular premises</em> 1.Consular premises of a consular post headed by an honorary consular officer of which the sending State is the owner or lessee shall be exempt from all national, regional or municipal dues and taxes whatsoever, other than such as represent payment for specific services rendered. 2.The exemption from taxation referred to in paragraph l of this article shall not apply to such dues and taxes if, under the laws and regulations of the receiving State, they are payable by the person who contracted with the sending State. 25 <em>Article 61</em> <em>Inviolability of consular archives and documents</em> The consular archives and documents of a consular post headed by an honorary consular officer shall be inviolable at all times and wherever they may be, provided that they are kept separate from other papers and documents and, in particular, from the private correspondence of the head of a consular post and of any person working with him, and from the materials, books or documents relating to their profession or trade. <em>Article 62</em> <em>Exemption from customs duties</em> The receiving State shall, in accordance with such laws and regulations as it may adopt, permit entry of, and grant exemption from all customs duties, taxes, and related charges other than charges for storage, cartage and similar services on the following articles, provided that they are for the official use of a consular post headed by an honorary consular officer: coats-of-arms, flags, signboards, seals and stamps, books, official printed matter, office furniture, office equipment and similar articles supplied by or at the instance of the sending State to the consular post. <em>Article 63</em> <em>Criminal proceedings</em> If criminal proceedings are instituted against an honorary consular officer, he must appear before the competent authorities. Nevertheless, the proceedings shall be conducted with the respect due to him by reason of his official position and, except when he is under arrest or detention, in a manner which will hamper the exercise of consular functions as little as possible. When it has become necessary to detain an honorary consular officer, the proceedings against him shall be instituted with the minimum of delay. <em>Article 64</em> <em>Protection of honorary consular officers</em> The receiving State is under a duty to accord to an honorary consular officer such protection as may be required by reason of his official position. <em>Article 65</em> <em>Exemption from registration of aliens and residence permits</em> Honorary consular officers, with the exception of those who carry on for personal profit any professional or commercial activity in the receiving State, shall be exempt from all obligations under the laws and regulations of the receiving State in regard to the registration of aliens and residence permits. 26 <em>Article 66</em> <em>Exemption from taxation</em> An honorary consular officer shall be exempt from all dues and taxes on the remuneration and emoluments which he receives from the sending State in respect of the exercise of consular functions. <em>Article 67</em> <em>Exemption from personal services and contributions</em> The receiving State shall exempt honorary consular officers from all personal services and from all public services of any kind whatsoever and from military obligations such as those connected with requisitioning, military contributions and billeting. <em>Article 68</em> <em>Optional character of the institution of</em> <em>honorary consular officers</em> Each State is free to decide whether it will appoint or receive honorary consular officers. CHAPTER IV. GENERAL PROVISIONS <em>Article 69</em> <em>Consular agents who are not heads of consular posts</em> 1.Each State is free to decide whether it will establish or admit consular agencies conducted by consular agents not designated as heads of consular post by the sending State. 2.The conditions under which the consular agencies referred to in paragraph 1 of this article may carry on their activities and the privileges and immunities which may be enjoyed by the consular agents in charge of them shall be determined by agreement between the sending State and the receiving State. <em>Article 70</em> <em>Exercise of consular functions by diplomatic missions</em> 1.The provisions of the present Convention apply also, so far as the context permits, to the exercise of consular functions by a diplomatic mission. 2.The names of members of a diplomatic mission assigned to the consular section or otherwise charged with the exercise of the consular functions of the mission shall be notified to the Ministry for Foreign Affairs of the receiving State or to the authority designated by that Ministry. 3. In the exercise of consular functions a diplomatic mission may address: (<em>a</em>) the local authorities of the consular district; 27 (<em>b</em>) the central authorities of the receiving State if this is allowed by the laws, regulations and usages of the receiving State or by relevant international agreements. 4.The privileges and immunities of the members of a diplomatic mission referred to in paragraph 2 of this article shall continue to be governed by the rules of international law concerning diplomatic relations. <em>Article 71</em> <em>Nationals or permanent residents of the receiving State</em> 1.Except insofar as additional facilities, privileges and immunities may be granted by the receiving State, consular officers who are nationals of or permanently resident in the receiving State shall enjoy only immunity from jurisdiction and personal inviolability in respect of official acts performed in the exercise of their functions, and the privileges provided in paragraph 3 of article 44. So far as these consular officers are concerned, the receiving State shall likewise be bound by the obligation laid down in article 42. If criminal proceedings are instituted against such a consular officer, the proceedings shall, except when he is under arrest or detention, be conducted in a manner which will hamper the exercise of consular functions as little as possible. 2.Other members of the consular post who are nationals of or permanently resident in the receiving State and members of their families, as well as members of the families of consular officers referred to in paragraph 1 of this article, shall enjoy facilities, privileges and immunities only insofar as these are granted to them by the receiving State. Those members of the families of members of the consular post and those members of the private staff who are themselves nationals of or permanently resident in the receiving State shall likewise enjoy facilities, privileges and immunities only insofar as these are granted to them by the receiving State. The receiving State shall, however, exercise its jurisdiction over those persons in such a way as not to hinder unduly the performance of the functions of the consular post. <em>Article 72</em> <em>Non-discrimination</em> 1. In the application of the provisions of the present Convention the receiving State shall not discriminate as between States. 2.However, discrimination shall not be regarded as taking place: (<em>a</em>) where the receiving State applies any of the provisions of the present Convention restrictively because of a restrictive application of that provision to its consular posts in the sending State; (<em>b</em>) where by custom or agreement States extend to each other more favourable treatment than is required by the provisions of the present Convention. 28 <em>Article 73</em> <em>Relationship between the present Convention</em> <em>and other international agreements</em> 1.The provisions of the present Convention shall not affect other international agreements in force as between States Parties to them. 2.Nothing in the present Convention shall preclude States from concludin</p></div></div>
55	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations 1961</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p>Done at Vienna on 18 April 1961. Entered into force on 24 April 1964.</p><p>United Nations, <em>Treaty Series</em>, vol. 500, p. 95.</p><p>Copyright © United Nations</p><p>2005</p><p>2</p><p>Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations</p><p>Done at Vienna on 18 April 1961</p><p><em>The States Parties to the present Convention</em>,</p><p><em>Recalling </em>that peoples of all nations from ancient times have recognized the status of diplomatic</p><p>agents,</p><p><em>Having in mind </em>the purposes and principles of the Charter of the United Nations concerning the</p><p>sovereign equality of States, the maintenance of international peace and security, and the promotion of</p><p>friendly relations among nations,</p><p><em>Believing </em>that an international convention on diplomatic intercourse, privileges and immunities</p><p>would contribute to the development of friendly relations among nations, irrespective of their differing</p><p>constitutional and social systems,</p><p><em>Realizing </em>that the purpose of such privileges and immunities is not to benefit individuals but to</p><p>ensure the efficient performance of the functions of diplomatic missions as representing States,</p><p><em>Affirming </em>that the rules of customary international law should continue to govern questions not</p><p>expressly regulated by the provisions of the present Convention,</p><p><em>Have agreed </em>as follows:</p><p><em>Article 1</em></p><p>For the purpose of the present Convention, the following expressions shall have the meanings</p><p>hereunder assigned to them:</p><p>(<em>a</em>) The “head of the mission” is the person charged by the sending State with the duty of acting in</p><p>that capacity;</p><p>(<em>b</em>) The “members of the mission” are the head of the mission and the members of the staff of the</p><p>mission;</p><p>(<em>c</em>) The “members of the staff of the mission” are the members of the diplomatic staff, of the</p><p>administrative and technical staff and of the service staff of the mission;</p><p>(<em>d</em>) The “members of the diplomatic staff” are the members of the staff of the mission having</p><p>diplomatic rank;</p><p>(<em>e</em>) A “diplomatic agent” is the head of the mission or a member of the diplomatic staff of the</p><p>mission;</p><p>(<em>f</em>) The “members of the administrative and technical staff” are the members of the staff of the</p><p>mission employed in the administrative and technical service of the mission;</p><p>3</p><p>(<em>g</em>) The “members of the service staff” are the members of the staff of the mission in the domestic</p><p>service of the mission;</p><p>(<em>h</em>) A “private servant” is a person who is in the domestic service of a member of the mission and</p><p>who is not an employee of the sending State;</p><p>(<em>i</em>) The “premises of the mission” are the buildings or parts of buildings and the land ancillary</p><p>thereto, irrespective of ownership, used for the purposes of the mission including the residence of the</p><p>head of the mission.</p><p><em>Article 2</em></p><p>The establishment of diplomatic relations between States, and of permanent diplomatic missions,</p><p>takes place by mutual consent.</p><p><em>Article 3</em></p><p>1.The functions of a diplomatic mission consist, inter alia, in:</p><p>(<em>a</em>) Representing the sending State in the receiving State;</p><p>(<em>b</em>) Protecting in the receiving State the interests of the sending State and of its nationals, within the</p><p>limits permitted by international law;</p><p>(<em>c</em>) Negotiating with the Government of the receiving State;</p><p>(<em>d</em>) Ascertaining by all lawful means conditions and developments in the receiving State, and</p><p>reporting thereon to the Government of the sending State;</p><p>(<em>e</em>) Promoting friendly relations between the sending State and the receiving State, and developing</p><p>their economic, cultural and scientific relations.</p><p>2.Nothing in the present Convention shall be construed as preventing the performance of consular</p><p>functions by a diplomatic mission.</p><p><em>Article 4</em></p><p>1.The sending State must make certain that the <em>agrément </em>of the receiving State has been given for</p><p>the person it proposes to accredit as head of the mission to that State.</p><p>2.The receiving State is not obliged to give reasons to the sending State for a refusal of <em>agrément</em>.</p><p>4</p><p><em>Article 5</em></p><p>1.The sending State may, after it has given due notification to the receiving States concerned,</p><p>accredit a head of mission or assign any member of the diplomatic staff, as the case may be, to more</p><p>than one State, unless there is express objection by any of the receiving States.</p><p>2. If the sending State accredits a head of mission to one or more other States it may establish a</p><p>diplomatic mission headed by a chargé d’affaires ad interim in each State where the head of mission has</p><p>not his permanent seat.</p><p>3.A head of mission or any member of the diplomatic staff of the mission may act as</p><p>representative of the sending State to any international organization.</p><p><em>Article 6</em></p><p>Two or more States may accredit the same person as head of mission to another State, unless</p><p>objection is offered by the receiving State.</p><p><em>Article 7</em></p><p>Subject to the provisions of articles 5, 8, 9 and 11, the sending State may freely appoint the</p><p>members of the staff of the mission. In the case of military, naval or air attachés, the receiving State may</p><p>require their names to be submitted beforehand, for its approval.</p><p><em>Article 8</em></p><p>1.Members of the diplomatic staff of the mission should in principle be of the nationality of the</p><p>sending State.</p><p>2.Members of the diplomatic staff of the mission may not be appointed from among persons</p><p>having the nationality of the receiving State, except with the consent of that State which may be</p><p>withdrawn at any time.</p><p>3.The receiving State may reserve the same right with regard to nationals of a third State who are</p><p>not also nationals of the sending State.</p><p><em>Article 9</em></p><p>1.The receiving State may at any time and without having to explain its decision, notify the</p><p>sending State that the head of the mission or any member of the diplomatic staff of the mission is</p><p>persona non grata or that any other member of the staff of the mission is not acceptable. In any such</p><p>case, the sending State shall, as appropriate, either recall the person concerned or terminate his functions</p><p>with the mission. A person may be declared non grata or not acceptable before arriving in the territory of</p><p>the receiving State.</p><p>5</p><p>2. If the sending State refuses or fails within a reasonable period to carry out its obligations under</p><p>paragraph 1 of this article, the receiving State may refuse to recognize the person concerned as a</p><p>member of the mission.</p><p><em>Article 10</em></p><p>1.The Ministry for Foreign Affairs of the receiving State, or such other ministry as may be</p><p>agreed, shall be notified of:</p><p>(<em>a</em>) The appointment of members of the mission, their arrival and their final departure or the</p><p>termination of their functions with the mission;</p><p>(<em>b</em>) The arrival and final departure of a person belonging to the family of a member of the mission</p><p>and, where appropriate, the fact that a person becomes or ceases to be a member of the family of a</p><p>member of the mission;</p><p>(<em>c</em>) The arrival and final departure of private servants in the employ of persons referred to in</p><p>subparagraph (<em>a</em>) of this paragraph and, where appropriate, the fact that they are leaving the employ of</p><p>such persons;</p><p>(<em>d</em>) The engagement and discharge of persons resident in the receiving State as members of the</p><p>mission or private servants entitled to privileges and immunities.</p><p>2.Where possible, prior notification of arrival and final departure shall also be given.</p><p><em>Article 11</em></p><p>1. In the absence of specific agreement as to the size of the mission, the receiving State may</p><p>require that the size of a mission be kept within limits considered by it to be reasonable and normal,</p><p>having regard to circumstances and conditions in the receiving State and to the needs of the particular</p><p>mission.</p><p>2.The receiving State may equally, within similar bounds and on a non-discriminatory basis,</p><p>refuse to accept officials of a particular category.</p><p><em>Article 12</em></p><p>The sending State may not, without the prior express consent of the receiving State, establish</p><p>offices forming part of the mission in localities other than those in which the mission itself is</p><p>established.</p><p><em>Article 13</em></p><p>1.The head of the mission is considered as having taken up his functions in the receiving State</p><p>either when he has presented his credentials or when he has notified his arrival and a true copy of his</p><p>credentials has been presented to the Ministry for Foreign Affairs of the receiving State, or such other</p><p>6</p><p>ministry as may be agreed, in accordance with the practice prevailing in the receiving State which shall</p><p>be applied in a uniform manner.</p><p>2.The order of presentation of credentials or of a true copy thereof will be determined by the date</p><p>and time of the arrival of the head of the mission.</p><p><em>Article 14</em></p><p>1.Heads of mission are divided into three classes, namely:</p><p>(<em>a</em>) That of ambassadors or nuncios accredited to Heads of State, and other heads of mission of</p><p>equivalent rank;</p><p>(<em>b</em>) That of envoys, ministers and internuncios accredited to Heads of State;</p><p>(<em>c</em>) That of chargés d’affaires accredited to Ministers for Foreign Affairs.</p><p>2.Except as concerns precedence and etiquette, there shall be no differentiation between heads of</p><p>mission by reason of their class.</p><p><em>Article 15</em></p><p>The class to which the heads of their missions are to be assigned shall be agreed between States.</p><p><em>Article 16</em></p><p>1.Heads of mission shall take precedence in their respective classes in the order of the date and</p><p>time of taking up their functions in accordance with article 13.</p><p>2.Alterations in the credentials of a head of mission not involving any change of class shall not</p><p>affect his precedence.</p><p>3.This article is without prejudice to any practice accepted by the receiving State regarding the</p><p>precedence of the representative of the Holy See.</p><p><em>Article 17</em></p><p>The precedence of the members of the diplomatic staff of the mission shall be notified by the head</p><p>of the mission to the Ministry for Foreign Affairs or such other ministry as may be agreed.</p><p><em>Article 18</em></p><p>The procedure to be observed in each State for the reception of heads of mission shall be uniform</p><p>in respect of each class.</p><p>7</p><p><em>Article 19</em></p><p>1. If the post of head of the mission is vacant, or if the head of the mission is unable to perform</p><p>his functions a chargé d’affaires ad interim shall act provisionally as head of the mission. The name of</p><p>the chargé d’affaires ad interim shall be notified, either by the head of the mission or, in case he is</p><p>unable to do so, by the Ministry for Foreign Affairs of the sending State to the Ministry for Foreign</p><p>Affairs of the receiving State or such other ministry as may be agreed.</p><p>2. In cases where no member of the diplomatic staff of the mission is present in the receiving</p><p>State, a member of the administrative and technical staff may, with the consent of the receiving State, be</p><p>designated by the sending State to be in charge of the current administrative affairs of the mission.</p><p><em>Article 20</em></p><p>The mission and its head shall have the right to use the flag and emblem of the sending State on</p><p>the premises of the mission, including the residence of the head of the mission, and on his means of</p><p>transport.</p><p><em>Article 21</em></p><p>1.The receiving State shall either facilitate the acquisition on its territory, in accordance with its</p><p>laws, by the sending State of premises necessary for its mission or assist the latter in obtaining</p><p>accommodation in some other way.</p><p>2. It shall also, where necessary, assist missions in obtaining suitable accommodation for their</p><p>members.</p><p><em>Article 22</em></p><p>1.The premises of the mission shall be inviolable. The agents of the receiving State may not enter</p><p>them, except with the consent of the head of the mission.</p><p>2.The receiving State is under a special duty to take all appropriate steps to protect the premises</p><p>of the mission against any intrusion or damage and to prevent any disturbance of the peace of the</p><p>mission or impairment of its dignity.</p><p>3.The premises of the mission, their furnishings and other property thereon and the means of</p><p>transport of the mission shall be immune from search, requisition, attachment or execution.</p><p><em>Article 23</em></p><p>1.The sending State and the head of the mission shall be exempt from all national, regional or</p><p>municipal dues and taxes in respect of the premises of the mission, whether owned or leased, other than</p><p>such as represent payment for specific services rendered.</p><p>8</p><p>2.The exemption from taxation referred to in this article shall not apply to such dues and taxes</p><p>payable under the law of the receiving State by persons contracting with the sending State or the head of</p><p>the mission.</p><p><em>Article 24</em></p><p>The archives and documents of the mission shall be inviolable at any time and wherever they may</p><p>be.</p><p><em>Article 25</em></p><p>The receiving State shall accord full facilities for the performance of the functions of the mission.</p><p><em>Article 26</em></p><p>Subject to its laws and regulations concerning zones entry into which is prohibited or regulated</p><p>for reasons of national security, the receiving State shall ensure to all members of the mission freedom</p><p>of movement and travel in its territory.</p><p><em>Article 27</em></p><p>1.The receiving State shall permit and protect free communication on the part of the mission for</p><p>all official purposes. In communicating with the Government and the other missions and consulates of</p><p>the sending State, wherever situated, the mission may employ all appropriate means, including</p><p>diplomatic couriers and messages in code or cipher. However, the mission may install and use a wireless</p><p>transmitter only with the consent of the receiving State.</p><p>2.The official correspondence of the mission shall be inviolable. Official correspondence means</p><p>all correspondence relating to the mission and its functions.</p><p>3.The diplomatic bag shall not be opened or detained.</p><p>4.The packages constituting the diplomatic bag must bear visible external marks of their character</p><p>and may contain only diplomatic documents or articles intended for official use.</p><p>5.The diplomatic courier, who shall be provided with an official document indicating his status</p><p>and the number of packages constituting the diplomatic bag, shall be protected by the receiving State in</p><p>the performance of his functions. He shall enjoy person inviolability and shall not be liable to any form</p><p>of arrest or detention.</p><p>6.The sending State or the mission may designate diplomatic couriers ad hoc. In such cases the</p><p>provisions of paragraph 5 of this article shall also apply, except that the immunities therein mentioned</p><p>shall cease to apply when such a courier has delivered to the consignee the diplomatic bag in his charge.</p><p>7.A diplomatic bag may be entrusted to the captain of a commercial aircraft scheduled to land at</p><p>an authorized port of entry. He shall be provided with an official document indicating the number of</p><p>9</p><p>packages constituting the bag but he shall not be considered to be a diplomatic courier. The mission may</p><p>send one of its members to take possession of the diplomatic bag directly and freely from the captain of</p><p>the aircraft.</p><p><em>Article 28</em></p><p>The fees and charges levied by the mission in the course of its official duties shall be exempt from</p><p>all dues and taxes.</p><p><em>Article 29</em></p><p>The person of a diplomatic agent shall be inviolable. He shall not be liable to any form of arrest</p><p>or detention. The receiving State shall treat him with due respect and shall take all appropriate steps to</p><p>prevent any attack on his person, freedom or dignity.</p><p><em>Article 30</em></p><p>1.The private residence of a diplomatic agent shall enjoy the same inviolability and protection as</p><p>the premises of the mission.</p><p>2.His papers, correspondence and, except as provided in paragraph 3 of article 31, his property,</p><p>shall likewise enjoy inviolability.</p><p><em>Article 31</em></p><p>1.A diplomatic agent shall enjoy immunity from the criminal jurisdiction of the receiving State.</p><p>He shall also enjoy immunity from its civil and administrative jurisdiction, except in the case of:</p><p>(<em>a</em>) A real action relating to private immovable property situated in the territory of the receiving State,</p><p>unless he holds it on behalf of the sending State for the purposes of the mission;</p><p>(<em>b</em>) An action relating to succession in which the diplomatic agent is involved as executor,</p><p>administrator, heir or legatee as a private person and not on behalf of the sending State;</p><p>(<em>c</em>) An action relating to any professional or commercial activity exercised by the diplomatic agent in</p><p>the receiving State outside his official functions.</p><p>2.A diplomatic agent is not obliged to give evidence as a witness.</p><p>3.No measures of execution may be taken in respect of a diplomatic agent except in the cases</p><p>coming under subparagraphs (<em>a</em>), (<em>b</em>) and (<em>c</em>) of paragraph 1 of this article, and provided that the</p><p>measures concerned can be taken without infringing the inviolability of his person or of his residence.</p><p>4.The immunity of a diplomatic agent from the jurisdiction of the receiving State does not exempt</p><p>him from the jurisdiction of the sending State.</p><p>10</p><p><em>Article 32</em></p><p>1.The immunity from jurisdiction of diplomatic agents and of persons enjoying immunity under</p><p>article 37 may be waived by the sending State.</p><p>2.Waiver must always be express.</p><p>3.The initiation of proceedings by a diplomatic agent or by a person enjoying immunity from</p><p>jurisdiction under article 37 shall preclude him from invoking immunity from jurisdiction in respect of</p><p>any counterclaim directly connected with the principal claim.</p><p>4.Waiver of immunity from jurisdiction in respect of civil or administrative proceedings shall not</p><p>be held to imply waiver of immunity in respect of the execution of the judgement, for which a separate</p><p>waiver shall be necessary.</p><p><em>Article 33</em></p><p>1.Subject to the provisions of paragraph 3 of this article, a diplomatic agent shall with respect to</p><p>services rendered for the sending State be exempt from social security provisions which may be in force</p><p>in the receiving State.</p><p>2.The exemption provided for in paragraph 1 of this article shall also apply to private servants</p><p>who are in the sole employ of a diplomatic agent, on condition:</p><p>(<em>a</em>) That they are not nationals of or permanently resident in the receiving State; and</p><p>(<em>b</em>) That they are covered by the social security provisions which may be in force in the sending State</p><p>or a third State.</p><p>3.A diplomatic agent who employs persons to whom the exemption provided for in paragraph 2 of</p><p>this article does not apply shall observe the obligations which the social security provisions of the</p><p>receiving State impose upon employers.</p><p>4.The exemption provided for in paragraphs 1 and 2 of this article shall not preclude voluntary</p><p>participation in the social security system of the receiving State provided that such participation is</p><p>permitted by that State.</p><p>5.The provisions of this article shall not affect bilateral or multilateral agreements concerning</p><p>social security concluded previously and shall not prevent the conclusion of such agreements in the</p><p>future.</p><p><em>Article 34</em></p><p>A diplomatic agent shall be exempt from all dues and taxes, personal or real, national, regional or</p><p>municipal, except:</p><p>11</p><p>(<em>a</em>) Indirect taxes of a kind which are normally incorporated in the price of goods or services;</p><p>(<em>b</em>) Dues and taxes on private immovable property situated in the territory of the receiving State,</p><p>unless he holds it on behalf of the sending State for the purposes of the mission;</p><p>(<em>c</em>) Estate, succession or inheritance duties levied by the receiving State, subject to the provisions of</p><p>paragraph 4 of article 39;</p><p>(<em>d</em>) Dues and taxes on private income having its source in the receiving State and capital taxes on</p><p>investments made in commercial undertakings in the receiving State;</p><p>(<em>e</em>) Charges levied for specific services rendered;</p><p>(<em>f</em>) Registration, court or record fees, mortgage dues and stamp duty, with respect to immovable</p><p>property, subject to the provisions of article 23.</p><p><em>Article 35</em></p><p>The receiving State shall exempt diplomatic agents from all personal services, from all public</p><p>service of any kind whatsoever, and from military obligations such as those connected with</p><p>requisitioning, military contributions and billeting.</p><p><em>Article 36</em></p><p>1.The receiving State shall, in accordance with such laws and regulations as it may adopt, permit</p><p>entry of and grant exemption from all customs duties, taxes, and related charges other than charges for</p><p>storage, cartage and similar services, on:</p><p>(<em>a</em>) Articles for the official use of the mission;</p><p>(<em>b</em>) Articles for the personal use of a diplomatic agent or members of his family forming part of his</p><p>household, including articles intended for his establishment.</p><p>2.The personal baggage of a diplomatic agent shall be exempt from inspection, unless there are</p><p>serious grounds for presuming that it contains articles not covered by the exemptions mentioned in</p><p>paragraph 1 of this article, or articles the import or export of which is prohibited by the law or controlled</p><p>by the quarantine regulations of the receiving State. Such inspection shall be conducted only in the</p><p>presence of the diplomatic agent or of his authorized representative.</p><p><em>Article 37</em></p><p>1.The members of the family of a diplomatic agent forming part of his household shall, if they are</p><p>not nationals of the receiving State, enjoy the privileges and immunities specified in articles 29 to 36.</p><p>2.Members of the administrative and technical staff of the mission, together with members of</p><p>their families forming part of their respective households, shall, if they are not nationals of or</p><p>12</p><p>permanently resident in the receiving State, enjoy the privileges and immunities specified in articles 29</p><p>to 35, except that the immunity from civil and administrative jurisdiction of the receiving State specified</p><p>in paragraph 1 of article 31 shall not extend to acts performed outside the course of their duties. They</p><p>shall also enjoy the privileges specified in article 36, paragraph 1, in respect of articles imported at the</p><p>time of first installation.</p><p>3.Members of the service staff of the mission who are not nationals of or permanently resident in</p><p>the receiving State shall enjoy immunity in respect of acts performed in the course of their duties,</p><p>exemption from dues and taxes on the emoluments they receive by reason of their employment and the</p><p>exemption contained in article 33.</p><p>4.Private servants of members of the mission shall, if they are not nationals of or permanently</p><p>resident in the receiving State, be exempt from dues and taxes on the emoluments they receive by reason</p><p>of their employment. In other respects, they may enjoy privileges and immunities only to the extent</p><p>admitted by the receiving State. However, the receiving State must exercise its jurisdiction over those</p><p>persons in such a manner as not to interfere unduly with the performance of the functions of the mission.</p><p><em>Article 38</em></p><p>1.Except insofar as additional privileges and immunities may be granted by the receiving State, a</p><p>diplomatic agent who is a national of or permanently resident in that State shall enjoy only immunity</p><p>from jurisdiction, and inviolability, in respect of official acts performed in the exercise of his functions.</p><p>2.Other members of the staff of the mission and private servants who are nationals of or</p><p>permanently resident in the receiving State shall enjoy privileges and immunities only to the extent</p><p>admitted by the receiving State. However, the receiving State must exercise its jurisdiction over those</p><p>persons in such a manner as not to interfere unduly with the performance of the functions of the mission.</p><p><em>Article 39</em></p><p>1.Every person entitled to privileges and immunities shall enjoy them from the moment he enters</p><p>the territory of the receiving State on proceeding to take up his post or, if already in its territory, from</p><p>the moment when his appointment is notified to the Ministry for Foreign Affairs or such other ministry</p><p>as may be agreed.</p><p>2.When the functions of a person enjoying privileges and immunities have come to an end, such</p><p>privileges and immunities shall normally cease at the moment when he leaves the country, or on expiry</p><p>of a reasonable period in which to do so, but shall subsist until that time, even in case of armed conflict.</p><p>However, with respect to acts performed by such a person in the exercise of his functions as a member</p><p>of the mission, immunity shall continue to subsist.</p><p>3. In case of the death of a member of the mission, the members of his family shall continue to</p><p>enjoy the privileges and immunities to which they are entitled until the expiry of a reasonable period in</p><p>which to leave the country.</p><p>13</p><p>4. In the event of the death of a member of the mission not a national of or permanently resident in</p><p>the receiving State or a member of his family forming part of his household, the receiving State shall</p><p>permit the withdrawal of the movable property of the deceased, with the exception of any property</p><p>acquired in the country the export of which was prohibited at the time of his death. Estate, succession</p><p>and inheritance duties shall not be levied on movable property the presence of which in the receiving</p><p>State was due solely to the presence there of the deceased as a member of the mission or as a member of</p><p>the family of a member of the mission.</p><p><em>Article 40</em></p><p>1. If a diplomatic agent passes through or is in the territory of a third State, which has granted him</p><p>a passport visa if such visa was necessary, while proceeding to take up or to return to his post, or when</p><p>returning to his own country, the third State shall accord him inviolability and such other immunities as</p><p>may be required to ensure his transit or return. The same shall apply in the case of any members of his</p><p>family enjoying privileges or immunities who are accompanying the diplomatic agent, or travelling</p><p>separately to join him or to return to their country.</p><p>2. In circumstances similar to those specified in paragraph 1 of this article, third States shall not</p><p>hinder the passage of members of the administrative and technical or service staff of a mission, and of</p><p>members of their families, through their territories.</p><p>3.Third States shall accord to official correspondence and other official communications in</p><p>transit, including messages in code or cipher, the same freedom and protection as is accorded by the</p><p>receiving State. They shall accord to diplomatic couriers, who have been granted a passport visa if such</p><p>visa was necessary, and diplomatic bags in transit, the same inviolability and protection as the receiving</p><p>State is bound to accord.</p><p>4.The obligations of third States under paragraphs 1, 2 and 3 of this article shall also apply to the</p><p>persons mentioned respectively in those paragraphs, and to official communications and diplomatic</p><p>bags, whose presence in the territory of the third State is due to force majeure.</p><p><em>Article 41</em></p><p>1.Without prejudice to their privileges and immunities, it is the duty of all persons enjoying such</p><p>privileges and immunities to respect the laws and regulations of the receiving State. They also have a</p><p>duty not to interfere in the internal affairs of that State.</p><p>2.All official business with the receiving State entrusted to the mission by the sending State shall</p><p>be conducted with or through the Ministry for Foreign Affairs of the receiving State or such other</p><p>ministry as may be agreed.</p><p>3.The premises of the mission must not be used in any manner incompatible with the functions of</p><p>the mission as laid down in the present Convention or by other rules of general international law or by</p><p>any special agreements in force between the sending and the receiving State.</p><p>14</p><p><em>Article 42</em></p><p>A diplomatic agent shall not in the receiving State practise for personal profit any professional or</p><p>commercial activity.</p><p><em>Article 43</em></p><p>The function of a diplomatic agent comes to an end, inter alia:</p><p>(<em>a</em>) On notification by the sending State to the receiving State that the function of the diplomatic</p><p>agent has come to an end;</p><p>(<em>b</em>) On notification by the receiving State to the sending State that, in accordance with paragraph 2 of</p><p>article 9, it refuses to recognize the diplomatic agent as a member of the mission.</p><p><em>Article 44</em></p><p>The receiving State must, even in case of armed conflict, grant facilities in order to enable</p><p>persons enjoying privileges and immunities, other than nationals of the receiving State, and members of</p><p>the families of such persons irrespective of their nationality, to leave at the earliest possible moment. It</p><p>must, in particular, in case of need, place at their disposal the necessary means of transport for</p><p>themselves and their property.</p><p><em>Article 45</em></p><p>If diplomatic relations are broken off between two States, or if a mission is permanently or</p><p>temporarily recalled:</p><p>(<em>a</em>) The receiving State must, even in case of armed conflict, respect and protect the premises of the</p><p>mission, together with its property and archives;</p><p>(<em>b</em>) The sending State may entrust the custody of the premises of the mission, together with its</p><p>property and archives, to a third State acceptable to the receiving State;</p><p>(<em>c</em>) The sending State may entrust the protection of its interests and those of its nationals to a third</p><p>State acceptable to the receiving State.</p><p><em>Article 46</em></p><p>A sending State may with the prior consent of a receiving State, and at the request of a third State</p><p>not represented in the receiving State, undertake the temporary protection of the interests of the third</p><p>State and of its nationals.</p><p>15</p><p><em>Article 47</em></p><p>1. In the application of the provisions of the present Convention, the receiving State shall not</p><p>discriminate as between States.</p><p>2.However, discrimination shall not be regarded as taking place:</p><p>(<em>a</em>) Where the receiving State applies any of the provisions of the present Convention restrictively</p><p>because of a restrictive application of that provision to its mission in the sending State;</p><p>(<em>b</em>) Where by custom or agreement States extend to each other more favourable treatment than is</p><p>required by the provisions of the present Convention.</p><p><em>Article 48</em></p><p>The present Convention shall be open for signature by all States Members of the United Nations</p><p>or of any of the specialized agencies Parties to the Statute of the International Court of Justice, and by</p><p>any other State invited by the General Assembly of the United Nations to become a Party to the</p><p>Convention, as follows: until 31 October 1961 at the Federal Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Austria and</p><p>subsequently, until 31 March 1962, at the United Nations Headquarters in New York.</p><p><em>Article 49</em></p><p>The present Convention is subject to ratification. The instruments of ratification shall be</p><p>deposited with the Secretary-General of the United Nations.</p><p><em>Article 50</em></p><p>The present Convention shall remain open for accession by any State belonging to any of the four</p><p>categories mentioned in article 48. The instruments of accession shall be deposited with the Secretary-</p><p>General of the United Nations.</p><p><em>Article 51</em></p><p>1.The present Convention shall enter into force on the thirtieth day following the date of deposit</p><p>of the twenty-second instrument of ratification or accession with the Secretary-General of the United</p><p>Nations.</p><p>2.For each State ratifying or acceding to the Convention after the deposit of the twenty-second</p><p>instrument of ratification or accession, the Convention shall enter into force on the thirtieth day after</p><p>deposit by such State of its instrument of ratification or accession.</p><p><em>Article 52</em></p><p>The Secretary-General of the United Nations shall inform all States belonging to any of the four</p><p>categories mentioned in article 48:</p><p>16</p><p>(<em>a</em>) Of signatures to the present Convention and of the deposit of instruments of ratification or</p><p>accession, in accordance with articles 48, 49 and 50;</p><p>(<em>b</em>) Of the date on which the present Convention will enter into force, in accordance with article 51.</p><p><em>Article 53</em></p><p>The original of the present Convention, of which the Chinese, English, French, Russian and</p><p>Spanish texts are equally authentic, shall be deposited with the Secretary-General of the United Nations,</p><p>who shall send certified copies thereof to all States belonging to any of the four categories mentioned in</p><p>article 48.</p><p>IN WITNESS WHEREOF the undersigned Plenipotentiaries, being duly authorized thereto by their</p><p>respective Governments, have signed the present Convention.</p><p>DONE at Vienna this eighteenth day of April one thousand nine hundred and sixty-one.</p></div></div>
56	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties 1969</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="featured-thumb"><a href="#"></a></div><div class="entry-content"><p>Done at Vienna on 23 May 1969. Entered into force on 27 January 1980.</p><p>United Nations, <em>Treaty Series</em>, vol. 1155, p. 331</p><p>Copyright © United Nations 2005</p><p>Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties Done at Vienna on 23 May 1969</p><p>The States Parties to the present Convention,</p><p>Considering the fundamental role of treaties in the history of international relations,</p><p>Recognizing the ever-increasing importance of treaties as a source of international law and as a means of developing peaceful cooperation among nations, whatever their constitutional and social systems,</p><p>Noting that the principles of free consent and of good faith and the pacta sunt servanda rule are universally recognized,</p><p>Affirming that disputes concerning treaties, like other international disputes, should be settled by peaceful means and in conformity with the principles of justice and international law,</p><p>Recalling the determination of the peoples of the United Nations to establish conditions under which justice and respect for the obligations arising from treaties can be maintained,</p><p>Having in mind the principles of international law embodied in the Charter of the United Nations, such as the principles of the equal rights and self-determination of peoples, of the sovereign equality and independence of all States, of non-interference in the domestic affairs of States, of the prohibition of the threat or use of force and of universal respect for, and observance of, human rights and fundamental freedoms for all,</p><p>Believing that the codification and progressive development of the law of treaties achieved in the present Convention will promote the purposes of the United Nations set forth in the Charter, namely, the maintenance of international peace and security, the development of friendly relations and the achievement of cooperation among nations,</p><p>Affirming that the rules of customary international law will continue to govern questions not regulated by the provisions of the present Convention,</p><p>Have agreed as follows:</p><p>PART I.</p><p>INTRODUCTION</p><p>Article 1</p><p>Scope of the present Convention</p><p>The present Convention applies to treaties between States.</p><p>2</p><p>Article 2</p><p>Use of terms</p><p>1. For the purposes of the present Convention:</p><p>(a) “treaty” means an international agreement concluded between States in written form and governed by international law, whether embodied in a single instrument or in two or more related instruments and whatever its particular designation;</p><p>(b) “ratification”, “acceptance”, “approval” and “accession” mean in each case the international act so named whereby a State establishes on the international plane its consent to be bound by a treaty;</p><p>(c) “full powers” means a document emanating from the competent authority of a State designating a person or persons to represent the State for negotiating, adopting or authenticating the text of a treaty, for expressing the consent of the State to be bound by a treaty, or for accomplishing any other act with respect to a treaty;</p><p>(d) “reservation” means a unilateral statement, however phrased or named, made by a State, when signing, ratifying, accepting, approving or acceding to a treaty, whereby it purports to exclude or to modify the legal effect of certain provisions of the treaty in their application to that State;</p><p>(e) “negotiating State” means a State which took part in the drawing up and adoption of the text of the treaty;</p><p>(f) “contracting State” means a State which has consented to be bound by the treaty, whether or not the treaty has entered into force;</p><p>(g) “party” means a State which has consented to be bound by the treaty and for which the treaty is in force;</p><p>(h) “third State” means a State not a party to the treaty;</p><p>(i) “international organization” means an intergovernmental organization.</p><p>2. The provisions of paragraph 1 regarding the use of terms in the present Convention are without prejudice to the use of those terms or to the meanings which may be given to them in the internal law of any State.</p><p>Article 3</p><p>International agreements not within the scope of the present Convention</p><p>The fact that the present Convention does not apply to international agreements concluded between States and other subjects of international law or between such other subjects of international law, or to international agreements not in written form, shall not affect:</p><p>3</p><p>(a) the legal force of such agreements;</p><p>(b) the application to them of any of the rules set forth in the present Convention to which they would be subject under international law independently of the Convention;</p><p>(c) the application of the Convention to the relations of States as between themselves under international agreements to which other subjects of international law are also parties.</p><p>Article 4</p><p>Non-retroactivity of the present Convention</p><p>Without prejudice to the application of any rules set forth in the present Convention to which treaties would be subject under international law independently of the Convention, the Convention applies only to treaties which are concluded by States after the entry into force of the present Convention with regard to such States.</p><p>Article 5</p><p>Treaties constituting international organizations and treaties adopted within an international organization</p><p>The present Convention applies to any treaty which is the constituent instrument of an international organization and to any treaty adopted within an international organization without prejudice to any relevant rules of the organization.</p><p>PART II.</p><p>CONCLUSION AND ENTRY INTO FORCE OF TREATIES</p><p>SECTION 1. CONCLUSION OF TREATIES</p><p>Article 6</p><p>Capacity of States to conclude treaties</p><p>Every State possesses capacity to conclude treaties.</p><p>Article 7</p><p>Full powers</p><p>1. A person is considered as representing a State for the purpose of adopting or authenticating the text of a treaty or for the purpose of expressing the consent of the State to be bound by a treaty if:</p><p>(a) he produces appropriate full powers; or</p><p>(b) it appears from the practice of the States concerned or from other circumstances that their intention was to consider that person as representing the State for such purposes and to dispense with full powers.</p><p>4</p><p>2. In virtue of their functions and without having to produce full powers, the following are considered as representing their State:</p><p>(a) Heads of State, Heads of Government and Ministers for Foreign Affairs, for the purpose of performing all acts relating to the conclusion of a treaty;</p><p>(b) heads of diplomatic missions, for the purpose of adopting the text of a treaty between the accrediting State and the State to which they are accredited;</p><p>(c) representatives accredited by States to an international conference or to an international organization or one of its organs, for the purpose of adopting the text of a treaty in that conference, organization or organ.</p><p>Article 8</p><p>Subsequent confirmation of an act performed without authorization</p><p>An act relating to the conclusion of a treaty performed by a person who cannot be considered under article 7 as authorized to represent a State for that purpose is without legal effect unless afterwards confirmed by that State.</p><p>Article 9</p><p>Adoption of the text</p><p>1. The adoption of the text of a treaty takes place by the consent of all the States participating in its drawing up except as provided in paragraph 2.</p><p>2. The adoption of the text of a treaty at an international conference takes place by the vote of two thirds of the States present and voting, unless by the same majority they shall decide to apply a different rule.</p><p>Article 10</p><p>Authentication of the text</p><p>The text of a treaty is established as authentic and definitive:</p><p>(a) by such procedure as may be provided for in the text or agreed upon by the States participating in its drawing up; or</p><p>(b) failing such procedure, by the signature, signature ad referendum or initialling by the representatives of those States of the text of the treaty or of the Final Act of a conference incorporating the text.</p><p>5</p><p>Article 11</p><p>Means of expressing consent to be bound by a treaty</p><p>The consent of a State to be bound by a treaty may be expressed by signature, exchange of instruments constituting a treaty, ratification, acceptance, approval or accession, or by any other means if so agreed.</p><p>Article 12</p><p>Consent to be bound by a treaty expressed by signature</p><p>1. The consent of a State to be bound by a treaty is expressed by the signature of its representative when:</p><p>(a) the treaty provides that signature shall have that effect;</p><p>(b) it is otherwise established that the negotiating States were agreed that signature should have that effect; or</p><p>(c) the intention of the State to give that effect to the signature appears from the full powers of its representative or was expressed during the negotiation.</p><p>2. For the purposes of paragraph 1:</p><p>(a) the initialling of a text constitutes a signature of the treaty when it is established that the negotiating States so agreed;</p><p>(b) the signature ad referendum of a treaty by a representative, if confirmed by his State, constitutes a full signature of the treaty.</p><p>Article 13</p><p>Consent to be bound by a treaty expressed by an exchange of instruments constituting a treaty</p><p>The consent of States to be bound by a treaty constituted by instruments exchanged between them is expressed by that exchange when:</p><p>(a) the instruments provide that their exchange shall have that effect; or</p><p>(b) it is otherwise established that those States were agreed that the exchange of instruments should have that effect.</p><p>Article 14</p><p>Consent to be bound by a treaty expressed by ratification, acceptance or approval</p><p>1. The consent of a State to be bound by a treaty is expressed by ratification when:</p><p>6</p><p>(a) the treaty provides for such consent to be expressed by means of ratification;</p><p>(b) it is otherwise established that the negotiating States were agreed that ratification should be required;</p><p>(c) the representative of the State has signed the treaty subject to ratification; or</p><p>(d) the intention of the State to sign the treaty subject to ratification appears from the full powers of its representative or was expressed during the negotiation.</p><p>2. The consent of a State to be bound by a treaty is expressed by acceptance or approval under conditions similar to those which apply to ratification.</p><p>Article 15</p><p>Consent to be bound by a treaty expressed by accession</p><p>The consent of a State to be bound by a treaty is expressed by accession when:</p><p>(a) the treaty provides that such consent may be expressed by that State by means of accession;</p><p>(b) it is otherwise established that the negotiating States were agreed that such consent may be expressed by that State by means of accession; or</p><p>(c) all the parties have subsequently agreed that such consent may be expressed by that State by means of accession.</p><p>Article 16</p><p>Exchange or deposit of instruments of ratification, acceptance, approval or accession</p><p>Unless the treaty otherwise provides, instruments of ratification, acceptance, approval or accession establish the consent of a State to be bound by a treaty upon:</p><p>(a) their exchange between the contracting States;</p><p>(b) their deposit with the depositary; or</p><p>(c) their notification to the contracting States or to the depositary, if so agreed.</p><p>Article 17</p><p>Consent to be bound by part of a treaty and choice of differing provisions</p><p>1. Without prejudice to articles 19 to 23, the consent of a State to be bound by part of a treaty is effective only if the treaty so permits or the other contracting States so agree.</p><p>7</p><p>2. The consent of a State to be bound by a treaty which permits a choice between differing provisions is effective only if it is made clear to which of the provisions the consent relates.</p><p>Article 18</p><p>Obligation not to defeat the object and purpose of a treaty prior to its entry into force</p><p>A State is obliged to refrain from acts which would defeat the object and purpose of a treaty when:</p><p>(a) it has signed the treaty or has exchanged instruments constituting the treaty subject to ratification, acceptance or approval, until it shall have made its intention clear not to become a party to the treaty; or</p><p>(b) it has expressed its consent to be bound by the treaty, pending the entry into force of the treaty and provided that such entry into force is not unduly delayed.</p><p>SECTION 2. RESERVATIONS</p><p>Article 19</p><p>Formulation of reservations</p><p>A State may, when signing, ratifying, accepting, approving or acceding to a treaty, formulate a reservation unless:</p><p>(a) the reservation is prohibited by the treaty;</p><p>(b) the treaty provides that only specified reservations, which do not include the reservation in question, may be made; or</p><p>(c) in cases not failing under subparagraphs (a) and (b), the reservation is incompatible with the object and purpose of the treaty.</p><p>Article 20</p><p>Acceptance of and objection to reservations</p><p>1. A reservation expressly authorized by a treaty does not require any subsequent acceptance by the other contracting States unless the treaty so provides.</p><p>2. When it appears from the limited number of the negotiating States and the object and purpose of a treaty that the application of the treaty in its entirety between all the parties is an essential condition of the consent of each one to be bound by the treaty, a reservation requires acceptance by all the parties.</p><p>3. When a treaty is a constituent instrument of an international organization and unless it otherwise provides, a reservation requires the acceptance of the competent organ of that organization.</p><p>4. In cases not falling under the preceding paragraphs and unless the treaty otherwise provides:</p><p>8</p><p>(a) acceptance by another contracting State of a reservation constitutes the reserving State a party to the treaty in relation to that other State if or when the treaty is in force for those States;</p><p>(b) an objection by another contracting State to a reservation does not preclude the entry into force of the treaty as between the objecting and reserving States unless a contrary intention is definitely expressed by the objecting State;</p><p>(c) an act expressing a State’s consent to be bound by the treaty and containing a reservation is effective as soon as at least one other contracting State has accepted the reservation.</p><p>5. For the purposes of paragraphs 2 and 4 and unless the treaty otherwise provides, a reservation is considered to have been accepted by a State if it shall have raised no objection to the reservation by the end of a period of twelve months after it was notified of the reservation or by the date on which it expressed its consent to be bound by the treaty, whichever is later.</p><p>Article 21</p><p>Legal effects of reservations and of objections to reservations</p><p>1. A reservation established with regard to another party in accordance with articles 19, 20 and 23:</p><p>(a) modifies for the reserving State in its relations with that other party the provisions of the treaty to which the reservation relates to the extent of the reservation; and</p><p>(b) modifies those provisions to the same extent for that other party in its relations with the reserving State.</p><p>2. The reservation does not modify the provisions of the treaty for the other parties to the treaty inter se.</p><p>3. When a State objecting to a reservation has not opposed the entry into force of the treaty between itself and the reserving State, the provisions to which the reservation relates do not apply as between the two States to the extent of the reservation.</p><p>Article 22</p><p>Withdrawal of reservations and of objections to reservations</p><p>1. Unless the treaty otherwise provides, a reservation may be withdrawn at any time and the consent of a State which has accepted the reservation is not required for its withdrawal.</p><p>2. Unless the treaty otherwise provides, an objection to a reservation may be withdrawn at any time.</p><p>3. Unless the treaty otherwise provides, or it is otherwise agreed:</p><p>9</p><p>(a) the withdrawal of a reservation becomes operative in relation to another contracting State only when notice of it has been received by that State;</p><p>(b) the withdrawal of an objection to a reservation becomes operative only when notice of it has been received by the State which formulated the reservation.</p><p>Article 23</p><p>Procedure regarding reservations</p><p>1. A reservation, an express acceptance of a reservation and an objection to a reservation must be formulated in writing and communicated to the contracting States and other States entitled to become parties to the treaty.</p><p>2. If formulated when signing the treaty subject to ratification, acceptance or approval, a reservation must be formally confirmed by the reserving State when expressing its consent to be bound by the treaty. In such a case the reservation shall be considered as having been made on the date of its confirmation.</p><p>3. An express acceptance of, or an objection to, a reservation made previously to confirmation of the reservation does not itself require confirmation.</p><p>4. The withdrawal of a reservation or of an objection to a reservation must be formulated in writing.</p><p>SECTION 3. ENTRY INTO FORCE AND PROVISIONAL, APPLICATION OF TREATIES</p><p>Article 24</p><p>Entry into force</p><p>1. A treaty enters into force in such manner and upon such date as it may provide or as the negotiating States may agree.</p><p>2. Failing any such provision or agreement, a treaty enters into force as soon as consent to be bound by the treaty has been established for all the negotiating States.</p><p>3. When the consent of a State to be bound by a treaty is established on a date after the treaty has come into force, the treaty enters into force for that State on that date, unless the treaty otherwise provides.</p><p>4. The provisions of a treaty regulating the authentication of its text, the establishment of the consent of States to be bound by the treaty, the manner or date of its entry into force, reservations, the functions of the depositary and other matters arising necessarily before the entry into force of the treaty apply from the time of the adoption of its text.</p><p>10</p><p>Article 25</p><p>Provisional application</p><p>1. A treaty or a part of a treaty is applied provisionally pending its entry into force if:</p><p>(a) the treaty itself so provides; or</p><p>(b) the negotiating States have in some other manner so agreed.</p><p>2. Unless the treaty otherwise provides or the negotiating States have otherwise agreed, the provisional application of a treaty or a part of a treaty with respect to a State shall be terminated if that State notifies the other States between which the treaty is being applied provisionally of its intention not to become a party to the treaty.</p><p>PART III.</p><p>OBSERVANCE, APPLICATION AND INTERPRETATION OF TREATIES</p><p>SECTION 1. OBSERVANCE OF TREATIES</p><p>Article 26</p><p>“Pacta sunt servanda”</p><p>Every treaty in force is binding upon the parties to it and must be performed by them in good faith.</p><p>Article 27</p><p>Internal law and observance of treaties</p><p>A party may not invoke the provisions of its internal law as justification for its failure to perform a treaty. This rule is without prejudice to article 46.</p><p>SECTION 2. APPLICATION OF TREATIES</p><p>Article 28</p><p>Non-retroactivity of treaties</p><p>Unless a different intention appears from the treaty or is otherwise established, its provisions do not bind a party in relation to any act or fact which took place or any situation which ceased to exist before the date of the entry into force of the treaty with respect to that party.</p><p>Article 29</p><p>Territorial scope of treaties</p><p>Unless a different intention appears from the treaty or is otherwise established, a treaty is binding upon each party in respect of its entire territory.</p><p>11</p><p>Article 30</p><p>Application of successive treaties relating to the same subject matter</p><p>1. Subject to Article 103 of the Charter of the United Nations, the rights and obligations of States Parties to successive treaties relating to the same subject matter shall be determined in accordance with the following paragraphs.</p><p>2. When a treaty specifies that it is subject to, or that it is not to be considered as incompatible with, an earlier or later treaty, the provisions of that other treaty prevail.</p><p>3. When all the parties to the earlier treaty are parties also to the later treaty but the earlier treaty is not terminated or suspended in operation under article 59, the earlier treaty applies only to the extent that its provisions are compatible with those of the later treaty.</p><p>4. When the parties to the later treaty do not include all the parties to the earlier one:</p><p>(a) as between States Parties to both treaties the same rule applies as in paragraph 3;</p><p>(b) as between a State party to both treaties and a State party to only one of the treaties, the treaty to which both States are parties governs their mutual rights and obligations.</p><p>5. Paragraph 4 is without prejudice to article 41, or to any question of the termination or suspension of the operation of a treaty under article 60 or to any question of responsibility which may arise for a State from the conclusion or application of a treaty the provisions of which are incompatible with its obligations towards another State under another treaty.</p><p>SECTION 3. INTERPRETATION OF TREATIES</p><p>Article 31</p><p>General rule of interpretation</p><p>1. A treaty shall be interpreted in good faith in accordance with the ordinary meaning to be given to the terms of the treaty in their context and in the light of its object and purpose.</p><p>2. The context for the purpose of the interpretation of a treaty shall comprise, in addition to the text, including its preamble and annexes:</p><p>(a) any agreement relating to the treaty which was made between all the parties in connection with the conclusion of the treaty;</p><p>(b) any instrument which was made by one or more parties in connection with the conclusion of the treaty and accepted by the other parties as an instrument related to the treaty.</p><p>3. There shall be taken into account, together with the context:</p><p>12</p><p>(a) any subsequent agreement between the parties regarding the interpretation of the treaty or the application of its provisions;</p><p>(b) any subsequent practice in the application of the treaty which establishes the agreement of the parties regarding its interpretation;</p><p>(c) any relevant rules of international law applicable in the relations between the parties.</p><p>4. A special meaning shall be given to a term if it is established that the parties so intended.</p><p>Article 32</p><p>Supplementary means of interpretation</p><p>Recourse may be had to supplementary means of interpretation, including the preparatory work of the treaty and the circumstances of its conclusion, in order to confirm the meaning resulting from the application of article 31, or to determine the meaning when the interpretation according to article 31:</p><p>(a) leaves the meaning ambiguous or obscure; or</p><p>(b) leads to a result which is manifestly absurd or unreasonable.</p><p>Article 33</p><p>Interpretation of treaties authenticated in two or more languages</p><p>1. When a treaty has been authenticated in two or more languages, the text is equally authoritative in each language, unless the treaty provides or the parties agree that, in case of divergence, a particular text shall prevail.</p><p>2. A version of the treaty in a language other than one of those in which the text was authenticated shall be considered an authentic text only if the treaty so provides or the parties so agree.</p><p>3. The terms of the treaty are presumed to have the same meaning in each authentic text.</p><p>4. Except where a particular text prevails in accordance with paragraph 1, when a comparison of the authentic texts discloses a difference of meaning which the application of articles 31 and 32 does not remove, the meaning which best reconciles the texts, having regard to the object and purpose of the treaty, shall be adopted.</p><p>SECTION 4. TREATIES AND THIRD STATES</p><p>Article 34</p><p>General rule regarding third States</p><p>A treaty does not create either obligations or rights for a third State without its consent.</p><p>13</p><p>Article 35</p><p>Treaties providing for obligations for third States</p><p>An obligation arises for a third State from a provision of a treaty if the parties to the treaty intend the provision to be the means of establishing the obligation and the third State expressly accepts that obligation in writing.</p><p>Article 36</p><p>Treaties providing for rights for third States</p><p>1. A right arises for a third State from a provision of a treaty if the parties to the treaty intend the provision to accord that right either to the third State, or to a group of States to which it belongs, or to all States, and the third State assents thereto. Its assent shall be presumed so long as the contrary is not indicated, unless the treaty otherwise provides.</p><p>2. A State exercising a right in accordance with paragraph 1 shall comply with the conditions for its exercise provided for in the treaty or established in conformity with the treaty.</p><p>Article 37</p><p>Revocation or modification of obligations or rights of third States</p><p>1. When an obligation has arisen for a third State in conformity with article 35, the obligation may be revoked or modified only with the consent of the parties to the treaty and of the third State, unless it is established that they had otherwise agreed.</p><p>2. When a right has arisen for a third State in conformity with article 36, the right may not be revoked or modified by the parties if it is established that the right was intended not to be revocable or subject to modification without the consent of the third State.</p><p>Article 38</p><p>Rules in a treaty becoming binding on third States through international custom</p><p>Nothing in articles 34 to 37 precludes a rule set forth in a treaty from becoming binding upon a third State as a customary rule of international law, recognized as such.</p><p>PART IV.</p><p>AMENDMENT AND MODIFICATION OF TREATIES</p><p>Article 39</p><p>General rule regarding the amendment of treaties</p><p>A treaty may be amended by agreement between the parties. The rules laid down in Part II apply to such an agreement except insofar as the treaty may otherwise provide.</p><p>14</p><p>Article 40</p><p>Amendment of multilateral treaties</p><p>1. Unless the treaty otherwise provides, the amendment of multilateral treaties shall be governed by the following paragraphs.</p><p>2. Any proposal to amend a multilateral treaty as between all the parties must be notified to all the contracting States, each one of which shall have the right to take part in:</p><p>(a) the decision as to the action to be taken in regard to such proposal;</p><p>(b) the negotiation and conclusion of any agreement for the amendment of the treaty.</p><p>3. Every State entitled to become a party to the treaty shall also be entitled to become a party to the treaty as amended.</p><p>4. The amending agreement does not bind any State already a party to the treaty which does not become a party to the amending agreement; article 30, paragraph 4 (b), applies in relation to such State.</p><p>5. Any State which becomes a party to the treaty after the entry into force of the amending agreement shall, failing an expression of a different intention by that State:</p><p>(a) be considered as a party to the treaty as amended; and</p><p>(b) be considered as a party to the unamended treaty in relation to any party to the treaty not bound by the amending agreement.</p><p>Article 41</p><p>Agreements to modify multilateral treaties between certain of the parties only</p><p>1. Two or more of the parties to a multilateral treaty may conclude an agreement to modify the treaty as between themselves alone if:</p><p>(a) the possibility of such a modification is provided for by the treaty; or</p><p>(b) the modification in question is not prohibited by the treaty and:</p><p>(i) does not affect the enjoyment by the other parties of their rights under the treaty or the performance of their obligations;</p><p>(ii) does not relate to a provision, derogation from which is incompatible with the effective execution of the object and purpose of the treaty as a whole.</p><p>2. Unless in a case falling under paragraph 1 (a) the treaty otherwise provides, the parties in question shall notify the other parties of their intention to conclude the agreement and of the modification to the treaty for which it provides.</p><p>15</p><p>PART V.</p><p>INVALIDITY, TERMINATION AND SUSPENSION OF THE OPERATION OF TREATIES</p><p>SECTION 1. GENERAL PROVISIONS</p><p>Article 42</p><p>Validity and continuance in force of treaties</p><p>1. The validity of a treaty or of the consent of a State to be bound by a treaty may be impeached only through the application of the present Convention.</p><p>2. The termination of a treaty, its denunciation or the withdrawal of a party, may take place only as a result of the application of the provisions of the treaty or of the present Convention.
